description:
Jaroll Luber was amazing to work with to get the Chairman to cater our wedding. Communication was excellent, and he answered all our questions in a very timely manner. We had an excellent tasting and got to try everything on the menu before deciding on choosing them for our caterer. They were so  helpful in making our decisions for our wedding menu. The overall price was fairly reasonable compared to some of the other popular SF trucks that we looked at. The truck showed up in a timely manner for setup and was able to serve all 90 or so guests within the first hour of service (2 hours total) with people going back for seconds (and maybe more). I was grateful that they were able to modify the coca-cola braised pork to be gluten free on a bed of greens (without the buns) for our gf friends, and even were able to make a veggie-only medley on a steamed bun for our vegan friend (the tofu is actually battered in buttermilk -so delicious, but not vegan). Service was very friendly, and the red truck was clean and quite a nice addition to our wedding. 

We were very  pleased to have The Chairman Truck cater our wedding, and would do it again in a heartbeat.
author: Amanda F.

description:
Best food trucks in the Bay! Love their food since the first time I've tried it 7 years ago. Too bad their brick and mortar location had to close, hope they have another permanent spot down the road. 

Can't go wrong with some delicious baos!
author: Gordon L.

description:
I don't eat meat so I was excited to try the Miso Cured Tofu bao for lunch. Let me tell you... this is probably one of the most delicious things I've tried in awhile. I literally went back to the truck a few hours later to get two more of the same thing because it was THAT good.

I'm looking forward to trying the Crispy Tempeh (Vegan) bao next!
author: Kelly F.

description: I attended a conference event that included the Chairman Truck, so was lucky enough to get to try their baos for free. I tasted each of the four types, and my favorites were the braised pork and tofu ones. Even though the pork belly is standard and probably the most commonly ordered, I thought the braised pork tasted more rich. The tofu one was so soft; the bok choy was not stringy and is marinated so that it is very flavorful. The nature of baos make them a great portable food truck food.
author: Amy G.

description:
This place totally surprise me in a good way.

I looked at the menu and have no idea what to order. There is no picture on the trunk and the menu is hard for Asian to navigate. What does it mean steam bun or bake? Why one is $5 other is $10? I have no idea what I will be getting.


When it come. It looks sad. $5 for this tiny thing? Why would the daikon goes with pork?

I was so sure this is a rip version of Asian food trunk version of 刈包 Guo Bao. 

One bite and my mind got blown away. It is like Japanese ramen cha Siu pork, roast, only much much better!

Daikon still does not goes with this pork bao but the pork is so good, I am in heaven!!! I imagine they will serve this on a bamboo basket, in a restaurant with a view. Not on a food trunk. Totally outstanding 

Go try it. You won't be disappointed. Especially another food stalls nearby sell hot dog for $12, and it was cold inside.
author: Olee L.

description: Street food is supposed to be eaten on the go right? well I ordered food from this truck and they gave it to me un wrapped in a box.  I've been out and about in the city and touched who knows what. It's a food truck so there's no place to wash my hands so how am I supposed to eat something with a dirty hand out of a box? I asked if I could have the sandwich wrapped up, not the box and they started wrapping the box with Saran Wrap. I said no can you wrap the actual sandwich and they said no we cannot do that it will be "mushy" and would not give me my sandwich back. I was late for something and did not have time to argue so I said forget it, lost out on my 9 bucks and no sandwich.
author: Brian G.

description: I've had the pork belly many times and every time it is delicious! I wish this food truck made it down to my area more often.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I got a bun at the San Mateo Farmers Market. There is so little meat in a Coca Cola pork belly bun. And what's in there is very lean and unimpressively plain. The bun is fluffy and tasty, but that itself is not worth the $4.50 they charge for the bun.
author: Philip C.

description:
From the Bride:
 We were fortunate to have Chairman Bao in our wedding.  Our wedding was on July 7, 2018 in Oakland's Preservation Park.  Chairman Bao is a staple in the San Francisco food truck scene and I was surprised that they were able to serve our wedding.  I negotiated the contract with Jaroll Luber.  It was initially difficult to get a hold of him, but once we had everything going he was very easy.  They also served a menu item not regularly offered in their menu for an additional cost.  It was the Muscovy Duck and it was so worth it.  Everyone enjoyed their food.  The kids loved the steamed buns on their own; I heard one picky eater had 5 pieces.  You can never go wrong with the Chairman.  

From the Groom:
 I agree.
author: Joan R.

description:
I remember getting to try The Chairman once in college when it came by campus, but I had yet to see it again despite my constant visits to food truck scenes. Yesterday (Tuesday) night, I saw it outside of Daly City's Serramonte Shopping Center while passing by and was excited to get some of that good stuff!

I decided to split a pork belly baked bun and a coca-cola braised pork steamed bun with another. The truck seemed to have quite a good amount of business and I often hear hype about this truck so I was excited to dig in. Unfortunately, I was a bit disappointed by what I was given especially since I probably overhyped it for myself. The baked bun was extraordinarily buttery and the pork belly was a bit dry. The daikon radishes added a nice sweet and sour taste to it, but I found it to be rather average overall. For the steamed bun, I found the bread to be slightly tough as if it had been sitting out for a while. The meat was certainly not bad though as I enjoyed the fatty bits here and there.

Overall, I ended up finding The Chairman to be all around not too bad, but nothing to get super hype about. I will certainly try it out again sometime though as I do like their creative approaches in what they serve and I find myself it situations where I would like a small and simple $4 steamed bun.
author: Joshua M.

description:
I don't know how I never ever wrote a review for this place. I must be losing my mind. 

Anyways, if you haven't been to any off the grid event around San Francisco. This truck is a truck to be at. My god, I can't tell you how many off the grid events I've been to and never got The Chairman. Their baos are so freaking good! Baked or steamed. The flavors are awesome, also the actually store front is fun to eat at as well. 

Yeah... they are just awesome!
author: Ann N.

description:
I've heard of The Chairman Truck before, but have never seen it until today at the Off the Grid in Alameda. 

We got the baked spicy chicken and the steamed coca-cola braised pork bun and their wonton chips.

The braised pork was good, tender and the slaw on top added a nice crunchy texture to the bun. 

The baked spicy chicken bun was better, although it might've been the baked bun that made it better. Very flavorful and the bun was big, made it seem like a chicken burger.

The wonton chips were simple, but addicting. I couldn't stop eating it.

Overall, it was good but I wouldn't say it was amazing.
author: James L.

description: Good steamed buns! I like the pork belly and the spicy chickens. They're a little overpriced for me, considering you can definitely eat a couple of them. Definitely a good treat every once in a while.
author: Lillian B.

description:
GET THE BAKED BAO!!!

Basically, it's like a fried bun replacing the bread as buns, and making a Chinese-inspired sandwich. I got Coca-cola braised pork and it was definitely a favorite of the crowd. A nice fusion twist for the traditional Chinese Gua-Bao, I'd say The Chairman Truck did a good job of balancing the flavor, it's Americanized but it's also creative! 

A baked order comes as one sandwich but I think you get 2 when it's the steam one. Either way, it's fulfilling in terms of the price. 

2017038
author: Leslie C.

description:
The Chairman's gua baos continue to tickle my buns! By far, my favorite food truck. No one else does it better. 

By the way, the price for one of these delicious Taiwanese steamed pork belly buns is steep ($4.00). Aside from pricing, the buns are out of this world tasty in my opinion. So far, I've only had the opportunity to try the tender pork belly w/ pickled daikon and the coca-cola braised pork w/garlic mayo. I am consistently impressed EVERY. FRIGGEN. TIME. I can't wait to visit their brick and mortar. 

+ Vegetarian friendly: ex: crispy tofu steamed buns!
author: Merica S.

description:
I kind of hate fusion food.  (I can hear you sharpening your pitchfork.)  Having heard all the hype, I was interested to try the food here but skeptical it would meet the lofty expectations.

We tried the tender pork belly bao (steamed and baked) and the Coca-cola braised pork bao (steamed).  The flavors were good, especially the pork belly with the pickled daikon.  I definitely preferred the baked bun, which reminded me of a buttery brioche and was much bigger than either steamed bun.  That said, it does cost almost twice as much ($7.75 vs $4.25).

Fusion food still makes me roll my eyes, but I'll admit this was pretty tasty.

Food:  4.5 stars
Value:  3 stars
Service:  4 stars
Overall:  4 stars
author: Kevin C.

description:
Let's just say that I stalk them at OTG. Now that I'm ok saying. Hahah But in all seriousness, I love these fluffy little pillow filled with juiciness from the daikon and packed with flavor from the pork belly. 

They are my go to, my #1 choice at OTG.  If you have never had a bao, I'm not sure what you are waiting for. Find where they are and try one TODAY. Lines for this truck can get pretty long, but it is well worth it.
author: Viclaire S.

description: When it comes to food trucks there is no better. No one told these guys they are a food truck and they don't need to go and invent crazy amazing tasty food so they went and did just that. My choice Everytime, that is if I am ever close to it
author: Sam S.

description: My favorite buns are from the Chairman Truck!! It's actually been a couple of years since I've had them at Off the Grid until last Monday as I was passing by and saw the truck parked with just a few people waiting for their order. No line! That was amazing and it was a sign. I ordered my favorite item and got the steamed pork belly bun!!!! Something about it got me hooked. More buns please!  I'm also glad to find out they have a restaurant. I must check it out!
author: Darlene V.

description:
I got epic food poisoning, along with the guy I was on a date with, when we went here at Off the Grid at Fort Mason. Puking my guts out all weekend. This was the only place we both ate at, so we knew it was The Chairman. I posted about it on the Off the Grid Facebook group and later connected with another group that had the same experience that day. We didn't have quite enough people to get the city to investigate, sadly. 

It was a long time ago, so maybe their food handling has improved, and maybe it was a one time occurrence. But--it happened.
author: George F.

description:
Their steamed baos are so soo good! 
Discovered them from Off the Grid Fort Mason and Serramonte which I'm gald I did because they are amazing! 
Tender Pork Belly = 5/5 (melts in your mouth and very flavorful)
Coca-cola braised pork =10/5 (my favorite!!!)
Those are my go-to! 
I have yet to try the other stuff in the menu!
author: Kayefaye B.

description: I tried the baked bun with tofu yesterday. I really like the way they cook their tofu. The tofu is crispy all around and the bun is super soft, so excellent combo. I'm not a meat eater so I can't really try any of their other items. But definitely down to vouch for this spot for fellow vegetarians.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
The food served from this truck is so unique and so delicious and consistent AF! it is absolutely worth it to hunt them down wherever they go. Even though I have tried almost everything on the menu, I am partial to the tender pork belly on steamed Bao with daikon pickles. The pork belly is oh so tender, melt in your mouth delicious seasoned in a mild 5 spice mix. The miso cured tofu on steamed Bao is also really excellent whether or not you are a vegetarian. The tofu is not fried yet it is slightly crisp when you bite into it and the flavor is really impressive, The Chairman really knows how to jazz up tofu.

The only other place I've ever had food like this was in Shanghai where steamed bao's are shaped like little clam shells and served in a bamboo steamer basket on the side as accompaniment to tender braised meats. The concept is the same as warm tortilla's served alongside the main dishes in Mexican cuisine. Except instead of tortillas, you are dealing with pillow-y soft and mildly sweet steamed buns - yum, yum! Simply put, Chairman buns are culinary cousins with tacos. Eat with your hands, try not to let everything fall out before it hits your mouth.

5 stars for the Chairman truck democratically bringing some seriously authentic Chinese cuisine to the masses.
author: Quiet R.

description:
Their steam bun tacos are beyond delicious! The bun is soft while the pork belly is juicy and flavorful. The pickled daikon was the best compliment to the taco. I wish the tacos were not so tiny so that I can savor the flavor longer. 

It's crazy to think something so small can be packed with so much flavor. Can't wait to try their restaurant!
author: Jenna T.

description:
OMG STEAMED BAOS! YUM! I was so excited when I saw that Chairman will be at OSL. Definitely a long line at the festivals, but so worth the wait.

We ordered:
Steamed Pork Belly Bao: SO good, it was topped with veggies, went so well! I loved it, pork was super juicy
Steamed Tofu Bao: Delicious, sauce was amazing and topped with bak chou leafs 
Steamed Coca Cola Pork Bao: Very good also and topped with Korean pickles. Can't taste much to the Coca Cola, but still delicious 

I will definitely go to their restaurant and location and try more of the baked baos!
author: Natalie L.

description: Found this truck on cinco de mayo Off the grid. The pork buns are SO GOOD...as a small snack. You have to try both the Coca-Cola braised pork and the tender pork belly.
author: Dale D.

description: I was thrilled to see this truck at the San Mateo farmers market. I had been wanting to try it ever since I first saw the truck over a year ago! They offer 4 different fillings with the option to get it as a steamed clamshell bun or a baked bun that resembles a brioche bun. The crispy tofu baked bun was the perfect lunch. The tofu was crispy and flavorful as described, and the complementing flavors of the garlic mayo made this a home run. I wouldn't call it very "Taiwanese" but it was definitely delicious. I was lucky to have only waited about 5 minutes for my order. It is a little pricey but on par with other food trucks.
author: Shilpa Y.

description:
I decided to try this food truck when it stopped by in our office lot. The Chairman's menu can be described as modern Taiwanese cuisine. It mainly consists of baked or steams buns with a choice of protien and bowls with rice/noodles along with a choice of protein. I decided to try the buns so got a steamed spicy chicken bun ($3.25) and a baked miso cured tofu bun ($6.25). Line was very small so I had my food in under 5 minutes.

The food turned out to be surprisingly very good. The bun was perfectly steamed. The spicy chicken was moist and flavorful. I generally do not like vegetarian sandwiches but I managed to put down the the miso cured tofu bun effortless. The tofu patty had a terrific outside sear which gave it a nice crunch. The sandwich itself was minimalist with only some crispy choy-sum along with the tofu that worked very well together. Price wise it was inline with what I'd pay for a similar meal at other trucks.

Overall I really liked the quality and taste of what I got so I'm definitely looking forward to trying some more stuff off their menu in the future. A generous 4.5 stars rounded to a 5 is how I'd rate this truck.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
I try to have guarded expectations when I come across Asian fusion/Americanized Asian fast food; in my experience, it's a pretty fine line between "Whoa, this is ingenious" and "Whoa, something went horribly wrong." Luckily, The Chairman does it right.

We got to try the pork belly bao and the braised pork and both were delicious. I loved the pickled daikon that accompanied the pork belly; it helped to lighten the sandwich and lent some brightness and crunch to an otherwise fatty meat. This felt like the closest approximation of the roast duck on bao dish, a pricey mainstay at Chinese wedding banquets, that I'm assuming was the inspiration behind The Chairman. 

I love how the size of these is well proportioned -- filling, but perfectly sized for buying a few to share with a friend. Can't wait to slowly work my way through the menu!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Good baos and aesthetics. Great bite-sized snacks full of flavor and juicy meats. 

I had the steamed coca-cola braised pork bun, pork belly with pickled daikon, and spicy chicken with toasted sesame purée and ONLY the coca-cola braised pork bun blew my mind. The coleslaw topping was a great compliment to the pork. I might have eaten the other ones too fast to really enjoy its subtleties but I'd say they tasted pretty alright--I'm personally not a huge fan of pickled veggies with juicy meat because that's too much flavor for me. Also, it  might be just me, but there seemed to be too high of a bao:meat ratio in the latter two baos. Still delicious though!
author: Lydia Z.

description: This review is long over due. I've tried many, many food trucks at different locations (Off the Grids and others), and the steamed pork belly bun is, hands down, my favorite food truck item! Despite it's price, at slightly higher than items in Chinatown, it's worth every penny. The pork is perfectly spread and the pickled daikon is the optimal condiment. I can never pass by this truck without buying one... or, ok, two.
author: Maria Y.

description:
I like buns... white buns... more specifically fluffy, steamed, white buns. I think they would taste good with just about any type of filling. I thought the buns were a little pricey. I wanted to hit up an Asian grocer and buy some steamed buns from the frozen aisle, heat them up, and stuff them. Well, that never happened. Too many people raved about these buns, so curiosity won me over. Everyone was right. They are good. 
They serve steamed buns (~$4) and baked buns (~$7). It's on the pricey side for a bao, but the steamed bun trend is still going strong.
The aforementioned steamed buns are a soft, mildly sweet, bleached white color. The baked buns are the larger, brown ones. They're also good, but I'm not as fond of the sticky sugary glaze, so I stick to the steamed ones.

Tender Pork Belly - red miso glaze, turmeric pickled daikon, green shiso:
Easily my favorite of the bunch. It's not red cooked pork, but the fatty pork belly nestled in a soft white bun is winner. The acidity of the pickled daikon helps cut through some of the richness and adds flavor, but sometimes they top the buns with so much daikon, the tart flavor overpowers the pork belly.

Coca Cola Braised Pork - savory cabbage, preserved mustard seeds, garlic mayo:
Not bad for braised pork. The cabbage was rather bland, and not too satisfying having a mouthful of shredded cabbage.

Spicy Chicken - toasted sesame puree, panchan pickled carrots & cucumber, cilantro:
Pretty tasty! Good balance of flavors, mildly spicy & tart. & Good chicken

Miso Cured Tofu - tofu, mayo, baby choy-sum:
Not surprisingly, my least favorite of the bunch. It was okay, but I thought I would like it better, since I usually like tofu. It was pretty bland. The mayo also didn't do much to bring a satisfying factor for a carb-on-carb combination.

Overall, I approve! They're more of a snack. If I wanted these things to fill me up, I'd need about 4 steamed buns.

&...storytime...
Several years ago, there was a legal battle over the 'Chairman Bao' name. A popular east coast steamed bun joint already laid claim to 'Chairman Bao' for his number-one selling gua bao. I didn't understand why such a name was coveted. An innocuous pun that alludes to controversial totalitarian rule doesn't seem like it would help sell steamed buns. Surely these business owners should be able to come up with something more clever and more catchy. I wasn't too interested in this East vs West Coast conflict, but the East won - with unnecessary belligerent words. The Chairman Truck still draws long lines, regardless of any name change. I'm sure most people didn't even notice these red panda themed trucks had dropped the 'Bao' in the name.
author: Joy W.

description:
I can't believe it's been 6 years since I first ate from this truck!  Geez, things change.

But you know what doesn't change?  How incredibly tasty the pork belly and pickled daikon is here.  

What changed everything for me was going for the baked buns.  Those feel like a better deal as you spend less to get a full belly with the same tasty ingredients.  

So, this truck is a treat for me and hubby.  And we really look forward to it!
author: Lauren S.

description: The "tuna" garlic "mayo" sauce is vegan! Got this on a Mido tofu burger on baked bread. It was pretty good! Could maybe have used some more toppings.
author: Maggie A.

description:
One of the best options at Off the Grid: Fort Mason Center! 

I tried both the pork belly and coca cola braised pork steamed buns. Both were amazing - the meat was so tender and flavorful. I think it's worth trying but the price of $3.75 a steamed bun is definitely pricey. This is much better for a small snack vs an actual meal.
author: Linda X.

description:
I visited the Chairman truck at the Pleasant Hill OTG Weds. You must check the schedule for a list of vendors. The Chairman is only there every other week I think if that frequent. I tried them once before a long time ago and remember enjoying it so I wanted to relive that memory. I got there early around 5:15 otherwise I am sure the line would be insane and they only have 1 chick working the truck when I was there. I ordered 3 steamed buns total. They ran $4 each and to have it baked it runs about $7. I got 2 braised Potok belly with pickled daikon i believe and 1 cola braised port with slaw in top. The buns were small, not going to lie. But they were tasty. The bun was perfectly
soft, the daikon complimented the pork belly. I could've eaten 3 but I am too nice of a wife so saved 2 for the hubs. He said they were good too. Overall yummy but pricey so get it as a snack. A meal will cost you an arm & a leg!
author: Jules K.

description:
An Off the Grid staple, they catered lunch. Steam buns are slider sized sandwiches in soft, pillowy bao. It's all refined white starchy dough, but man is it satisfying, slightly sweet, glazed and soft. The baked buns are larger and buttery like a small burger. I'd say 3 small steamed bao or 1 baked bun + 1 steamed bun would make a decent lunch, though on the pricey side for quantity. The menu is simple, the service was pretty efficient and quick, and the buns are tasty. Toppings are well paired and seasoned with the protein too!

I got three steamed buns on order of deliciousness:
Pork Belly - Two slices of really juicy, fatty, melt in your mouth pork belly. Daikon brought some brightness, sweet acidity to cut through the fat and texture for a satisfying bite.
Crispy Tofu - Soft on the inside, savory and slightly sweet miso marinade and crispy panko outer breading. The miso greens gave more crunch to it.
Spicy Chicken - Interesting nutty flavor from peanuts and sweetness from carrots. Pretty well balanced, but not that spicy at all.
author: Truc N.

description: So I've had food from The Chairman Truck in many various areas. Whether it's in Alameda, Larkspur, or Fort Mason, the food has always been excellent. This review will be short and sweet because all you need to know is...order the pork belly steamed buns!!! Just do it!! Amazing price, amazing food, and amazing taste! I've also tried the baked version, which is also good, but the steamed buns take the cake! The pickled radish topping balances the fat from the pork belly well. I could probably eat 10 of these things in one sitting if I really tried. If you're wondering what location they will be at on the day you decide to check them out, you can look them up on the off the grid website or check out their FB or twitter for their location. Like I said...give me a try! You won't be disappointed!
author: Joven S.

description:
Goodness, I am a sucker for steamed baos and fusion in general. 

Went with the spicy chicken- which yes, was on the spicy side. The bao was the perfect texture- nice and fluffy, melting in my mouth. Good contrast to the spiciness of the chicken and the veggies. Friend tried the pork belly- must have been good because he finished it before I even got my bao. 

If you were trying to get full off these, I wouldn't recommend it because you'd need a good amount and would end up spending a pretty penny. I like to say this a great starter to your next meal. Just enough to satisfy you until you move onto the next place.
author: Arezou A.

description:
I suffer from The Delicious Dilemma with The Chairman truck - I loved what I got there the first time so much, I get that every time and have yet to try something new!  As has happened so many times, as soon as I see peanut sauce on a menu, I'm sold.  Their spicy chicken bao with peanut sauce and pickled veggies was right up my alley, and I tried it steamed as it's half the price of baked (plus I heard a worker tell other patrons the baked bun has a sweetness to it, which sounded less appealing).  And oh my goodness it is exquisite!  An absolutely perfect flavor combo!  One of these days I will branch out and try the pork, which I've heard nothing but raves about, but oh man...it's tough to switch it up when you find such a good thing!  

Anytime I see that Chairman truck at an Off The Grid event, spicy chicken is in my immediate future - make it part of yours too!
author: Terri N.

description: Best steamed pork bun I've ever eaten.  Ate from the truck at Snow Park in Oakland.  Deliciousness.
author: kate l.

description:
I tried Chairman Bao during my visit to Off-the-Grid. It does definitely live up to its hype. The baos are nicely steamed and the meat is packed with flavor. I got the following baos:

BBQ Beef- a bit too much sauce for my liking, but the beef is very tender
Pork Belly- my favorite! It has a nice pairing with the daikon
Spicy Chicken - also delicious, but a bit too much spice for me to handle! 

Overall, they offer flavorful, delicious baos. My only complaint is that they're a bit overpriced for the size that they are.
author: Sharon I.

description:
I've chased this truck before!  If I ever see it I'm stopping!  I don't care if I just ate!  I LOVE their steamed bun pork belly tacos! 

Great flavors all around!  
The baked buns are very much like burger buns, but I prefer them steamed!  

Happy truck munchin!
author: Aureliano C.

description:
The baos were quite small for ~3-4 a piece, but wow the spicy chicken with the pickled veggies.. Just take all my money!!

The braised pork w/ cabbage was lacking in flavor and the pork belly with daikon was great, but the spicy chicken packed so much flavor that the pork belly also paled in comparison.
author: Trang B.

description:
Pretty good stuff. The Chairman is definitely one of the more hyped up food trucks in the area, and if you ever see a Chairman line during Off the Grid on a Friday night, it's a total nightmare. I think I once waited over half an hour to get my order in. The good thing is that once your order is in, they assemble the food pretty quickly and you get the order almost instantaneously. It's good, but I'd personally prefer to attend one of their locations with no wait (e.g. went to The Chairman yesterday at Off the Grid Cupertino -- didn't wait, and got my food in less than a minute, it was great). 

I've tried the tender pork belly and the coca cola braised pork. I'm at an odd position where I love the tender pork belly itself, but don't super love the slaw that comes with it, and I like the daikon on the braised pork but not so much the pork -- so my actual dream would be to have the tender pork belly with the daikon.

That being said, the Chairman basically specializes in steamed buns with a type of meat sandwiched in the middle. Prices are fairly good -- $3.75 for one which I guess is moderately expensive, but that's just how much the landscape actually costs these days. I recommend them steamed -- I've tried their baked buns, but found them to be a little on the disappointing side. It kind of just tasted like the meat in a brioche bun... underwhelming indeed. Better to just go steamed. Quality is good -- it's pretty delicious and they can also be pretty filling as well. 

tldr; one of my favorite food trucks! not necessarily worth the crazy long wait, but it's still good
author: Jasmine X.

description:
I was introduced to the Chairman Truck by a six year old who on one afternoon was pining for some pork belly baos. The little man knows what's up. If you (and perhaps your child in tow) are not up to tracking the whereabouts of the truck, you could always show up when Off the Grid is at Fort Mason.

When it came to choosing the steamed or the baked bao, I opted for the buns that had a bit of a crisp to it. The baked bao was that exactly, two large breads toasted to a dainty crisp on the outside but soft and moist on the inside. Paired with the juicy pork belly, the bao never once became too dry or bland in flavor. The pork belly was marinated to perfection, a piece of meat and its fatty side that properly retained savory juices. Crisp and crunchy pickled daikon interject between the tender meat and fluffy bread to give the bao some bite (sourness and texture). I think the ratio of pickle to meat was decent, although I could have used a little less daikon. The bao was the size of a large burger, so it wasn't easily devoured in a few bites. It was messy to eat, especially when unable to get all layers of the bao with each mouthful.
author: Cici T.

description: Have you had the spicy chicken? Oh my, this dish is food heaven! I often plan my bike ride to end up wherever the Chairman Truck will be. Totally recommend this place.
author: Marcie B.

description:
Mmm... It's hard to beat these tasty little fluffy, crunchy, meaty, sweet, umami-y, steamy buns. We just tried the pork belly and coca-cola pulled pork steamed bao on this particular evening. The coca-cola pork was a wonderfully delicious surprise. The pork belly was sweeter than I imagined, but nonetheless very tasty. I am so eager to go back and try the baked buns and the other combinations. Spicy chicken and crispy tofu--hello. 

Buns.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Long waits are usually worth it, and The Chairman Truck follows through with the pattern. I ended up waiting about 30+ minutes before I could order . However, the food was definitely on point.

The pork belly is definitely the highlight -- the steamed bun came with only one strip, but boy was it juicy and succulent. Literally dripping in fat, but hitting all the right tones. The spicy chicken bao was pretty damn good too, but not at ALL spicy -- needed some amping up with Sriracha (which they do have at the truck).

At $3.75 for the pork belly steamed bao, and $3.25 for the chicken it was a little on the pricey side, but the advantage of buying the smaller, steamed buns meant I could have a greater variety, and really taste the contents of the bun as opposed to the bread itself. You definitely need to try this place out, and if you're on the fence about a big baked bun, try the smaller steamed ones so that you can sample the favours this truck has to offer.
author: Sameer C.

description: Wonderful vegetarian and meat options! Huge portions sizes and my fresh springs salad had a variety of flavors packed into one salad. Really tasty and inexpensive food.
author: Clark S.

description:
Their STEAMED BUNS!!!! Yummm!

My favorite part of the Coca Cola Braised Pork ($3.75/bun) were the buns itself. The buns were soft and fluffy, probably the best I've had in terms of Peking-Duck-type-of-buns. It came with cabbage, mustard seeds and kewpie mayo. The meat was flavorful and there is a slight hint of coca cola, it's not too strong. Perfect balance for the meat. It was delicious and I would get it again. 

The portion sizes are on the smaller side, one bun is between $3.25-$3.75. Pretty pricey for one, but I would definitely come back and order again! Perhaps to try the baked buns :)

'Till next time, Chairman!
author: Eileen L.

description: Liked this outstanding place! Excellent menu options, favorite is a couple of steamed Baos (whichever meat I'm in the mood for, they're all excellent) usually with an egg on one. Perfect for fast break.
author: Bryson S.

description:
I LOVE CHAIRMAN BAO.

On many Tuesday afternoons you'll find me waiting in line (it moves quickly!) for one baked Coca-Cola braised pork and one steamed pork belly. The baked is much larger and more filling, but I do love me some steamed too. I've never tried the spicy chicken or tofu, but I don't think I will ever venture from my standard items...

This is my happy place. Will need to make it out to the brick and mortar location sometime.
author: Valerie L.

description:
Love the Chairman. Get either two steamed or one baked bao for a meal.  Add sriracha for extra heat.  The Chairman can be found most Thursday nights at the Off the Grid Street Food Truck Park on Stanyan off Haight.  I usually go for the steamed. My growing teenage son and I came here on a Thursday night given that the girls were out of town and we were bacheloring it.  My son  a growing boy!

I'm a fan of the pork belly with tumeric pickled daikon and green shiso.  My second favorite is the Coca Cola pork with savoy cabbage, mustard seeds and cabbage.  There are two other choices... A crispy tofu for you vegetarians and a tender chicken option for those who do not like pork.

Check your orders though.  A couple times I've walked away from the truck and realized they gave me a wrong item.

Try the crispy bao chips.  We did not have them on this evening as we were trying to keep a healthy bachelor diet.  

Of course the warm Spring evening with great music an a lively atmosphere was a mice way to get my Thursday eve going.
author: Erik H.

description: OMG!!!  My co workers have been talking about this food truck for months and I finally got a chance to try their food when they were at Serramonte Mall.  I ordered the spicy chicken on a steamed bun and the coca cola braised pork on a regular bun.  I also got an order of the won ton chips which were amazing.  Enough to share with a few people.  All the food was very good, but I think my favorite was the spicy chicken on the steamed bun.
author: Melissa L.

description: I was really really excited to try out this truck because I had something similar to it when I visited Taiwan and it was AMAZING. unfortunately, chairman truck did not compare at all. Bun was ok, filling not very good, flavor combo is lacking
author: Melody Y.

description:
The legendary chairman truck!!  It's good, but I can see how some could think it is overrated.  I personally like it because it's easy access to baos that taste pretty darn good.  I've had the pork belly with daikon, and coca cola braised pork.  They were both really tasty but I really liked the pork belly and daikon combo.  

My favorite to get is the pork belly in a steamed bun- the more traditional bao.  I asked what the diff was between a baked bun and steamed. They said the steamed is like a taco and baked is like a burger.  Well, that comparison was more accurate than I thought because I LOVE tacos and I don't like burgers so when I tried one of each, I definitely preferred the steamed buns.  Plus, it's more like a traditional bao.  

TLDR:  pork belly with daikon in a steamed bun is so good!  YUM!
author: Lyn C.

description:
I literally finished my bao two minutes ago, and had to jump on the computer to write my review. 

This foodtruck is probably one of the tastiest I've had so far in the city! Based off of reviews, i got 2 steamed pork belly bao and 1 steamed spicy chicken. Both did not disappoint! The pork belly was not too fatty, which is always a plus for me. Each had the perfect bun to meat ratio, with some veggie for each bite. I honestly could not say which was my favorite, as both were THAT good. Definitely get at least 3 if you want a meal. 2 is only enough for a snack for sure. 

They also have a baked option, but it kinda just looked like an average sandwich to me. Steamed is the way to go!

The baos are on the pricier side, about $3.75 for each bao. Skip your mocha latte that day and go try the Chairman Truck!
author: Gina P.

description:
Seen their trucks at Off The Grid in Alameda and Pleasanton.  Based on the one item that we have eaten here, my wife and I will be making this truck a regular stop whenever we see them.

What is the one item that we tried?  It was their Pork Belly Baked Bun ($6.75).  Portion is about the size of a slider so it is quite expensive.  Not surprising since most food truck items are overpriced.  The taste of the Pork Belly Baked Bun was delicious.  All the ingredients went well together.  

Look forward to trying more items from their food truck in the future.  The Chairman Truck is one truck that you should not miss.
author: PatrickJ T.

description:
Fire bao buns. I'm a fan of the spicy chicken on a steamed bun, but I just tried the coca cola pork and it was also on point.

I gladly hand over my money when I find the truck.
author: Raymond L.

description:
Believe the Yelp hype! I was lucky enough to get to try The Chairman Truck for free at Capital One 360 one day. They rotate between locations in SF, South Bay and East Bay. Check their website to find out where they're going to be for the week.

The menu is very simple here. They have various gua baos, which are a Taiwanese sandwich with some sort of meat and/or veggie filling in a steamed or baked bun. The steamed buns ($3.75 each) are smaller and like the buns you'd get with peking duck. The baked buns ($6.75 each) are more like burger buns. They also have wonton chips on the menu.

I got two steamed buns: the tender pork belly and the spicy chicken. The buns themselves are nice and fluffy and slightly sweet. The fillings tend to be a little greasy so the buns help to cut that greasiness. At $3.75 each, the buns are kind of on the pricey side, especially given the size. They aren't super filling, so unless you get many buns, they make more for a snack or light lunch. Two buns was definitely just a snack for me, and quite a pricey snack if it weren't free that day. But they're super yummy!

==========================

-TENDER PORK BELLY - 4.5/5 
(with tumeric pickled daikon + green shiso)
The truck is known mostly for its pork belly bun. And true to its name, the pork is super tender and moist, but also VERY fatty. I'm not a huge fan of fatty pork belly, so I wasn't too fond of the cut of meat, but I still liked the bun overall. The skin on the pork belly is crispy but not overly crunchy, and the pickled daikon added some crunch and texture to tender pork as well as a nice tangyness to the sweet marinade of the pork. Definitely recommend, unless you really don't like fatty pork belly.

-SPICY CHICKEN - 5/5
(with toasted sesame puree, pickled carrots/cucumber + cilantro)
There was a lot going on in this bun flavorwise - spicy from the chicken, creamy and nutty from the sesame puree and tangy from the pickled veggies - but I really liked the combination of flavors. I only wish the chicken were spicier. Unless you have a really low tolerance to spiciness, this is a must try!
author: Jessie L.

description:
I'm consistently amazed at just how popular Asian food for non-Asians can be. Don't get me wrong, I love my Panda Express as much as the next guy, and I'm thrilled to see the spread of delicious foods like mantou baos into the general foodie environment.

That said, I paid $7.50 for a pair of baos--one pork belly, one spicy chicken--that, while good, weren't worth the coin. And then I promptly went to eat more Asian food after this, because I was still hungry.

Of the two, I liked the pork belly better. It's more traditional in the baos, after all, adding a more sweet, succulent taste to complement the bread. The spicy chicken might be better in between a bun, as it's more Chick-Fil-A than Panda Express.

Kudos to the truck owners for spreading the gospel about delicious baos, but thems prices are a bit absurd.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: Such great tofu veggie buns! Steamed and baked... get one of each. The baked ones are a lot bigger than the steamed ones, but one of each fills up a hungry stomach perfectly. Trust me- If you just order one you'll regret it.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
Can I just gush about how much I loved their pork belly sandwich! Soooo good! This was my favorite food truck during my first visit to Off The Grid and if I hadn't filled up on so many other great foods I would have doubled up on the Chairman! 

I tried their pork belly sandwich on the baked bun and now, after seeing other reviews I wish I had tried their steamed bun. However, I was definitely pleased with the baked bun! I loved the combination of meat, veggies and sauce and I'll let you know I had the Bacon trucks pork belly as well and the Chairman outdid them! 

Friendly people, tasty food and some good looking wheels! I cannot wait for my second visit!
author: Rachel K.

description:
I'm so torn about The Chairman Truck - is it a 5-star review, or does it get knocked down to 4?  Hmm...

The case for 5-Stars:  Man, the food is tasty.  This is one of a handful of food trucks that I go to regularly.  The menu is incredibly simple - four types of Bao, each coming in two versions:  Baked or steamed.  The offerings are great.  Two of the buns have pork - one with the most delicious Coca-Cola braised pork, the other with rich and well-cooked pork belly.  There is also a chicken option with tender and flavorful chicken, and a terrific tofu bao.  All are finished with sauces that compliment the other ingredients perfectly.  Also, as a popular food truck goes, the lines move fast, and you won't get a Sisig-esque lunchbreak killer.

The case for 4-Stars:  $$$.  I just never feel like the dollar goes quite far enough here.  Bao are $3.25 or $3.75 for steamed - upwards of $6 for baked.  This is not a bad-deal, per se.  It's just not a great deal.  And, three steamed bao are tasty, but if you were starving, three wouldn't do the trick.  Additionally, I eat my lunch late.  Usually after 1pm or 1:30pm.  On a few occasions they've been out of things - sometime one of the types of bao (which is tough, when there are only four options to begin with), sometimes just a single ingredient.  Yesterday, no sesame puree sauce for my chicken.  These aren't killers.  Just, not 5-star traits.

Tips:
1.  Go with the steamed bao.  One of the great qualities of this place is that you can try a few different flavors in a single visit.  While some of the bao are better than others, it's good to try a few things.
2.  The braised pork is the best.  Mmm mmm...  The meat is extremely tender and has a great flavor.  The toppings are savory cabbage and a mustard-cream sauce.  
3.  If you like spicy food, soup-up #2 with a little Sirancha.  It compliments the flavors nicely.
4.  Even if you don't normally dig pork-belly, it's worth trying theirs.  It's rich and flavorful, and as tricky as prok-belly can be to do well, it's always cooked correctly here in my experience.
5.  Looks like a brick-and-morter place is coming soon on Larkin and Eddy.  

Bao!
author: Adam S.

description:
I recently found out about a cool Foodie and Beer festival called Eat Real in Oakland. I recently moved to the area, so this was definitely a good opportunity for me to venture out into the community and see what Oakland has to offer. The festival was held at Jack London Square and included tons of bars, restaurants and food trucks. Among the list of  trucks was the Chairman Truck. The folks I was with said they heard some amazing things about this truck and  that they served baos. Awesome! I'm such a fan of Asian foods, so naturally a food truck that served it was definitely on my radar. 

For the festival, they offered three things: steamed buns for $4 each, baked ones for $7 each and bao chips for $3 an order. When it came to the bao flavors, they offered 4 different types of meats and flavors. Here's what I got:

-Tender pork belly with tumeric pickled daikon and miso glaze. OH-EM-GEE! What an amazing bao! The pork belly was marbleized, crispy on the outside and packed with flavor. The daikon, pickled radishes, were thinly sliced on the top and brought a tangy element to the dish. ON POINT!

-Coca-cola pork with savoy cabbage, preserved yellow mustard seed and garlic mayo. This was by far, my favorite bao! The pork was also marbleized. This time, the mayo enhanced the entire dish and brought it to new heights! Creamy from the mayo, coupled with the crunchy cabbage and you've got a heavenly combination of flavors and textures. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

OMG, this food truck is on point! Definite 5 star in my books. I can't wait to stumble into them again! This ranks as my favorite food truck of SF so far! If you ever have the opportunity to visit them you NEED to try the baos. They will change your life! LOL, maybe not, but they're so finger licking good!
author: Rockne H.

description: Tried the steamed "bun" with coca-cola pork for $4.27. While it was good and I liked the flavors, I had barely three bites and it was gone!  Also, I thought I was getting an actual bao, not a tiny taco made out of bao dough. Judging from other people's reviews, it looks like the size went down and the prices went up. Bummed out...
author: Melissa G.

description:
SOOOOO DARN GOOD! By far one of favorite food trucks!

Coca Cola Braised Pork Belly with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved yellow mustard seeds! SO GOOD! The pork was juicy and tender. I got it baked so it was a normal sized burger bun. The steamed one is a bit smaller. I always attack this food truck after class and get super happy when I see it!
author: Tiffany H.

description: We love the food served to us, it is very delicious. Their steamed baos are so soo good!
author: Mega Team R.

description: At Larkspur landing today we ordered three steamed bao. From the woman taking orders to the guy who handed me my food to the cook who answered a question, all three of them were so rude and inhospitable that it ruined our experience. We will never purchase food again nor will we recommend them to anyone. If the enjoyment y of operating a food truck has disappeared, for the love of God find a new line of work. What a bunch of miserable human beings. Food sucked too.  None of us felt well after eating their food.
author: B F.

description:
Went for the chairman steamed buns today at $3.75 per piece it's not a bad deal but got to warn u they are small so you would need two or three to fill u up. Has the coco cola rubbed pork belly, pulled pork, crispy tofu. Fav was the pork belly, melts in your mouth.

Value 4/5
Amenities 4/5 
Service 4/5 quick takes credit
Quality 4/5

16/20
author: Nina S.

description: Baos are delicious.  Really robust flavors and all the ingredients complements each other.
author: Samantha C.

description:
FYI Come later near their closing time and you won't find a line.

I prefer the steamed buns rather than the baked ones, as i can try different ones rather than just getting one kinda meat. At first they look like they wont fill you up, but trust me they do and they are good. I got the pork belly, the braised pork and the chicken. 

The best one out of the bunch is the pork belly, love them both baked and steamed, you can't go wrong. The pork belly is cooked to perfection, it a bit crispy outside and amazingly tender on the inside. 
Get it now, but make sure to workout after cause you are kinda just eat fat.
author: Anuj C.

description:
REVIEW #222--appropriately numbered because Chairman Bao is so unreasonably delicious that it should be a CII requiring a DEA 222.  Okay, pharmacy puns aside, let me get to the review.

I'm not much of a food truck fan, which often seems like hipsterfied fabricated street food, often insidiously draining your wallet.  However, Chairman Bao really lives up to the hype.  

It is a fine art of fusion, unlike the slackers who add kimchi to something American and think they've pulled off something worthy for a foodie.  Well, THIS foodie is rarely impressed by fusion, and the Chairman truck is one of them.  They use traditional Chinese peking duck buns as the vehicle for a filling incorporating Asian ingredients with modern flavor profiles.

They have steamed and baked buns; the baked buns were uncomfortably similar to burgers, and the steamed buns are smaller so you could try more different ones (yes I shamelessly got 3, best decision ever):

Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso, $3.75: Not that pork belly ever disappoints, but this surpasses fried chicken in being a comfort food.  It's indeed tender, and when combined with tangy daikon and pungent shiso, it is just an amazing flavor explosion (and the explosiveness is appropriately diffused by the soft white bun).  

Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro, $3.75: It's actually spicy o.O Again, the veggies and seasoning complemented it very well.  I would just suggest eating this before the tofu because it becomes quite comforting after the spiciness.

Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum, $3.25: I got this to feel like I'm being healthy, but it was actually very tasty as well.  The texture of the tofu is wonderfully soft on the inside (almost like a scramble), with a crispy outer layer marinated in miso.  There is also copious amounts of choy sum (it's almost like a salad), and it all goes so well together that it makes me wonder why miso tofu choy sum isn't already a Chinese dish.

Coca-cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Yellow Mustard Seeds, $3.75: This is quite popular but personally I liked the other ones better.  I found the mustard seed cabbage to be somewhat bitter, and the tangle of endives-textured cabbage was a little difficult to eat.  Not bad, obviously, because there's pork belly but I would recommend the other ones.

They also have a duck one, but that's too fancy for me... it's also pricier and I already get my fix of duck in steam buns at Chinese restaurants.   (Oldschool but way more affordable)

Service and ambiance?  Meh it's a food truck... of course they're going to be friendly, of course you're going to admire--and perhaps Instagram-- the colorful truck, of course it's going to have a cute name (though this name is pretty darn cute), and of course you're going to have difficulties finding a place to eat.  But I must say, the culinary finesse at Chairman has renewed my faith in food trucks, after a few other saucy/salty/dehydrating food truck excursions had dashed my hopes.

The Chairman has extraordinary culinary finesse... if only it could live up to its philosophy and widely distribute yummy steamed buns for all.  I wouldn't mind being communist if it meant lifetime loyalty to Chairman Bao.
author: Edna C.

description:
Bigger buns will give you bigger buns. Now, some may interpret that as a bad thing. But hey, stop looking at the glass half-empty, mistah Debbie downah. Keep in mind that bigger buns mean a smaller waist-to-hip ratio, which translates to the possibility of fewer health risks.

Glass half-full. BOOM--optimism served.

Hypocritically, I got the smaller steamed bun haha :P $3.75 for a smaller Asian clamshell-shaped bun, with a slightly sweet flavor and overall fluffy texture, enveloping tender pork belly with turmeric pickled daikon and green shiso (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-chairman-truck-san-francisco?select=lU_fS0AacEh81ao1ZYJ5Dw#lU_fS0AacEh81ao1ZYJ5Dw). My roommate, who actually is more of an optimist than I am, appropriately ordered the bigger baked bun: $6.75 for a large Asian dinner roll-shaped bun, baked with a light sugar glaze for a golden-brown crust and a fluffy center, enclosing the same filling of tender pork belly with turmeric pickled daikon and green shiso (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-chairman-truck-san-francisco?select=lU_fS0AacEh81ao1ZYJ5Dw#zhmFjiazDkpJL1tqRKJEWw).

My thoughts? For pork belly, this is lean (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-chairman-truck-san-francisco?select=lU_fS0AacEh81ao1ZYJ5Dw#4xyIVogXU4GV8d_llR_b9w). It's healthier, which is why my roommate likes it. As for me, well, I could have used a bit more fat to lend a chewier texture. Plus, tbh, I could use a smaller WHR. But, what makes this bun such a bada$$ is the frickin' tumeric-soy sauce-pickled daikon. Frickin' picklin'.

So, what has this experience taught me?

One, they take CC. Two, the line moves quickly. Three, I think we can all agree that bigger buns are bettah. But who really cares about the bun when you have the perfect union of pork belly and pickled daikon in front of you? Make your bun choice based on how much meat you want to eat. And THAT is a different conversation for a different day ;)
author: Adele F.

description:
I dream about this trucks steamed buns! Especially now that I don't live in the Bay any more when I do come home to visit I am searching for them at everytime I see food trucks! This last time we were home I lucked out that they were at the Off the Grid event near me. I could eat these every day and not think of other food! Ok maybe ...some soy ice cream ;).
 My fav is the steamed bun with tofu and char... even if you don't like tofu you need to try it! I can't even begin to describe how delicious it is! There is an awesome sauce on it! The spicy chicken and carrot one is awesome too!  Its got a kick so I normally eat that one first and allow the tofu one to cool down my taste buds after ;) 
umm I want some now.....
author: Alisa R.

description:
PORK BELLY BAKED. 

I think I eat at least 3 of these every Outside Lands. 

Not last year though, last year at OL I ate 3 in one day not counting Friday and Saturday.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Chairman Bao's pork belly bao with pickled daikons was melt in my mouth and INVENTIVELY delicious...the spicy chicken was equally packed with the same flavor punch 
 ...YUMMMO .gimme more!!!

Fort Mason Off the Grid
author: Dee R.

description: I ordered 3 steamed buns and it came to about $12. The chicken and pork were amazingly flavorful and I'll definitely order them again -- but the tofu steamed bun lacked a lot of the flavor that the meat options had. This may become my regular lunch spot! Very curious to check out their physical location on Larkin.
author: Michael P.

description:
I confess I just love Gua Bao's, the classic Taiwanese red sugar and cilantro encrusted Pork Belly Bao's. The Chairman's pork belly bao's are sort of a fast food slider version of the Gua Bao's I crave. They are not perfect, but they partially satisfy my desire. With the steamed bun Bao's you need to order at least 3 to make a meal, they are small. The baked bun Bao's are a larger and twice the price.

The Chairman's spicy chicken and carrot bao's are also good.

I visited The Chairman at OTG Fort Mason, bring a jacket, it gets cold there.

Also be warned that  if you plan on getting your Baos's to go, you need to bring your own bags. The Chairman no longer provides plastic bags. 8 steamed baos packed 4 to a box is probably all you can safely carry while weaving through the crowds at OTG Fort Mason. The boxes are soft cardboard and not terribly sturdy. So plan ahead and bring your own Bao transportation containers or bags.
author: David T.

description:
I first ate at The Chairman on Larkin St. and loved this place like no other.

I had been to Off the Grid on 5th & Mina and seen the crazy lines for The Chairman truck. I went at an earlier time this week, around 12:15, and the line wasn't too bad. "Cool!" I thought.

After waiting only 10 minutes, I had a pork belly baked bun. I only had had their steamed baos before and blue potato bowl - which were amaziiiing.

Wow, I did not think I could be even more impressed with The Chairman, but their baked buns were as good as the steamed ones! The pork belly and its glaze just melt in your mouth. 

The pickled daikon is crunchy and is the perfect addition to the bao.

I looooove The Chairman and I wish I could have it at least once a week always :-D
author: Leslie S.

description:
Heard a lot about you! Good Stuffs
Do you have something against San Jose Area?
author: Lewis L.

description:
I have a love-hate relationship with any type of fusion food. This is because I definitely have noticed tons of fusion food places starting up in the city----which I am okay with, that is, as long as they are not pushing out local businesses...and of course this kind of food is catered to a certain demographic. A bit disappointed that The Chairman now has a physical restaurant in Little Saigon (branch of the Tenderloin, a neighborhood that majority comprises of people from low income backgrounds and people of color). Most locals there do not eat at places like these.

The food is good. I like to indulge myself once in a while when I feel like being more adventurous. They have "steamed and baked baos." The "steamed baos" are comprised of a bun like the ones you tend to get when you order roasted duck skin at the Chinese restaurant with some meat/tofu and pickled vegetables. The "baked bao" is made of a baked bun (the ones with the egg wash on top) but burger style. 

People usually get 2-3 steamed or 1 baked.
author: Anna H.

description:
Amazing pork belly buns. So tender and flavor is really seeped into the meat. Definitely try it with the mantou (steamed buns). They use pickled diakon radish instead of sour pickled Chinese cabbage. 

I am slightly bothered by the fact that they called the truck the Chairman, when they're serving food originating from Taiwan.
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
I'm stuck between a 3.5 and 4 stars. 

Tried 2 steamed baos at the Alameda OTG. 1 spicy chicken and 1 coco-cola pork $3.50 each. Hubs had the same order our total was $14.

The 4 baos were packaged together in a cardboard to-go container. We ate them quickly on the curb, they looked and smelled delicious I couldn't wait. 

Both were seasoned and meat cooked perfectly. The cabbage and pickled veggies were good topping. No additional condiments needed. 

My only complaint is that they are small for the price. After 3 bites (6 total) they were gone and I was longing for more. I would recommend ordering 3 or 4 to get full or order another item. It is considered a snack item according to their online menu. 

I would hit them for more baos or maybe try the baked type.
author: Amber S.

description:
I have not even eaten the food I just got because the service was bad. They had to remake my 1 baked bun order 3 times. First because they just threw it away because I was not there immediately when they called my name? Second time was because it was a the wrong order and then finally got it right on the 3rd try. Also what did they do with the other 2 things they made for me? 

Lastly, when I handed the guy my number he asked me multiple times, what's my number and then he just asked me what I ordered. What's the point of using numbers if you don't even connect those numbers to someone's order? 

Maybe the food is good but the service is lackong
author: Darius K.

description:
Ever since my friends had gushed about their amazing Gua Baos, I've had my eyes on The Chairman Truck. I was stoked to have finally caught up with them at my local Off The Grid food trucks event. 

I normally don't like pork belly, but these buns really lived up to the hype! Who knew that the combination of pork belly braised in Coke for hours could turn out to be this mouthwatering! 

Stuffed between fluffy, freshly-steamed buns, the pork belly itself was super tender with some delightfully crispy edges. Altogether topped with a turmeric daikon pickle, the whole harmonious combination just, gosh, melted right in my mouth making me sigh ahhhmazing! 

Portions were tiny at $3.75 each, but get two and your tummy will thank you later :)
author: Veronica C.

description:
I love this food truck! I am a vegetarian and I have tried their Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum with steamed bun. I got 2 of them and I was in heaven! I love it so much. One of the bests I have had. 

Get 2 steamed if you aren't too hungry. If super hungry, get 3 steamed or 1 baked bun.
author: Hiral P.

description:
The Chairman Truck (previously known as The Chairman Bao Bun Truck) serves some delicious, mouthwatering, and flavorful meat-stuffed buns.

You can get your buns one of two ways: baked or steamed. The baked buns are nice and fluffy with a mild hint of sweetness. It's moist but doesn't get soggy with the additional ingredients inside. The steamed buns are also fluffy and delicious, but they get soggy quickly and don't hold all the ingredients as sturdily.

The most popular ingredient option seems to be the tender pork belly with pickled daikon and green shiso. The pork belly is SO GOOD! The edges are slightly crispy, but the fatty meat as a whole is very flavorful, moist, tender, and smokey. The pickled daikon is mildly acidic and has a nice crunch, complimenting the pork belly's flavor and textures very well. The coca cola braised pork is pretty good as well, but the shredded cabbage it's topped with leaves a very strange and bitter aftertaste, reminiscent of brussel sprouts. The spicy chicken option is somewhat misleading. It seems that the chicken would be the spicy component, but it's actually the pickled carrots and cucumbers that have quite a bit of heat. The chicken still has good smokey flavor, but it's those pickled vegetables that will surprise you.

Occasionally the truck has "Bao chips". For $2.50, you get a generous portion of crunchy fried wonton crisps tossed with togarashi spice blend and seaweed. The wonton crisps are very crunchy, but not too oily. They're salty and slightly spicy. If you like the umami taste in Calbee's shrimp flavored chips, you'll like Chairman's Bao chips.

The amount of food you get for the price you pay at this food truck is reasonable. A single baked bao ($6.75 average) or two steamed baos ($3.75 each, average) is quite satisfying. The major downside is that the menu is very limited, so within three or four visits to The Chairman Truck, you would've tried everything. Whatever happened to their lion's head meatball and duck confit options?
author: Priscilla W.

description:
Still a good as the last time. Consistent buns and great flavor. They got a couple of new trucks so more locations to find them which is good.  

Come check it out if you want some tasty chinese tacos. Get the pork belly, it's still the best.
author: Vincent W.

description:
Steamed buns are a popular Taiwanese snack, and I was so excited when I found out Chairman made those. I wouldn't say Chairman is 100% authentic, but IT IS YUMMY!

I recommend the pork belly for first timers. If that's too fatty for you, go for the spicy chicken.
author: Vivian W.

description:
Yum!!! This food truck magically produces some heavenly Taiwanese-style bun sandwiches (gua bao).

We got the Steamed Tender Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon and Steamed Coca-Cola Braised Pork. The bread on these sandwiches is so soft and fluffy, it looks like they pump them full of air before serving them! The meat packed within is absolutely top notch. You'll be paying a premium for each of these mini sandwiches, but you'll certainly get your money's worth.

Follow them on Twitter (@chairmantruck) to know where the Chairman is giving its blessings.  They are part of Off the Grid: a posse of amazing food trucks that travel all over the Bay Area. Check out their schedule and hope that they come to a neighborhood near you!
author: Mark C.

description:
The last time I gave a food truck five stars was back in 2010.  

Okay.  I think I've gone to pretty much most of the food trucks in SoCal and thought I should try SF's coveted Chairman Truck at Off the Grid.  I asked for the most popular bun and was told that it was the pork belly with daikon.  I'm not easily impressed by food trucks because I've been disappointed so many times before but damn...that pork belly was so off the Richter good that I wish I had gotten another one.  The pork was so tender, it melted in my mouth and the daikon was a good complement to the savory meat to add texture to the bun, bringing it to perfection.  

My only regret was not trying the rest of the buns at this truck.  I probably should have planted my ass in front of this truck instead of wasting time and money at the other trucks that were only mediocre.  This was the only joint where I ate the food in its entirety.  I'm just sayin'...

Wonder what it would take to have this food truck become a regular in LA?

P.S. The lines get long.  Go early if possible.
author: Rosie H.

description: Seems you find these baos everywhere these days. Nothing special anymore.  Had two at fort mason off the grid.  There was tax and it was $10 and some change.  Would I want the dirty coins as change and then grab the baos to eat?  Why wouldn't you include tax in your price and not have to deal with coins.  Also, almost $11 for two baos is way expensive and was just ok overall.  I could get 3 banh mi sandos at L&G.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Yum pork belly bun!
They're quite small, so make sure to order 2.
I prefer the steamed over the baked.
Loved the daikon over it!
author: Cay A.

description:
Amazing. These guys were at the Maker Faire in San Mateo this weekend and I can't recommend them enough. 

I had the braised pork sandwich on the baked bao. It's the larger of the sandwiches (compared to the steamed bao). 

The pork was cooked to perfection and the coleslaw-like concoction inside the sandwich with the pork was a great compliment. 

The sandwich was neither greasy or overly heavy. 

Also try out their bao chips. Salty and crunchy!

Service was incredibly fast considering how busy they were. Will definitely go back given the chance.
author: Andrew L.

description: I am in LOVE with The chairman!!!!! Whenever I get to SF I try to get to an OTG to find The Chairman truck. I usually hit up OTG on Upper Haight. They are always there. My fav is the coca cola braised pork....OMG love love love it!!! Its perfectly balanced with the cabbage & mustard seeds. I'd hop on a plane right now to get it. I've tried the spicy chicken too it was really good and had a nice spicy kick to it. The veggies on each sandwich  really pair perfectly with whatever you get.  The chef was formerly Charlie Trotters executive chef in Las Vegas. They know what they're doing. The buns are perfect too, the steamed bun a soft pillow and the baked bun a sweet place for the fillings. Love you Chairman!!!! See you on my next trip!
author: Karen R.

description:
The thing is -- it's so hard to find Taiwanese "gua baos" in Toronto. There are probably only two places that I can think of. I got really excited when I got to San Francisco, to find out that there is a food truck devoted to this.

I got myself the tender pork belly bao, which I HIGHLY HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMEND. Even my friend who's from Taiwan absolutely loved it. For a Taiwanese person to recommend and love this, then it MUST be amazing.

I also had the Coca-Cola braised pork, but it definitely was no pork belly.

Pork belly, all the way.
author: Joanne W.

description:
Short, sweet and simple

Didn't get the hype, no highs or lows, wait not worth wild IMO

Overall Thoughts

The more food trucks I try the less there is something to be desired but I leave it up to you to try for yourself and see if The Chairman Truck is worthy of all the press
author: Eddie W.

description: Found The Chairmen at Bishop Ranch split a variety of their offerings with my husband, the steamed buns are the way to go. The tofu bun is juicy flavorful and mouth watering. The pork belly is sinfully rich and delightful it pairs nicely with the lighter steamed bun and pairing it with the tofu steamed bun.
author: Lacy C.

description:
My  coworkers have proclaimed this food truck their favorite! 

The steamed baos are itty bitty, but packed with flavor. 

The baked baos is a lot of bun, with the same amount of filling. 

We all prefer the steamed baos.

Recommendations: The chicken and the pork belly!
author: Ladi Da A.

description: One of out Go-to food trucks! We will travel to get this for lunch on occasion. They never disappoint! All their pickled veggies are mouth watering delicious! Fun to eat, great presentation and flavor! I'd love to have them cater my next big event!!
author: Sierra M.

description:
Oh my, Chairman Truck. Foodgasm in my mouth.

I tried the pork belly, and some other ones, but clearly my tastebuds only vividly remember the pork belly one. Good balance of flavors - fluffy bun, delicious and piping hot pork belly, and some veggie on top to add some citrus in there. Now I see what the hype is about.
author: Kris I.

description:
We ordered some buns delivered to the office. And I'm so glad we tried it! I had three flavors - pork belly, spicy chicken, and beef rib. Pork belly is clearly the winner for me without doubt. It's very flavorful, cooked with soy sauce, cooking wine and many more ingredients with love and care, sinfully tender that it could almost melt in my mouth. And it's so magical that I can't really tell the difference between lean meat and fat by tasting as the texture is almost the same - you will have extremely tender lean meat enriched by fat, and "compact" fat that you won't feel guilty to have. On top of it is pickled thinly-sliced radish, a great complement that brings freshness and saltiness to make the pork belly even more enjoyable. I'm usually extremely picky about animal fat in food, and for most of the time I would simply leave fat on my plate if it's too rich. But this time it totally won me over.

Since the pork belly bun shines so much, it's almost unfair to write reviews for the spicy chicken and beef rib bun next to it. The texture of the chicken is good, not too well done with enough flavor. But I would expect a bit more spice. The beef rib bun is surprisingly good paired with cabbage and the bun, but of course the flavor is not as memorable as the pork belly one.

Get the pork belly ones, and one piece won't be enough!
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
I recently joined a friend and enjoyed a nice lunch provided by the Chairman Truck!

I ordered the tender pork belly with turmeric pickled daikon and green shiso that was baked. It came with chips and a drink for $11.25.

 The pork belly sandwich was great and had the nice crunch of the pickled daikon and green shiso.

I would highly recommend and return!
author: Richard G.

description:
Oh dear, sweet baby jesus. 

I had yet to try chairman bao since they are seemingly never EVER in the east bay, or I miss them when they make a rare appearance at OTG out here. Well, after the color run in SF this past weekend, they were parked in the lot and there was a huge line of hungry or drunk or possibly both patrons (I may or  may not have fallen into the both category). I grabbed my wallet and hopped into line, super excited to finally try these (yes, I get ridiculously excited for food. don't judge me.) 

I ordered one pork belly and one chicken, and I've been kicking myself ever since for not ordering 2039850239850283 to keep in my freezer so I can eat these for the rest of my life. They completely lived up to the hype! The pork belly was tender and flavorful, and the buns are soft and pillowy. The chicken was actually VERY good, dare I say it may have been better than the pork belly! It was spicy and super tender and delicious and awesome and oh god why didn't I buy more..... *sobs*

...


*keeps sobbing*
author: Angela L.

description:
My very first experience w/ Chairman Bao was when Sis insisted we get their Tofu Buns

The truck used to come to her place of work & she always had a special place in her heart for their steamed buns

So when we saw them at Stoneridge Mall during their Farmers Market, beelines were made

Steamed Tofu Bun had wonderfully fried tofu that was a bit crispy on the outside but soft on the inside, baby bok choy that still had a bite to it & this sesame dressing that wasn't too oily but extremely flavorful.........and even though these were deemed "buns", I found them to be presented more like a taco (but what do I know about such things?  Delicious is delicious!)

The bun part was soft & bready & this was bao perfection - can't wait until next time!!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
I ate lunch from this truck for the first time...couple of minor critiques.  #1 it would be helpful if they had pics of their food posted on their rig like most trucks.  #2 they are kind of pricey (especially on the steamed items).  
Notwithstanding the critiques listed above, this truck has two types of buns...steamed and baked with the steamed being significantly smaller.  I had the pork belly steamed bun and spicy chicken on baked bun.  OMG!  They were both amazing!  I ate the tiny pork belly bun first and the explosion of flavors in my mouth were indescribable.  I followed it with the spicy chicken on baked bun and different flaves but, again indescribably amazing!  The fresh pickled veggie condiments were like nothing I have ever had.  My mouth just had an orgasm...no, it had a MOUTHGASM!  Only reason they didn't get 5 is because of the two issues above.  Other then that this truck is legit!
author: Anthony M.

description:
I tried this this at Off the Grid Southside in Berkeley. 
The Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso was a bit too sweet, but contained large juicy pieces of pork belly. I had it baked, and the bun was pretty good, slightly toasted and soft. The baked Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds was my favorite of the two. It was a bit hard to eat as with every bite the meat would start to fall out, but it was a great mix of soft braised pork and cabbage salad. I liked eating it with a bit of sriracha, which I thought enhanced its flavor.
author: Kristy K.

description: This was one of the first food trucks I've ever tried.  I used to be a baked type of guy but slowly the steamed baos started to grow on me.  I usually get the spicy chicken bao which is totally great.  While the other ones are good as well I've always stuck with the spicy chicken.  If you're not sure what one to get, the steamed ones are small enough that you can order one of each on their menu and try them all out.
author: Scott T.

description:
I get SOOOOO excited when this food truck comes to our work to serve us lunch.  One of my favorites!  Can't miss this free lunch!

Line is always super long because everyone loves it too, but it's definitely worth the wait.  I always get the same thing; 2 steamed buns:

Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso
Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Puree, Pickled Carrots, Cucumber, & Cilantro

Add some Siracha on it and I'm uber satisfied!  It doesn't seem like a lot of food, but it's pretty fulfilling.  If I had a 3rd steamed bun, I'd definitely be stuffed.  I've tried the baked pork belly one before, but I wasn't a fan.  So I'm sticking to the steamed buns!
author: Erica S.

description:
I recently tried the Chairman Truck last week, and only sampled two of the baos so I can't give an accurate rating. But based on those 2 things, HOT DAMN! It was like a party in my mouth!!

I ordered the crispy miso cured tofu steamed bao. Everything was on point, from the bao to the salad on top! The only complaint that I had was that I only ordered 1! I also tried a bite of the spicy chicken bao which was delicious as well, but my friend finished that in a blink of an eye so I was lucky to even sneak in a bite!

After walking around, I was tempted to order another one but the line got too long =( it's ok, I'LL BE BACK!
author: Noelle H.

description: My favorite Bay Area food truck!! I always get so excited when this truck is in my neighborhood! I always get their tender pork belly baked/steam bao and wonton chips!
author: Alice X.

description: Delicious! Love them from the beginning. Food is always consistent no matter if it's from the truck or the restaurant. We go to the food truck and farmers market events just to get their food. Wish they had a restaurant in the peninsula.
author: Lily P.

description:
Love their food!

Tender Pork Belly on a baked bun and Crispy Miso Cured Tofu on a steamed bun are the best. 

I never miss this truck. When they are in Sac for the SacMofo or Treasure Island in SF, I'm there. I know this truck goes to other places too (like Mission in SF, etc) but those are my fav spots. I even had them cater my wedding and they were awesome. So easy to book for a wedding and had excellent customer service. Very professional. They did all the stuff they promised at the wedding and they even gave more food at the wedding. They were fast in cooking and all my guests loved them hence the extra food. I'm probably going to hire them on my events (bday maybe even on a baby shower). So much love to The Chairman Truck!
author: Ai M.

description: Today I had a Bao for the very first time. I've never had Taiwanese food and my oh my am I sooooo happy this was my first experience! I had the Spicy Chicken Baked Gua Bao and omg it was delicious tonight at OTG!  So filling! Can't wait to have another!
author: Tiffany W.

description:
The Chairman Truck as yet to disappoint! Came early/on time to set up and were ready on time/early for our scheduled lunch time as well!

They're steamed buns are really good. I highly recommend those. I personally enjoy the tofu the most. The chicken is a close second. (Not a fan of pork specifically to say for the other options though.)

We've had them come out a few months ago to cater our weekly lunch, and all of our employees remember them and were excited that I brought the food truck back. I will definitely book them again!
author: Jackie E.

description: Pork belly bun is my favorite. The meat was well marinated and super tender. Pickles add a light sour taste to it so it doesn't feel heavy for the tummy. I also like the chicken bao. The bun was soft and fluffy. Love it
author: Zisele N.
