description: I've seen the light.  The Chairman is one of the best trucks in the Bay Area.  I've been able to try most of their items, they are all quite excellent.  The pork is tender and flavorful, especially with the tumeric pickled daikon.
author: Angel S.

description:
It's good... But the line is always so darn long.  I opt for the steam bun option because its half the price.... But I gobble those down like nothing... I can easily eat 4 buns and still go for a snack... 

The buns are flavorful. I like the coca cola braised pork and the pork belly. 

If you're going to be waiting awhile it's worth it to buy a few. But don't expect to get super full off the steam buns. 

I wanted to try the bao chips the other day but of course after waiting 30 min in line when i got up there it had just sold out :(

The truck is good but it's pricy. Ill get it more as a snack.
author: Belinda T.

description:
What can I say that hasn't already been said?  Well, I could talk about my wedding!  We hired The Chairman Truck as one of three food trucks to cater our wedding reception.  Initially looking for an Asian option food truck in the bay area, everyone and their mother kept suggesting them, so we decided why not?

We gave our guests the choice between Pork Belly, Braised pork butt, Tofu, and Spicy chicken steamed buns.  Each was exquisitely yummy, but the pork belly was definitely the crowd favorite.

The Chairman Truck was by far the most professional truck we worked with.  They were very prompt, straight forward with their options and pricing, communicated with us regularly, and had catered before at numerous wedding events.  This made the process extremely easy and comforting.  While they were one of the more expensive splurges of our event, they definitely lived up to the age old saying "you get what you pay for."

During the reception, everyone working the truck was also really helpful, fast, and fun.

Even after the whole event, they stayed to box up all our extra buns...we over estimated the ability of our guests to stuff themselves...and they made sure we got everything before they left.

In regards to The Chairman Truck's ability to cater an event, I'd highly recommend them.  The steamed buns lived up to expectation and the service was great.
author: Matt Q.

description:
This truck takes steamed pork buns to another level. Both of the pork buns are amazing. The official names for the pork buns are "Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso" and "Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds." I can't tell you what "turmeric" or "shiso" or "savoy" are without googling, but I can tell you that whatever they are, they're delicious in these pork buns. Tender and juicy meats in delicious marinade, you'll wish all of your burgers tasted like this.

My only complaint is the sizing and pricing. The steamed buns are tiny, so you'd probably need to order three to satisfy your hunger. The baked buns are bigger, but one will probably still not be enough. Your best bet is probably to get one steamed and one baked bun. Maybe two baked buns, if you're feeling particularly hungry. But when you start ordering multiple buns, the prices add up! Capitalism at work in this communist food truck.
author: Brittany C.

description:
The steamed pork belly bun was amazing. 

It is the only menu item we got but the bun was the softest bun I've had. Better than Momofuku's bun. 

The pork belly was very soft. The pickles on top went very well with the pork and bun. 

Overall I had 2 delicious bites. I wish I got my own. 

I think we paid 3.75 for 1 bun?
author: Hae A.

description:
The Chairman has continued to surpass every other Bay Area food truck I've tried in terms of service and quality!

All of the steamed buns are excellent, but my favorite by far is the Pulled Pork. You have to try these little puffs of heaven! The fluffy buns from a local bakery, combined with bold, carefully selected meat and veggie combinations, are some of the best things I've ever had in my life (seriously!).

I never imagined giving a food truck five stars, but The Chairman is to die for. Please please please come to more events on the lower peninsula!
author: Jackson L.

description: The Chairman Truck came to my workplace in Sunnyvale for employee appreciation week. We got two steamed buns and a drink as part of our complimentary lunch. I ordered the Coca Cola Braised Pork steamed bun and the pork belly steamed bun. Words do not begin to describe how amazing the food was. The bun was very soft and a perfect compliment to the meat. The pork was delicious. Both were a perfect balance of savory and sweet. This is something you have to go try. Oh hey... I did use words to describe the food. :D
author: Victor T.

description:
I am now a fan and am following them on twitter, so when they are close to me, maybe within 100 miles or so, I can rush out to get my fatty fix.

I never thought poky belly sounded good. Oh, how wrong I was. These tasty, fatty morsels are worth waiting in line to purchase.  There were two pieces on my steamed bun.  I offered one to L, she only wanted a taste; I am so happy that I got to eat them both.
author: Terry T.

description: I can see how the convenience and uniqueness of Chairman's gua bao makes it attractive. The braised pork in coke is great - good amount of fat and nice flavors. The cabbage and pickled mustard seeds compliment it well. There's nothing that special about the chicken..a lot of chili oil. The buns were disappointing too, they use yeast culture from China to make them but the flavor is a bit underwhelming. Overall, worth checking out.
author: Matthew L.

description:
I am ride or die for these buns.  The cold and the rain have not kept me away from tracking this truck down on the weekends.  That is how delicious these little snacks are. 

Coca Cola Braised Pork with Savory Cabbage and mustard seeds:  This food truck could put on a clinic for restaurants on how to braise without turning meat into a dry tasteless mass.  The pork is so juicy and semi sweet mixing well with the tangy cabbage and mustard seeds.   

Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro:  The combination of spicy with the pickled veggies is so right.  

Now, I would love to make a meal out of these tasty buns but the price makes me feel like this is more of a snack.  I would need at least 4 ($15 total at $3.75 a piece) of the steamed buns to feel satisfied.
author: Melissa R.

description:
Jeez-Louise, I had no idea there was a big brouhaha over the existence of this truck due to a vociferous charge of copyright infringement from an East Coast food truck owner who claimed the name of Chairman Bao for his own pork belly bun. I was wondering why this truck suddenly became The Chairman like the serene-looking but totally totalitarian panda in the logo was Sinatra or something. Truth be told, I really don't care about the political battles that caused the name change since I was excited to try the buns. Why, you may ask?

Well, it's the first time I have had anything in these parts remind me of a menu item from David Chang's Momofuku operation, probably the best Southern-fried Asian fusion food I've ever had. It's obvious that's the inspiration for chef Eric Rudd's creations here since the steamed buns look like carbon copies of Chang's appetizers (see my photo from Momofuku Ssam Bar if you don't believe me - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/1Ed-tb_0dBGrXfsYyehmvg?select=1fLj9Y-XQNAeEw9r9n8Chg). The truck was parked at the Chevron station next to the 17th Street Plaza where I usually see the Crème Brulee Truck. I got so excited I think I made a little penguin fin-clapping gesture and decided to try two of them. Hey, they're small, and I couldn't help myself.

The steamed ones sounded healthier and at $3.75 a piece, were three bucks cheaper than their baked cousins. Both were in the poufy white-clamshell buns I recall so well from Momofuku. The first was stuffed with Coca-Cola-Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage, Yellow Mustard Seeds and Kewpie Mayo. Delicious and about three bites in my famished condition. But I have to tell you my preference was the Tender Pork Belly with Tumeric-Pickled Daikon and Green Shiso (see photo). Pork belly is a can't-miss food item for me, especially when it's braised into a crispy texture making the crunch of the daikon a nice complement. I doubt if I'll ever try the spicy chicken or tofu variations because, well... what for? Pork is for the ages.

FOOD - 4 stars...hey, if you're going to copy anyone, copy David Chang, I say
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...gee, it's a truck, granted a cool one with a Communist panda logo
SERVICE - 3 stars...you order, you wait, you pick it up, no big whoop
TOTAL - 4 stars...pork belly for the proletariat...Mao would shed a tear
author: Ed U.

description:
On this rainy day, I had to pick up something at South Shore Shopping Center. Driving by I notice that the Off the Grid area, which is normally crowded, was practically empty.  Then I spot the red Chairman Truck parked there.  I thought, heck with the rain, and I'm going to get a bao/bun from the Chairman.

I've heard rave reviews from fellow Yelpers and friends about the pork belly. The choice was getting it in a steamed bun at $3.75 or baked bun at $6.75.  After reading the reviews, I opted for the Tender Pork Belly on a baked bun.  The bun was fluffy and loved that it was toasted on the grill, which helps it from getting soggy.  The pork belly is tender and so flavorful and it was complemented nicely by the turmeric pickled daikon and green shiso. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-chairman-truck-san-francisco?select=PXuHTrIBxUq_TGMV3vM4OA#_mA8_NJUNGdQwQ8aICc04Q)

The baked bun sandwich is good sized in relation to even two of the steamed bun sandwiches.  Good call fellow Yelpers.  I am now a fan of the tender pork belly sandwich in a baked bun.  To round out my experience, I might have to give their Coca-Cola braised pork and spicy chicken buns a try.  But it might be hard to give the other fare a try because I love tasty pork belly and The Chairman does it so well!
author: Al L.

description:
I can't stand a roach coach. I don't eat pork.  Then why was I at the chairman? ?? A drunken night out and a spicy chicken bao whaaaaaaaaaat yummmmm.

 It's actually delicious and i just pray they have enough got holding for everything they serve it always makes me nervous but I've eaten off this truck a few times now and it's always hot always good.
author: Niah N.

description:
Trust me, you want to eat here. And you want the steamed buns (which are cheaper) over the baked ones. And you can't go wrong with any of the meats.

One of the best things that Off The Grid: Menlo Park has to offer.
author: Sean B.

description: My fave food truck in SF!  Steamed bun Pork Belly-sweet sauce, melt in your mouth goodness, much better than the baked.  Service is quick & they are very nice.  I had to find them so I emailed them before my lady day in SF so I can leave very happy!
author: Jem B.

description:
I've only ever been to Treasure Island once and I just found out they have a monthly flea market. Seizing the opportunity to see the city from a new angle and possibly score some great gifts or desk toys, my girlfriend headed across the bridge for adventure.

We didn't find any trinkets to buy, but The Chairman truck was present. I distinctly remember it being called Chairman Bao, but the must have offended somebody and changed their name as a result. Luckily, their buns haven't changed and I opted to try their famous pork belly bao. I really enjoyed the contrast between the pickled radish and savory pork belly, which while could have been a tad thicker, had great flavors. For $3.75, it was a small bite but surprisingly filling, and I think two would have actually filled me up.

They relocate all the time but I'm glad I finally got to try their fare. I actually prefer baos to tacos so this really hit the spot. The event, and the usual truck spots, are pet friendly so be sure to bring your dog out to enjoy the day. I'm not a big food truck fan in general, but I'm sold on The Chairman.

Food: 8/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Every time this truck comes to the Hiller Aviation Museum, I grab my buddies and race over there.

I've been to this truck half a dozen times and it's one of my favorite trucks in the bay area.

I like their steamed "sandwiches" because they're smaller, fluffier, and I can order a variety of them. Like Asian sliders.

 So, I order one of each: tender pork belly, coca cola braised pork, spicy chicken, and fried tofu.

Love 'em all, but the tender pork belly is my favorite. Though, if I were a vegetarian I would probably live off of their miso tofu sandwiches.

 If there are tons of trucks, and you're head is spinning because you can't decide.

Choose this one.
author: Jack R.

description: They had the longest food truck line @ the Eat Real Festival, so I figured all these people know something I didn't. After 15 min waiting, I found out. You can pick either small sweeter steamed rice flour bun or the Chinese brioche-type bun as your carb boat and I was torn between the coca-cola slow braised pork or the fried pork belly...so I did both.  The braised pork was just okay, but that pork belly is OFF THE CHAIN!  It's lightly fried, correctly seasoned, so so good with the slaw and the perfectly buttered & griddled Chinese brioche bun.  Needless to say, it was worth the wait in line, but next time I'll skip the braised pork.
author: Kathryn L.

description: OMG they came to my job *Netflix* at first ii was a little skeptical on what to get so ii ended up getting the steamed pork belly, spicy chicken, and the coco cola pork, omg it was like a party in my MOUF!! Trust me ii will find you guys and bring my family with me. THIS IS A MUST TASTE!!
author: Lone E.

description:
The Chairman has been my white whale for the past two years. I've never been able to catch it. Edgewood eats? They're not there that day. Downtown San Francisco? They're just pulling away. Today was the day. I found the truck and it was glorious.

As everyone says, the steamed buns are better than the baked. You can get more variety and the bun is softer. The baked ones look like a burger, which is fine but you're here to get the best Chairman experience you can. Get the steamed.

I had the spicy chicken and the pork belly and both were amazing. The chicken is not especially spicy, but more tangy and rich and flavor. The pork belly is likewise very soft and has a bold taste where you want to lick your fingers after. The pickled vegetables on top add a nice counter balance to the heavy meat so it doesn't feel as greasy as other types of street food. My friend had the tofu and was not so impressed, so if I were you I would stick to the richer meats.

Enjoy! It's worth it.

If you're on Stanford campus, the Chairman comes every two weeks to the street right outside Mitchell Earth Sciences (near the big fountain outside Thornton). Check out foodtrucks.stanford.edu for the schedule!

Note: I notice that there's a main Yelp entry for The Chairman based in San Francisco (http://www.yelp.ca/biz/the-chairman-truck-san-francisco). It's really hard to find unless you're near SF (I didn't even find it except for a Google Search). Since the truck moves all up and down the bay, is there a better way for Yelp to show search results for food trucks? I'm going to leave my review here so people in South Bay can more easily find it.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Chairman Bao is my new favorite food truck.

I've had BaoHaus in New York and have yet to try a place that has similar baos. I've been wanting to try Chairman Bao ever since I heard about them on Check Please. My dad wanted to go to Off the Grid in Hayward, so I was excited when Chairman Bao's twitter read that they would be here tonight.

We came here a total of four times in one night. Yes, four times. The first time to try their steamed pork belly bao, the second time to order the braised pork and spicy chicken baked baos, the third time to buy a bottle of water and the fourth time to take one home for my mom.

The flavor of the meat paired with the crunchiness of the veggies went so well together. I loved the tanginess of the mayo on the braised pork bao. My favorites were the pork belly and braised pork. I liked the spicy chicken but it was too spicy for me to finish a whole bao. It's really not THAT spicy but I can't take a lot of spiciness. I liked both the steamed and baked bao equally. If you're trying to decide between the two, go with the steamed bao for a smaller portion and the baked bao for a larger portion. Both are slightly sweet and soft. Everything just worked well and was delicious. Prices are a little steep but I think it's worth it. 

They said they're at Hayward's Off the Grid every other week so I will definitely be coming back.
author: Charlene E.

description:
This was the first truck I hit up at the South Point Gourmet Food Truck Festival (11/5/11) in Las Vegas. I was smart enough to check out the menus of most of the trucks online before going there so i didn't have to waste time deciding what to try. The line was already about 30 people deep but from the looks of it, wait times were about the same for most other trucks. I spent about half an hour waiting in line to order and another 15 minutes or so to get my food -- not great, but not bad either.

The best of the two steamed buns ordered was the pork belly bao ($3.75). Pork belly rarely disappoints and their rich and savory version was a winner. Coupled with the sour and acidic taste of the tumeric pickled daikon and green shiso, the flavors left me begging for more. 

Unfortunately, I ate the pork belly first. The braised pork bao ($3.75) with savoy cabbage and preserved yellow mustard seeds wasn't nearly as pleasing. The pork itself was excellent but I wasn't a fan of the other ingredients.

I do have to commend them for the amount of food. While $3.75 for each bao is steep, they pack them with as much food as possible. Plenty of it will spill out as you bit into it, so grab a fork to make sure you can eat every last morsel.
author: Clint B.

description:
Awesome! Kind of stumbled across this place on Yelp and walked by so we gave it a shot. We had the steamed rolls of pork belly, beef short rib, and coca cola braised pork. The best, by a long shot, was the pork belly. Everything was so good and fresh though, it's hard to not want it all.

I'd recommend getting at least 3 of the steamed buns since we first ordered 2 per person and it wasn't enough. Each of the pork belly steamed buns at the time were $3.75 so three per person would run you around $11 plus tax. Not too bad but absolutely delicious.
author: Ian S.

description:
Location: Diff locations caught then at upper haight!


Customer Service: Awesome they are so friendly!!!


Decor: Cute little red food truck with a panda chairman, haha the irony.



How did the food taste?: Delicious!!!!! I got the Steamed Bao which had the pork belly and the daikon! I feel like the steamed Bao is much lighter vs the baked Bao I think it goes better. Anyways the pork belly was cooked to perfection and the crisp fresh taste of the daikon was on point!


Overall Experience: I saw them on tv before and I knew I had to try their food!!! If I lived in SF or if I could magically transport myself in a snap to whenever they were every time I was craving their food I would be at their location 24/7!


Would I Come Back?: YES!!!!
author: Rosh E.

description:
First in line at the South Point Gourmet Food Truck Fest here in Vegas,We tried three different Bao- Marinated Miso Tofu, Braised Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon, and the Duck Confit with Papaya Salad.

All Three were very tasty and delicious-tofu was very flavorful, and the pork belly and duck confit was melt-in-your-mouth good!

Thanks for sharing some Bay Area love!!!   ALOHA!!!

YELP 365 CHALLENGE-(74/365) " Bao Down to Tasty Goodness"
author: Nelson Q.

description:
Steamed pork belly buns. OH. MY. GAHD.

It's salty. It's unctuous. It belongs in MY belly.

$3.75 is a small price to pay for a little piece of heaven.

Do yourself a favor and get some.
author: Vi T.

description:
As a mostly vegetarian terrified of pork (but in love with bacon, go figure), I have traditionally shied away from bao, dim sum, anything resembling a dumpling. At the Haight st. food roundup, I faced that fear. 

My sister recommended a little something from a few trucks. At The Chairman Truck, she ordered the steamed tofu buns. This was a wise move. Because those things are delicious. Full of flavor, texture and easy to eat in public, we enjoyed every bite!

Another highlight - the staff are very friendly.
author: Em L.

description:
I met my friends at Justin Herman Plaza for lunch this past Sunday. Besides the ice skating rink, the Plaza offered about 5 food trucks for our holiday dining pleasure. One of my favorite trucks, The Chairman, was featured. 

I decided to attempt the "quad-fecta"  or the Porker as it is listed on the receipt. I ordered all 4 fillings in 4 steam buns. Would I succeed? It was a home run and a touchdown. It was a struggle, but I did it! The steamed buns are the perfect portion size if you want to attempt the "quad-fecta." 

I loved 3 of the 4 fillings. Perhaps I should have eaten the fried tofu bao first. Instead, I ate it last and I think the quality suffered. The flavor was good but the crispiness from frying the tofu was lost as the sandwich cooled down. 

The pork belly bao is also best eaten hot or it may suffer the same problem as the tofu bao. The order of consuming the Coca-Cola braised pork or the chicken is probably interchangeable, but remember the chicken is spicy.
author: Cece E.

description:
So I finally got the chance to try out the Chairman Truck! And I have to say, it lives up pretty well to all the hype.

The truck was over at the Truck Stop the other day when I went over with a coworker. The line was pretty long, but luckily a friend was near the front so we got all of our orders in together. I had to decide quickly, so I ordered the Baked Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso! I probably should've ordered at least one more...because I destroyed the pork belly bao...

The fatty, tender pork belly along with the tart pickled daikon was pretty awesome. The baked bun itself was a tad underwhelming to me. Reminded me of a mediocre hamburger bun.

I'll be back soon to try the rest of the items on the menu!
author: Vivian L.

description: In the moment, I thought it was delicious but that may be because I was really hungry in the moment. In retrospect, it was not bad. It's a Chinese fusion place that attempts to recreate traditional chinese meals such as pork belly and chicken baos and americanize it into buns, adding more veggies and other very american ingredients. I can see why people really like it because it is savoury and delicious but I feel like it's nothing new to me.
author: Christopher L.

description:
I can not believe that I did not capitalize on such a ridiculously normal idea.

Introducing Chinese man tau (steamed white chinese buns) with different meats to the Western world. First off, I would really like to share that man taus were originally reserved for poor people. It's what you would see in movies when their family is going through hard times and it was the only available item to eat. I've had plenty in my life.

Indeed, these man taus are not exactly the same. They're lighter, fluffier and much prettier. The meat fillings are deliciously cooked, braised and tenderized to fit its shell.

These baos taste good, they are well-made, of Asian-fusion and are enchanting to the senses but in no way should they ever cost so much.
I remember receiving my first one from all of the Chairman hype only to receive a mantau with two sliced pieces of pork belly. You realize I can get this elsewhere (esp. in SF) for a much much lower price, right?

Idk, I just can't believe I didn't capitalize on this idea. I grew up eating those things!
author: Winè C.

description:
Ahhh one of my favorite buns!! Haha 

Ok so I've had the steams buns way back probably 2 years ago and didn't really see how this place is so special. It's like any other Chinese bao to me.
But at OTG presidio yesterday... I got the baked buns.. Oh my gosh I've been missing out and eating the wrong thing! Duh this is what yelp is for! 

So I got the tender pork belly baked and the bf got the coca-cola braised pork ($6.75/each). I think it was a lil pricey considering it's just a bun but omg he flavor is soooo worth it! The pork belly like melted in my mouth! So did the bun.. Before I knew it it was gone! I was reluctant to share but had to let my bf experience the pork belly goodness.
The coke pork was good too but after having the pork belly, everything else was mediocre.
I am so lucky this truck isn't convenient for me cuz I would definitely grow fat and poor. But the next time I see it... I know what I will definitely be lining up!
author: Katie T.

description:
Hey, look what I found at the Chevron Gas Station on Market Street and Castro: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sT8TRzofJym5w0khZkOJhw?select=1LgWJiUn4p8OMFFZ210mUw

The food truck is usually parked near the Civic Center for lunch. But I don't go to that area that often. Nevertheless, I finally found one of the hottest food trucks and businesses in the Bay Area. 

On my debut of the food truck and looking at the small menu posted on the side of truck where we place our order, there are only three choices of meat with a choice of baked or steamed buns. I chose the Braised Pork on a baked bun. For $6.75, I get shredded grilled pork with a scoop of marinated shredded savoy cabbage and a hint of mustard seed in a baked bun that is most commonly used in Chinese bakeries. The meat combine with vegetable and spice and the sweetness of the baked bun make this hefty sandwich very unique. I like the sandwich very much and I'm glad I found the truck.   

The food truck only accepts cash. The truck is primarily parked in front of City Hall during lunchtime. You can also follow the journey of the truck on Twitter and Facebook.
author: Matt G.

description:
I will never view a veggie burger the same! I have had so many variations of a veggie burger but the miso tofu burger is the best- hands down! 

The Chairman was at West Sacramento's Trucktoberfest and after all of the buzz around the truck, I had to check it out. My husband and I both got the tofu burger with a baked bun and did not come up for air at all until every last delicious morsel was consumed. The grilled tofu was crisp and warm and oh so delicious and the savory tofu was contrasted by the sweet (but not too sweet) miso sauce that topped the greens. Looking back, I wish we would have gotten a steamed and a baked bun so I could try the different styles but I really can't complain at all as it was so good I considered going back for another. There was a bit of a line but the wait was totally worth it! 

I only wish that there was a Sac truck but as there is not, I can guarantee that when in SF, I will most definitely be stopping at the Chairman!
author: Nicole I.

description:
The Chairman several years ago was my first foray into the food truck movement.  It's been hard for others to compare.  I set them as the high standard.

Their signature bao satisfies my lust for pork belly.  The buns are light and there's a brightness from acid to cut through the richness of the pork belly.  It's just so well-rounded.

Everything I've ever had on those occasions when I've been in the vicinity of one of their trucks has been outstanding.  I'll continue to be a fan.
author: Ed G.

description:
Pro: Taste very savory and delicious. I'm a fan for steam buns and this is soft and unflakey. 

Cons: $4ish for this small!!?? It's smaller than the half of my hand!

I would rather buy the bigger bun but the price... I rather buy clam chowder that includes butter and bread for less than this...
author: Jackie T.

description:
Steamed Tofu!

I know I know - I LOVE Pork Belly as much as the next Hapa but hands down, the best item the Chairman offers is actually the Tofu!

I always go steamed :)

Trust me! Give it a shot!
author: Michelle K.

description:
Bao down to The Chairman for making such yummy little treats!

It's a nice variation from the traditional steam bun that everyone is used to. They took it and amped it up to different flavors and combinations that makes it reminiscent of those traditional steam buns but different. 

You can get their buns steamed($3.75) or baked($6.75). The difference is the steam buns are the small ones that you normally see and the baked is the dinner roll bun so it's bigger in size. 

-----Food-----

Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso: (steamed) This is super yummy! The pork bell was really flavorful and tender and the pickled daikon gave it a nice acidity that cut through the fattiness of the pork belly. 

Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds: (steamed) The pork was cooked perfectly! And it had a hint of sweetness to it! the slaw that came on top gave it a nice crunch to it 

Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum: (steamed) tofu never tasted so good! They really added a lot of flavor to the tofu and it was fried beautifully! one of my favorites :) 

Can't wait to try other new flavors the next time I visit (:
author: Jennifer H.

description:
4.5 Stars

Still my favorite food truck.  Prices have been slowly creeping up (steamed buns are now at $3.75 from $2.95 a year ago) but it hits the spot.  

Definitely recommend the white steamed buns over the brown baked buns.  Daikon pork belly is still the favorite but the other varieties are often good and creative.  

Chairman Bao is cash only, but will take credit card in a pinch.
author: Randy F.

description:
My second time at this spot and I loved the Spicy Chicken with Sesame Puree!

This was savory, spicy and sweet all at once...the sesame added a nice richness and the pickled vegetables added a tangyness to the dish that balanced everything out.
author: Ken G.

description:
Baked buns, steamed buns, I love them both! This is currently my favorite gourmet mobile food truck in the Bay Area! Why you ask? Let me dive into several reasons why it is MY FAVORITE.

A little background, The lines have always been long at Off The Grid SF and at other food truck gatherings throughout the Bay Area. I have tried to wait in those long lines but would give up after 30 minutes. Finally, at Moveable Feast San Jose a few weeks ago, I was finally able to try Chairman Bao and I was hooked. Everytime the truck makes a stop at Moveable Feast, I try to be one of the first in line to get their pillowy soft steamed buns with pork belly. 

The pork belly is tender and flavorful with slices of pickled yellow daikon. A simple concoction is combined into a highly addictive and hand held bun for on-the-go goodness. These buns are portable which make them a huge winner in my book. I can eat them easily while driving or walking through Downtown San Jose or SF. I can eat at least four but I typically purchase about two so I can be able to try other things at Moveable Feast. In addition, the staff is very friendly. I have had several conversations with the owners and staff and they work very hard to pump out lots of buns without sacrificing the quality of their food.

The other bun fillings are very good as well but the pork belly takes the cake. Some other things to note, line up early because the lines for Chairman Bao can get long so either line up early or be patient. Also, Chairman Bao has just been voted as one of the Bay Area's top 5 food trucks by Zagat! Woohoo!
author: Danster L.

description:
Waited about 10-15 minutes for the Chairman at OTG: Forty May. 

Ordered the coca-cola braised pork steamed bun ($3.75).

Coca-cola pork w/ savoy cabbage & yellow mustard seeds hugged by a fluffy steamed bun. Aww yeah. It was savory & 'licious! Definitely tickled my buns ;D 

I wanted to order from them again, at Sacto MoFo, but the wait would've been too long. So, if you come across them and there's a short line, order up! XD
author: Vicky L.

description:
I've always heard raves about this truck (not to mention one of friends worked on the truck a couple years ago) and I finally got a chance to try it!

I wasn't super hungry so I got 2 of the steamed buns - tender pork belly and coca-cola braised pork. Both had really tender meat and tons of flavor stuffed between a delicious Asian bun - a nice change from normal burger buns or sandwich breads. My only complaint was that I was just satisfied with 2 buns. I think you need AT LEAST three of the steamed ones to have a full meal. 2 was more of just a heavy snack for me.

Overall though, these were really good and I would definitely go back to get more!
author: Sophia Y.

description:
I have tried the Chairman Truck twice now and both times were scrumpdillyumptous! The lines can be long but they are worth the wait and if I happen to run into this truck again, I will wait again.
I have tried the braised pork and the pork belly but the pork belly is by far the stand-out item for them. Both the baked and steamed buns are good but I feel like the steamed bun is a better base for really tasting all the goodness and flavor from the pork belly.
author: Schelly Y.

description:
REALLY torn about how to review Chairman Bao.  While I LOVE their innovative spin on classic Chinese baos, I just can't justify $3.75 for their teeny tiny baos.

First off, when I read the descriptions, I was already drooling. Pork always catches my attention so I ordered a steamed bun with pork belly and pickled daikon and another with pulled pork. I was expecting something resembling a classic bao stuffed with pork yumminess.  When I received it, I was baffled by what it was.  The baos they used are like the ones you get with peking duck, little steamed buns big enough to put in a pinch of meat and maybe a bit of veggies.  I was so disappointed, until I bit into it.  Thus began the conflict. While I was disappointed with the size and shocked by the price, the taste transported me to porcine heaven.

So, I tried Chairman Bao again, just to see if maybe I'd get over this indecisiveness.  We had the pork belly again (since I'd been dreaming of it since I had it) and the sesame chicken with scallions.  After two tries, I'm still on the fence.  

I still have dreams about the pork belly which turn into nightmares of not having enough cash when I finally get to the front of the line that I've been waiting in for an hour. AAGGHHH!!!!
author: Judi M.

description:
My favorite truck in the whole wide world! 

A 7x7 sf big eats 2011 contender, and well deserved so. There's a reason why Chairman Bao's always has a crazy long line, yet I'm still willing to wait in it to get my BAO on! 

I've had the baked and steamed buns, but I prefer the steamed ones. That's not to say you shouldn't try all of them though. The baked buns look like burgers, with the same ingredients in it as the steamed ones. 

Yes, it's those steamed buns like what you get at a Chinese restaurnat with your duck. But the ingredients they put in it, it's just downright clever and delicious. 

MY FAVORITE: braised pork steamed bun. 
2ND FAVORITE: TOFU steamed bun
3RD FAVORITE: Pork belly daikon bun - Yes, this is the one on the 7x7, it's pickled daikon with pork belly. A winning combo, but I still prefer the first 2 yummy ones. 
4TH FAVORITE: Sesame Chicken bao - new on their menu, a bit spicy, but good flavor.

The baked buns are about ~6-7 bucks, and steamed ones around ~3-4 bucks. For one person, sure a baked bun would satisfy you for lunch, but if it was up to me, I'd get a braised pork, and a tofu veggie bun. Those are soooo good. Trust me, i know what you're thinking. You're a meat lover, so am I. But man, that tofu is fried and is meaty already and the dressing they use on the veggies is just finger lickin' good. 

I sound like a Chairman Bao commercial, but really I just wish they will get some trucks runnin'  on a usual basis in south bay. Or HECK, open a flagship store please! I've had them at Edgewood Eats, SJ Eats and Off the Grid Fort Mason. So keep a look out for the line ups at meets, because I highly recommend their amazing baos!
author: Joanna S.

description:
Look at my ratings distributions, it has to be something for me to give 5-stars.  I want to set the story here a bit...

I was in the Bay area of the weekend, only wanted to eat non-chain local-type places.  I was driving, astonished by the beauty of the whole area, and boom- a huge sign saying FOOD TRUCK SUNDAYS.  Now, food trucks automatically have an advantage in my heart.  Something about moving wonderment in the form of food- yes, I love food trucks... anyway... I veered off the road and opted for an adventure.  I surveyed my options and for some reason, the Chairman called out my name... soon I was sitting down to pork belly an some form of chicken sandwiches... and in love.

After just a few bites of each, I proclaimed- I have to Yelp this B*** its a 5-star affair.  And here I am.  If you have a different experience than me, I would be surprised.  As Guy Fiere says, "Welcome to Flavor town!".... this is flavor town on wheels coming to a location near you.

...I want a franchise for Chicago
author: Charlie C.

description: 3-3.5 stars. I used to think the pork belly at The Chairman was delicious, and couldn't get enough of it. However, on my last couple of visits, I haven't been quite as impressed. I was last at The Chairman when they were at the Hiller Aviation Museum on a Wednesday (they come every other Wednesday from 11am - 2pm). We went early (around 11:15am) so there wasn't much of a line for any of the trucks. I was able to order right away, and it took 5-10 minutes to receive my Baked Pork Belly Bun ($6.75, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-chairman-truck-san-francisco?select=oSDTv_8Hk-epqxwAS1MCAw#M9FRKXQS23OslC35z4YQ7w). I thought the bun was on the dry side, and needed more sauce. Also, the pork belly wasn't as tender as I remember. However, I didn't eat my bun right away and had to re-heat it, so will have to try it again when it's fresh.
author: Amy D.

description:
When faced with the choice of a steamed or baked bao, I went with baked, and I received one most unlike any bao I've ever had before (in a mostly good way).

In essence, I received a bun sliced in half (filled modestly with a spicy chicken filet, toastd sesame purée, and a small mountain of pickeld carrots, making a burger. It was quite good, albeit a little messy to eat, and an interesting take on the bao.

Definitely worth trying out at least once!
author: Claire S.

description:
The Chairman Truck is probably one of my favorite food trucks at Off the Grid. My boyfriend and I first stumbled upon the Chairman Truck at Off the Grid: Fort Mason and  we were more than excited to try their pork belly bun since we heard tons of good things about them! The wait for the Chairman Truck was around 10-15 minutes, which wasn't too bad since their employees seemed super friendly and were extremely patient with each customer. I also happened to stumble upon their truck at Off the Grid: Serramonte, and they forgot one of my orders so they not only were very apologetic, but they threw in another chicken bun for free. It wasn't necessary, but was very much appreciated because it showed how awesome their customer service is! A steamed pork belly bun is $3.75 and a baked pork belly bun is around $6, I believe, so we ended up getting 2 steamed pork belly buns.

Steamed Pork Belly Bun with Pickled Daikon - Steamed to perfection, the bun was very similar to a peking duck bao bun, but with pork belly and pickled daikon, which is a type of radish. It smells awful, but it is so freaking delicious and is the perfect complement to that equally perfect pork belly!

Overall, I would highly recommend The Chairman truck. In fact, the steamed pork belly buns alone deserve 5 stars! Great customer service, great food, and great prices. I love the Chairman Truck!
author: Joyce E.

description:
Yes to great service, terribly inconvenient locations, disproportionate bao sizes, completely overpriced, and corrupting the way steamed and roasted bao should be eaten.

After 20 minutes of battling the blistering cold weather of SF, we were rewarded with hot, steaming bao filled with disgustingly tasty ooze. The pork belly and braised pork are the best. It doesn't matter if it's in a steamed or roasted bun. You basically have two options of winning.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
The first time I had Chairman Bao, I wasn't too blown away by their food.  While I found the Steamed Buns tasty, I thought their portions were small and overpriced which was a bit of a turn off for me.  Since I usually give places more than one try, I decided to give them another chance when they stopped by Brisbane again.  And this time I tried their Baked Bun.  It's so much more worth it than the steamed buns.

The Pulled Pork Baked Bun is huge!  Take a look at the pic (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw&select=6YZaRgVAiw8cFE6dS8q85w), it's just as good as it looks!  Loaded with Pork, it was delicious!  Word of note, like a Burrito, after having one of these, it should keep you satisfied for a few hours.

And because you have to order them when you visit Chairman Bao, I also ordered two Steamed Buns, one Pork Belly and one Red Sesame Chicken (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=F_5_UNX-wrAFCXuAkBZRDw&select=G3ZZErMfHpLd2_TuVWyKwQ).  The Red Sesame Chicken had a nice sweet and spicy kick to them which I liked and the Pork Belly was amazing as usual.  I think I was gypped the first time I had their Steamed Buns because the ones I had this time were loaded with meat!  And yes, I had these with my Baked Bun.  I'm such a pig!!

So why the upgrade to only 4 stars and not 5?  It basically comes down to pricing.  While I believe that $6.75 for a Baked Bun is worth it, I'm still on the fence with paying $3.75 each for their Steamed Buns.  Though now it's a little more understandable with the portions I had this time.  They were like mini sandwiches.  But now I'm convinced why people flock over to this truck at Off The Grid.  Their stuff is really good!
author: Rodney H.

description:
Oh my gosh what can I say that hasn't already been said?  I am so very lucky that this truck comes to my work usually one day a week.  Its pretty much impossible for me to not venture out to the parking lot when they are here.  The steamed buns are perfection.  So soft and light...I could eat a million of them.  The combinations have the right about of texture...the pork belly which is soft and greasy has some crisp vegetables to help cut some of the fat.  I am really wanting to try the duck one but its not been available the last couple of times.  I hope they bring it back!!!  I also had the angry chips...or bad chips...or some time of chip that is wontons with some spices and seaweed.  It was crunchy and delicious.  

If you ever see this truck...run...don't walk to the ordering line.  Yum Yum!
author: Kate F.

description:
I LIKE BAKED BUNS AND I CANNOT LIE........

Chairman Bao is Chairman WOW! A really nice spin-off from the traditional savory steamed or baked buns, the Chairman Truck incorporates some of the more unconventional ingredients to create awesome lunch bites. The white steamed bun is pillowy soft and fluffy and the subtly sweet baked bun eats more like a nice toasted  roll. This fare is certainly not for the diet conscious, it is loaded with fatty goodness, their pork belly bun being their flagship product. I had the Coca Cola braised pork bun with savoy cabbage and yellow mustard seeds. The pork was nicely charred and had the texture and crunch of a burnt end, the cabbage and mustard seeds provided an additional crunchy kick. The real Chairman would appreciate the concept, though he'd probably want doggy or kitty in his bun (I'm kidding, I love all animals, they're all very tasty, including Snoopy and Garfield).

Come here early to avoid the long lines. I came here at 11:30 am and was helped right away. After getting your bun, take a look at it to see if it will be filling enough for you. I didn't look right away so I only ordered one bun, then got hungry again two hours later. It is a little pricey, but one of those things you have to try at least once and then cross off your culinary bucket list.
author: Mike L.

description:
a hand-sized baozi for $$$?
Good thing it's freaking delicious to have soft, generous pieces of pork belly sandwiched between pillowy soft buns with sweet pickled daikon.

Every time its at Off the Grid, I'll go to this truck.

Now this truck doesn't have fries but they do have chips.
Chips were oily, semi-flavorless, but addictive (as anything fried and crispy is).
So I'd pass on those.
author: Jun K.

description:
TOTAL PORK BELLY REDEMPTION...

Just one bite of the "New" Pork Belly Bun moved Chairman Bao from the bottom to the TOP of my list of food truck favorites!

After my most disappointing food truck experience last August with Chairman Bao, I swore I would NEVER return. However, when I was in Vegas two months ago for a Bachelorette Party, my gf told me our mutual friend took over Chairman Bao. Although hesitant, I was longing to do a re-do and last Friday's (4.8.11) OTG - Civic Center gave me the perfect opportunity to do so as the lines are much shorter. My colleagues and I got in line at around 11:35 AM (opens at 11:30 AM) with 7-8 people in front and we had our buns in tote in about 8 minutes. 

I got the Steamed Pork Belly Bun w/ Pickled Daikon ($3.75) and was BLOWN AWAYYYYYYY! I couldn't get the picture I wanted because I was getting funny stares as I often do, so this pic does NOT do the Pork Belly Bun justice. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sT8TRzofJym5w0khZkOJhw?select=5U-Jh9WoArY5NqCg84KsZg

Nestled between a soft and fluffy steamed white bun was a thick slice of seared pork belly. The pork belly was crisp and as I bit into it, all the savory juices burst into my mouth. It was JUICY, SUCCULENT and lightly drizzled with hoisin sauce for that hint of salty sweetness. The pickled daikon's acidity complemented the pork belly by helping to balance the richness of it. 

After devouring the Pork Belly Bun I wanted more and didn't even feel like eating my Katsu Curry from JapaCurry anymore. Hands down, it was the BEST pork belly and BEST rendition of a Chinese steamed bun I've ever had!!! 

As soon as I got back to the office, I text my friend to let her know about my re-do of Chairman Bao and she told me our mutual friend had been braising the pork belly till 5 AM that morning--talk about dedication! The Pork Belly Bun I had was NOTHING like my experience with Chairman Bao last year so itching for more info, I sent the new owner a message. He told me that he revamped the recipes along with a new steamed bun and made sure that extra care is taken when preparing these buns which truly shows in the execution and taste of the mouth-watering bun. 

As someone who is a harsh critic of Asian Fusion Fare (because flavors are often watered down), Chairman Bao's Pork Belly Bun totally WON me over! For those of you that had a disappointing experience with Chairman Bao before, I urge you to try it ONE more time. I *pinky swear* that you will NOT be disappointed with the Pork Belly Bun although your doctor may be when he/she sees your cholesterol levels just like how mine will be...
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
YUM!  The Chairman Truck paid a visit to my office and I'm so glad I got to try their grub!! 

SO GOOD.  Was a big fan of the pork bun - had a sweet and savory flavor to it.
author: Alyx F.

description:
Had my first experience at the Eat Real Fest 2011 in Oakland, and just simply pure genius. Every bite is full of mouth watering, flavorful meats and veggies and special sauce for garnish. The steamed Peking buns are a simple complement to the tangy flavor of the meats and veggies. At 4 dollars a pop, I thought it was ridiculous, but totally worth it. I had the pork shoulder and was actually kinda full from it already. Can't wait to hit up the truck again and try everything else yelpers recommend!  

Cash only!
author: Winnie G.

description:
AHHHH! so tasty!

Although I couldn't taste their famous and well-known pork belly bun (i'm vegetarian). I vouched for their steamed tofu option and was pleasantly surprised! the bokchoy on top was crunchy and fresh and it came out on hot steaming tofu with I think a tahini sauce. So divine. I could eat it again and again. 

My boyfriend was impressed with their pork belly too. Next time we will try it baked instead of steamed!
author: Sam L.

description:
This truck catered at my office the other day so I finally got to try them.  Goooooooooooood stuff.  We had a limited menu since it was a special catering job but I was able to try the pork belly, coca-cola braised pork and chicken... each on a steamed bun with their individual garnishes.   

The pork belly was the winner, hands down.  But then... when is it not?   

The other two were also fantastic and I certainly wouldn't turn them down were they offered to me.   Everything was fresh, flavorful, hot and delicious.     

The lychee lemonade was also very nice.  Not too sweet... with big pieces of lychee and a little mint.   I normally just stick with water but this was a refreshing change of pace.  

All great stuff!!  Try it!!
author: Shanna K.

description:
I will mirror what was said by a few of the other reviewers - the quality and flavor are great, but I lean towards the baked bun due to the fact I can get by with one sandwich instead of two to fill me up.

Friendly staff who handled a large amount of orders expertly and fantastic flavors make this a go-to truck.  Keep it up!
author: Andreas H.

description:
The Chairman Truck, one of San Francisco's best food trucks! I am constanly checking their schedule to see where they will be.  I have tried both their baked and steamed buns though both are good I must say anything steamed is amazing! The dough is a perfect balance of sweetness and soft dough.   I tried the Coca-Cola braised pork, the tender pork belly and the spicy chicken. 
I have to say the spicy chicken with toasted sesame purée, crunchy pickled carrots, cucumber & cilantro is my favorite,  the chicken was tender and the flavors are something I keep dreaming about!  
The Coca-Cola braised pork with savoy cabbage & preserved yellow mustard seeds had such an interesting, unique taste one just has to try it. Super tender pork with a tangy twist. My next favorite was the tender pork belly with turmeric pickled daikon & green shiso it had juicy bits of pork belly, and the daikon sliced so thin, it made a perfect slaw each bite was heaven!
I introduced The Chairman Truck to my co-workers and they told me why I did not share this great find earlier.  Now we all look forward to when The Chairman is at Truck Stop SF.  Street food at it's best. An inexpensive yet enjoyable food experience.
author: Maria M.

description:
If you love the pork buns at NYC's Ippudo, you will love the The Chairman Truck. 

Order the Crispy Miso Cured Tofu w/ Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum bun and you will not  be disappointed.
author: Viennelyn C.

description:
Man, the food is sooo tasty and delicious.  Every bite is jam-packed with great unique flavor.  I got three steamed buns to maximize my variety (Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon, Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds, and Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro)!  You get all of them in one box, so I honestly could not remember which was which, but they were all very enjoyable in their own way, and the flavors are very multifaceted, and you could taste every ingredient they mention on their menu.  Just as a note, the spicy chicken is preeetty spicy!

The steamed buns are a little small to be honest (one bun flattened out was probably smaller than my palm), but they stuff those buns, and the quality more than compensates.

Also, there must be a lot of oil on those things, but, I did not mind.  Since they were pretty heavy, three easily filled me up 'til dinner.

The cashier was very nice, and their service is QUICK!
author: Lily N.

description:
The Chairman makes me happy!!! Just picked up my usual pork belly, braised pork and chicken steam buns and I am dancing in my chair. Every other Friday the Chairman is at Civic Center. I don't care what other food trucks are there, I am eating at the Chairman.
This is not just good food truck food, this is damn good food in any restaurant standard. The pickled veggies compliment the meat perfectly.
Sorry, I have not tried the tofu, I am sure it's good, but I will leave it to you to try. 
Last time I had a baked bun. It did not look very exciting, but it tasted incredible. 
One baked bun is enough for me as a light lunch.
But I usually get 3 steamed ones (and struggle to finish..).
author: Melinda T.

description:
Pork belly with pickled daikon on a steamed bun is what i get every time. Even if you're not a big fan you should try this :)

Food Quality - Excellent
Food Taste - Excellent
Food Originality - Excellent
Price - Excellent
Customer Service - Excellent
Ambiance - It's a food truck!
author: Vibhor C.

description:
Probably my favorite food truck in the area!
Long line, but it's worth the wait!

The Baked Pork Belly Sandwich was so tender and perfectly complimented by the sauce and pickled daikon radish slices. The Steamed bun is good too (very soft and slightly sweet), but it's much smaller so don't expect it to fill you up.

A little pricey, but definitely worth a try!
author: Hye-Min O.

description:
Well, Well, Well. Chairman we meet again. Went to off the grid and saw them there. Decided that  I would give them a second chance due to the owner contacting me. 

Boy did it NOT disappoint. the second time around the bun were hot, the pork belly hot, tender, juicy and bursting with flavor from the seasoning and the slightly caramelized meat. This time with the meat done well, the daikon definitely was a good contrast to the pork belly. One cold, the other hot. One savory, the other refreshing. 

I knew SF is better than NY. Definitely would recommend!
author: Reginald W.

description:
Pork belly is not my favorite cut of meat, actually I don't like eating fat off my meat. The pork belly bun at The Chairman is my first exception. Per a Yelper's recommendation, I ordered the Baked Pork Belly bun. Absolutely fantastic! The buns help mask the taste of the fat, and instead you get the creamy-fat texture from it. Pickled radishes are also something I don't usually go for with my chopsticks, but they cut through the bun and meat to round out the sandwich nicely.

We got an order of the bao chips and my tip is: to pass the Bao chips. They were too salty for me.
author: Angie D.

description:
Thoroughly impressed with this food truck! I got to go during Off The Grid and they were the only trucked with a roped off line, and deservingly so. I felt so bad for JapaCurry next door, who had no line at all! Anyways, it's definitely pricey for street food, but the ingredients are solid. They didn't have the Duck Confit that day so I was a bit sad, soI opted for the Tender Pork Belly with Daikon in a steamed bun and my bf had the Rosemary Chicken in a baked bun (which was huge, kind of like a burger). Glad we tried out both types of buns; I think the baked bun is better for meats with lots of sauce (baked bun soaks it up) and the steamed bun is better for when the taste of the meat is the star. 

I wouldn't stray too far from the truck after you order; they may expedite your order if other people's orders contain items that are still cooking, your order was small, etc. The price does make me question if this place is worth it, so far now, I'll think of it as a treat. Definitely beats the Kogi Truck of LA-- When I was attending UCLA, there was a lot of hype around Kogi so you'd see all these people chase after it around the campus-- which was not worth it at all. I'd run around for Chairman Bao though.
author: Ghia G.

description:
I LOVE their tofu steamed bun. I grew up eating tofu, prepared well, so I do like it. But, for you tofu skeptics out there, try this bun, you won't even know you're eating tofu! 

Their other pork belly and chicken buns are good, too, but I don't get those as often because they're almost sickeningly sweet. I mean, the pork belly IS cooked with soda which is sugar water. 

That's the only thing I don't like about their meat buns. It would be perfect if it wasn't so darn sugary! The pickled daikon is also delicious, but ALSO really sweet. 

So, for the delicate palettes out there, be cautious. 

Buns are all well-priced, and served quickly.
author: Jay T.

description:
After all the hype and missed opportunities, I finally snagged a Chairman Bao steamed Tender Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon during Off the Grid. Yes, it is tiny and you have to wait at anywhere from 5-15 minutes but this bad boy is worth the wait if you like fatty meat.

The bun is just like the steam bun you get if you order peking duck but the pork belly just melts in your mouth. And the picked daikon pairs perfectly with it. I am just dreaming of the day I can go back and get more. 

Actually since I waited 10 minutes, I decided to get one of eat for a total of $14. The other steamed buns were okay, nothing spectacular and a little dry. Also, they were in such a rush they forgot to put the savory cabbage and preserved mustard seeds on my pulled pork steamed bun. Next time I will pass on the red sesame chicken with scallion and bok choy as well as the crispy garlic tofu with miso greens. I will probably try their baked bun next time. I want to know if taste outweighs the cost. 

What I recommend:
Tender Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon (if you are fatty meat fan)
author: Andrew W.

description:
Delicious!

They came to the San Mateo Fashion Island Moveable Feast for lunch today, and it was a hit. The long line was worth the wait; these are some tasty sandwiches. My only qualm is that the streamed bun sandwiches are significantly smaller (and maybe a bit overpriced), but still very good. An average adult would probably want 2 to qualify it as a meal.

UPDATE: Today (5/13) they came to Capcom in San Mateo. A coworker and I drove over and arrived to the truck 10 minutes after their start time and they had signs all over the truck notifying everyone that they have *no steamed buns*... So I tried a baked bun. It's basically a hamburger bun and not nearly as good. In fact, the whole sandwich tastes about 10% as awesome outside a delicious steamed bun. I don't know why they'd go to any advertised events with only one bun option.
author: Melissa T.

description:
The Chairman rocks!

We stalk this truck on the regular for their tasty treats. Thank my lucky stars for the interwebz which makes tracking these guys easier. 

I'm going to admit, before the Chairman, pork belly was not in my vocabulary. One brave Sunday morning I got the steamed pork belly bun, and now I'm hooked. I also enjoy me some tofu, and their steamed bun is really great. The BF noms on the braised coca-cola steamed buns. The only problem we have with this place is that there is not enough room in our tummies for more ;). Not a bad problem to have.
author: Alyssa J.

description:
Every time I see this truck, I have to buy one for me and one for a friend. If I'm too full, I'm taking it home with me. Steamed vs Baked. I've tried the items steamed but enjoy the ingredients a lot more on the bun. It just seems to bring the flavors together cohesively a lot better.

My absolute favorite is the baked pork belly. My mouth waters just at the thought of it! The hot pork belly with the pickled veggies is just an explosion of flavor in the mouth. The pickled daikon and shiso brightens the whole bun so it doesn't taste so heavy and gives great contrast.

The Coca-Cola braised Pork w/cabbage & picked mustard seeds is good but not close to the pork belly in my opinion

The seasoned wonton chips are topped with dried seaweed and just taste like salt. Wouldn't recommend buying them.
author: Kitty K.

description:
Get 2 steamed Pork Belly baos. Not the baked bun. Not the Coca-Cola Braised Pork. Not the Spicy Chicken. 

You're welcome.
author: Sophia V.

description:
Easily the most popular food truck at Edgewood Eats and very deserving.

Although the line may seem daunting, it moves pretty quickly... I've never waited more than 15 minutes to order with a 5 minute speedy delivery of food.  Not great, but not terrible.

I ordered a dozen to go (to bring back to work to share with a few lucky coworkers working during dinnertime along with me) on my first EE visit and they remembered me the second time... BY NAME!  Amazing!  Love it!  Makes for a memorable customer experience.

Consistently delicious and worth stalking to try!
author: Ruth C.

description:
Yummy!

Had the baked pork belly sandwich. As expected, it was a raging torrent, flooded with deliciousness of taste cascading into a waterfall of flavor.

Ditto.

The pickled daikon pairs so awesomely with the pork belly. A few squirts of sriracha added the perfect kick to dump this down my neck in about 5 mins flat. Service was quick and friendly.
author: Matt R.

description:
I have wanted to try Chairman Bao's buns for soooooo long. I love Chinese food, and I LOVE these buns. It brings me a nostalgic feeling of when I would go back to Asia and order these at half past midnight off those crowded busy night markets.

Although there aren't pickled vegetables with fatty pork sprinkled with peanuts, Chairman Bao does a tasty Americanized version of these buns. Instead there's slow cooked pork topped with different pickled vegetables. 

I also thought it was very strange that the people in this truck actually resembled pandas. It's understandable for the lady who took my order because she had lots of black eyeliner and an orange panda-faced hat, but the guy who passed out the food looked very kung-fu panda-like.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
This truck was at the tradeshow that I was showing at on Treasure Island. My friend told me I should try it out and go for the Pork belly steamed buns. They had a small tight menu of four different ones, and you could either get them on steamed or baked buns. I ordered two pork belly buns and it was topped with pickles and a sauce inside. The pork belly was crispy and went perfect with the steamed bun. I enjoyed this dish. I would definitely eat it again. So good! 

Recomendation; Pork Belly steamed buns
author: Andy N.

description:
I've been hearing about this truck for years, but I live in San Carlos and don't make it to the city for lunch all that frequently.

This past weekend I was at the San Mateo Farmers Market and was thrilled to finally see it in person. I didn't let the opportunity pass me by, and thank god I didn't.

The Chairman has four different kinds of buns, each served in either a small steamed bun or a large baked bun. I was interested in variety, so I went with three of the small buns.

Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum: Lightly fried tofu made for a slightly crispy exterior and soft interior. The garlic mayo added flavor while the choy sum added crunch. Delicious, and a great start.

Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso: Holy crap this is unbelievably good. The pork is insanely tender and juicy and flavorful. The pickled daikon gives a cool acidic crunchiness to balance the fattiness of the pork. 

Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro: I had been planning to eat this second, but mistakenly grabbed the pork first, and I have to say that while a good bun, the chicken really paled after eating the pork belly.

I really loved this truck. Now I just need to figure out how I can get more chances to eat here.
author: Jason G.

description:
I was debating on whether or not to eat out for dinner....and then I saw the Chairman truck and the decision was made. It was that easy.

I wanted to get something small because I knew I was pretty full from coffee and I didn't want to have that insanely heavy feeling in my tummy. I wanted to try a new flavor as well. For those reasons, I chose to get a steamed chicken/toasted sesame puree/pickled carrots-cucumber and cilantro bun. 

The steamed buns aren't as great of a deal as the baked buns (not at all) but it's good for if you don't want to eat too much at once. 

Anyway, the chicken was good. I was worried that the toasted sesame puree would overpower the flavors and make me dislike it, but it complimented everything well. If anything, there was an overwhelming amount of heat, but that's probably because I went overboard with the sriracha. 

Great truck! Never disappoints.
author: Sofia R.

description:
"Gua bao - its like a Chinese taco!"

This update - is to quickly comment - on the catering prowess of TCT. At an organization function TCT was one of 2 trucks and they did a great job. Even though it took them some time to get opened once open they delivered. If you get a chance i highly recommend the coca cola braised pork and pork belly gua baos - truly memorable hand food - especially if you're a fan of pork items. Also - the bao chips - aint too shabby.
author: Oleg H.

description:
Got to taste The Chairman at Friday night OTG at Fort Mason and I was pleased.  It was high quality buns with well thought out traditional filling.  The Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso was my favorite.  Betty and I also tried the Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds, which was good.  

The line is very long, took at least 30 minutes to get our order, but I had to give it a go.  I make my own Taiwanese steamed bao at home and enjoy playing around with different non-traditional fillings as well so I do appreciate the product.  When back in SF I would definitely seek out The Chairman.
author: Bob B.

description:
I will stand in line for 30 minutes to get food from the Chairman. That's pretty dedicated, right? Oh, and that's my whole lunch break.

They have the best steamed bun asian burgers (as they call it) which are the perfect size. I can usually eat 2 of these and get full, but it's been 4 because they're soooo good. They have four different kinds to choose from:

Pork Belly with Daikon**** (my most favorite)
Coca Cola Braised Pork
Spicy Chicken
Miso Tofu

The buns are consistently soft, they season the meat/ingredients perfectly and I am never disappointed!
author: Sammie T.

description:
Word on the streets is, "if your a foodie and have not tried the Chairman Truck, your a wannabe". Is that true? Or should I say If you don't know what traditional Gua Bao is, then your just someone who wants to be a foodie. With that being said, there's a few factors to throw in before giving an honest rating of this truck. 

Background: 
-I'm motha-fa'king Taiwanese! 
-I go back to Taiwan once to twice a yr. I know what is traditional and what isn't. Street food is in my blood, my culture. 
-Let's not even think about American food prices and American hormoned filled pork! 

Okay, now here's the story. Put all that junk aside and eat like an American, this place is a hit. Even if your Taiwanese and you put yourself in another shoe. You think you can get better Gua Bao (or should I say Chairman Bao) from a Taiwanese restaurant in the Bay Area? I doubt it (unless you like prebraised frozen of a week fatty pork).

Chairman was a hit place for me. Yes, I spent 6.5 for a damn bun (made not by Chairman but from a Chinatown bun factory). Normally something like this in Taiwan nightmarket should be around $1.5 if not less and maxed at $2USD. Put aside the price, and the plane ticket, and all that jibberish that a foodie can talk about, this place is darn good. 

The pork fatness wasn't overwhelming. In fact, it was just right. They added their own twist to the filling which doesn't exist in our traditional Gua Bao. I normally like to see peanut powder, cilantro, mustard greens and the nice steam bun. But here at Chairman, you have a choice between the traditional steam bun and the more American style baked bun. They didn't fill the thing with unnecessary junk that would ruin the taste. In fact, every bite was mouth watering (not from juices, but the natural aroma of the fatty pork). It tasted like the braised pork belly was done early in the morning and ready by noon time. It tasted like grandma's cooking, except mixed with their grandchildren's american twist. 

Even though it sounds all good, it's still not a 5 star thing. I still prefer grabbing my $1.5 bun in Taiwan when I'm back. It's not the same yah-know?
author: Eric Y.

description:
Well worth the wait.

I tried the pork belly and spicy chicken steamed buns and they were A+. The pork belly was juicy and fatty, and the pickled daikon added a good sweet flavor. I just had one bite of the spicy chicken but I really liked it. It wasn't too spicy, but had a good enough flavor. Overall, I think I liked the spicy chicken more, but the pork belly was a close second, especially with some sriracha.

I thought the size of the buns were pretty small for the price, honestly. I'll keep coming back to try more of their buns, though.
author: Adri A.

description:
I absolutely love chairman bao!!! 

Tip: get the baked option over the steamed one. It's more worth it and alot bigger! 

Everytime I've had chairman bao I haven't been disappointed. I recently tried their red sesame chicken baked bao and it was so delicious. The chicken was seasoned nicely with the slaw and bao together it was so good.
My usual is the pork belly bao which has succulent, fatty pork that is cooked to perfection and slightly crispy. It's so good it almost Made me think that it was crispy duck. Yum. 

Will def be back for more. Generally I havent had to wait too long for the bao. Usually about 10 mins but then again I go to the otg at the civic center. Love it! :)
author: Stella J.

description: I dream of the Chairman Truck on a weekly basis. Their magical buns will leave you frantically finding time to catch their truck during the week. Please open up a restaurant for all those Chairman addicts out there!
author: Kayla A.

description:
Usually, when faced with a row of 4+ food trucks at Off The Grid, I pace up and down the line, deliberating over the options of the day. Factors weighed include: line size, whether I've already tried a particular truck, what my tastebuds feel like that day, how heavy the food is, etc. Important stuff. 

After countless such food truck lunch runs, Chairman Bao remains the only truck amongst trucks that I make a beeline for without thinking. 

They serve Taiwanese steamed and baked buns filled w/ different kinds of meat covered w/ flavorful sauces+veggies. 

Favorites: Spicy Chicken, Tender Pork Belly. Not as big on the Coca-cola Braised Pork or Crispy Miso Cured Tofu. Never tried the Muscovy Duck. 

The baked buns are bigger and pretty good too, but I prefer the steamed. Get at least 3 if you go steamed.
author: An Y.

description:
Just by looking at the long line every time, there is no doubt that Chairman Bao is serving up some good stuff. I finally decided to suck it up and wait patiently in line.

Spiced duck confit with mango salad: The duck was lean and tasty. This bun packs a powerful punch of spiciness, but is balanced by the sweetness of the mango. Delicious!

Braised pork shoulder with cabbage slaw: The pork was juicy and tender. This bun was flavorful and the cabbage salad added tanginess and crunchiness to the whole thing. Delicious!

While I thoroughly enjoyed my steamed buns, I'm doubtful of my return. My 2 buns cost $7 since the prices have gone up. Before each steamed bun cost $2.95. Now the buns are separated into 2 categories: People's buns ($3.25) and Chairman's buns ($3.75). 

Taste & quality: 4 stars
Size & price: -1 star
author: Marti L.

description:
I went to Arizona last November and had these pork belly buns. They were amazingly good! Hearing that Chairman Bao had these too I have been dying to try them out. 

I ordered the The Pork Belly with the pickled radish. It was 3.75 for steamed. Man was it tiny! It was 6 something for baked. God I hope it was bigger than the steam one. 

It wasn't bad but it wasn't amazing either. The reason for the two stars is that after 90 minutes of eating it I had a stomachache. I can't be sure it was the bao but I didn't eat anything after wards. 

I am happy I tried it but I don't know if I am willing to pay $3.75 for another one.
author: Sarah C.

description: The steamed buns were good - I just think it's funny to say "steamed buns" :).  Anyway, the pork belly and braised pork were very good.  This time the truck was at Sacto MoFo in West Sac.
author: Jason G.

description:
There has been many changes since my last visit 6 months ago.  The drinks menu has been eliminated completely.  The menu has shrunken a bit.  My favorite, egg and Chinese sausage with oyster sauce, is no longer on the menu.  =(  I've noticed that the bao/buns are significantly large in diameter now.  There's also the option of adding Bao chips, which are fried wonton strips.  Dismayed by the lacking in choices, I settled for the red sesame chicken baked bun.  It smelled really good.  The sesame oil fragrance is hard to resist.  The sandwiches are now a substantial meal with the heaping filling of meat, pickled veggies, and green onions.  It was super-spicy.  Well, I am a weakling with a low tolerance level for spice.  I had to down 3 glasses of water to finish the sandwich!  My coworker's duck confit sandwich was also too spicy for him to handle.

Ooohhh...I almost forgot the game-changer.  My bao was a blackened burnt mess.  I peeled away as much as the carcinogen-laced bun as I could without having my sandwich fall into pieces.  I guess I could've sent it back, but I'm the type to not complain to the people who's preparing my food.
author: Melinda Y.

description: You can't get quality gluten free food from the truck. They don't do rice bowls as they do at their restaurant. I ordered pork and they put it on a cabbage salad for me. It was tasty but more like a side than a meal. I still had to pay $10 for it and it should have cost no more than ~$3! I was really disappointed to find out what they served me when I opened the box up and how it did not correlate to the charge!!!
author: Lauren B.

description:
The fact that I don't eat meat means I have one option at The Chairman- Tofu. This is not a problem, or I wouldn't be a vegetarian. It just means I can't review this truck with reference to the other items on the menu. 

As a first-timer I felt I needed to try both the baked and steamed versions of the Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum. This is definitely a filling option and next time I'll probably go for two of the smaller steamed buns. The baked bun looked just like a hamburger bun with a fluffier texture and sweeter taste. I picked off abut a quarter of the bun as I ate. The steamed bun was like a blown up taco shell, and also fluffy and sweet.The tofu was perfectly seared on the outside with a great texture. The baby choy sum was a good compliment. The sauce was tasty but I could have done with a little less. As usual, I wish I had added more sriracha than I did before walking back to my office to cut some of the sweetness of the buns. Overall, a very enjoyable trip to Off the Grid on Vallejo & Front.
author: Blair C.

description: I personally prefer the steamed buns... I grew up loving them and asking my mom to make them plain! Chairman came up with the perfect recipe for chicken with cucumbers and carrots. I would love to try the pork belly one... I know it'll be good :) I'm definitely a fan!
author: Holly H.

description: Alas, fellow Yelpers- I have figured out the perfect concoction! Order one Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso (steamed bun), and one Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro (steamed bun). These two are by far the best entrees and are packed with a punch!
author: Nicole W.

description:
Bao tacos that I can get from a truck and pay for with a credit card. America is great indeed!

The spicy chicken was good, the braised pork was delicious, but it was the pork belly made my heart sing. My heart sings very similar to Celine Dion, so if you're a Celine Dion fan, I recommend the pork belly.
author: Loli L.

description: I heart the Chairman Truck.  So much so...that when I got married at the San Francisco City Hall on a Friday, I pre-ordered a whole bunch of steamed buns and had a friend walk over to the Civic Center Plaza (food trucks are parked there every Friday - thanks Samie and Berniedette!) to go pick them up after my ceremony so my guests would have something to snack on while we did our champagne toast.  My guests loved them too.
author: Sandy H.

description:
This is no char siu bao, but something much more amazing. My favorite is the spicy chicken. Why so? Because I abhor pork belly and am allergic to tofu. But that's not all... The spicy chicken bao is amazing because of their sauces and fillings are so exotic. It's meaty, yet crunchy due to the pickled carrots. And it's flavorful, yet spicy. 

My only gripe is its price because I'm so used to ordering char siu baos and peking duck buns for much less... And peking duck buns are tastier.
author: Mabel Y.

description:
Off the Grid- Fort Mason Center

When I arrived at Off the Grid, I made my way to this truck first. I've wanted to try Chairman Bao when it came to Sacramento but I missed my opportunity due to long lines at Sacto MoFo.

Tender Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon (Steamed Bun):
The fatty pieces of tender pork belly melt in your mouth while the pickled daikon added a tangy crunch. The steamed buns were soft and fluffy. It definitely lived up to my expectations!

[As Seen On Eat Street]
author: Helen H.

description:
If you've ever been to Tiananmen Square in Beijing you'd know that there is always a massive queue to see Chairman Mao in his final resting place inside his mausoleum.  A somewhat morbid intro to a food review, but similarly, in order for you to partake in the deliciousness of Chairman Bao's buns you'll have to be willing to queue up as well.  There is a reason Chairman Bao has the longest line at Off the Grid, because the food is off the hook!

I've pretty much had everything Chairman Bao has to offer with respect to its steamed buns-- pulled pork topped with savoy cabbage and mustard seeds, pork belly with pickled daikon, duck confit with mango, red sesame chicken with bok choy and scallion, and crispy garlic tofu with miso greens.  All of the baos are exceptionally delicious and none have disappointed.  My ultimate favorites though are the tender pork belly, savory pulled pork, and succulent duck confit inside the moist steamed buns.

I've also read from Chairman Bao's Twitter that the buns used for the baos come from Wa Li Bakery & Cafe in Chinatown, SF.
