The shaved ice drinks they offer aren't too bad.  I've had the pineapple salted caramel and the mango green tea matcha on separate occasions.  The mango one is better in my opinion.

Interestingly the logo, being a profile view of a panda wearing Chairman Mao's garb, bears a strong resemblance to the logo on the Chairman Mao watches that were shoved in my face by a myriad of hawkers during my time in Beijing.

Clever name, cool looking truck, phenomenal grub!
author: Erich D.

description:
I cannot believe that I haven't reviewed this yet. This review is a bit late, but better late than never. 

With that said, I am not sure what else that I can add to the plethora of reviews for this food truck.  Just go.  Eat some bao.  Be happy you made the effort. 

I've only had the pork belly and the chicken, but both were amazing.   The buns are actually much bigger than I expected.  Yummy and filling and  definitely worth their price.  

I was lucky to show up to the Moveable Feast event early enough to avoid the famous long lines for this truck, but would gladly wait in them in a heartbeat. 

It is late, I'm not hungry......and I am now craving bao just from writing this.  That good.
author: Katharine A.

description:
eBay was sponsoring FREE food from Chairman Bao & Kung Fu Tacos - that was SWEET on Black Friday 11/26/10.

We happened to be in town & saw it advertised so we went.  Got there about 11:20am and there was a short line.

The eBay people were out there with video cameras & showed or just talked to people about eBay app for their smartphone.

We could pick a FREE drink (strawberry/coconut) or ginger/lychee) & FREE chips.  I thought that was it, but then there was someone that passed out a container.  Inside the container was 2 steamed buns: spicy chicken w/ bok choy & a cabbage/meat bun.  Liked them all.

Thank you eBay & Chairman Bao!
author: Ann L.

description:
Turns out I couldn't even wait 24 hours before coming here again.  

Although no pork belly was available, I got to try all that they offered the next day:

1. Red sesame chicken with scallion and bak choy: This is very Korean inspired because the scallion and bak choy is really one of many versions of kimchi.  I was a little confused as to whether this or #3 was the pork because they're both shredded/pulled-ish.  At first sight I could tell kochujang (red pepper paste) was the main ingredient so it might be re-creatable at home.  As for the "red esame" in the name, I don't know where that was.

2. Crispy garlic tofu with miso greens: Almost everyone preceding us in line skipped out on this one because only freaky vegans would pick it.  But I went with my hunch and didn't regret it at all.  The flavors are really light and the tofu is a different texture but somehow, it works.  It's on the firmer side and you can definitely taste the garlic.  The greens were marinated in a way that made them really refreshing and held true to their original flavors.

3. Pulled pork with pickled daikon:  A little disappointing maybe because I have daikon fairly often.  I didn't feel that the pork had incredible flavor compared to the others so what a bummer.

With all these the mantou is still consistent in every order and bite.  Number one in my book is still the pork belly.
author: Shannon L.

description:
Really really good. 

The only reason why i didnt give it a 5 stars are for the following reason. The lines are super long! but then again im so impatient sometimes and i cant blame the truck for that, but when i go to off the grid it makes me not want it as much because the line is super long. During peak hours the line would be close to 45- 60 mins long. Not to mention that your standing and waiting in the cold and have no where to sit after. It is more understanding when your in restaurant cause your in a restaurant. 

The pork belly is their best dish. Its about $4 each. Its the same portion size you would get at any Chinese restaurant, so i would need to eat about 4 of them to get full. So now im at a total of $16 with no drinks. Tip and drinks about $20. Kinda high for a food truck, but i wouldn't buy a steak for $50 from a food truck even if it was the same steak from "Mortons"

With that said...

I would recommend this place to ANYONE who loves good food. Would i go here all the time? If they had a restaurant front and i didnt have to wait an hour every time.
author: Ryan R.

description:
My parents. The most finicky, hard-to-please human beings on the face of this earth. Never have I dared to introduce any man friend of mine to them, for my ego and his would surely be beaten to a infinitesimal pulp with their criticism. 
After meeting Chairman Bao post-work @ OTG Fort Mason, I started seeing him regularly but tried keeping our relationship on the DL.  A few months passed before he made the venture into my hometown @ MVBLFST San Mateo. I knew it had to happen eventually.
I got my baked pork belly and pep talked the box all the way home. How could anyone not love your meat, so crispy on the outside, yet tender and juicy on the inside? Who could resist dat crunchy daikon, or those big, fluffy buns? 
NOT EVEN my parents.

I think Chairman Bao and I will last for a very long time.
author: Jenny Q.

description:
We made this the first stop at Off The Grid and had the Pork Belly, Coca Cola pork, and the Spicy Chicken, all on steamed buns.  Seriously. Freakin. Delish.

My advice?  Wherever this truck turns up, do yourself a favor and grab a bite - you won't regret it.
author: Kevin K.

description:
The food truck experience. So many hits and misses right? Well the baked spicy chicken bun hit it on the big red dot for me at the San Jose Night Market: http://nightmrkt.com/ . 

I'm usually a healthy eater so it was a bit of a challenge staying away from red meat and pork, so I was about to let down my guard for the pork belly bun which everyone was raving about. At the last minute I realized there was a chicken option 3rd rows down on the menu. 

First I started off with a fork trying to peck and the 'fusionite' dish that looked so familiar yet foreign to me. Chicken was tender, the rich sesame dressing was not overly salty with just the right creaminess, the bun was soft and somewhat tasty. Eh... not bad. Then I realized, what a dumbass. It's in a bun, so put down the fork and go grab it with your hands! That's what I did. Put it all together and you get a really delicious Asian infused spicy chicken sandwich with sliced pickled carrots that really enhance the experience. 

$6 and it was worth every penny. Next time I'll grab this as well as the pork belly bun. The line was too long for me to go back that night, but I'll be back ANOTHER night! BTW I didn't see the bok choy version so they must have changed the ingredients, which is A-OK by me.
author: David K.

description:
For some reason I held back before trying Chairman Bao; don't ask me to explain why  because it was a serious mistake. I got the Coca Cola Braised Pork on a baked bun. It was so delicious. I felt as if each one of my tastebuds were made love to by the unique flavors, serious savory-ness, and the great price of a satisfying lunch under $7. Needless to say, "Yes, yes, Give me more!" 

Ahem......I will be back for more. Soon. Now?
author: Chelsea B.

description: I stopped by this truck about a month ago at Oakland's Off The Grid and I ordered a couple of different steamed Baos. They were really very tasty and I'd highly recommend them! Two of them was about the size of a decent snack. If you are really hungry, I recommend ordering three or four of them.
author: Robert F.

description:
Brief statement: I've been eating at a decent amount of food trucks lately, and it seems that we are in the wave of trucks coming into the game to make the money, rather than the original wave of trucks that came into it because they couldn't afford to run a brick and mortar. I haven't been impressed with hardly any of the recent trucks and Chairman Bao is one of the only ones that I'm continuously impressed with.

They're still pushing hard. Still consistently creating delicious food. Still creating massive lines no matter where they're parked.

Good job, dudes.
author: Illyanna M.

description:
Update: the pork belly is good, *and* consistent: nice crusty outside, juicy inside, and the steamed bun itself is good:
http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/sT8TRzofJym5w0khZkOJhw?select=fPI-UkpcwCjtQybLzzqc6A#fPI-UkpcwCjtQybLzzqc6A

The tofu is good: better texture than typical tofu.  But, it was not crispy on the outside as others have reported.  Maybe next time I'll ask for "extra crispy."

The Motorola parking lot in Sunnyvale is hard to find: it's in the "Moffett Towers", off Enterprise way:
http://www.yelp.ca/biz_photos/sT8TRzofJym5w0khZkOJhw?select=fPI-UkpcwCjtQybLzzqc6A#iHnwhVWzp3CzOLn948RHxQ
author: Scott F.

description:
This food truck does it right!  They took the Bao, and made it something modern, new, and delicious!  Came here at the Moveable Feast, and this truck definitely stood out more than others.  The contemporary approach to turning a simple bun with meat into something original was great.  

Had two of the steamed baos, the pork belly, and the cocacola braised pork?  The pork belly was an interesting mix as baos are Chinese, however it had Japanese style daikon.  Made for a delicious combination.  The meat was crispy, light, and tender.  Braised pork one was good as well.  Less bursting with flavor, but still delicious nonetheless.  

Overall everything I tried was great.  This is definitely one of the better food trucks out in the Bay!
author: Bryson L.

description:
The Pork Belly Bun is featured on the 7x7 Big Eat. http://www.7x7.com/big-eat-2012-photos#/30

I LOVE Chairman Bao! The first time I had it was at Off the Grid when I waited a half hour in line, but I haven't had to wait more than 5 minutes, if at all, every time after that.

Although all their buns are pretty good, the Pork Belly (Steamed) is definitely the way to go! I have gotten the baked version before, but because it was so big, it didn't taste as good as the small, clam-shaped bun. I didn't appreciate it as much because there was so much of it (think hamburger-sized). Now I just order multiple steamed buns if I want more. The fatty pork belly melts in your mouth like better. I'm drooling just thinking about its deliciousness.

This red truck with the friendly panda on it has me running to it every time I see it, like a little kid when they hear the ice cream man.
author: Ava S.

description:
Date & Time:  Thursday May 20, 2010 @ 12pm
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  SOMA, Potrero Hill & Mission Bay Lunch Crowd- Steve from Gobba Gobba Hey, Pairs of Girls and Guys in Graphic Tees, Diesel Jeans & Colorful Sneakers
Vibe:  Chill
Decor:  Red Food Truck
Service:  Nice & Efficient
Imbibe:  Fresh Fruit Shaved Ice:  Pineapple Salted Caramel, Strawberry Coconut(My Pick), Ginger Lychee, Mango Matcha Green Tea.  
Devour:  Choice of Baked or Steam Bun.  Tender Pork Belly w/ Daikon in Steamed Bun, Chinese Sausage w/ Egg & Hoisin Sauce in Steamed Bun & Spiced Duck Confit w/ Mango Salsa in Baked Bun.  Combo Meals $9
Total:  $15
author: Genevieve Y.

description: This is one of my favorite food trucks in the Bay area. I have tried and enjoyed all of their different buns, though the Coca Cola braised pork is definitely my favorite. Great food, good service, and decent prices. Definitely worth a visit if you see them at Off the Grid or just rolling around town.
author: Kyle K.

description:
Bow to the Chairman! Chairman Bao is the latest SF food truck to debut yesterday in the SOMA area selling Chinese bao (stuffed steamed or baked buns, like mini sandwiches). http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/mm8E0AevUmxiray5APcfqA/l This iconic truck is currently parked at 1200-7th street, in front of Economy Restaurant Fixtures from 12-2pm. http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/r4IUojLiXmixL6pZAnyN9Q/l Check twitter for updates on upcoming evening locations and hours.

The prices are not exactly cheap (since the average bao costs less than $1 in Chinatown, and gua bao at Tea Garden is under $2) but affordable. A combo goes for $9 - choose two steamed buns OR one baked bun, plus a shaved ice drink. If you order a la carte, the baked baos are $5.75 each, while steamed baos (clam-shaped) are $2.95 - because they hold less filling. There are 6 choices for fillings: pork belly with pickled daikon, sesame chicken with scallion & bok choy, lion's head (pork meatball) with kimchee, duck confit with mango salsa, Chinese sausage with egg and hoisin sauce, and the vegetarian bao: garlic tofu with miso greens. http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/f7fkjC7OYTNh30oXrDNfIw/l

The fresh fruit shaved ice drinks ($3.50) have a few unusual flavor combinations: pineapple salted caramel, strawberry coconut, ginger lychee, and mango matcha green tea. http://static1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/k3PaVqjbiNOFpID6r6W5NQ/l It's similar to Vietnamese dessert cups filled with chopped fruits and gelatin, but with shaved ice added. Other drink options include: iced tea, coconut water, vitasoy and others for $1.50 or more. The location is remote but so far so good (the fatty pork is the best choice so far). I'll update and add pics later after I try more menu items. Overall, 3.5 stars but rounded up to 4 stars because of the nice friendly service!

This is actually the 2nd street vendor to offer the steamed gua bao or siao bao in SF (not including regular Taiwanese restaurants). The other street vendor is "MaliNumNum Treats", she makes a slightly smaller version for $2, with 3 meat choices, no veggie version yet.

*****

Rivalry with east coast vendor? - As soon as I heard the "Chairman Bao" name being used I knew there might be some controversy. Because I had read (previously bookmarked for places to try) about a small NY shop that opened last year named Baohaus, which has a menu item ($4 each) with that same name. And today it surfaced, the owner of Baohaus posted a reproaching foul mouth rant in his blog claiming that he owned that name. At first I was willing to consider his point of view as valid, but after he mentioned how he "hates yelpers" (even though he's a yelper too. Yelp flagged his 5-star review of his own place.) I lost all interest and his rant became meaningless noise to me. Yelpers are customers too, I believe that owners should respect all customers. Also no longer bookmarked to try that east coast spot.

Update: Legally same/similar name use is not an issue since they operate in different regions.
author: Luis C.

description:
Perhaps my expectations were too high?  I tried a couple of steamed buns -- pork belly & tofu -- when The Chairman was in San Jose for the Moveable Feast in Willow Glen.  I found both disappointing.

Firstly, the "tender" pork belly was anything but ... in fact, I almost reflexively spit out my first bite since the texture took me by surprise.  When you are expecting melt-in-your-mouth sumptuous pork belly and what you get is like a super-fat slab of bacon it is just not good.  Also, while normally I would agree that daikon paired with a greasy food is a good thing, it just didn't work for me in this case.  The flavor of the daikon was overwhelming, and though the pork belly's flavor was underwhelming it just didn't balance out.

I liked the tofu bun better than the pork belly, but it still had its problems.  For being "miso cured," I sure struggled finding the hit of miso umami I was expecting.  The tofu itself was nicely crisped on the outside and had a decent texture (though after eating the exquisite tofu from San Jose Tofu Co. at mom's house and at area Japanese restaurants it was a bit of a let down).  The pairing with the Chinese greens worked better than the daikon/pork belly pairing, and there was some sort of dressing/sauce that was tasty but I could have used a more generous dollop.

On the bright side, I did like the actual steamed bun in its pillowy goodness.  I suppose if I ever ran across this truck again I might try some of their other offerings -- I mean how could you ever go wrong with duck confit?  Though now that I think about it, I used to think the same thing about pork belly ...
author: Susan Y.

description:
The Chairman is probably my favorite food truck out of the variety that visit Menlo Park's Off the Grid Wednesday night gatherings.  Meat eaters, go for the tender pork belly with turmeric, pickled daikon, and green shiso.  I prefer the steamed version ($3.75) over the baked version ($6.75).  Get a couple pork belly baos, add a dollop of sriracha on top and you are set for the night.  

Veggie lovers, go for the baked crispy miso cured tofu with garlic-tofu mayo and baby choy sum ($6).  I've tried the steamed tofu version and it definitely pales in comparison. 

Note that the coca-cola braised pork and spicy chicken baos aren't necessarily bad -- I think the pork belly bao just blows them away.
author: Kristin C.

description:
They are in Emeryville Mondays (Hollis & 53rd) & Wednesdays (Hollis & 45th) from 11:30 - 1:30 . . . should there be another listing so their E-ville location is more prominent?

Anyway, I got there a little after 1pm and they had 4 available buns. Pork Belly, Sesame Chicken, Pulled Pork, and Tofu with Duck & Lions Head Meatballs sold out. It looks like the Pulled Pork has taken the place of the sausage & egg variant on the menu.

Anyway, I got one of each pork in a steamed bun. (See my dark blurry pic)

Visually the Pork Belly with Daikon reminded me of the Momofuku Pork Bun with daikon instead of cucumber. The flavor was good, but the meat a little dry and tough in spots.

The Pulled Pork was much better for me. The spicing seemed similar to the pork belly, but was much juicier. The cabbage & mustard seeds added a good contrast . . . I just wish there was more of it in the bun.

Decent stuff, but at $2.95 per bun, they seemed a little overpriced for their small size (2-3 bites). $1.25 street tacos have ruined food truck pricing for me!!
author: Andrew C.

description:
Looking at the list of the Eat Real 2012 vendors, there wasn't a "must try" for me...  except for The Chairman!  I've heard so much about it and couldn't wait to see if it would live up to the hype.  We got to Eat Real at 10:30, did a walk around to scout out the food, and then promptly went to The Chairman at 10:45...  when there was already a line!  Thankfully the line wasn't very long since not so many folks were out eating yet and we only waited 15 minutes for our 5 spice pork belly bun and the Coca-cola braised pork bun with cabbage.  We walked by the truck again around noon and the line was much longer, as I would have expected.

The baos were awesome!  We were pleased with the size of the buns and they looked delicious.  The braised pork was nice and tender with a good amount of meat.  But we liked the 5 spice pork belly even better.  Very flavorful meat, nice and juicy and fatty, just as you'd expect pork belly to be!  I hate pickled vegetables, but the daikon's taste wasn't too sour or overpowering and I liked how the flavors worked together.  I'm not sure it's worth a 45 minute wait like some yelpers have had to experience, but I loved my Chairman experience and can't wait to have some more!
author: Jeff C.

description:
The first thing I typed when I started this review was, "This place is five stars. Done."  They are really that good.

The lines can be long (because they're just that good!), but it usually goes faster than other lines since they're pretty efficient at taking your order. Usually, there aren't too many people waiting around for their order either, since the Chairman is pretty quick at getting you your food.

I always order the steam version since I think the slightly sweet bao pairs so well with the fillings, but there's something to be said about the baked version too (for one thing it's bigger, which means more to eat!).

In order of favorite:

Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds
At it's best, this one is my favorite. But, the braised pork suffers from one thing: inconsistency. One day, it can be tender, juicy, and flavorful with a touch of sweetness, but another day it might be a bit dry, or just lacking in flavor.  Still, I always order it since when it's good, it just blows the pork belly (my second fav) out of the water!

Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso
Consistently delicious. I always order this with the Braised Pork, since regardless of how the Braised Pork turned out, the Pork Belly will always be crisp, tender, and flavorful. After all, how can you mess up pork belly--it's just extra thick bacon!

Muscovy Duck Confit Terrine with Green Papaya, Orange Pickled Red Onions & Mint
The one thing about this is that Chairman is usually out of it. Of all the times I've gone to Chairman (more times than I can count), I've only seen the Duck available once. It's nice change of pace if you can find it, though. The papaya on top is fresh and crunchy and the duck is savory and tender.  But, if I had to choose, I'd still say the two pork flavors are better.

Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro
I always thought I liked chicken over pork, but Chairman is making me eat my words (or just their delicious bao!). It's good, and if you won't eat the even better pork buns, I'd highly recommend this as a substitute, but if you're not eating pork because you don't think you like it, try the Pork Belly...I'm sure it'll change your world!

Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum
I'm going to be honest, I always prefer meat to non meat, but my love for Chairman was so strong that I wanted to try their meatless option. The flavoring on this was light and it didn't convert me, but in a pinch, I'd still eat it.

And there you have it. Delicious Asian Street Food buns! Go, go eat it now!
author: Joshua B.

description:
The Chairman Truck is one of my favorite food trucks! I love the pork belly sandwich and get it any chance I can! 

Word of advice - make sure that you order your pork belly crispy! I didn't do that once and it came out a bit soggy and not as awesome as it usually is.
author: Casey S.

description:
Excellent! I both love and loathe the days that the Chairman shows up to off the grid.  Their pork belly bao's are so ridiculously good that I just want to eat a million of them.

The nice, crispy crust on the meat pairs super well with the soft and tender middle.  The tartness of the daikon radishes cuts the fattyness of the meat and creates a playful melody of flavor.

Wow read that last line again, I am a d-bag.

The lines get long as with any popular truck and prices are a bit high but man they're worth it.

TL/DR - Good food.
author: Tu T.

description: I tried the miso tofu bun! Unfortunately, it is by far my least favorite of the bunch. I can taste a bit of the flavor, but it is overall quite bland and I need to add sriracha to make it enjoyable. I don't have any dietary restrictions, so I do not have any incentive, nor desire, to get the tofu one again. However, this doesn't change my feelings about The Chairman at all because I still think their other selections are delicious!
author: Karen T.

description: I got both the pork belly and coca cola braised pork with steamed buns. Tasty but small portions which isn't too surprising. Pork belly definitely is the way to go out of the two I tried.
author: Matthew P.

description:
I've been suspicious of the new food trucks on the Stanford campus, since they've been running out some delicious, unfussy, local trucks.  But we saw the Chairman truck and decided to give it a shot.  And the steamed buns were really quite good!  The pork belly bun is, as another reviewer says "a perfectly respectable mid-market" offering.  The tofu bun was too sweet and had an overly uniform mushy texture.  The chicken bun was really quite excellent.  

I put this on the cusp between three stars and four.  Rounded down because they're part of the evil new food truck monopoly.
author: William B.

description:
Along the side of the street, we bumped into The Chairman Truck, one of San Francisco's best! Having already tried two of their buns with Sharon on my last visit, I knew it was worth a second!

They specialize in making tasty buns, a perfect balance of sweetness and soft dough, with great toppings. You can either have the smaller steamed version of the bun or the larger baked version. I have yet to try the baked version, something I'll be sure to do on my fourth trip to San Francisco!

With Sharon: spicy chicken with toasted sesame purée, crunchy pickled carrots, cucumber & cilantro. I remember the chicken being a bit tough, although the flavors were bang-on! The bun is the most memorable of the components, definitely unique to the food truck.

On the left: a Coca-Cola braised pork with savoy cabbage & preserved yellow mustard seeds. Super tender pork with a tangy twist. On the right: tender pork belly with turmeric pickled daikon & green shiso. Juicy bits of pork belly, and the daikon sliced so thin, it made a perfect slaw. Although their descriptions sound like very strong flavors (yellow mustards.. tumeric..), they're done very nicely with not one flavor overpowering another. Good balance!

At this point, we saved our stomachs for the other food trucks on the other end, only to return to The Chairman to buy another bun. Yes, they're that good! Even the guy on the truck smiled as if this happens all too often. We ended up getting my favorite of all four that I've tried now: the crispy miso cured tofu with garlic-tofu mayo & baby choy sum. Whatever they use to batter that medium-firm tofu is amazing. And although I'm not usually a fan of baby choy, it worked really well with the mayo sauce. Best one of them all, despite it sounding way less appetizing! As a snack for down the road, I also ordered the chips. Might as well try as much as I can on the menu! Deep fried wonton chips sprinkled with Togarashi spices and slices of nori seaweed made this a salty snack I wouldn't mind buying packaged in the grocery aisle. Nom nom.
author: Cindy N.

description: I've tried the baked buns from here, but I really enjoyed the steamed ones a lot more. They were way more flavorful.
author: Jessika V.

description:
While on my way to AutoReturn after my car got stolen, there was a small episode of giddiness during that somber time, brought to me by Chairman Bao.

I had only heard of this food truck as one of the better ones at Off the Grid, but when I went, I did not wait in that long line - how lucky that a few days after, I would run into the Chairman while on the way to the police station/AutoReturn!

I ordered miso tofu and braised pork belly, and both were delicious. Personally, even though I'm a meat-lover, I thoroughly enjoyed the miso tofu baked bao. Such moist tofu and incredibly flavorful sauce...I don't think I've ever been happier eating a non-meat bun.

Taking a bite of the baked pork belly, it was tasty as well - very good texture...although even though I'm Japanese, the takuan (pickled radish) they used sort of took away from the savory tenderness, which I would have been happy with.

Of course, since it's a food truck, expect to pay as much for a regular meal for not as much food, but you're getting a unique taste and style from the Chairman! :)
author: Brandon Y.

description:
You had me at pork belly.....

I love this truck! Remember the days when you heard that little jingle from the ice cream truck and you start to run towards it? This is my adult ice cream truck....hold the ice cream and bring on the pork belly! I see the Panda Bear and I start to salivate!

Steamed pork belly bun in a nutshell:

-Soft, steamed buns
-Nice big chunk of crispy pork belly
-Yummy pickled relish of some sort layered on top
-Perfect Tasty Combo

The buns can seem bit pricey because you want to eat like 10 of them in one sitting but they are so worth trying. Seriously, what are you waiting for??? GOOOO!
author: Kristina C.

description:
It's one of my favorite food trucks that consistently provides excellent food.  It's amazing how much food they produce in such a small space.

The star is definitely the pork belly bao. It's perfectly cooked then seared on the grill and put into the bao with pickled daikon.  The perfect marriage of crispy, acid and fatty goodness in a soft steamed bun.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
I got one pork belly steamed bun and one chicken steamed bun at off the grid cupertino. The pickled vegetables complimented the meat perfectly... and the best part is that there's never a line!

Hands down better than koja. 

Only thing is that the customer service could use some work. None of the workers were smiling and seemed annoyed at the customers. 

I will definitely be back.
author: Christine L.

description:
How can you go wrong with Pork Belly?

The Chairman, formerly known as "Chairman Bao" truck, serves delicious pork bellies in steamed ($3.75) or baked ($6.75) buns. Tender pork bellies that's topped off with turmeric, pickled daikon and green shiso. The delightful combination is like Heaven & Earth wrapped in a cloud of soft, fluffy and pillowy buns.

How about some Coca Cola braised pork with savory cabbage, yellow mustard seeds and Kewpie mayo? Hey, don't knock it till you try it. If that ain't your cup of tea, they also have spicy chicken with toasted sesame puree, pickled carrots, pickled cucumbers and cilantro. And for the vegans, they offer a crispy miso cured tofu with garlic-tofu mayo and baby choy sum. Prices for the chicken and tofu are $3.25 for steamed buns and $6.00 for the baked buns.

But the Chairman's star is the Pork Belly that just oozes with delightful flavors that will make you crave like a meth addict willing to prostitute yourself just to get another hit. Yeah, they're that addictively good. 

The Chairman is a regular fixture at Off The Grid events all over the Bay Area, and it's often the star attraction at the Fort Mason location as they are usually positioned in the middle with the other trucks surrounding them like a cavalry protecting the herd. 

Whether you spot the big red truck with a logo of a Giant Panda wearing the Communist hat in the middle of an OTG event or parked on the streets of San Francisco, be sure to line up and get some buns. 

And a message to Eddie Huang:

Giant Panda from the West will fart in your general direction, you douchebag!
author: John G.

description: I love chairman bao!! I will never skip chairman when I'm at off the grid. All of the steamed buns are delicious!! Most especially the pork belly with daikon and the chicken with pickled carrots. Both are my fave !! Then I like the tofu bao then coca cola braised pork. They are so yummy. I get really excited when they're there and instantly line up. You will not regret it unless you're worried about your weight of course. The taste is divine. It is a little pricey though but it is a must have. Can't say I have any regrets. If you feel like going a little heavier get the baked buns. I wouldn't though because I get full fast and its a little more oily than I would like. The baked bun is the size of a little burger and I would much rather have variety.
author: Lyra C.

description:
The first time I tried the food at The Chairman was when I was introduced into the whole food-truck scene two-years ago, at Off The Grid in SF. So when I heard that they make their way to the South Bay ever-so-often, to join the Movable Feast, I was psyched!

Let's get down to the important stuff: How is their food? Well I'm glad you asked! Let me highlight my two-favorite entrees.

I'm a sucker for Pork Belly, and their Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon and Green Shiso Baked Bun is to-die-for. And their Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Cabbage and Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds Baked Bun is spectacular. As you can see, their baked-buns sandwiches are my favorite, but I have still yet to try their Steamed-Bun options.

So you're lucky enough to be in the area when The Chairman food truck rolls around, I recommend heading their way and trying them out. Top-quality food at a decent price.
author: George T.

description: The tofu steamed bun is so good, you'll need 2-3 to fill up though. It is pretty simple with cooked greens and a piece of lightly fried tofu. The garlic mayo really makes it. Super tasty.
author: A S.

description:
I went to the soy/tofu festival at Japan Town and my brother tells me, "There's the Chairman Truck!" I didn't know what it was, but he said it was the best food truck for steamed/baked buns. Now that sparked my interest.

The line wasn't too long yet, so I immediately lined up and ordered the steamed pork belly. $3.50 for a small bun?! Well then, it better taste delicious....

It definitely was amazing. The pork belly was so moist it just melted in your mouth. The other toppings created a well balanced taste with the perfect steamed bun. IT WAS HEAVEN. However, for $3.50? It was pretty pricey and unreasonable I dare say. Maybe for $2.75 or something and I'd be one happy and satisfied customer :)

Anyhow, their buns are a must try for all you foodies!!!
author: Fiona L.

description:
This is my favorite SF food truck by far. I hope they open up a brick-and-mortar location soon so I don't have to hunt it down. I always get the steamed buns. I've tried all of the meat options. (Spicy chicken, braised pork, and pork belly.) You can't really go wrong, but the spicy chicken and pork belly are my favorites. If you ask for a "meater," they'll make you one of each.

This is a quality over quantity place, so beware of that. Portions aren't huge for the money, but it's SO good that I don't even care.
author: Adam N.

description: The most amazing tofu burgers I've eaten !! The steamed version was delicious ! Must try for everyone ! Money is totally worth the food :)
author: Shruti B.

description:
SIMPLY EXCELLENT! I'm not sure what else can be said about the Chairman staple at this point.

After all of these years Chairman is still EASILY the best truck in the Bay (I am sorry.. I just never understood the Koja craze). It's always a delight to enter a Chairman induced food coma.

A quick tip: While there's much deserved love for the pork belly option, I feel like the miso-cured tofu bao gives it a run for its money!
author: Mike K.

description:
I'm so dumbfounded at all the rave reviews here that I'm almost afraid to be contrarian. I've tried this truck twice, and while the ingredients - especially the coca-cola braised pork - are tasty enough and fairly rich, you could do almost as well exploring your way through Asian bakeries, sandwich shops, and restaurants in suburban Asian strip malls or in urban Chinatowns. Lots of variety, reasonable freshness and quality, and far lower prices.

With baked buns going for $6 or more (and more... and more... it seems, every time I see this truck), this is one expensive experience. They're really gussied-up sliders with decent-quality ingredients, a little Asian flair, and clever packaging in that they come from a funkily decorated truck with cute pandas. On their own, they merit 3-4 stars at most.

For me, they weren't a satisfying experience either, unless you get 2 or 3 of the baked or steamed buns. All in all, super long waits, uncertain variety (they tend to sell out of certain items quickly), and a poor price/value proposition.

If you're at a food truck festival like Moveable Feast or Off the Grid and plan on spending $10-12 anyway, you'll likely find better taste and value at other trucks if you compare their menus closely and look at what other people are eating.
author: Vincent L.

description:
The Chairman is hands down the best food truck in the Bay Area!! I have literally driven miles out of my way to get my fix of their Taiwanese deliciousness!

The Spicy Chicken on a steamed bun is outrageously good. The spicy chicken and pickeled vegetables stuffed in their soft, pillowy steamed buns equals awesomeness! The spicy chicken also taste really good on their baked buns. I'm also a fan of the coca cola braised pork on a steamed bun. Soooooooo good!

The Chairman is usually present at most Off the Grid weekly markets across the bay. The employees have always been very friendly, fast and efficient. Prices are super cheap for the quality food you get. Check this truck out next time they roll up in your hood!
author: Paul C.

description:
We got:

People's Buns, Steamed (Red sesame chicken with scallion and bok choy) - Got description online but ours had picked carrot topping. Way too much carrot, definitely not enough meat. Bun was really nice, soft, & fresh though. What meat there was, it had very generic flavor.

Chairman's Buns, Steamed (Tender pork belly with pickled daikon) - Again, not enough meat! Pretty good tender pork, but way way too much daikon. Can you tell by my pics where you can't see the meat at all??

Overall thoughts..
This place is just overrated. My mom's homemade buns are always better.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Oh my buns!!! :) This truck is awesome! Their pork belly sandwich is super tasty, and a really creative, new take on a classic Chinese dish! I often find myself chasing this truck around the city and down the Peninsula! It is a must try! Your taste buds will thank you.
author: Chase B.

description:
Chairman Bao's reputation precedes it. I've been wanting to try this truck for the longest time. Mr. G and I lined up at the OTG Alameda at 11am. There was already a line, but the wait was not too long. 

We got the steamed bun with the braised pork, pork belly, and spicy chicken. They came out hot and ready to be devoured. Sweet steamed bun on the outside, with hot spicy meat and yummy toppings on top. It was amazing. Gotta have more. 

They also take card, which makes paying so much easier.
author: Lori L.

description: Went to off the grid last night in Oakland ca . They had so many food trucks to choose from but we chose the chairmans. And let me tell you we do not regret choosing them! We had the pork belly and spicy chicken! The pickled Veges in both complimented the meat and just went so well together with the steam bun. It was absolutely amazing. We had to go back for seconds! I definitely recommend trying it! You won't be disappointed!! Steam is the way to go!!!
author: Sarchar S.

description:
At $3.75 a bun, these buns aren't cheap: With my appetite, it would probably take 5 or 6 to fill me up. But as a snack or an appetizer to other food truck eats, they hit the spot. Pork belly buns are moist and fluffy and loaded with large, juicy pieces of pork belly. Probably the best I've had in the Bay Area, but not quite as good as Momofuku or Ippudo's. Also had the Zesty wonton chips, which were salty, but nice. 

In sum, go to the Chairman when it's at an Off the Grid, where you can grab some heartier food truck fare to go with your buns.
author: Pierre B.

description: I wish they had a few more veggie options, but man, that tofu bao. I wish it was a bit cheaper, and I could have two, but man, that tofu bao. I wish they were all organic, that would be the best, but man that tofu bao. I'm still thinking about it. The bun, so delectable. The greens, healthiness never tastes so scrumptious. The tofu, so good. Man, that tofu bao. I'd go for one right now! So simple, so delicious, man, that tofu bao.
author: micah f.

description:
The Chairman Truck was about two blocks from my work on a Friday, and we decided to check it out.  We went at a good time and the line wasn't too long yet.

I had tried them once at the JP Morgan Corporate Challenge, and I already knew what to get.  I went with one pork belly and one braised pork bun.  They have a good system going, and our food came out fast.

Both buns were super good.  The pork belly was so tender and tasty.  Its melt in your mouth kind of good!  The braised pork is definitely one to try as well.  If I had to pick one and only one, the pork belly would be the winner.  If you're really hungry, order the small steamed buns, so you can try the different meats.  

The Chairman Truck is definitely one to seek out and try!
author: Patra I.

description: really good coca cola braised pork bun. the steamed buns are better than the baked. one of the better food trucks in SF.
author: Vivienne K.

description:
Stumbled upon this place at the Off the Grid food truck event in SF on Friday night! Apparently, this is a pretty popular truck in SF, so naturally...I had to try it!

I was expecting the "bao" to be a completely enclosed bun, but instead, Chairman's baos are more like little sandwiches! One pork belly bao cost us $3.75 and it was as big as one of those small sandwiches you make at a Chinese restaurant when you order the Peking duck dish! They topped the pork belly with some crunchy daikon, which added a really nice texture to the bao. 

Overall, it was super good and fatty-tasting, but I don't know if it was worth the price or the wait. I would recommend checking it out if you like Chinese food, which I personally love!
author: Nancy T.

description: Superb experience.  One of the best tasting / best valued food truck experiences I have had.  I tried their steamed pork belly and steamed spicy chicken buns yesterday at the StrEat Food park- and they were both delicious.  Two steamed buns at a combined $7 made for a nice meal.  These guys are very organized- smooth ordering, providing numbered receipts, twitter updates, etc.  I will be back for sure, and look forward to trying some of their other options including their baked buns.
author: Andy S.

description: I saw this truck on either a food network show or on the cooking network and wanted to try something from here!  My friend recommended the pork belly.  When it came time to order, there were two different types of buns to order, either a baked bun, or a steamed bun.  The baked bun was larger and more expensive and the steamed bun was smaller and cheaper. Since I wanted only a tasting, I opted for the steamed bun pork belly.  The steamed bun was very soft and light and fluffy.  The pork belly melted in my mouth. In terms of presentation, it did not look very pretty.  They added a picked veggie of some sort which made the dish unappetizing. Thankfully it tasted a lot better than it looked.
author: Janet E.

description:
I'm sorry Chairman Bao, I really wanted to like you.  After seeing you drive past me while I looked out the window on my elliptical at 24 Hour Fitness, I finally got my chance to try you outside of John Colins last Thursday night.  

PRICING: 
$5.75 for the baked buns, $2.95 for the steamed buns
Accepts cash and credit cards

BUNS:
I got my chance to try 4 buns (I was hungry!!) and I was majorly disappointed as the buns lacked authenticity and were small (think 3 bites and you're done).  In my opinion, most of the buns were a great idea, but poor execution on how they actually tasted.

*Tender Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon - It was okay.  Normally I'm not a fan of daikon, but it added the extra crunch to the bun.  The pork belly lacked tenderness and was a bit on the dry side. 

*Red Sesame Chicken with Scallion & Bok Choy - Good.  I got this bun by mistake but it was the one I liked the best.  The chicken marinated in red sesame had tons of flavor and the scallions and bok choy added a slight crisp.

*Lions Head Meatball with Fresh Kim Chee - Probably my least favorite.  The bun consisted of two small meatballs (I wouldn't even classify them as lions head) which had little flavor and soggy kim chee that didn't have the spice kick like it should.

*Pulled Pork with Savory Cabbage & Preserved Mustard Seed - My friend didn't like this much, but I thought it was okay and had more flavor than the lions head one I had first.  The mustard seed added a nice flavor to the pork and cabbage.

LOCATION:
Check their Twitter account for exact locations
author: Nicole S.

description:
The weather was beautiful today and perfect for taking a walk across the street to OTG at Civic Center to get my Friday lunch.  

Besides the cupcakes from Cupkates, I wanted to try something different, something that I have never eaten.  I wasn't feeling the Hapa truck; they're okay, but it wasn't tickling my fancy at the time.  Even though I like Southern Sandwiches, the line was long.  The choices left were Seoul on Wheels and The Chairman Truck.  Pacing back and forth between the two truck vendors, I decided on the latter.

Steamed baos were $3.75 each, except the Crispy Tofu baos with baby bok choy and garlic mayo, $3.25 each.  I ordered the pork belly bao and the crispy tofu bao for $7.00.  I opened the container and looked at my savory goodies...hmmm...they seemed a bit small for the price and I asked myself - did I get my money's worth?  Oh my, looks can be deceiving!!!  I love them and I did get my money's worth!!!

The steamed pork belly bao topped with pickled daikon and green shiso was delicious, quite filling and the pork belly itself was tender and tasty.  However, for some strange reason it had hardly any fat on it.  I guess the vendor must have taken one look at me and thought she got plenty of fat on her, and doesn't need the added fat on the pork belly...awww I feel so deprived not having to chew on some of that fat or some fat back...lol.    

Next up was the crispy tofu bao with the baby bok choy.  Ooh wee (or oui), I inhaled it and wished I had bought another one.  I have eaten miso soup, ma po tofu, stir fried green beans with tofu, deep fried tofu stuffed with ground pork, but I never had a crispy tofu bao and I never knew how great they taste.  Better yet, never mind about getting a pork belly bao the next time, I'll settle for three steamed crispy tofu baos.

Definitely I will add this truck to my short list of mobile food vendors.
author: Carol C.

description:
Holy crap. This place is bomb-bay! Best food truck I've ever had. Best bun I've ever had. Only think keeping this from a 5 star rating is the price. At $3.75 - $6.75, its a pretty pricey snack. 

The pork belly is soft, succulent and melts in your mouth. The pickled diakon adds great sour and acidity to the bun and cuts through the pork flavor. The bun is soft and light, the perfect vessel for the pork and diakon. 

The braised pork was is sweet and bursting with flavor. The pork itself is pull apart tender. The cabbage adds some texture and almost a bit of creaminess to the bun. Be careful not to let it sit for too long. The pork is juicy and soaks into the bread. Wait too long and the bread will start to disintegrate. 

If you see the red truck with panda head logo, follow and enjoy those beautiful morsels from heaven.
author: Billy T.

description:
Really happy I tried this place at the Alameda Antique Fair. I got the steamed baos, which aren't like the typical steamed buns you find at Chinese bakeries and dim sum restaurants. The steamed baos they make are the same pastry from the buns, but folded up like a taco with the menu items of your choice. They had four types to choose from which also come baked.There was a line to order and they were already out of one item when I ordered. 

I got the Fried Tofu bao and the Spicy Chicken bao. Everything was seasoned "Asianly-perfectly" (a cross between Korean cuisine meets Chinese cuisine) with super fresh toppings such as kale and cucumbers. I don't think the chicken was too spicy so I think even the sensitive types could handle it. Anyone who wanted more spicy could use siracha sauce from their counter. These are a little messy to eat but believe me you will want to get messy for these. I think a fork and knife would be too cumbersome to save you from the mess. 

Two were perfect for me but a third might be better for some. I heard the baked bao is larger too so that might be a better choice for the really hungry.
author: Fabi F.

description:
So, ever since i found out the Chairman was coming out to West Sacramento for the Trucktoberfest, i said, "this is a must!"  So , i waited it an entire month.  

First truck i went to when i got to the fest was The Chairman.  Went for the  steamed pork belly bun and the coca-cola braised pork.    i have to say this was delicious.  Wasnt too heavy, nor greasy.  It was just right.   Flavors were perfect.  Them pickles on the pork belly gave it the perfect touch.  The coca-cola braised pork was just as delicious.  The Chairman did not disappoint at all.  This was money well spent.  Looking forward to trying it again when i'm in san francisco.
author: Oscar G.

description: This was one of the best food trucks I've had. We had the Special and it was bomb. Definitely can't go wrong here.
author: Dana G.

description:
First truck and last truck we hit up today at the Eat Real Fest! Seriously, the pork belly bun was blissful and the sesame chicken a slight notch below. The crunch and spiciness of the outside, tender goodness on the inside along with the tangy crunch of the daikon were an amazing combination on the pork belly bun.

I was such a fan that came back and the the pork belly and sesame again but also tried the cola braised pork. Again all were excellent1 

Definitely worth the wait and screw all you haters that talked smack about how long the line was. It wasn't that bad and if you don't want to stand in line, you don't have to so let everyone else that's waiting do so in peace.
author: Art O.

description:
My favorite food truck in SF -- I've only had their steam buns and they're awesome. I get one of each and then have trouble telling them apart. 

Which one is the Coca-Cola briased pork belly? I think the cabbagey-looking one is the chicken. 

But who cares, each one is delicious. They're wonderfully seasoned/marinated meat contrasty with cispy spicy pickles or stiff frizzy lettuce.

I think the Chairman represents a Great Leap Forward (communist humor) in providing the maximum amount of utility to the largest amount of people!

Foodies of all nations, get on the twitter, and track down these steamy buns!
author: Ryan S.

description:
What can I say?  How can I NOT give them 5 stars??!!!  I have now (didn't I already post this review?) tried this truck twice; once at that food festival (S.F.) and more recently @ Off The Grid, Fort Mason. I am hungry as I am writing this...why aren't you outside my window....Chairman!   :(  Waaaaaaah.  Otay.  I tried the.......
 
TENDER PORK BELLY  ....loved the pork, pickled daikon, etc (nice crunch)
COCA COLA BRAISED PORK ....cabbage, mustard seed (asked for no mayo)  and..
the SPICY CHICKEN ...toasted sesame puree, pickled carrots, etc....(not too spicy)

They are all amaAazeballs!!!!!!!  The added crunchy veggies are so delish and complimentary to the super moist flavorful meat, on all the bao.   I did get all on the steamed (tiny!) buns (2 bites!)...soooooo good.  Did I just drool on the screen?!  My fave is the COCA COLA BRAISED PORK, the MOST tender, but you can't go wrong with any.  My mom loved all, but I think her fave was the .....ALL of them!  I did try the GINGER LEMONADE, which was amaaazing (I love ginger lemonade, not a huge fan of regular lemonade).  However, NOT, repeat, NOT a fan of the weird jello cubes  floating and creeping up my straw. Although, I did restrain myself from spitting them out at people.

Also (yeah, there's more!)  the service is amazingly fast (even @ Off Da Grid-Fort Mason) and hospitable; they did not bat one eyelash when I asked for no mayo on the Coca Cola Braised Pork. I REALLY think they should have a super size option for the steamed bun bao!  PWEEEEEEAAAASE?!?!  Love it.
author: Delicious B.

description:
I have wanted to try this place since I heard about it over the summer, but I've always been too busy to make it to the OTG events.  That is until last Thursday.  First thing on my mind was to get one of the Pork Belly Buns I've heard so much about!  I was concerned the line would be ridiculously long and that my belly would give in to one of the deceivingly attractive carts with shorter lines.  So I started strategizing with my friends as to how to handle the lines, but hold up....as we approached the truck, the line was only 5 people deep!  

The whole ten minute wait left me starving for the two buns I ordered.  I had the steamed buns but they also have a baked bun option.  The baked bun is served more like a burger, and therefore it has more filling and is pricier.  

The buns were DE-LIC-OUS!!!  The pork belly had the perfect consistency with the fat and bbq sauce forming a crispy coating over the juicy meat.  Coupled with the softness of the steamed bun and crispness of the pickled radish, the overall sensation was that of a party in your mouth.   No holding back, no letting go, just grab a bun and go to town!   You might need at least four to make a meal out of it.
author: Veasna H.

description:
Out of all the reviews waiting for me to type, I feel wholeheartedly that The Chairman formerly known as "Chairman Bao" a) deserves 5 million stars and b) deserves to be my 900th review! 

Out of all the food truck meets I have been to, I have never tried Chairman because either the line for this truck is ridiculously long or because I have already spent way too much on other food items. I normally go to at least 2 if not 3 trucks because it is true, I am a fat penguin :(

And here I was yesterday indulging when I know I shouldn't but it is ok since strict dieting starts tomorrow. Anyway, I saw a few I wanted to try but I was drawn to the red truck that The Chairman embodied. Moveable Feast Saratoga shuts down at 2pm every Saturday, we got there a little after 1:30 so the hype has surpassed. I got in line, excited that I was behind just 2 folks, excited to see a "We accept credit cards and debit cards" sign, and the menu which was easy to read and somehow made me want to order "the everything" but I held back and ordered 2 steamed buns: pork belly w/ turmeric daikon and the crispy tofu w/ something-something. I did not request for anything to be omitted though I am not a "vegetable" person but felt like trying the buns as is.

You get in line, you order, you pay, you wait for your # to be called, and once you take your first bite you would not want to stop at 1. I am glad I got 2 but scolded silently to myself because I should have ordered more and I wanted to try the baked version bun. The steamed one is less in carbohydrates because it is a lot smaller and a lot cheaper than the baked ones. The baked buns is double the size of the steamed ones and double the price - I think it will be worth it. I will try the baked ones next time. An Asian hamburger.. cute. 

Anyway.

I tried the pork belly first. I am shocked to see how everything was packed on 2 tiny albeit airy, soft, and delicious ass steamed buns. The turmeric daikon looked weird to me at first because I am strictly a "meats and potatoes" girl however, I ate the entire thing almost in 2 gigantic bites because it was that finger-lickin' yummy! I tackled the tofu one next and oh.. my.. cupcakes.. I would have said "yes" if the buns asked me to marry it. 

In short: a must.

Mental Note: this will be requested when a) at my future wedding w/ a guy unlucky to end up w/ me because although I don't need fancy shmancy things, I eat as if I am a king and b) as part of my last meal.
author: Tram N.

description:
OMG. OMG. The buns. The buns. SO GOOD!!!! 


I don't even know what we got? We were all so hungry that we ate fast.  a few were steamed, the rest were baked.  I want it again.  Wanted to buy some to bring home but they wouldn't have made it home.  

I thought that the buns were on the pricier side at $4-$6 a piece but they were worth every penny. 

They also had Hubert's lemonade which was a plus!

There was a reason that these guys had the longest line of all of the food trucks!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
My boyfriend brought home The Chairman's Pork Belly Steamed Bun for me to try when they were at Moveable Feast Willow Glen.

I am not a fan of pork, but they did a really great job at cooking the pork belly to maintain it's tender fatty nature. The daikon pickles were really good. The steamed bun had a good taste, but sort of dense in texture. One problem with the pork belly steamed bun was that it needed some sort of sauce, if there was any... it was too mild. I could barely finish one bun because it tasted so fatty. A sweet soy sauce like they use for peking duck at chinese restaurants would have made my steam bun so much better. I really think they should consider adding this option. It would've knocked my socks off. Another problem was the lack of fresh veggies, perhaps cabbage or butter lettuce. There's a lot more potential for the pork bun, but overall it was a little bit of a disappointment.
author: Ashley T.

description: How many times should I update my 5 star reviews of the Chairman Truck?  Obviously not as often as I eat their perfect baked pork belly bun, but just making sure you know they are still as awesome as ever.
author: Lorianne L.

description: I heard about the baos and finally tried all 4 of them steamed. Yay me! So happy to have stopped by at Off the Grid. The lines are long and if you're not close enough to the truck it's hard to hear your number. There's live music playing around at Off the Grid so you can't really blame them.
author: Corie L.

description:
Out with the old and in with the new.

Fire trucks used to be my favorite big red truck. I mean who doesn't love a man in uniform speeding off to save lives?

The Chairman Truck is my new favorite big red truck. Because they save hungry, overworked, cubicle-ridden lives one meal at a time.  

The first time I had the Chairman Truck was at the Treasure Island Flea a few years ago. They might as well call themselves the Crack Truck because after one bite of my pork belly bun I was addicted.

So when my office started having food trucks come in for lunch on Wednesdays I told all of my co-workers how life changing these buns are, one by one they finally braved the Disneyland line to get some pork belly in their bellies. Go ahead, call me a bun pusher, I'm not ashamed. Now-a-days we check the food truck line up each week in hopes that the Chairman is coming. And we can't be the only ones with our fingers crossed because there is no other food truck that creates lines like the Chairman does. I almost feel bad for its competitor food trucks, but then I don't because they don't sell pork belly buns.

I've tried everything on the menu except for the tofu. Usually I opt for baked buns over steamed buns, but if you want to keep your lunch on the lighter side, or sample a bit of everything, steamed is the way to go. A little bit of Sriracha is the perfect sauce. And (as I already raved about) the pork belly is my favorite. The meat is perfection and I'm obsessed with the pickled daikon.

So is it Wednesday yet?
author: Kristen K.

description:
Went to Off the Grid Friday night in SF. WOW!! Yes the line was super long, but it was so worth the wait. It takes a while to order your food (long lines), but they are quick to get your food out to you. 

We ordered the pork belly steamed bun thing. It was delicious!! The pork belly melted in my mouth and the bun was sticky and sweet... my mouth is watering right now. We also had the coco cola braised pork, it was good but nothing compared to the pork belly... I can't wait to visit again! 

The service is good, they are friendly and super fast.
author: Audra M.

description:
Mmmm, bao chicka WOW wow!

I can't stop thinking about the party that happened in my mouth yesterday!

I can't thank the glorious pig enough for giving of itself in becoming soooo many delicious varieties of meaty-meat treats.
 
I can't believe I've lived this long without snarfing on The Chairman's most honorable way of getting pig in my mouth - pork belly bao!

So be like the rest of the sheep and get in line. I don't care how LONG that line is, just be like Nike and DO it!  Your mouth will thank you. The spicy chicken bao was no slouch either! Damn that Chairman has got some ninja skills on not only farm animals, but pickled carrots, and other veggies my kiddos wouldn't normally, but... willingly inhaled!
author: Kara B.

description:
There should be a different rating system for food trucks, because in my book they are consistently 4-5 stars. I guess when you do only a handful of foods, you do them pretty damn well. 

I had the tender pork belly first. Honestly, this is as close to perfect pork belly as I could imagine. First and foremost, the skin of the pork walks that fine line between being crispy without being too tough to get your teeth into. The meat inside is moist and melts in your mouth. The bread is fresh and lightly toasted, which leaves the entire mouthful feeling pleasantly warm. 

I also got the sesame chicken, which was equally good. But if you compare the ideal chicken sandwich to the ideal pork belly sandwich, you know pork belly is winning every time. Luckily, prices are cheap enough that you can buy one of each and figure out which you prefer for yourself. 

They were out of buns when I was there, I've heard those are even better. Don't understimate the bun though, these guys know what they are doing.
author: Jake B.

description: So Freakin Delicious. I've been a fan ever since my first Chairman Bao meal. Big fan of the Pork Belly and Braised Pork. Just wish they offered more meats for your bao. I will keep coming back here when i need that bao fix.
author: Ryan H.

description: These guys were out here in Danville today and wow was it tasty!  I had the chicken bao with the pickled carrots and cilantro.  Normally I hate the 'coolness' of food trucks and think it's a stupid trend but the Chairman is legit!
author: Jonathan A.

description:
Buns? Baked or steamed are fine with me!

I was lucky enough to get my hands on these awesome buns at OTG Haight. I ended up getting the red sesame chicken with pickled sliced cucumber and carrot as well as the crispy garlic tofu with miso greens. Both baked "People's Buns" at $6 each. Steamed ones are $3.25. "Chairman's Buns" such as the pork belly are $3.75 steamed and $6.75 for baked.

The red sesame chicken was my favorite! Really delicious! The chicken was tender and slightly spicy and the cucumbers and carrots were refreshing. The crispy tofu on the other hand, was lacking the garlic flavor I was looking for and the tofu could have been crispier. It was just alright.

I gave this truck another go when they were parked in front of the Frey Norris Gallery opening a couple of weeks ago. Anyway, I got the red sesame chicken again, but this time steamed...and it was just as good! I also tried the Bao chips ($2.50), which were basically fried wonton chips with bits of nori and salt. They were a little too salty for my liking so I really wouldn't recommend them. 

To sum it up, I've had pretty good experiences with this truck and look forward to eating more buns from them. Sure they're a tad pricey, but IMO they're worth it. Also, if you see them at OTG make sure you stand in their line first before you decide to venture to another food truck because their line is always the longest!
author: Fallon P.

description:
After hearing so much about the famous Chairman Bao Truck, I recently gave them a try at Edgewood Eats.  Luckily when I got there, there was not a long line so I literally had to wait 2 minutes to order, Yeah Me!

I decided on the Steamed version which is priced at either $3.25 or $3.75 depending on which one you order, they are the smallest ones so I thought this would be the best way to just get a tasting.

First the Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage, Yellow Mustard Seeds & Kewpie Mayo ($3.75): I have to admit this one was just ok, now I personally make a killer Coca-Cola Ham, so their Coca-Cola Braised Pork was just blah to me.  I was really hoping this wasn't what everyone was raving about!

Than the Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Puree, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Clantro ($3.25): ok, WOW, this redeemed The Chairman, I can eat these all day long.  The spicy chicken was cooked perfectly and had a great flavor and all those pickled carrots and cucumbers, OMG, YES PLEASE! The bun was light and fluffy and with all the ingredients together was just excellent.  

Thank god for that 2nd Bun, because otherwise they would have only gotten 3 stars. Next time I'll have to try the other 2 options...Until next time Chairman.
author: Sandra L.

description:
Asian fusion steam bun sammiches! Just as good as everyone raves! 

I went to the Jameson Bartender's Ball last night and The Chairman catered the event! Well, it parked outside of Public Works and servers brought the food from the truck into the building. I posted up right near the window and snatched them up as they came out, hot and fresh. I tried almost every flavor bao. My favorites were the pork and the duck! The chicken was pretty good too and of course, the pork belly. I'm sad I missed out on the tofu. My friend said it was bomb. I loved how each one has its own pickled vegetables. 

I'm so lucky I finally got to try this place out! I was more than impressed with the caliber of food. I'm amazed that chefs could produce such complex flavors out of such a tiny truck kitchen. I'm stalking this place from now on.
author: Elise G.

description:
Oh man! Came across this truck of awesomeness at the SJ Taco Festival of Innovation. A few friends in the group I went with made a bee line towards this truck, saying it was the best. BAO, were they right! Sorry for the cheese, haha! Their offerings are kind of like peking duck, where it's a sandwich / taco of meat with the bao.  A bao(zi), for those of you not familiar, is a type of chinese steamed bun or bread, usually white in color.

We only got 3 baos (2 different ones), and they were all de.li.cious! The baos were fresh and fluffy, moist enough, and without a thick skin on the outside. The pork belly was super tender and tasty. There was a nice lining of fat along the pieces to add just enough of that heart clogging taste. The other bao we tried was the coca-cola (seriously) braised pork. I couldn't really taste the coke much, if at all, but it was good nonetheless. I didn't care much for the cabbage and mustard seed topping, but then again, I don't care for cabbage at all. 

The service was decent, the wait wasn't too long considering the amount of people in line, and the price was fairly reasonable. Not sure how much their baos normally are, but they were $2 a piece at the festival.

Damnit...writing this review is making me drool with regret that we didn't get more of these baos of bliss. =)....


TL/DR (ratings out of 5):

5.0 - Pork Belly
4.2 - Braised Pork
5.0 - Service
4.5 - Price
author: Darwin T.

description:
The steamed bun is really delicious. I love the soft texture, and the fact that it's smaller means I get to try more!
I had the pork belly and the coca cola braised pork, and I preferred the coca cola. It was so tender, seasoned really well, and super tasty!
The staff is also really friendly and nice!
author: Christina W.

description:
Food truck goodness!

I have only ever tried steamed braised pork and pork belly, I've never gotten around to the other options.

Pros:
-Delicious steamed buns with pork
-Food made quickly
-Comes to Stanford

Cons:
-Never seem to serve duck at Stanford
-Expensive
author: Jason S.

description:
Just a bit of advice to those going to a food truck rally... 

DO NOT make Chairman Bao your first stop as you will be dissapointed by everything after.  

We decided to share a baked pork belly sandwich and it was heaven in my mouth.  Perfectly seasoned, just enough pickled daikon, soft roll, what more can a girl ask for.  

Only con... had to share my other half as we planned on stopping by a few more trucks.

My mouth melts as I type about the bun.
author: Princess D.

description:
These buns don't lie; they'll straight up tell your stomach, "Hey intestines, get ready to digest some tasty treats served out of an automobile!" 

Nestled in a back alley, this truck will serve up some hot and tasty buns. If you opt for the larger size you'll get a nice sandwich that looks like a bbq sammie. I got the coke braised pork and it made my taste buds squeal with delight.
author: Erich G.

description:
Yum, yum, yum!  Wow.  I love coming here every time it's at the truck stop.

Steamed and baked are both excellent.
Great vegetarian option -- the tofu is quite delicious.

Definitely give this place a try!
author: Matt N.

description:
If you're into pork belly then you'll love The Chairman Truck
If you're not into pork belly, well, you're lame

I came across this truck while visiting the Off The Grid event at the Fort Mason Center. Their menu is quite small. They offer baked and steamed buns with your choice of meat filling. 

The night I visited the truck they had pork belly, tofu and red sesame chicken. They also had bags of fried wonton chips. 

My wife and I bought one steamed pork belly, one steamed red sesame chicken bun and a baked pork belly bun, which was more like a sandwich. We also got a bag of wanton chips. 

The steamed pork bun was fabulous. It was filled with tender, juicy, fatty pork belly, turmeric pickled Daikon and Green Shiso. The baked pork belly bun was filled with the same filling but it was not good because the baked bun was to doughy. 
The red sesame chicken bun was also good. The red sesame chicken was juicy and slightly spicy and was topped with pickled cucumbers and carrots. The chips were just OK, nothing special. 

The prices at this truck were a tad high seeing how small the portions are. The trucks employees were really friendly and got our order out extremely fast. 

If I ever come across this truck again while I'm visiting that bay I would definitely stop by and pick up another pork belly steamed bun.....or two......or five.
author: Craig R.

description: The Chairman stopped by work today so I gave them another shot and picked up a pair of pork belly and chicken steamed buns. I don't know if I'm just unlucky, but I thought it was even worse this time. Although the pickled veggie toppings were still good, the pork belly was dry and sinewy, and about half of the chicken pieces were severely burnt. I pretty much waited half an hour to eat dry, stringy pork and chicken that resembled charcoal. Ugh. Check out my pics and see for yourself.
author: Nei N.

description:
A great food truck. I got Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds. 

I went with steamed, and next time it will be baked.  Good stuff and worth it!
author: Roger A.

description:
3.5 stars 

Food trucks were considered a cheap alternative to sit-down restaurants before they became a hype. 
Baos weren't bad, but kinda pricey for the amount you get. I actually enjoyed the bun more than the pork belly filling itself. You can get this dish (with other fillings) at  practically any Chinese restaurant.
author: Samantha K.

description: My absolute favorite food truck.  The chicken is my favorite, followed by the Coca-Cola braised pork.
author: Richard G.

description:
I feel like I've regarded food truck hype too highly and have consistently been disappointed with the food I've eaten at food trucks. The reviews are good and the lines are deceiving but when it all boils down, the food here is decent.

I normally love baos and this sort of food is comfort food to me so I came here hoping to satisfy my craving for some of that home cooked taste but it didn't exactly live up to my expectations. The baos are a little expensive for their size and each of them has a little twist to it but I guess in the end I just wanted a traditional bao the way I'm used to and they didn't deliver. 

Maybe I'm being too harsh, but it didn't satisfy my craving at the time. That being said I would still come back for more but this time with lower expectations.
author: Zach C.

description: Pork belly with daikon salad- did without the bun.  Very tasty salad and pork.  Love the pickly goodness of the daikon salad.  Could have used a little more pork, but i bought the steamed size.  Next time I will try the baked size.
author: Alex M.

description:
I'm going to be honest, I did not think standing in line for more than 20 minutes in line for some steamed buns with fancy meat/garnishes was going to be worth it especially for $3.75.

OW BAO, BABY! I got the Pork Belly w/ Pickled Yellow Daikon and this simple combination was filled with contrast and flavor. I'm not a real fan of pork or fatty meats, but the pork belly was so tender and flavorful ... and was perfect with the tartness of the Daikon. Plus, how can you go wrong with their steamed buns?!

Definitely a place to visit, if they're around.It's a perfect little indulgent, savory snack. 
My regret? Not ordering more of their buns and the other ones they had. Brb, gonna cry about it now.
author: Janet N.

description:
caught up with CHAIRMAN BAO at the food truck festival in PALM SPRINGS. love their logo and paint job -- really a well designed truck.

had a couple steamed buns with PORK BELLY (both times). loved the quick PICKLED DAIKON -- sweet, tart, a little spice and tumeric yellow. the kids ate their share and then some. interesting, inventive and very distinctive food. got two of our three votes for best of show.

great eats. great crew. the only truck at the festival we went back to for seconds.
author: Scott T.

description: Holy smokes! I ordered the baked pork belly bun (sandwich)...soooo good! the pork belly is full of flavor (duh, the fat has all the goodness)! The bread is nicely toasted and goes very well with the pork and the kimchee ( I think that's what it was) I am a fan and will go back to try everything on the menu! I know I have the Cee-lo syndrome right now..! :/
author: Carla F.

description: Wow, I really enjoyed the steamed Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon and Green Shiso ($3.75). Soft, fluffy white bun with flavorful and juicy pork belly. Didn't notice much else as I quickly chomped down and tried to finish it before my bf could get to it.
author: Alice T.

description:
Excellent. Tried the Coca-cola braised pork and the Tender Pork belly, both on steamed buns, and they were excellent. I liked the coke one slightly more though- more interesting flavors. Other than that, the baked buns are more bang for your buck, but the steamed buns taste authentic and pretty darn good. 
Will track this truck down again.
author: Jo C.

description:
OKAY the chicken steamed bun was so good. it was nice and spicy and the pickled carrots/cucumbers were delicious!! I can't wait to eat here again O.O 

I also tasted my friends braised pork one and it was really good but I think my chicken bun won. 

(not a fan of pork belly so didn't get it but if i liked pork belly i bet it'd be super good)

girl taking our order was so nice. she said the wait would be a while so we went to wander around and look at other trucks and when we came back all our orders were waiting for us. HAha
author: Elaine L.

description: I liked the tofu steamed bao. It seems to be recommended on Yelp less frequently than the other flavors, but it was definitely my favorite. I also tried the pork belly. Not the best I've ever had, but a solid 4 stars. I usually find that food trucks are overpriced with average food, but I'd actually get this again.
author: Paulina L.

description:
The Chairman is great, I love their steamed buns. My new favorite is their steamed coca cola braised pork,  served with savoy cabbage cilantro and preserved yellow mustard seeds. The mustard seeds are an amazing compliment to the tender pork.

I prefer to visit the Chairman when they are at Off the Grid Proxy in Hayes Valley because there is less of a crowd, at Fort Mason the line goes on forever!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
So I first went here without really knowing too much about it. I was a recent transplant from Portland, OR (where the foodcart reigns) and my friend dragged me here without too much of a fuss. I ordered the pork belly bao and nearly died -- could this be my San Francisco version of the Portland food carts?

When I went back nearly a month later, I was bursting to the seams with anticipation -- I ordered every bao available after waiting in an insufferably long line at OTG Fort Mason. What followed was disaster: I was underwhelmed by the chicken, tofu, and duck bao. I thought the chicken was too spicy with not enough flavor, the tofu too soft and bland, and the duck was awkward with its sauce. The pork belly bao was still a real winner, but I was disappointed by the rest.

So conclusion? Chairman Bao's real winner is their pork belly bao (this bao alone earned a star to itself -- otherwise I would have just given it a three). But a secret is to go on Wednesdays after work when they're parked by Bloodhound on Folsom in SOMA -- small line, usually little wait -- that's what really cemented their 4 star rating in my book. Otherwise, they're really not worth the long wait on their OTG days.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I've waited in long lines for the Chairman Truck at Off the Grid several times. More and more recently they've been venturing to other food truck meets. Sometimes i'll catch them around Divisadero, most likely making their way to another spot. Each time i eat their food i have a different experience. The waiting time directly correlates to how much i enjoy the food hah.

Steamed or Baked? Choose baked for the pork belly. Steamed for the tofu. Baked or steamed for the sesame chicken. Note the baked buns are much larger (and cost more too). Yum, pickled veggies. The tofu is surprisingly tasty! It doesn't sound as exciting when you put it on a menu with pork belly but it's crispy garlic tofu topped with miso greens is goood.
author: Samantha L.

description:
This is my favorite food truck.  

The steamed bun is pretty small.  I usually end up getting both a steamed bun and a baked bun.  The tofu is great and it isn't oily or fried.  I like this sandwich so much, I wish they had more menu items to try!  (tofu is the only vegetarian option)
author: Angie I.

description: Heard a lot about the Chairman's truck so had to indulge while they were at the food truck stop near 2nd and Harrison (G food lounge?).  Went with the miso tofu but wanted to compare steamed to baked and understand the diff as well as why one is twice as expensive.  Both were terrific - hard to say which was better... prolly the steamed.  But on the baked, the bun was toasted and slightly crunchy which was a nice touch.  Kinda like toasted kings hawaiian bread.  Awesome flavor, not too rich, not too sweet.  5 stars for the food.  3 for the price and value.  C'mon... $9.25 for 2 buns?
author: Rick K.

description:
SOOOOO GOOOOD! First visit, I tried 3 out of 4 steamed buns (all but the tofu) and they each tasted amazing. Each with their unique flavor to them. The only complaint I'd have is the price. The steamed buns aren't very big for $3.75 a piece, and adds up easily.

Second time around I go a baked bun ($6.75) and a steamed bun ($3.75) if I remember right. Got more bang for your buck with the baked bun, and it was easier to eat.

Definitely one of my favorite food trucks!
author: Norman L.

description:
I admit, I am a food truck junkie!  Yes, you pay a little more than you might be inclined too, but if you're like me, you get to try a lot of delectable dishes, one truck at a time.
