I had been dying to try the Chairman's bao for the longest time but could never time it right or be at the right food truck gathering in SF until now...I was so excited to see the truck lined up with the many that alternate every other Wednesday in Albany off of San Pablo Ave.

It started with the Coca Cola Braised Pork Belly with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved yellow mustard seeds in a steamed bun!  Oh, I was in heaven!  The soft steamed half moon shaped bun hugged the savory tender pork belly and cabbage ever so perfectly.  It was like a little bite of heaven until it was gone and I wanted another!  

I also tried the steamed spicy chicken, tofu and other pork bao.  All were so different but equally delicious.  I would have to say the Coca Cola Braised Pork Belly was my first love.

I have not tried the baked bao yet, but the picture makes it look huge.  Some things like cupcakes are good to try once then I never need to eat them again.  Chairman Bao's is my new fav, where I would probably eat over and over and over until I got sick of it.  It is sooooo addicting!  How can I eat regular char siu bao now?!

Thank you Chairman Bao.  I salute you!
author: Carlyn C.

description: I am not sure what to think of this truck. I tried the spicy chicken and pork belly bao. The "bao" actually were more like Peking duck buns, with a round flat bao dough surface being filled with meat and vegetables before able to be bent into taco shell formation. Both bao I tried were just meh. The spicy chicken was too spicy for me, though it had good flavor with the pickled vegetables on top. The pork belly meat was pretty succulent, but did not have very much flavor. I think it would have benefited from a savory sauce more than the pickled vegetables. In any case, the price is ok and the portions were generous, so I will lean towards a 3 more than a 2 star.
author: Dianna D.

description:
This is an elite food truck. 

The pork belly baked bun is highly addictive. 

Also, the wonton chips. 

You can order the belly on a bed of greens for a low carb option.
author: Dan A.

description:
If you haven't noticed, you tend to pay a premium for gourmet food trucks. 

While Chairman Bao is not an exception here, it does favorably compare (price-wise) to what others provide for similar costs. 

A baked bun ($6) can easily be your lunch. It's hamburger-sized, and they're generous with the fillings. 

I gorged here. For $20-something, I bought 

- 2 steamed pork belly buns 
- 1 baked crispy tofu bun
- 1 baked sesame red chicken bun
- 1 baked pork shoulder bun

I can see why the pork belly filling is the most popular, but it's not my favorite. The daikon pickles are fantastic on top, though. 

Crispy tofu was actually really good (I'm not that big on tofu, usually). But It had nice flavors and was substantial without being dense. 

The red chicken had carrot pickles (yum!) and had a healthy kick to it. If you like spicy food (it's not super spicy), I think you'd be happy with this. 

The pork shoulder was my favorite - I really like the slaw on top. Yum! 

I'd eat it again. I wouldn't gorge myself to the brink of reverse osmosis again, though. 

I like Chairman Bao's flirty modern attitude.
author: Ingrid C.

description:
I ate here during the Oakland Eat Real festival. 

OH MAN!!! I was absolutely blown away by their food. I had the steamed pork bun!

Words cannot describe how well all of the flavors worked together. 

If you haven't eaten here yet and are in the bay area, look for their location on Twitter or check out their schedule on their facebook page. 

Just so yummy!
author: Christina C.

description: I booked The Chairman truck for an employee luncheon. I've had 8 different food trucks so far this year, serving 100 people each time. The Chairman was the fastest service of all of them - they put out 200 steamed buns and chips in about one hour. Service was friendly, speedy and the food met rave reviews by our staff. Good marks for catering your event!
author: Nathaniel B.

description:
BAO BAO BAO!

Oh man, this was the first mobile food truck that struck me eye at Off The Grid - Alameda.  My boyfriend and I had the tender pork belly and spicy chicken.  We managed to get the last order since there were only 8 buns left. The only choice was steamed buns for $3.75 ea. It was a little pricey for a little taco looking Bao. 

Despite the price, the pork belly and spicy chicken was really tasty!
The Tender Pork Belly was topped with pickled daikon (delish!). I couldn't help myself from picking off my boyfriend's food. 
Spicy Chicken was topped with pickled carrots & cucumber. I love the heat in it. 

I was a little bummed that it was so tiny though.

The second time I had The Chairman Truck was at SactoMofo 5. Everything was the same and delicious. This time I had the option of baked bao (yum!!). For $2 more, the baked bao had more meat and a little bigger compared to the steamed bun. The only thing that made me "irked" was that the meat was whole pork belly, but when I had it at Off The Grid - Alameda, it was chopped and there was less. I'm assuming it's because they were running out of supplies during that time. 

Nevertheless, I'm overly satisfied. This will always be my "go to" food truck. Tasty & yummy!!
author: Karla Marie D.

description:
One of the best, maybe the best, food truck in the city. Its really expensive though. One order is more like a small h'orderve. You will need an order of four of what ever your ordering to fill you up. 

Go here, I promise it will be simply amazing.
author: Justin S.

description:
HIGHLIGHTS:
Pork belly bun

My favorite of the Asian food trucks I've visited.

Just get the pork belly bun.  Get two, dammit.  You will thank me later.
author: Navin W.

description:
It was Tuesday, and I was filled with the blues because I started feeling like a grown-up. I hate that feeling. I don't turn 25 for a whole month! Distressed as I was, I went to go and meet up with my boyfriend for lunch in that little alley way for bao. He knows I'm a sucker for puns, and the Chairman? I mean, really, how could I NOT go?

I moped around and was generally sad in line while the boyfriend ordered one of each on steamed bao. We took it up to his office to eat, and I was already surprised that it basically looked like a taco, if you described a taco to a person who did not know what a taco was and only had steamed bao in the form of discs. The toppings were pork belly (oh yes, KAKUNI!), coca-cola pork, and spicy chicken. Each bao had its own pickled vegetable to keep it company.

Sullenly, I took a bite. My mood elevated - not to the point of extreme happiness, mind you, but there's something about food that takes a bad day and turns it into "better than expected". The bao was excellent. I was one of those kids that took steamed bao and only ate the bread part, and left the meaty bits behind. This was not the case here. I sincerely wished I was in a better mood while we were in line, because I definitely would have ordered one of each for myself, too. Surprisingly, the pickled veggies were my favorite, but I wouldn't have them without the meat. Honestly, if they just gave me a giant Spirited-Away-sized bao with all the meats and veggies in it, I'd be a happy camper.

I'd definitely come back again. Next time, I'm getting my own portions. I'm surprised my boyfriend shared...well, not really, but I mean, I don't really know if I'd share them...they're perfectly sized when you order three for yourself! The baked buns were much bigger, so if you're looking for a sandwich, that's probably what you want to go for.
author: Robbin A.

description:
After missing OtG so many weeks in a row, I was ecstatic that CB would be coming to Palo Alto for Edgewood Eats. Then they postponed it by a week! So tonight, after much too long of a wait, I finally experienced the awesomeness that is the Bao. Because I'd waited so long, and because I didn't know when I'd get to try it again, I went a little overboard and got 3 steamed buns - pork belly, duck confit, and braised pork. The pork belly was by far the best, with the duck coming in a somewhat close 2nd. The braised pork, very meh. I mean it was good, but compared to the other 2 - I mean, there is no comparison. The bun isn't your typical pork belly bun that you'd get at a Chinese restaurant; it's more...fancy? Fusion? Something like that. Still VERY good, but if you're looking for a taste of Taiwan, this isn't it.

$3 something per bun, and they accept credit cards! Yay.
author: Kathy L.

description:
Get the tender pork belly steam bun!  It's absolutely delicious, especially when the pork contains a little bit of fat (just enough to make the meat really moist, but not enough to make you feel unhealthy).

I think their baked buns are pretty good, but its the steamed ones that make the visit worthwhile.
author: Pat S.

description:
Beware of the pork buns...they are so good they may just break your mouth!  

The baked buns are just under $7 and worth every bite!

A friend of mine always calls me when the truck is around the south bay and I find it almost impossible to say no.

They have two pork buns and I can't figure out which one is better...it's like awesome and awesomer.  They are both so different, but at the same time so similar...as in AWESOME similar.

Try them, you won't regret them =)

If you don't want the meat, just go somewhere else!!! :-P

Happy Eating!
author: Bradley H.

description:
Went to OTG at Fort Mason today. Since it was gloomy outside and looked like it was going to rain, the lines were short. 

We got the steamed bun with sesame chicken. It was good, but it was so small. I most likely wouldn't get it steamed unless I wanted to eat a small portion. Getting the steamed bun when you're hungry is such a tease to the tummy and the taste buds. 

So we decided to get the duck with baked buns. It made a huge difference, size wise too. It was very very good. Very flavorful, it had a hint of lemongrass and a good kick of spice. I love the mixture of the flavor, the mango salad and the sauce. Man, what a combination in flavors.
author: Mandy D.

description:
I officially feel like an idiot for missing out on these baos after seeing this truck countless times at the million street food festivals/food truck events I've attended! The line was just too daunting. Well, my friends, if you see this truck...I have four words for you: STAND IN THE LINE. No joke.

I stood in (no) line thanks to the truck appearing at my workplace, and ordered a spicy chicken steamed bao and a miso-cured tofu steamed bao. Holly hell! WOWZA. Both were so, so flavorful, tender, juicy, and DELICIOUS. I just cannot give enough praise!

I must say that I have no clue whether these steamed buns (there are also baked varieties that resemble a hamburger) represent the authentic Taiwanese version, but I personally don't care...they were THAT good.

Helpful tips:

- The steamed variety is like a mini taco, except wrapped in a steamed "bun." The filling is plentiful.
- The baked "bun" resembles a hamburger and is roughly the size of one. Equally stuffed.
- Two steamed buns or one baked bun makes for the perfect size lunch.
- Siracha hot sauce is available and adds a nice kick if you like heat, but honestly, these goobers were good -- sauced up or not.
author: Mansi A.

description:
I feel that THE CHAIRMAN deserves a re-review so I can add that prestigious 5th star. 

I shared a pork belly bun a few months ago with a friend, but this time went with the Red Sesame Chicken on Baked Bao this go around. I loved loved loved the chicken! The roll is awesome as usual, but the veggies on this roll were more up my alley (carrots, cucumber and onion). The baked bun if far superior to the steamed one, in my opinion.

Can't wait for the next time I see The Chairman... I'm all about the Red Sesame Chicken...

4.75 stars!
author: Joel V.

description:
I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS FOOD TRUCK! 

I've tried a lot of different food trucks/carts and chairman always wins my heart at the end of all my food truck adventures.

My only complaint is that they don't have enough bao on the menu..or a restaurant where I can order a million different buns...but that's just my fattie fantasy kicking in.

Anyways..I always get the steamed buns and everything is honestly amazing..but of course the pork belly is the ultimate. Despite the fact that you're eating a chunk or pure fat it is somehow still refreshingly good.

Flavors of all the baos compliment each other perfectly, customer service has always been friendly..lines can be long but totally worth the wait (they're pretty fast anyways). I recommend everyone in the world to try this place out!

*edit review update*
 FINALLY tried the baked bun! It was okay... definitely preferred the steamed. Baked bun was a little too dry for our tastes, but the steamed buns melt in your mouth just like their "fillings"! If you're hungry just get a couple of em in a steamed instead of one big baked bun... well my suggestion at least =p
author: Melissa C.

description:
Delicious pork belly sandwich. 

The chairman came to Off the Grid in Berkeley this week and the tasty sounding dishes caught my attention. I wasn't too hungry, so I just got the pork belly sandwich which I thought was pretty good value for $6, especially compared to what is offered in other food trucks. 

The sweet Chinese bun and daikon worked perfectly with the crispy on the outside, tender on the inside, and deliciously fatty pork belly. It was simply scrumptious. 

I will keep an eye for The Chairman every Wednesday.
author: Augusto T.

description: Love, love, love the baked buns with the tofu. With a drink, it's a whole meal for like $8! The bun is so soft, the tofu is so flavorful, generous, and hearty, AND they have diet coke! I'm always excited when I see this big red truck.
author: Allison M.

description:
Probably my favorite food truck in SF.

Favorites? The steamed buns. All are good but I love the chicken and pickled veggies combination. 

Also, considering the long lines that usually await this place, they turn over orders quick. THUS, 5 stars from me!
author: Teese N.

description:
Baked  bao sliders:
Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso
Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro
They taste just like what they say they are :-)
Definitely will try the duck next time :-)
author: Arissa C.

description:
I still don't understand this food truck craze, but if one of these babies is close by and I am hungry, I'm willing to give it a try.  

They were out of the baked buns, so I got a steamed spicy chicken.  It was small for $3.25, but tasty.  The vegetables (pickles and carrots) were pickled asian style, and the meat was juicy.  The bun ended up being soaked a bit with grease, which I assume is what made it spicy, which would be considered tasty for some people, but not for me.
author: Shinny L.

description:
I definitely know now why there is so much hype around this truck.  They came to West Sacramento this weekend for trucktoberfest.   

It was really hot that day and it was probably about 95 ish???   Well I waited in line for about 10 min or so which felt like forever as I was sweating my ass off.   

The wait was well worth it as I got the spicy chicken with pickled carrots and cucumber I believe.  The pickled veggies were done amazingly well and the chicken had a nice kick to it.   The sandwich was $6.00 and well worth the amount.   

My only hesitation to giving them a 5 star is I'd like to try each food truck at least twice before giving them a 5 star review.  So until then Chairman I will wait for you in SAC!
author: Eric K.

description:
I always get the tofu on steamed bun.  

If I had only one thing to eat the rest of my life, this would be a contender

It's so good!

It was especially good today when their food truck was at Truck Stop between Fremont and First on Mission St.
author: Foodlover B.

description: Love this truck! I became a fan of them at Ft. Mason in SF! My favorite thing to order is their great steamed buns with the tender Coca Cola braised pork with the tangy slaw and topped with some mustarda I'm actually on my way to alameda to have some now! You must try these guys if you ever see them! Delicious!
author: Kayla T.

description:
MMMeow for Mao! Jokes. 

There was a long line, but food comes out pretty quickly and efficiently.  
We ordered the coca cola pork, the chicken, and the pork belly: all steamed.  We also ordered the chicken and coca cola pork on the baked buns, since we were hungry :3  The coca cola pork really wasn't special.  It was slightly salty and, while the meat wasn't dry, it wasn't juicy either.  The coleslaw with it was meh, but didn't really balance out the saltiness of the pork.  On the other hand, the chicken was great!  It was juicy, spicy, and the pickled carrots went really well with it! Definitely worth trying.  As for the pork belly... Holy christ.  I find myself sitting in bed just mouthwatering over it at this very moment, not being able to find the words to describe it.  This one was by far the winner, as the meat itself was sweet, succulent, and had the perfect amount of fat.  Now, I devoured it to quickly to admire any sauces, but if there was some, it was damn good.  Also, the pickled daikon with it... I would vote it as the tastiest pairing I've had in awhile.  The steamed buns were pretty good, and were about the size of the buns you get when eating peking duck (don't be confused with the pancakes, I'm talking about the Americanized buns).  The baked buns resembled that of char siu bao, except slightly toasted.  

I'm just angry that we didn't order the pork belly with the baked buns, which is three times the size of the steamed buns.
author: Stefanie T.

description:
That was damn good. 

The steamed bun is amazing. Pork belly is damn nice and the other one with braised pork is...so flavorful as well. 

The line at the Sunset Fair was short so it was nice to get some buns.
author: Nina Y.

description:
One word - AMAZING!

The best pork belly bao I ever tried and so far my favorite food truck ever! I will follow you on twitter and like on Facebook. :)

Your true fan,
author: Anelya S.

description: usually food trucks are seriously 50/50. this one is memorable. the steam bao pork belly was the one to try. the braised pork i got was just okay a little bit dry though. if i go the the off the gird again i will go get another pork belly. this time ill try the bun.
author: Lisa V.

description:
Chairman Mao. You can have the little red book to worship. That's all yours for your delusional mind and for you to use to brainwash your peeps.

Chairman Bao, that's for me to worship. Oh how I dream of your soft braised pork belly... nestled in a fluffy white bun... or slightly sweet chewy baked bun, topped with vinegary crunchy daikon. Chairmon Bao, you make me look forward to checking the Edgewood Eats Facebook Page religiously to see when you're going to bless me with another trip down the Peninsula so I can get in line and pay my moola to experience gastronomical heaven. 

I hate the gym but you're inspired me to do cardio on Sundays so I can accrue my caloric deficit to gorge myself on your delightful baos... religiously...bi-weekly...
author: Vicky L.

description:
WOW so delicious! My first time ever... had the steam bun with 

#1: Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds 
#2: Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro
#3: Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso

Happy Tummy!
author: Jane D.

description:
$3.75 for a steamed not even authentic Chinese style "bun" with meat and some pickled veggies inside? What is this, a cupcake?

I must say, Chairman Bao gave me mixed feelings as I stand here staring at the remains of what was my $20 lunch (hey, I try to get everything in case I never get to go back again ...) which included the pork belly, the braised pork, their "new" spicy chicken and some vegetarian option.

Although they are tasty and creative, they are by no means authentic. The ingredients are not used in any Chinese cooking involving the other ingredients in the same bun and these aren't even real "buns" since they are actually breading for peking duck or chicken - a traditional Beijing dish where you put the roast duck or chicken inside the sweet wedged bread sliced down the middle with some hoisin sauce and green onions.

That aside, $3.75? really? That's quite pricey for something that doesn't blow me out of the waters or make me full on the first one. At least with a cupcake you're full of sugar and happily buzzing on high after.

The steamed buns are not as tender, chewy and sweet as they could be and you can find this at almost any Chinese restaurant that serves Peking duck. The baked bun is almost $7!! Looks like a hamburger, is way too heavy on the bread to meat ratio (as in ... too much bread) and it isn't even soft and buttery like what you would find at a Dim Sum place.

I'm not complaining that I got to try it out, of course, because now I know what it is and what the rave is ... but is it really worth it? Not if it's not around the corner and you can buy a lot tastier things with $20.
author: Lorrie M.

description: Awesome baos. I love the chicken and pork belly. Can't go wrong. Prices are reasonable and food is just flat out amazing.
author: Yasi N.

description:
Call me a true-believer of Chairman Bao!  I lined up with the Chairman at 11am OTG Alameda.  The line went quickly and the Baos were in our hungry little hands after a short wait.

We had the Pork Belly - steamed and baked.  Wife liked the steam while I was more partial to the baked.  

The Chairman truck sets the standard for movable feasts!  Hail to the Chairman!
author: Scott L.

description:
Decided on the Baked Pork Belly and Baked Braised Pork and was so glad I did.  The Pork Belly was delicious and the Bao was perfect.  The Braised Pork was also solid and the slaw added a nice crunch to the sandwich.  Both Bao's were soft and fresh and almost melted in your mouth.  

Found the truck at OTG in Alameda today.  So happy there were there.
author: Lon H.

description:
PORK BELLY with PICKLED DAIKON = AMAZING!! pork belly is incredibly tender, moist, delicious. and the daikon is great! i'm not a huge fan of pickled things, but this one is def worth it. The bun is like a huge hamburger bun but buttered and toasted lightly. omgasm.

I also got the
DUCK bun thing, which was good too with shreds of daikon in a white tender moist bun. Pretty good too.

Tip: Go at the top of the hour (or whenever they're open) because the line gets long very very soon afterwards!! 

Def worth it. Flew all the way across America for Chairman Bao Yums.
author: Christine L.

description: So delicious! Tender pork belly is to die for. They had s special tonight of clam chowder. Soooooooooooo good!
author: Constanza j.

description:
We had the pleasure of the cousin who introduced us to the food truck. The steamed buns are amaaaazing.

We brought home 6 steamed buns and 1 baked bun. My brother stared at it for 5 minutes and could even decide where to start! I don't think I can decide which was the best one. The only one I did not try was the tofu one but I bet that was is as delicious as it sounds.

We will definitely be coming back to chairman when we are back in SF.

The SF Streat Food park was pretty calm at 8pm. So if you check out this place on a weekday at 8pm. All the surrounding food trucks have probably mellowed out. There are places to sit,which is a plus and a plethora of free street parking spaces. Even at 8pm, this place had the most patrons than any other food truck on the cluster. That tells you that the chairman is a popular place to eat at =)
author: Kimmy C.

description:
Utmost food truck awesome-ness. Not only did it take Chinese fusion to a different level, it also introduces "gua bao", the white buns that we eat in Taiwan, to the masses in SF. (I'm sure there are other places that have it but definitely haven't seen it in a popular place like this).

First off, all of their items are awesome, but you can only eat so much in a setting. If you want to try more, get the steamed buns -- they're like a slightly big taco and you can easily down 2, if not 3 in one go. The baked buns are a full-sized sandwich, so when you know which filling you like best, go for those.

Do NOT pass on the pork belly. It's pure heavenly with the pickled daikons -- and I love that their daikons are not overly salty like the stuff they sell in Chinese markets. The daikons are crunchy, savory, and they're just the perfect match for the super savory pork belly.

The coca-cola braised pork with mustard and cabbage is pretty good too, but they pale next to the pork belly. Don't get me wrong, it's still *really* good in food truck terms, but the pork belly just takes you straight to heaven.

I still have yet to try the spicy chicken, but word is, it's good too. Heck, is there anything that's not good from this truck?

If this truck passes through your neighbourhood, be sure to give it a try!!
author: Alice C.

description: This is by far my favorite food truck ever. I always get the pork belly baos. I love them and they always taste just as good as the first time I tried them. Chairman you are the best
author: Jeannette H.

description: We attended a holiday party that was catered by Chairman Bao. Food was delicious.  A great idea for a party.
author: Trudy D.

description:
I often frequent the food trucks around my work place and thought I had a pretty good grasp of food truck quality food. I've been to a lot that I like, a lot there were just ok and a few I hated but they were all "food truck quality." It was relative. Besides the dirty taco trucks that I love, food trucks can't compare to full sized kitchens. No way! Or so I thought. That is until I ate at The Chairman. Their Pork Belly Baos were a revelation.

The bun was a little sweet and it's elasticity kept it intact. No crumbly bun here. The pork belly was amazingly soft but kept it's form while maintaining a nice bite. The sour pickled daikon radishes perfectly contrasted and complimented the sweet, tender pork. This wasn't just food truck food anymore. This was better than most things I've had at Chinese restaurants. Just like In-and-Out transcends fast food, The Chairman transcends food trucks. I could have died there and been happy. Seriously amazing.
author: Anthony O.

description:
Best food truck in bay area.
The name and logo is freaking genius. That's worth 3 stars alone.
The pork belly is amazing. Steamed or baked bun, don't matter, both delicious. Just make sure to get the pork belly. 

This is what all food trucks should aspire to be.
author: Wes C.

description:
After spotting the Chairman Truck driving by in Emeryville, I made a mental note almost immediately to check out this well decorated, avant garde food truck. Fate has it, we met again at Off the Grid Fort Mason San Francisco. We quickly learnt through our fellow yelpers t hat this is the bun place. True to that, this Taiwanese snack mutated food truck contains miso cured tofu with steamed buns that melt in your mouth, the baked buns are soft tasty and the pork belly! My friend didn't like pickles in general, so we picked up the pork belly and ate it solo. Delicious! Munch munch. Too bad we didn't have the path of fate to meet the duck, but hell to the yes, we will be back soon. 

Double shot : sweet potato thai tea fat face popsicle on the left hand and then chairman on the right. I feel I can take over the world.
author: Dilys S.

description:
I ventured out to Palo Alto, especially for Chairman Bao. I was really looking forward to the spiced duck bun, but they didn't have any duck that day. They had the crispy garlic tofu with miso greens, red sesame chicken with scallions and bok choy, tender pork belly with pickled daikons, and braised pork belly with some sort of slaw. I ordered one of each (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sT8TRzofJym5w0khZkOJhw?select=k7H8rqrkz4OyzF3kgmrwhA), for about $3.75 for each steamed bun. The baked bun was about $6, which I thought sounded a little overpriced so I didn't get it. I also prefer my buns steamed, not baked. 

I was very impressed with how delicious the buns tasted! The tender pork belly with pickled daikons (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sT8TRzofJym5w0khZkOJhw?select=NUIdqZY892mJlFIudDEocw) and the crispy garlic tofu with miso greens were my favorites. The pork belly slices were predominantly fat, but that's what pork belly is all about. It was gluttonous, but oh so good! It was very well prepared and full of flavor. The pickled daikon was crisp and served as a perfect contrast to the jelly pork belly. The crispy garlic tofu with miso greens was very refreshing. The tofu was soft inside, crispy on the outside, and complemented very well with the miso greens.

The lady who took my order was very nice. She wasn't pushy and allowed me time to decide on what I wanted--even if it was everything on the menu. I assume that everything is already prepped, so it didn't take them very long to put my order together. If Chairman Bao ever makes it out to your area, I recommend giving them a try!
author: Lien T.

description:
Checked out the Chairman Bao truck at SactoMofo 4, where they easily had one of longest (if not THE longest) lines at the event. Luckily the hour wait wasn't in vain. I got a steamed Coca-Cola braised pork bun and my friend got the baked pork belly bun... both of the buns were pretty killer, I understand why the Chairman truck is so popular.

The reason I'm not giving 5 stars is the ridonkulous wait time, which was made worse by them forgetting my order. I asked them, after 10+ people behind me got their order, where mine was... they said my ticket was dropped on the floor so they weren't aware of it. Hustle them buns, yo, I'm hungry!!
author: Summer M.

description:
This food truck is amazing!!!  The steamed spicy chicken bun is our favorite item, although all of the buns, steamed or baked, are extremely delicious! Especially with the pickled veggies on the freshly baked bun.  My mouth is watering just thinking about it.

We're looking forward to trying their restaurant up in the Tenderloin soon!  This food truck is by far our favorite!
author: ami s.

description:
Today marked my first time trying out the Chairman. I ordered a braised pork steamed bun w/ mustard seeds and cabbage. The meat was sweet, savory, and flawlessly cooked. The cabbage tasted very fresh and gave a pleasant crunch to the otherwise soft/savory bite. There was just enough of a mustard presence, which works well as the primary spice. The bun was smooth, soft, and a little sweet -- very good. 

My steamed pork bun ran me $3.75, which I find to be an appropriate price. I wish there was a little more meat tacked on, but maybe next time I'll get lucky. 

I also like how The Chairman sells 16oz cans of Tasco coconut juice for just $2. It's very refreshing and is a legit form of sustenance.

Next time I'll come back for the pork belly :)
author: Nick P.

description:
My favorite food truck.  If they're around... I'm eating what they're selling.  
My favorite is their pork belly on their steamed buns.  Filled with delicious pork and pickled veggies.   I'm not really into their baked buns, the steamed is WAY better.
author: Sam C.

description:
Chairman Bao has an interesting concept of serving steam pork buns. they use an open bun, taco shell style. unfortunately it's a concept i'm not enamored of. 

is it evolved from the beijing duck ways of peeling a steam bun to get thin layers of wrapping buns to put the crispy duck skins in?....

buns filling options ("steam 3.25-3.75, baked 6 ish)
-tender pork belly with daikon
-brised pork with spicy cabbage & preserved mustard seeds
-red sesame chicken with pickled cucumbes and spicy ?

foodnotes:
-tender pork belly has the most meat. best value.
-interesting filling ideas, not wowed.
-might try a duck to satisfy my duck fetish.
-takes 5 minutes waiting to get bun after ordering.
author: Victor G.

description: We got the bao chips, coca-cola braised pork on a baked bun, spicy chicken on a steamed bun, and the tofu on a steamed bun. All were excellent, but I preferred steamed buns. The baked buns are more like a typical sandwich roll and one is enough for lunch. If you order the steamed buns you will need 2-3 for a lunch (but they are only $3 and change). I prefer eating more meat and veggies than bread, so the steamed rolls were a better option for me. I thought everything was delicious, but I especially liked the chicken. Fast service and the line for the trick wasn't too long when I went. I'll be back!
author: Christine B.

description:
OMG ! Must try this truck!
Coca cola braised taco !
And the pork belly taco !
Do it! 
Go now!
author: Roman J.

description: We were at Off the Grid, and visited the The Chairmen Truck ... long line as well. I remember I saw this food truck on TV once, I forgot which channel anyways, we ordered the popular Pork Belly Steamed Bun with pickled daikon. The bun was really warm and soft, pork belly tender. But come on ... $3.75 for a steamed bun like a size of a White Castle? I think that's just too expensive for food truck steamed bun. It was good, but not that good.
author: Sandi C.

description:
This is one of my favorite food trucks.  Whether it's the tender pork belly or the braised pork, I'll get two orders of it steamed or a larger baked glaze bun.  If you're cold, try the clam chowder with bacon and mushrooms to warm you up.  They are a bit expensive for the portions, but that is the price of the novelty of these Taiwanese good eats.  

Lines are long, so be prepared to go early or wait.  Service is fast and efficient.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I waited over an hour in line at the Sacramento Mobile Food Festival back in April for this truck.

And all I can say is.....DAMN! IT WAS WORTH IT!

It's all about the Pork Belly with daikon.  So juicy and delicious, that if I wasn't worried about my health, I would eat over and over again.

Wish this truck would drive through the Central Valley more often!
author: Alma R.

description:
I've eaten here on several occasions in South San Francisco.
Today, there were at the Soma StrEat Food Park. Yay! 
I already knew what I wanted and it's really hard to stray away from PERFECTION. So, I ordered 2 steamed pork belly buns - my fav! I added a nice squirt of sriraccha, and it just made the day. I crave those steamed buns all the time.

My gf had the miso tofu stemed bun. I eat miso, tengjan and tofu all the time, so I didn't feel like getting one. She made it look sooo good. It also was quite a substantial meal for being tofu! I'm totally getting one next time. 

We can totally agree that this is SF's #1 food truck!
author: Rosie M.

description:
This was my second visit to Off the Grid in Concord.  The atmosphere was laid-back, with a folk singer playing acoustic guitar.

Had the pork belly with baked bun.  The bun is like the outside of a baked char siu bao, but the size of hamburger roll.  Pork belly is the same meat as bacon, but braised or roasted instead of fried (and not smoked).  So you have tender strips of lean and fat, and that is why the meat is so filling and rich tasting.  It has a little seasoning, maybe a hint of Chinese 5 spice.  The tanginess of the pickled daikon on top is a refreshing complement and helps to cut the richness.   

I asked the guy taking orders if the spicy chicken was really spicy, and he said no, it was mild.  So I ordered it on the baked roll and got a wonderfully flavored bun filled with medium-spicy (to me) chicken cooked in a sauce with complex Asian flavors including the advertised toasted sesame puree and I think hoisin sauce.  The pickled carrots and cucumber were good, but I wish the vegetables had been a little crisper.

This is a great contribution to the Asian food offerings in Concord, better than the first OTG visit, and I will definitely be back.
author: Priscilla Y.

description:
food: 3/5

Nice to try this asian fusion truck, but will not be buying again

I've heard a lot about chairman bao (I guess chairman truck now??), so I decided to try their steamed and baked baos at off the grid. I would have to say that each of the elements of the baos are very good by themselves. Example is that the pork belly, toppings, and the baos are made very well. I just don't think they should be combined into a sandwich type deal. Good concept but doesnt work for me.  But honestly, the prices are what really turns me off. I paid $6 and what I got was a snack portion of food when I was expecting more of a meal. If you want better baos and chinese food, I suggest you just visit an actual chinese establishment. Growing up with chinese food in the bay area and also trying out various fusion places, the chairman truck did not meet my expectations at all.
author: Cecile S.

description: Really loved The Chairman Truck!! I got the Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum in a steamed bun and it was flavorful and tasty without being too heavy. The steamed bun was also a nice change from the traditional baked bun and everything was reasonably priced. Definitely worth the try!
author: Arathi S.

description:
I feel like I've visited a fair amount of food trucks and it's safe to say that The Chairman is probably one of the better ones or maybe the best! I love The Chairman! 

The steamed bao's are such a treat. We sampled four of them and they did not disappoint. The tender pork belly, braised pork, chicken and tofu. There is some thought to each bao with a good balance of flavors. There's some saltiness, sweetness and crunch! The baked ones are just as delicious but they are more like a size of a burger. There's also a hint of sweetness to the bun too.

The favorite is the baked bun with the tender pork belly, pickled daikon and green shiso. You bite into it and get this nice fatty pork belly flavor accented with a vinegary, salty crunch from the pickled daikon. Yum. 

There's also some chips on the menu which have some seaweed and sprinkles of  togarashi spices. Great to munch on while you wait for your order.
author: L L.

description:
This place is pretty legit, if only for the braised pork belly bun. Wrapped in a large fluffy white bun, the pork belly's tenderness and flavor really stands out, without the addition of other items. I actually picked off all of the pickled daikon and ate it separately.

I am amazed that the could charge $4 for a single bun, and that people were ordering them in multiples of five and more. I decided not to get caught up in the hype, and one was more than enough for me.
author: .Alan Y.

description:
Was not super impressed with the pork belly bun. Also the beer battered ribs bun had way too much slaw on it. Really messy to eat while walking/standing.

Coincidentally, is this the food truck that Eddie Huang complained about for taking the name from his dish? I should give this truck an extra star just for that.
author: Sherry L.

description:
My coworker told me how one of his friends waited 2 hours in line for Chairman Bao's, and it was totally worth the wait.  I was kind of skeptical, but having already heard great things about this place, I was eager to try it out.  Luckily, I only had to wait only 10-15 minutes to sample their goods.  My conclusion:  Chairman Bao's is worth a 10-15 minute wait at best.  If I had to wait longer, I wouldn't.  

I tried all 3 buns: the pork belly, braised beef and the sesame chicken steamed buns.  My favorite was the sesame chicken one.  But, that doesn't really say much since I wouldn't care to eat it again.  Also, for paying close to $12 dollars for 3 small buns, it really isn't a bargain.  In my opinion, not worth the hype.
author: Jenn W.

description:
The Chairman is probably my FAVORITE food truck. How can you not be obsessed with these amazing little buns?! 

Yesterday I had the pork belly and the tofu in the smaller, steamed buns--they practically melt in your mouth. Realistically I could probably indulge in twelve dozen, but I was trying to make socially acceptable choices at the time. If I had been riding solo, WHO KNOWS what could have happened?! 

If you're ever walking by this majestic truck, do yourself a favor and wait in the line, even if it's questionably long. It's absolutely worth it.
author: Meredith C.

description:
I finally had a chance to try Chairman Bao after food trucks started coming for SJ eats weekly on Saturday evenings in Downtown San Jose!

Basically you have an option of having your bun steamed ($3.75) or baked ($6.25). The steamed bun most resembles the taste and size of a Peking duck bun while the baked bun resembles the taste of a baked BBQ pork bun that you get at Dim Sum and the size of a small burger bun. While the baked bun is heavier in terms of being greasy, it is much tastier and definitely more worth it for your money.

I was told that the pork belly was the specialty and the most popular item so I opted for that. The pickled daikon paired with the meat inside the bun was a perfect pairing to offset the sweetness of the bun and saltiness of the meat. 

Tip: Sometimes they run out of the baked buns before the end of the night so even if you're thinking of trying other food trucks around, hop into Chairman Bao's line first to ensure that you'll get a baked bun because it's so much more worth it and tastier than a steamed one
author: Stacey L.

description:
Pork belly steamed and baked coca cola

Baos, baos, baos, baos, baos! Since I couldn't decide between baked or steamed I got both. One pork belly steamed bun and a baked coca cola braised bun. Pork buns are always the best. The steamed bun tasted mellow and light. The flavors weren't too overwhelming. The daikon was a nice way to balance out the tender pork. The baked buns was similar to a burger like bun. The braised pork didn't have any coca cola flavor?? It was oozing with juices though. The baked buns are definitely a lot bigger than the steamed buns. The steamed buns are like a nice appetizer while the baked buns are more like an entree.
author: Virginia Y.

description:
Had a spicy chicken sandwich here. It was amazing.

Bursting with flavor, good pickles (very sweet and tangy) to balance, and two amazing sauces (a spicy red oil sauce and a sesame paste type sauce). It was on a bun, not a bao, which I was surprised about - but even though I was looking forward to the bao, their regular bun was also totally fresh, chewy, and delicious.

Absolutely awesome, would eat again.
author: Adam W.

description:
Update:

My second time putting that delicious ass baked pork belly bun in my mouth and it's gotten even more mouth watering! I don't understand. It's seriously amazing. It's the BEST burger/bun/sandwich I've had yet. And trust me, I've had many things in my mouth. (Ignore that unintentional slutty innuendo.) 

That pickled daikon is genius and I don't even like pickles OR daikons LOL. My only gripe is the chubby line. Be prepared to wait. You should order as much as you can because getting back in line is not fun. But like Boiling Crab, I'll always wait for that heavenly grub. I'm drooling just thinking about it. Damnit.
author: Abigail D.

description:
Woah! A taste of this bun suddenly I was like, "Am I in an outdoors market in China, bargaining with the street vendor?"  No.  Good.  Because this bun did not remind me of a Chinese market at all.

Judging solely on the food, it's pretty good.  During SJ Eats, we bought one of everything on the menu - steamed bun with chicken, steamed bun with pork, and steamed bun with tofu and miso greens, in addition to a baked bun with pork.

The steamed bun was soft and fluffy.  The slight sweet taste offset the saltiness of the chicken/pork.  The chicken bun was a bit spicy, but with goof flavor and the chicken was very tender.  The pork belly bun was very, very good!  The pork belly melted in my mouth, and the pickled daikon added crunchiness to the softness of everything else.

What I did not like were the steamed bun with tofu and miso greens and the baked bun with pork belly.  The tofu bun lacked flavor, even with the miso greens.  Even though the tofu looked fried, everything was just a bland, soft mush.

The baked pork belly bun was way too dry, and the portion was simply too big.  Not saying "too big" as in it is worth the price tag - I meant too big in terms of having to chew the same dry meat and flavor for an extended period of time... Eeek.

Overall, I don't think this is something that worth waiting for two hours for, even though the steamed buns were very tasty.  I could probably get something with similar flavor at a sit-down Chinese restaurant.  If the wait wasn't two hours long, it's worth a try.
author: Peggy S.

description:
My favorite food truck in SF.   It's hard to find this type of food(unless you are in manhattan or Asia). 

Favorite ones are:  steamed bao with crispy tofu and baked bun with pork belly.  I only wish their steam bao was softer.
author: So S.

description:
We caught them at Off the Grid in Fort Mason while visiting. We were there shortly after 5, and the line was only 3 people long, but steadily got longer and longer. 
Get the pork belly steamed bun. Actually, get several. The food is worth all the hype. All. Of. It.
author: Evie P.

description:
How much I love Chairman.....
I usually brown bag my lunch. But there were way too many times that I left my brown bag lunch aside and rushed to the Chairman truck at 11:29am to get my Bao. And I purposely "forget" to "bring my lunch" If I know they are going to be around at the office or my client's site in advance. 
My face - lighted up when I heard Chairman would be my lunch~ 

My all-time favorite is always the pork belly with the big bun. The pork belly is crispy outside and it's tender inside. The picked daikon is just perfect to cut the fattiness. And I think only the big bun can hold up to the pork belly (I had that on steam bun before but I just didn't like it - or maybe it's because I just prefer to have a BIG PIECE OF PORK BELLY. HA HA HA)

The tofu one was a surprise to me when I first had it. It was way too flavorful then I expected. I thought it could be very blend but it was not the case. 

The braised cola pork, in my opinion, is the best when it's on the steam bun. But I have friends and coworkers who believe it's best on the baked bun. 

When the truck first started - the menu has the duck confit on the steam bun BUT TO THIS DATE I STILL HAVE NOT HAD IT. When the truck first started - it was on the menu but it's always "out." Now it's not even on the menu (had a red tape over). Not sure if they would bring this back or not since it's still on the menu on their website. Ugh. that's one bao that I have yet to try!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Tried this place one day when Off the Grid was hosting lunch at Minna & 5th St. This place is quite unique! Some what of an Asian Fusion kind of thing.

You can either chose steamed buns (about the size of a slider) or baked buns (size of a burger) of each of the entree choices. I would say a good sized meal is 2 steamed buns or 1 baked. But I was adventurous and wanted to try both so I got one steamed and one baked. Personally, I like the steamed bun more just because it is soft and unique while Baked buns are more crispy (like a toasted bread).

Now, the pork belly is a must try! I got it in a baked bun. It was so juicy that when I picked it up, the burger was basically dripping. They put a decent amount of meat in there and pickled daikon for flavoring. The daikons add a little sweetness to the overall salty meal.

In the steamed bun, I ordered Spicy Chicken and wow, I wish I ordered another one. The bun was so soft and it soaked up all the flavor of the chicken! But honestly, I think I would have enjoyed the pork belly more too if I got it in a steamed but... But remember, steamed buns are really small, so if you are looking to try different flavors order a couple of them.

The line for this truck is... decent. Usually have about 5-10 people waiting at OTG on Minna (which is a lot because some trucks have no line at all). But I have seen a pretty long line when the truck is at OTG at Fort Mason on Fridays! But if the food truck has a long line, must mean it is good and worth a try.
author: Jessica L.

description:
With over 1000 reviews, I know mine is completely unnecessary. BUT I CAN'T STOP THINKING ABOUT THE DELICIOUS STEAMED BUN! 

Stopped by the Chairman on a visit to Off the Grid. It was our first stop of the night and the line was fine. As was the pork belly. It was fiiinneeeeeeeeeee. Caramelized, hot, steamy, fluffy, refreshing. This bun was all that and I truly enjoyed it more then the bun at Momofuku.

This style of bao is pretty non-existent up in Portland so I guess I will have to keep dreaming about the Chairman.
author: Leah H.

description:
Want to try something new and different? Then give Chairman Bao Bun a go... YUM! 

Definitely worth every penny, portions are decent and the flavor combinations are outstanding! 

My sister and I had the pork belly baked bun with daikon. OMG! lol... it made me just forget all my troubles that day... I was relaxed and just in the zone eating the sandwich. The pork belly was tasty! and the daikon added a nice crunch and tang. Combined all of that with the bun they use and well it was pretty amazing! 

My buddy had the red sesame chicken and pickled carrots, his looked amazing also but I was too distracted with my pork belly. 

Love this truck! Come to San Jose lol...or closer to San Jose. : D
author: Clara H.

description:
I finally tracked the truck down! The pork belly was great! So was the cola braised pork and the chicken. I could eat 5 in one sitting, which brings me to why it is not 5 stars....kind of expensive. That's an expensive lunch out of a food truck which I need to now eat in my car. 

Don't get me wrong, I liked it but it won't be an every day treat given the price.
author: Steve L.

description:
Drool...

Get the pork belly! It's fatty and super oily but you only live once, right? 
Braised pork was pretty awesome as well! Buns are soft, flavors are complex and complement well together. 

Steamed buns are $3.75 each, a little pricey but worth every penny and the ridiculous lines.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Vivian D.

description: I was driving to lunch and spotted the Chairman's truck without a line (only because it was 2:00 pm) and I immediately blew-off my other plans.  ALWAYS great food and equally good prices.  I recommend checking their website-- they list where they will be for the coming week. You and your stomach will not be disappointed.
author: Cary G.

description:
Before I met the Chairman, I was a closet pork belly lover.  I was ashamed to admit that I love that fatty, salty part of the pig and how it gave me such pleasure to bite into its greasy goodness.

I first experienced these dreamy bites of heaven at the Eat Real Festival last year.  And as I stood in the long line with the other pork belly lovers, I got in touch with my pork belly pride, and realized i wasn't alone.  It was ok to eat it.  It was ok to love it.  I should no longer be afraid to show my true self!

Since then, they have extended their reach into the East Bay.  I've been able to get my Pork Belly Bao fix when they take a post at the Newark and City Beach events.

All the buns are good.  The baked ones are bigger and just as yummy.  One of my favorite trucks by far!
author: Teresa P.

description: This truck is the reason I started following food trucks.  I love those steamy buns with pork belly, chicken, beef, whatever you wanna put on them!  It is all sooo good!  The only reason I didn't give them 5 stars is the price.  I think it's a little high for a food truck.  Otherwise, any time I see this truck I will go straight there and order 3 or your steamed buns!
author: Elena N.

description:
My friend highly recommended Chairman Bao's buns during today's Moveable Feast in San Jose. We were there right before it opened and it was the only cart with a line forming already! 

I ordered the steamed red sesame chicken and steamed braised pork. Both were tasty!! I thought a steamed bun would be like an actual chao see bao-type bun, but it was more of a pocket bun. Nonetheless, I still enjoyed them. Braised pork was okay but I added some sriracha sauce which made it so much better. I liked the red sesame chicken more for its own kick of spiciness and delicious carrots on top. Each steamed bun was $3.75...overpriced, yes? I would like to try the baked bun one day but I wouldn't care if I didn't since it's $6.75 each.

Chairman Bao is expensive but it's definitely worth a try!
author: Pansy L.

description:
This may be the best tasting & quality food that I have ever had from a food truck since the "craze".
I had a steamed pork belly w/ pickled daikon and braised pork.
I must say it was wonderful porky goodness. It was the bomb and worth $3 something a piece. Any time The Chairman is in my hood I'll be there to get a fix. ;P
If you are lucky enough to get the duck, GET IT IN!!!
If not, the braised pork on a steamed bun. 
(Off the grid Hayward)
author: Lauren E.

description: Speedy service, tasty little buns. And conveniently located for once in the middle of downtown Palo Alto. Went for the crispy miso tofu on a steamed bun, and wish I would have gotten at least two more to continue enjoying them. Speed, quality, and great flavor. You really can't ask for any more than that from a food truck.
author: Amy S.

description: You'd think Chairman Bao would understand the plight of the workers and not charge $3.75 for a bun half the size of your fist. It would take 4 of these things to make me full. I guess they really are trying to keep true to the cultural revolution and keep the masses hungry. Still, the decently fluffy buns and flavorful fillings have me bowing to chairman bao. Excuse me while I go melt down all my metal belongings so I can afford more buns.
author: Monte H.

description: This place was really great.  We had the pork belly bun and the braised pork bun too. It was nice and juicy which I liked.  It was $7.00 for both of them, but definitely worth the money.
author: Keven W.

description:
Get baked not steamed!  Baked buns are pricier but BIGGER and better!

The tender pork belly with daikon pickles is heavenly.  The crispy garlic tofu with miso greens is divine.  I'm usually not one to rave over anything involving healthy green things, but putting those miso-soaked greens alongside the crispy garlic tofu is genius!

I can stomach the slightly high price tag for the yummy-stuffed buns.  But, the 45+ minute wait at Fridays' Off the Grid at Fort Mason or looking up where they are at other times makes it just a little bit less fabulous . . .
author: Christina L.

description:
Baked bun is the way to go, hands down! I split each of the following today with a buddy and had the following thoughts on each item:

Spicy Chicken Baked bun - 5 stars
Perfect mix of spice on a delicious roll, on point, can't go wrong. If you don't want pork, don't hesitate to order this guy, you'll love it

Pork Belly Baked bun - 4.5 stars
My friend thought it was better than the chicken but I disagree. The taste and texture weren't my thing. Good but not GREAT.

Coca-cola Pork - 3.5 stars
taste was pretty good, just very small and not a value ($3.75 for two bites?) not my thing. Decent but go with the baked bun unless you love steamed rolls.

All in all I'd say a must try in the city, pick a meat and go with the baked bun and you won't be disappointed.


AND last but not LEAST get there EARLY! we got there at 1120 and had our food in 15 min, line was crazy long by 1140 tho

1000th review?! i'm honored
author: Michael R.

description:
WOW! My wife kidnapped me and took me to SF last Sunday to sample their food.

This was definitely the best food I've ever had off of a truck.

I had the larger baked bun with the Coca Cola marinate pulled pork with the mustard slaw. So moist and tasty and with all the other food I could only eat half of it. Four hours later it was still just as fantastic. I also tried the steamed one with the spicy chicken with pickled carrots on top and like it a lot but I enjoyed the pork more. I also had the steamed version of pork belly and that came with pickled daikon which was perfect with the richness of the belly. My wife who has had the pleasure of trying everything previously just had one steamed one with the moso glazed tofu and marinated bok choy.

I wish the truck was in areas that I frequent but it was totally worth the trip across the Bay Bridge.

Some of the best pork I've ever had.

And one of the cutest trucks I've ever seen too.
author: Marco M.

description:
I LOVE Chairman. They have flavors that range from, light, creamy and tangy, from juicy strong savory flavors. I love the pork belly, and the tofu especially. 

I think the price is a bit too much but since we're in San Francisco in which is now considered the most expensive place in the United States, I guess I'll let it pass..But I think the big pass was it's amazing flavors. Very good and we get it often.
author: Elaine N.

description:
Finally got some chairman bao! So happy. 

I ordered the baked braised pork with cabbage - pretty good. I loved the mustard seeds scattered about. The baked bun was also super good. 

We also got the pork belly on steamed bun - oh my freaking goodness! This was soo amazing. I loved the slab of pork belly - not too lean not too fat. The sauce was perfect and the pickled daikon went so well with it. Next time I'm getting this in baked form. 

Finally, got the spicy chicken; really spicy but may be indigestion inducing. I didn't enjoy this one as much as the porks...but it's definitely not bad. 

TL;DR get the pork belly, get it now! 

:)
author: Jennie C.

description:
Wait, what?  I haven't reviewed Chairman Bao yet???  Must be because the mixture of drool and pork belly grease locked up my keyboard.

Yeah, it's all true. You'll likely have to wait in a massive line for their incredible pork belly buns (I think steamed is a bit better than baked) and it's worth it.  Anyone that's had Dong Po pork in Hong Zhou, China, will find the massive fatty layer deliciously familiar.  Do it.

Also, I've sampled their full menu a couple times now, and the coca cola braised pork has also been a winner... in fact it was even better than the pork belly last night!
author: Aaron M.

description:
Crispy Garlic Tofu Steamed Bao is a guaranteed foodgasm!!

I talk about you any time I can. I remember the goodness that you were and I will wait in another 20 minute + line to have you in my life :)

Come back to Sacramento, pretty please!!

xoxo,

A true admirer
author: Steph G.

description:
Indeed, the pork belly did melt in my mouth!

I've heard a lot of good things about the chairman truck, but I didn't get a chance to try it until yesterday! They happened to be around washington square and so I finally get to try it. 

They don't have too many choices on the buns, but i'm sure pork belly is what they are famous for. You can either order the steamed or baked bun. Baked bun are like burger bun. My friend ordered the baked one and I ordered the steamed one. The steamed one came with 2 pieces of pork belly with some pickled daikon and sauce. I'm not a fan of pickles so I ordered with no daikon - basically it's just the steamed bun and 2 pieces of pork belly. Portion is not huge, but it was delicious~ Baked one was a lot bigger....and i think there were 3 pieces of pork belly. 

Other than this I did not try any other items. It was a good experience and I hope to try out other stuff  soon!
author: Louisa L.

description: Yummy pork belly sandwich! Had it at Off The Grid in Oakland and I was told this is the best from all thr trucks. Not over priced at all because the sandwich was pretty big and also delicious.. The pickled daison was really good too! Please try it when you see it around.
author: Altoni Leen C.

description:
My top two:
1. Crispy Miso Cured Tofu (I bet most people don't even try this, but it is sooo good.)
2. Coca-Cola Braised Pork 

Also I think it's ironic that it's named the Chairman, when it's serving Taiwanese-inspired food.
author: Lilian K.

description:
Let's start with the food. I ordered one of each bao and for the ones with mayo in it, I told them to hold the mayo. When I received the bao, they were all cold. And of course the bao that I ordered still had mayo in it. The food is very overrated and is nothing special. Definitely not authentic. This was my second time at the truck, and I was also underwhelmed the first time.

Now onto the non-food related mishap. I paid with credit card, and the woman at the register disappeared into the back with my card for an uncomfortable amount of time (2 min). I figured it was a reputable food truck so I'd have nothing to worry about.

To my dismay, the next day I check my credit card statement and I was charged twice for the same transaction. Not a big deal normally, I just dispute it, but on the mis-charged transaction they gave themselves a 25% tip... who does that??? 

Dislike.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Went to the Streat Food Park on Folsom last night.  Wanted to try the pizza truck, but they weren't open.
Close to $4 for 1 bun.
If you are hungry you need at least 3 buns, so that might be a little pricey for some people...But not for foodies that are willing to pay for quality.
I highly recommend the STEAMED buns:  specifically the Pork Belly and the Coca Cola pork.  These are the two types that I ALWAYS order and haven't explored otherwise.  They always taste fresh and hot.  Service fast and friendly.

WARNING:  they are somewhat difficult to eat, so definitely get napkins and get ready to drip and spill!
author: Kai N.

description:
(See pics) Review #1154. Food truck 3.6 stars. Okay buns but good flaky house made egg tart.

The baked bun looked more like a burger bun and the pork belly tasted more like pork meat while I was expecting some crispy side of happy lard, though it's quite juicy.

The steamed coca-cola braised pork bun, while not totally authentic, was on a fairly good dough but the meat was with too much cabbage and yellow mustard seeds and I was having trouble searching for the meat. But once found, it was pretty flavorful.

They made their egg tarts too so I had to have some. The flaky custard was good lard-y delicious. The center was drowned in vanilla extract, unfortunately, even the texture was really good.
author: T L.

description:
These stupid (yet amazing) little steam buns are literally haunting my dreams. I've been dreaming, craving & yearning for Chairman Truck since my first encounter with them a couple weeks ago at Hiller Aviation. 

I ordered a pork belly & tofu steam bun. What can I say, it was love at first bite. So simple yet so incredibly delicious. The pork belly was juicy & fatty, the sauce on it sweet & tangy, what more could you want? The tofu, I can't even explain the flavor but just as amazing as the pork belly. 

My only disappointing part was that I didn't try all 4 flavor options.....Chairman Truck, I'll be back. Often & Forever.
author: Courtney O.

description:
Just to further echo Lady K's review Bao o Bao is in the HOUSE! 

I definitely bao down to Chairman Bao Bun, they are one of the many that is leading the way for the Street Food movement that is engulfing many major cities in the Northern and Southern California. Here in San Francisco Chairman Bao is certainly one of the major players in this Street Food revolution so when I found out they were going to be in Emeryville this Monday I was going to hunt them down. 

Just before lunch I took my daughter, my brother and his girlfriend down to Emeryville to find this truck. (It's not that hard to find since it looks like a fire truck with tattoos. You can see it three blocks away.) When we got there there were only a few people in line since they were still setting up, but as soon as they open, the masses of followers started to show up. 

As soon as they started taking order I ordered the Steamed Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon and Duck Confit with Mango Salad in a baked bun. My brother and his girlfriend ordered the Steamed Sesame Chicken with Scallions and Bok Choy and the Steamed Pork Belly. 

My immediate favorite is the Duck hands down. It is shredded duck and some kind of sweet mango relish thrown in a baked Chinese bun. The immediate reaction to the first bite is "Humm this is different, a little spicy, hummm." Then as I took the last bite I'm saying "G-- D--- this is good, I'm buying another one." 

The Sesame Chicken was also delicious and spicy, as my brother's girlfriend gave me some to try. I'm definitely getting more of that on my next visit. 

The Steamed Pork Belly was also good, although it didn't make a big splash as the other food. 

Overall I loved it. No problem giving Chairman Bao a cool 5 stars. I love the whole Street Eat Revolution and it's my honor to support this movement. 

One request for Chairman Bao Ban, please pay a visit in Hercules Market Hall, PLEASE!!!

Update 1/3/2011: Follow up meeting with the Chairman and this time I got the Braised Pork w/ Savoy Cabbage and Preserved Mustard Seeds. It was delicious, but I still put the Duck Confit above them all.  I also got to try their Ginger Lychee Lemonade, it was so good, you got to try it.
author: Mel B.

description:
THE Chairman Truck or Chairman BAO truck? Would a rose by any other name smell as sweet?  Yes!  For a total of ~$10, I ordered three different steamed buns, 1 of each of the meat options that were available: The Coca-Cola braised pork, the tender pork belly and the spicy chicken.  Surprisingly, the cola braised pork was my favorite!  The tender pork belly was a close second. 

I had to minus a star for the spicy chicken though.  There were more pickled carrots in the bun than even chicken and cucumber combined and all I could taste was spicy, sour carrots.  Shame. 

The buns are little doughy clouds of perfection, perfect capsules to transport extra yummy to my tummy. I will be back.
author: Nicole A.

description:
I came here alone while I had some idle time in the city and did I feel like a super fatty mcfatty mcfatty for doing so?  Definitely.  But was it worth it??! TOTALLY.  I think I was the only person there by myself who was not picking up food for the office/friends.  BUT Yelp readers, this is why my solitude was justified:  

1. This is finger food of the highest caliber.  Sumptuous meats (pork belly and duck confit are amazing) and fresh vegetables (baby bok and pickled daikon) combined and sandwiched into a fresh Chinese style steamed roll serve as a totally awesome reminder of the more authentic dishes natives like myself love and also as a gentle introduction to Asian snacks for those less fortunate and less Chinese.

2. The shaved ice/jelly/boba drinks are different.  Salted ginger with little tiny cubes of lychee jelly and boba on the bottom?  More please.  Unlike anything I've ever had at any Asian tea shop.  

3. Have you all seen the Chairman truck?  That truck is seriously just really awesome to look at.  I dont think any other Bay Area food truck has been as successful in its viral marketing using the truck itself.  Very commendable. 

Minus 1 star for the wait time, but they do their best and I could tell the service staff was really stressed out trying to bring out all the food as fast as possible.  I don't understand why the girl in the front passing out all the food is there though. I didn't find her to facilitate the process all that much. 

I will admit that maybe this concept is a bit overrated, and more delicious Chinese food can be found easily in SF at a smaller cost with only a fraction of the wait time, but I have to commend the homies/comrades over at Mobi Munch for doing such an excellent job with its marketing for this truck.  After all, the long lines that have since become a fixture to the truck aren't there for no reason.  All hail the Chairman!
author: Cecilia X.

description:
This was phenomenal. Finally a pork bun that competes with Momo in NY. Pickled daikon was a great garnish. Wonderful bun.

Tried the cola braised pork with slaw which was also just fantastic.
author: Eric B.

description:
I LOVE this food truck. The tender pork belly is simply amazing. Tender, tender, tender. They did go a little overboard on the radish, but that's a moot point. Simple fix: remove some. I ordered the baked bun this time, but next time, will definitely order the steamed one. I don't think the baked one was worth [almost] twice the price of the steamed ($3.75 vs $6.00).

I'd definitely come back to this place again for lunch. Be warned: you might be standing in line for a long time during lunch hours (20 min+).
author: Austin W.

description:
Love live Chairman Bao. 

Not much to say that hasn't already been said. Great interpretation of the Chinese classic "gua bao". Offerings came in two sizes: steamed bun and baked bun. Steamed bun is soft and sweet, and the 2-3 bites-sized portion; you'd probably have to eat at least 2 or 3 to feel really satisfied. Baked bun is closer to the size of a burger; if you're really hungry you could probably eat one and a half of those. 

Highly recommend the pork belly with pickled daikon and the spicy chicken. Unlike some food trucks, Chairman gets the flavor balance right between the richness you get from the meat and the acid from the topping. 

Don't forget about the Tofu, either. They do a good job of crisping up the sides and the miso topping is actually quite tasty.
author: Tim C.

description:
After seeing Chairman Bao's concoctions i knew i had to try them. I also heard that the line is usually super long and the wait time can be over an hr?? pure craziness!! Luckily I was joining fellow yelpers for off the grid at civic center. Arriving early made a difference, I noticed Chairman Bao had the longest line of all the trucks. To be able to try a different variety of them, my good buddy and i decided to order 3 buns and share. We decided to go for the Chairman combo and add in one more bun. The Braised Pork with savory cabbage and mustard seeds, Tender Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon and lastly Spiced Duck Confit with Fresh Mango Salad. It also came with some Bao chips. http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/oZpVZoqtkKLUMdecTdc85w/l
http://media1.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/nvfo5cbM1C2jDxRc3nvUyA/l

My favorite was the Pork Belly with the Pickled Daikon, although the other two were also up to par in taste and mixture of flavors as well. The Bao chips were very interesting, it was basically wonton skins deep fried and had shavings of seaweed in them. They were good  but a bit oily after eating them for a while. 

The greatest thing that deters me from having Chairman Bao again is the price. almost $4 for one steamed bun or $6 for a baked one. Seriously you can go to Chinatown and get one bun for a lot less. I understand and love that you are taking a new creative edge on a traditional concept. Other than that after having Chairman Bao once, I don't feel the need to have it again. The experience was nice but I don't think i will be back.

3.5 stars
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Pork Belly - Steamed Bun with daikon... add some Sriracha..grab a cold drink.

yeah buddy..
author: Alic H.

description: I got the baked coco cola braised pork. I was a little bit intimidated with the size at first when I got it, but I gobbled the whole thing. It looks like a burger but taste like bao with a twist. The pork was so tasty!!! Didn't feel fatty or heavy with the veggies they put in it. The bread was just amazing. It was sooooo soft!!! After eating the whole baked braised pork bao, I went back and got the spicy chicken in a steamed bun and ate the whole thing. It's just THAT good!
author: Lydia Y.

description:
I went here for the first time today. I've been wanting to go since I heard about it months ago. It did not disappoint!  I tried the steamed Crispy Miso Cured Tofu. It was so tasty! Next time I'll try the baked version. 

I do not frequent food trucks often, but from what I've encountered thus far in my food truck adventures, I would suggest that they all need to be more approachable and friendly. Smile!
author: Kate H.

description:
The Chairman is everywhere.  That's good because they are so good.  They are at Fort Mason, Treasure Island, Eat Well, Canoas Park, Hiller Aviation, Garden City and more places that I have not been to yet.

The bao is so so so good!  That is how all bao should taste. Slightly sweet, soft with that peely bread skin that gives the bao that smoothness.

The fillings are excellent.  I love the pork belly with the the takuan.  Genius!

The ultimate is to get three different ones and munch your way through them in one sitting.  You will be fulfilled!

One of the gastronomic delights of our time.
author: Rebecca B.

description: Tried the pork belly bun and braised pork bun.  The braised pork was just OK, but the pork belly was awesome.
author: Simon L.

description: Finally had a chance to try this truck after having walked by it a dozen different times.  Although the steamed buns are a little on the pricy side, it still was worth it.  Especially the pork belly steamed bun which was unbelievably yummy.  The pork belly was so nicely prepared and the slightly sweet and spicy garnish they put on top of the bun was a great complement.  Wow.  What a great treat.
author: Lewis C.

description:
Two long and delicious years ago, I was lying on a sofa one night, watching food channel with my bacon-soaked mouth wide open, welcoming a big burger in my hand. 

Suddenly, a piece of golden meat stuck showed up on the screen. It was Chairman Bao. The meat was put in between a beautiful pearl white bun. A nostagic flashback of buns came up: My mother lifts up the steamer as the lightly sweet scent of the bun permeates the whole room. I then, have no hesitation in my mind that I will go find this truck someday.

In the past two years, the search was almost completely marred by close successes, but ultimately, failures. I remember seeing the truck outside my window on the train, but was unable to get off the train, for my destination was far far away. I also remember seeing it stopping by a gas station with a closed sign on its door.

Finally this Monday, I screamed as I finally stood face to face to this truck, and ordered my crispy pork belly bun.

It did not disappointing me, I immediately sank my teeth through the soft pillow-like bun and the surprisingly crispy exterior of the pork and the bun. The juice of the meat immediately surrounds my tongue as the flavor it rang in my head loudly, and I was even more mesmerized when the coolness of the pickled daikon lifted me up light in the air.

and I couldn't remember what happened after that, I probably fainted as I took the last bite.

It's so good, chase it.
author: David H.

description:
These bao buns were oh-so-good! I bought 3 baos from their menu at Off the Grid. I was lucky enough to only have to wait 45 minutes in line to get some of their bao! I was unlucky on the part where they had run out of half the items they started out with by the time I got to ordering! 

Daikon pork belly on steamed buns were delish!
Tofu was also yummy!
Braised pork was also very good!

These buns melted in my mouth so, 45 minutes in line is the most I'd tolerate for a bite of these buns. Not a fan of lines but these buns were yummy.
author: Zar A.

description:
$3.75 for a 2 bite taco? I think I need to eat 4-5 of these to feel full. Why is it I pay the most for food when eating standing in a parking lot sucking in generator fumes? I'm so over this food truck thing. Often over priced, seldom better than brick'n mortar fare. 

The Chairman might be one of the exceptions. The food is tasty, but just kinda overpriced IMO.
author: John H.

description: I couldn't contain myself, I stalked them down at the farmers market in San Mateo... I tried the tofu this time too... tofu was great but was very mild in flavor next to the chicken and pork ones.... I'm second guessing may favorite I'm falling more and more in love with the braised pork now...
author: Lindsey A.

description:
After seeing this on tv and hearing good things about it from people, I was determined to try The Chairman when I saw it at OTG in Belmont this evening. To say I was giddy would be a gross understatement; I felt like I was bouncing and vibrating the whole time I was in line, and I was in line for probably half an hour, working up an appetite. I got their most popular offering, the pork belly, both on a steamed bun and a baked bun, and then I threw in a Coca Cola braised pork steamed bun for good measure. The steamed bun is just as I'd imagined. It's the type of bun you get with Peking duck, only bigger and slightly more refined. The baked bun is the type of bun you get with a char siu bao -- brown, slightly sweet, and toasted to perfection. 

The pork belly was so far beyond disappointing that I'm still questioning just what cut of meat was used. It was dry, hard, and not at all the luscious, fatty, tender pork belly that my taste buds are accustomed to. There was supposed to be some sort of sauce, but hell if I could find it, and shiso? Where? Shiso has such a specific taste that if there had been even a hint of it, I would've noticed, but nope. Nada. The Coca Cola pork was better because it was shredded and tender, but it didn't really have the flavor I've come to associate with soda-braised pork. 

I'd like to think I just hit them on a bad night, since everyone still has such glowing things to say about 'em, but I'm not sure that I'll ever feel compelled to wait in that ridiculously long line for mediocre, borderline expensive, pseudo-Chinese food.
author: D C.

description: The pork belly with daikon radish on a steamed bun, and the tofu with baby bok choy also on a steamed bun are awesome.  The spicy chicken with pickled carrots was good but definitely not as great as the other two.  Next time I have to try the braised pork!  Either way, this was delicious.  The folks I was with ordered two each but I had no trouble finishing 3 for lunch - they were so good!
author: Vivian W.

description:
Delighted to run into The Chairman at the San Mateo Farmer's Market to check out his buns.

Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro on Steamed Bun (4.5 stars) - really delicious, flavorful, nice slight spicy kick.

Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum on steamed bun (3.75 stars) - first time I had this, I thought it was too bland. This time the tofu had a more tasty crust with good flavor along with the bak choy. But probably wouldn't order this again. 

Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso on steamed bun (3.5 stars) - the flavors and picked daiso were so tasty. But I'm not a big fan pork belly I guess... biting into a big chuck of gooey soft pork fat isn't my thing.

Bottom line: Nice buns Chairman. Hail to the Chairman for scrumptious spicy chicken on steamed bun. However, buns are slightly expensive ($3.25-$3.75 each) for the small amount of food you get and can leave you still hungry.
author: Jim C.

description:
Delish! Highly recommend the braised pork steamed bun - which does come in the shape of a taco and not the traditional steamed bun.
