The service is friendly and food is fast! The longest line at Off The Grid by far, but totally worth the wait.
author: Rana A.

description:
I love coming here every time I go to off the grid. They are one of the best food truck there. 

I love their crispy miso tofu with baby bak choy, the pork belly with pickled daikon, and the coca-cola braised pork. I have yet to try the other other buns, but I am sure they are as equally delicious. Though my favorite is the crispy miso tofu bun!! I grew up not liking baby bak choy, but damn The Chairman has converted me. If I had the bak choy like how they prepare it I would eat it everyday. IT'S SOOOO GOOD!! The only bad thing about this truck is that the buns aren't big enough. I love every bite, but I wish I could prolong it. Maybe that's just the fatty inside me saying that, lol.

Perfection, everybody must go here they're DELICIOUS!
author: Denice D.

description: It doesn't get any better than this for food truck cuisine. Expertly wrought dishes that are consistently delicious, affordable and appealing. Whether you get a vegetarian or meat option, the food is rich, piquant and original. We've found its best when very fresh, so we plan ahead ahead for a picnic at a local park. My husband has become a big fan, and it's one of the places we take friends and family visiting from Europe.
author: Maureen P.

description:
two words:  Pork Belly!!!!!

The pork belly bun with pickled daikon was off the charts crazy good and i could have eaten 5 of them.  

The garlicky tofu bun was good, but i wish i would have gotten another pork belly.  

I dont care what the rest of their food tastes like, or if its "overpriced" or 
"overhyped", its all about the pork belly buns, and they are totally worth the wait and price.
author: Christian C.

description:
Now that I've tried The Chairman's baked duck confit with mango steamed bun, as well as their pork shoulder steamed bun with mustard seeds... I can say that they're officially one of my favorite mobile munchie operations around.

Look for 'em at just about every Off The Grid event, and outside of Bloodhound on Mondays. Blizzow!
author: Ruggy J.

description:
i was super excited to try this out because ive heard alot from yelp and friends.  longest line yet already at opening time!  plus, i heard they run out, so this was our first stop at off the grid.  

i got to try both the pork belly and the braised pork baked bun.  

hmm, it was good considering that its from a food truck, but it wasnt LIKE OMGGGGG like how everyone says.  

its pretty darn pricey if you ask me!  6 bucks something each was soooooo not worth the moola and long wait!  

but, it was prob one of the best thing i ate at the off the grid event.
author: mong linh n.

description:
On my most recent visit to the Chairman Bao truck I ordered a steamed bun with pork belly with pickled daikon, and not only was it delicious in terms of flavor, texture, and presentation, but for once I didn't have to wait in a ridiculously long line before ordering my food.  The two biggest complaints about Chairman Bao seem to be the prices and waiting in long lines, one of which is valid.  

If you attend an Off The Grid event where the Chairman Bao truck is taking part, especially if it happens to be Off The Grid Fort Mason, then you will without a doubt find yourself waiting in a long line to place your order.  Yes, it's in part due to the truck's trendiness among those who regularly attend Off The Grid and similar food truck events, and you can't dismiss the awesome design and paint job that adorn the truck itself, but the biggest reason for the long lines at the Chairman Bao bun truck is without a doubt the food.  Buns, steamed or baked, filled with fresh, well prepared ingredients, and made to order.

If you're looking for taco truck prices from a decade ago then Chairman Bao is probably not what you're looking for.  Take into consideration the cost of food items at similar trucks currently operating all over the Bay Area, and Chairman Bao's prices are not out of line with that of their competition.  If there was a negative side to the prices charged by trucks like Chairman Bao, it's that the old school taco trucks see this trend as a reason to jack up their own prices.  A pork belly or duck confit steamed bun for $3.75 each from Chairman Bao makes more sense to me than a $7 or $8 breakfast burrito filled with chorizo, refried beans, rice, and guacamole (not even potatoes) from a taco truck.
author: Jay U.

description:
I wait almost an hour for these baos at San Jose Eats, luckily I was the 5th person in line. Yes, it still took an hour!! I waited before the truck even showed up and they still ran out of pork belly.  So we ended up ordering the steamed Red Sesame Chicken bao and baked Braised Pork bun. Baked buns are $6.25 and steamed are $3.25. The steamed ones are a bit smaller and the baked ones almost looks like a hamburger bun. The baos were interesting, not your typical Chinese bao. They're creative and the flavors are unique. 
 
The red sesame chicken was soft, but a bit too spicy for me. It's topped off with fresh cucumbers and carrot slices. The braised pork bun was better in my opinion, especially if you don't like your food spicy. The braised pork meat was soft and fresh and it was topped off with pickled daikon an mustard seeds and lettuce.
author: Victoria N.

description:
I wish I could give them more stars!

The Braised Pork Sandwich is what my dreams are made of. Best bite of food that I had at the SactoMoFo 6! Plenty of good reviews so no need to elaborate about my pork wet dreams. . .
author: Foodie For Life L.

description: Went to Off the grid the other day and was able to give the bao truck a second try. I was excited to try the pork belly bao since it has been the talk of the town for quite some time now. Let me just say this... it is freaking DELICIOUS.. yes the meat is fat but helloooo it's pork belly.. it's suppose to be fatty. Yum the daikon and onions went extremely well with it too. It is overpriced but it's a food truck what do you expect?
author: Tiff C.

description: I've eaten with The Chairman back when it was known as Chairman Bao.  Great baked bao sandwiches and super consistent.  However I've noticed that recently the storefront and the trucks are pretty inconsistent.  Sometimes the store has dry sandwiches without enough sauce and sometimes the trucks don't have a consistent flavor.  I believe that if they can figure out how to make their food consistent between locations, it will go a long way.
author: Jeff W.

description: It was our first trip to Off the Grid and after making a couple of laps around the trucks to figure out which one we wanted to order from, we decided on the Chairman truck. It's hard to turn down a big red truck with a panda face on it after all. Anyways, my fiance ordered the Baked Tofu and I ordered the Baked Chicken - both were delicious and tasty! A lot of people seemed to be ordering the steamed buns, so we will have to try those next time! We ordered the won top chips as well -- good, but pretty greasy. Customer service was great, the line moved pretty fast, and the wait wasn't that bad. Especially for my fiance who absolutely hates waiting!
author: Irene L.

description: Everything on this truck is lights out. Huge fan of the pork belly buns! If you are near Thai truck ever don't hesitate to give them a shot.
author: Chris L.

description:
So I've tried all 3 types of steamed buns now, there's the pork belly, red sesame, and pulled pork. As everyone's been saying the pork belly one is the BEST!! Red sesame 2nd, and pulled pork 3rd. The very first time I had Chairman Bao was the pork belly bun and at first, you look at the little guy and think "$4 FOR THIISS?!" But once I put that puppy in my mouth...it had me speechless! I scarfed it down so fast I think I pulled a neck muscle, and choked a little bit too. Hands down, TOP 3 Best Foods I've Ever Eaten!

I try to catch them at least once a month, but with my most recent visit I noticed they were becoming more and more unimpressive. I even brought one home for my brother to try (it was his first time having Chairman Bao) and even he said "it was just ok." Sadly, I had to agree.

But I think everyone should try Chairman Bao for themselves at least once!! It's certainly worth the $3.75 to try it yourself, and you just might dazzle your taste buds. But be warned, chew your food carefully!!!
author: Cammy C.

description:
YUMMMM. So good! 

The pork belly bun is really good! I really liked the steamed bun as it reminds me of peking duck! But it's more on the small end, like a snack size, which makes it a great way to try multiple food trucks! 

Definitely a must try! The meat is really tender and the flavours are amazing! I really love the addition of pickled radishes (daikon?) to the buns!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This is one of my most favorite food trucks ever.  It's been YEARS since my mom has made gua bao, and finding the Chairman Truck transported me back to childhood at first bite.  The pork belly is tdf YUM.  I usually take off 1/2 the pickled daikon, so that I can get more of the fatty pork taste.  Hubby likes the coca-cola braised pork.  And my son loves the tofu.  The tofu is a close second for me- it's marinated and is crispy on the outside and meltingly soft in the center.  
I always get the steamed buns-  reminds me of my mom's gua bao :)
Try the bao chips- deep fried wonton skins with seasoned salt, chili, and nori flakes- they're addictive.
author: Lois B.

description:
I ordered the tender pork belly and the coca cola braised pork steamed buns while at Off the Grid.  The line wasn't too bad, and the food came out right away.  

Pork Belly - My favorite of the two.  The pork belly was tender, rich, and salty; nicely offset by the crunchy and vinegary pickled daikon.  Overall a very nice combination but could have used a tad more daikon to cut through all the heaviness of the pork.  

Coca Cola Braised Pork - A successful Asian spin on the traditional pulled pork sandwich.  The cola added a nice sweetness but the flavor wasn't overpowering and the coleslaw lightened it up with some crunch from the cabbage and tang from the mustard seeds.
author: Deanna J.

description:
3.5 stars

I have started dedicating my Fridays to walking over to City Hall and scoping the truck scene. It really makes my Fridays THAT much better!

Last Friday I was so happy to see the Chairman Bao Bun Truck because the thought of pork belly stuffed inside a bun made my stomach happy. The line was somewhat long but moved quickly. By the time I got to the front I realized that half the menu had already been sold out- the menu wasnt that long to begin with.

The fresh pork belly was really good and complimented well with the bun and pickles. The bun was a little overpowering and would have probably tasted better if it was a bit smaller. Perhaps I should have ordered it with the steam buns instead. I had a few bites and saved the rest until I got back to my office- bad move. By the time I got back, the bottom bun was all soaked and soggy from the sauce. Lesson learned. 

I would love to try their duck in the future!
author: M W.

description: Who doesn't love the Chairman's pork buns?! Anyone should try out the Coca cola pork buns after trying the original as their different. The slaw is on point and gives a different crunch and dimension to the steamed buns
author: Vhalerie L.

description:
Chairman Bao chairman bao, chairman bao...

I never knew your exact location! NOW I DO! Thanks yelp..

 I always go to foodie events and the line for Chairman Bao is always long. What's the fuss? Well.. Chairman bao has the perfect combination to make a revolutionary BAO. It's not prices my traditional Chinese mom would pay for a bao but I would because of how unique the flavors clash. It's not like our steamed buns from dim sum. They use sweet clam buns (the kind served with Peking duckskin appetizers at chinese restaurants). The lines are worth the wait. I'm just going to outright state the obvious that if it's your first time, get the pork belly.

Bao Appetit!
author: Mary C.

description: Just inhaled a deletable baked bun with braised pork!  This truck is one of my all time favorites for porktastic goodness!
author: Scott P.

description:
Oh gawdd are you serious!? This truck is way too overrated and over hyped. Just give that other bao truck guy in New York his freaking name back. 
I got to try a chicken and tofu bao and geezus christ, where'd all the juice go!? It was the driest bao i've ever had in my whole entire life. I could definitely smell all the sesame oil in it, but when I bit into it all I tasted was steamed bun and SPICY. i had to gulp some soda down afterward because my mouth was all dry like I had cotton mouth..  how the hell does one make a bao that dry when it has TOFU in it? geezus.. 

NEVER AGAIN. And all the suckers waiting in line too, I shake my head at you.
author: Susy C.

description:
Chairman is the best food truck in the Bay Area. If you're going to try it, definitely order their pork belly bao (steamed, not baked). I've also tried their tofu bao, which is also delicious. But nothing beats straight up fatty pork belly. Tender, juicy and sweet from the small hint of hoison.. it really hits the spot! 

Chairman is the only place that serves up pork belly bao closest to my absolute favorite, which is Momofuku in NYC.
author: Helen W.

description:
The pork belly steamed buns are unreal. I get Chairman at least once a week. Usually at Willow market on Monday.

My fav is their Delicious marinated pork belly with pickled veggie (radish perhaps?) on a soft slightly sweet bun. I usually eat about 3-4. I can't help myselfs. Savory frick snips. 

Fast friendly workers pump out buns faster than you can say Jiminy biscuit.
author: Phil I.

description:
The Chairman is a very popular food truck, isn't it? I'd followed it with interest online for awhile and when I finally made it to Off the Grid, Fort Mason (an event that I heartily recommend by the way) I was glad to see the truck there, in all its glory. It's a sight to behold, and whoever designed it did a killer job! 

I had read very positive reviews of the food and apparently, many other people had, too. The line for the truck doubled back on itself perhaps a hundred deep. I decided to abort thankfully there are other places to catch the truck. I discovered Wednesdays on 7th at Folsom (near Sightglass) is a fantastic time to go. I walked right up to the truck with no line. It was fantastic!

And lucky me, that day they were serving a new bun. Called the Dragon, it was made of grilled eel (a big portion) with salad, avocado and grapefruit in a somewhat spicy and tangy marinade. The combination of textures and colors was beautiful (see photo, uploaded to the album here) The marriage of citrus/ sweet/ salt perfectly balanced. I look forward to trying more of their sandwich buns in the weeks to come!
author: Mark N.

description:
Here's the breakdown...

FOOD: "Tender Pork Belly" [pork belly, pickled daikon, shiso, on a steamed bun]
TASTE: ** [The pork belly was too SALTY... didn't care much for the daikon, steamed bun was decent.]
CONVENIENCE: **** [Off the Grid Fort Mason]
SERVICE: **** [Fast, Friendly... super longgg line? I jus dungetit.]
PRICE:  $ [under $5]
OVERALL: ** [2-stars, I didn't like it before when it was Chairman Bao... I shoulda regurgitated the 200+ calories... cuz I coulda enjoyed my 200+ calories elsewhere.]

It's a food truck... what more can I say?
Nuff said.
author: Lily Y.

description:
Come, my fellow proletariat foodies, let us march on the steps of... whatever street it is, and fest on the meal of the glorious Chairman Truck. 

I mean, I don't know about you, but if there was a bread line for food trucks... I wouldn't mind the fall of capitalism one bit! Indeed, The Chairman truck takes political activism to another step and lets every want to be socialist enjoy a little bit of delicious food.... using a capitalistic model. 

Dear god, it's like buying a Che shirt - only so much more delicious. 

Okay, so it's a little hypocritical to buy something from this truck, but let's just put it out there - those steamed pork belly buns are something that I would topple a foolish imperialistic tyrant over. 

And yes, this truck, even though it is charging a little bit of a price for some amazing food, is General Mao approved. While some true blooded Americans would say it's better to be dead than red, I'd say it's better to be red so you can be fed.

You have the option between baked and steamed. I will admit that the steamed bun is the only way to roll on this one.  The pickled daikon that comes with is something else entirely. It's really good and I would have just chowed down on a hand full of that if I could. 

Lines when I arrived to the truck were non existent, though I hear this truck has a popular following to it. With how delicious those buns were, I could see why. And while I know we're not going to topple over the chains of capitalism any time soon, setting free the utopia of a socialist revolution, I can at least munch on these little delicious suckers.

Truly a food fit for the working class!
author: Javier J.

description:
I think this is, hands down, the best food truck I've ever come across. Every single bite was so good! The buns were soft and pillowy and have the perfect toppings. I heard about Chairman Bao just recently through friends, and was fortunate to find out that it was coming in to town at the SJ Moveable Feast. This was by far, the most popular truck there, as they were the only one with a real line, about 10 people deep! Luckily, wait was only about 10 minutes and the food was ready shortly after we placed our order. We decided to order one of everything! Steamed, of course. I loved steamed baos. The steamed baos are $3.75 and the baked baos, which look more like a huge hamburger bun, was going for $6.75. 

Duck confit - the green papaya and mint toppings complimented the duck confit perfectly.

Red sesame chicken - generous portions of moist flavorful chicken with a small kick, loved the pickled carrot/cucumber mix. Great crunch!

Pork belly - best part was that there wasn't too much fat! And the daikon, omg, the pickled daikon. Sweet, sour, crunchy. So good!

Braised pork - very flavorful, but not too salty. The cabbage and mustard seed mix topping was savory and gave a good crunch.

Crispy garlic tofu - the tofu was crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. The miso greens were light and refreshing. 

We definitely enjoyed them all and inhaled them in minutes! I was tempted to go for seconds, but I had to calm the piggy inside me down. 

They're cute little bao tacos! 
Easy to eat. 
Must try. 
Worth every penny.
Really.
author: Cindy T.

description:
You slutty food slinging truck.. how dare you do this to me. 

What delectable, sexy little buns with juicy meat bursting from within.

I had dreams about eating here after I missed out on the Eat Real fest. The dreams were so good, that today, I dashed out of work an hour before my regular lunch hour just to beat the crowd. Ain't no one gonna stand between me and these buns I tell ya.

I got one of each to experience the steamed and the baked.
I can see how the steamed might be a favorite to some..it was good, but nothing fantastic. I'd never had pork belly before so, all that fat kinda grossed me out & I removed it all.. but it was still good stuff with the pickled daikon, which I thought I'd hate, but it had a unique flavor.

Then I opened 'The One'... the king of all Bao: The baked, duck confit with mango salad.
Again, this was another first.. I don't believe I've ever had duck confit.. and I certainly never had it with a mango salad on top.  Talk about an exotic flavor party.. all in a bun. 
If I could regurgitate and re-eat that sandwich, I would. But I'm full so, I'll just sit here in a food coma, refraining from drinking anything that might mess with the after taste this delightful, ample, meat-filled bun has left on my tongue. 

Chairman Bao is seducing the tastebuds of the Bay Area, and let me assure you, he got all up in my head, down to my belly and back up to my heart with his tasty talents. I shall be back, but not too often. Food this good cannot be good for you.

If loving Bao is wrong, I don't wanna be right.
author: T C.

description:
AMBIANCE: Truck. Self-service. Find your own place to sit, whether it's a bench, steps, or your car.
PRICE: $3.75 for steamed bun, $6.75 for baked bun
VALUE: Great price for really tasty lunch options. Two buns are usually enough for me.
CHANCE OF RETURNING: 100%

NOTE: There were a few (rare) times when we saw on their website that they were supposed to be somewhere - except they weren't. Be patient, they're worth hunting down or at least a quick stop when you finally do spot them somewhere.

___________________________________


:::: THE FOOD ::::

* TENDER PORK BELLY w/TURMERIC, PICKLED DAIKON, & GREEN SHISO
         - [4.5/5 - They are roughly 70-85% consistent w/how much sauce they put in. Request extra sauce, maybe on the side so you can gauge if you need it or not.]
* COCA-COLA BRAISED PORK w/SAVOY CABBAGE & PRESERVED YELLOW MUSTARD SEEDS
         - [4/5 - Tender juicy pork.. Decently flavored, though not as tasty as the pork belly.]
* SPICY CHICKEN w/TOASTED SESAME PUREE, PICKLED CARROTS-CUCUMBER & CILANTRO
         - [4/5]
* CRISPY MISO CURED TOFU w/GARLIC-TOFU MAYO & BABY CHOY SUM
         - [3.5/5]

___________________________________

:::: Ranked: PORK BUNS :::: 
(Only includes the open-faced kind, not the traditional Cantonese baozi.)

1.) Steamed Pork Buns (2pc), $15, REDD, Yountville, CA - [5/5]
2.) Hirata Pork Buns (2pc), $9, IPPUDO, New York, NY - [4.5/5]
3.) Crispy Pork Belly Bun (3pc), $12, HOLSTEINS, Las Vegas, NY - [4/5]
4.) Tender Pork Belly Bun (1pc), $3.75, CHAIRMAN BAO, San Francisco, CA - [4/5]
5.) Steamed Pork Buns (2pc), $11, MOMOFUKU SSAM, New York, NY - [3/5]
author: Asha S.

description:
After reading so many reviews about the pork chop bun, i grabbed a bun from Belmont off the grid to eat together with my home-cooked dinner. $3.75 for a little thing? It is good, but not that good. I've had a lot better pork belly bun from NYC east village, a japanese restaurant. it's just a taiwanese gua bao. i can make it myself easily.

My second try with the Chairman Bao was in Truck Stop in SOMA. The staff was friendly and gave out Bao Chips samples (wonton chips). It was too greasy to me.
author: Ashley C.

description:
I was so excited to hit up this food truck since it's from the city I used to live. I tried this food truck out at the Gourmet Food Truck Fest near South Point in Las Vegas. The line was long but was going by really quick. My sister and I checked out the menu and we are glad that we picked this truck. We tried all the buns out since they all sounded so good. The pork belly was our favorite out of the four we tried. 

Make sure your not hella hungry when you come to a food truck festival; the lines are long and just the smell of all the food cooking around you just makes it worse.
author: Francine G.

description:
Hmm.. Probably no better than 3 stars.

Nothing here really wow'ed me. I tried the baked bun with the pork belly, and also had the steamed bun with the braised pork. The baked bun was sweet and fluffy, but that sweetness overpowered any flavor that the pork belly had. The belly itself wasn't super-tender like the ones in the buns at Momofuku in NYC, either. It just didn't have that melt-in-my-mouth texture. Flavor-wise, it was also lacking... 

The braised pork with mustard seeds on it had a bit more character, but it's not like it left a lasting impression. Wait, I just had it a few hours ago, but I already kind of forgot what it tasted like.

So what's with all the hype? I mean.. it's just a BUNch of buns! .....See what I did there?
author: Kazu O.

description:
I love mobile gourmet week!  Thanks again Bishop Ranch for bringing street food to our hood!

2.5 Stars:

So I ordered the BUN meal which consists of a Baked bun, and a Fresh fruit shaved ice (complete with boba) . $9

-BUN:  Spiced duck with mango confit
-Shaved Ice drink: Pineapple Salt Caramel
note: I've posted pictures of both.

Sounds good huh?  great concept right?  Yeah well.. the food in my opinion fell kind of short...

The Bun:  The bread itself tasted a day old, it was not bad and it looked great (nice golden shiny coat) but it was not soft, fresh and steamy the way a fresh baked chinese bun out of the oven tastes like.  The bun was cut in half and stuffed with shredded duck .. while you can taste the 5 spice (star anise, ginger, pepper etc), it was very salty, and it took some convincing for me to realize that this was dark meat duck, and not some over marinated pork.  The duck meat was then topped off with a type of sweet mango relish.  There was some good "heat" to the seasoning, but I have to stress that the dish overall was very salty.  Too much for me to really enjoy.

The Shaved ice: Once again, fell a bit short...looking at the drink, it looked really good.. however, it literally tasted like a can of chopped pineapple over some shaved ice.  Think of a can of Dole Crushed pineapple, now pour it over crushed ice and tapioca.  That's the drink!  No flavor of caramel, no salt... 

Overall: At face value the concept of the menu and meal sounds really great, however the preparation of the meal could have been better executed.
author: amy m.

description:
The Chairman is my FAVORITE food truck of all times.  I can't resist their pork belly. I usually get two steamed pork belly and my boyfriend will get the pork belly on a bun.  The bun is buttery and the pork belly melts in your mouth.  If there's a long line, it's worth the wait and usually moves pretty quickly. Do it! You won't regret it! 

I highly recommend The Chairman!
author: Tegan H.

description:
So good!!!!
Pork belly and chicken buns are awesome!!!
author: Christina R.

description:
The Chairman needs another review like I need another ripple on my muffin top. 

Just kidding. (No, I'm not.)
I'm hawt. (Really.)

I've been a longtime fan of the Chairman and have eaten more-than-I-can-count pork belly buns at Off the Grid. I have friends who hate them. But me, I'm definitely a fan. Long line and all. I have the patience to stand in line for a pork belly bun or two. Other peeps, maybe not so much.

Why? Because I've actually made them at home and know that waiting in line for those little pillows of porktastic-ness is worth every cent and every second of your life that you will never get back from waiting in line.

Yes, I've attempted to make Momofuku's pork buns at home and holy smokes Batman, let me tell you, they are a labor of love (aka, in Anastasia lingo: they are a mutherphuckin' pain in the a$$!!) It took me FOUR PHUCKING HOURS from start to finish. Make the dough. Let in rise. Wait. And wait some more. Knead the dough. Let is rest. Let is rise again. Wait again. Blah. Blah. Blah. In the meantime, the pork belly needs to roast in the oven for a gazillion hours. Then you have to make the pickles and last but not least steam the little buggers. Oh, and did I mention assembling the damn things before they are chowed down at lightning speed. I might as well take up smoking or something if I want to knock off five years of my life in one day!

As much as I love the Chairman's buns (moist and fluffy, yes they are.), sometimes I need a change from the same ol' same ol'. I have to admit the last couple times I've been to OTG, I've walked on passed the Chairman. Without a second glance. I've been tempted by something new. Thou shalt not speak its name, but it rhymes with MoJa (say that three times) -- the new long line in town.

So kids, the next time you begrudgingly moan and groan about the Chairman line, just think of me slaving away in the kitchen for FOUR PHUCKING HOURS. And just be grateful it's not you having to make these buns. A 15-20 minute wait in line is not all that bad considering what goes into making those little pillows of porktastic-ness.
author: Anastasia B.

description:
Thursday nite found Off the grid in Millbrae, and your truck was there.  I had the baked tender pork belly.  Oh so yummy!!! AWESOME.  I just couldn't get enough!!  Tender, Juciy and crunchy veges.  Will be back 
Thank You!!!
author: Jeanne W.

description:
One Word: OVERRATED..


Sorry folks.. After waiting for 2 hours for these so called 100 things before you die food SF list, it was definitely not the case.....$3.75 for steamed buns... $6.00 for Baked buns... overpriced...

Maybe next time I will try the duck one, which I am sure I will enjoy more than the pork ones... I should of gone to a chinese restaurant to get peking duck, which would hit the spot more!
author: Kathy D.

description:
With 500+ pics and almost 1000 reviews I thought, what the heck whats one more awesome review for these guys?

I have experienced this truck more times than one should admit.  Even worse is admitting that I dream of these little steamed goodies sometimes. Is there a 12-step program for them yet?

I have only tried the steamed buns because the baked look really big and I like to have a variety of flavors instead of just one.

Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso: 5 Stars! Its always been cooked to perfection with the perfect amount of fatty goodness!  The Daikon is tasty but watch your fingers they will be yellow if you pick them off your sandwich! (Lesson learned)

Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro: 5 stars.  When it says 'spicy' it doesn't mean mouth on fire, but a subtle ting on your tongue.  The sesame puree is what really makes this work!

Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum: Most times 5 stars.  Once it was under cooked and a little too soggy ( that's one time out of 10)  For anyone who says "I hate tofu" try this it will change your mind!  The baby choy and that garlic mayo kill this bun!

Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds: 4 stars.  This is not always on my order menu.  The flavors together work great but sometimes the meat isn't as tasty as others so its a bit inconsistent for me.  I have tried is several times and most likely will get again.  In the last 5 times I have not ordered it however.

Dont think about it, just order one of each and thank me with a compliment!!
author: Tarra R.

description:
Seems silly to review this truck- 
who doesn't love steamy buns amirite!?

But really- both pork options are delish. Chicken also amazing. And if you're lucky- you'll catch the duck option that pops up sporadically. 
Yum.

I'm surprised more people don't order the bao chips- give them a try! Nice accent to the buns!
author: Sydney S.

description:
HANDS DOWN my FAVORITE food truck!!!!!

I have tried everything on their menu on both baked and steamed bun and it NEVER ever disappoints!  The food is always ON POINT and consistent.  

The meats are ALWAYS so tender and flavorful!  Always dressed to the T....love love love!!
author: Sarah N.

description:
The only thing great about the Chairman Bao is the truck. Horrible bastardization of Chinese food has been committed here. Both the pork belly with daikon and the red sesame chicken were way over sauced and mediocre...the chicken was borderline awful. I generally can't turn down food but after a bite of the chicken...I wanted to throw it away. =(

If you love this truck, you need to check your tastebuds...you clearly can't seperate what your eyes see from what your tastebuds taste. 

I really wanted to like this truck too because the let's admit it, the truck is eye-catching. But at the end of the day...it's about the food.

1 star for the truck, 1 star for the super friendly service, 0 stars for food.
author: Cindy C.

description: Trust the hype! It's as good as everyone says it is! I just tried their buns for the first time on Friday and I already can't wait for next time. I had the pork belly and the chicken. Loved them both. Spicy kick of the chicken bun was nice surprise. First thing I thought when I looked at them was "these are gorgeous!" Really colorful! I was satisfied with two but I've heard getting one baked and one bun is perfect sized lunch if you're hungry.
author: Semuteh F.

description: I just had to put in a high recommendation for the Chairman's catering offshoot--we threw a holiday party and I ordered two trays of sandwiches.  Curtis @ Chairman was very responsive and helpful in ordering/logistics.  The day of the party, the sandwiches (pork belly and chicken) arrived early, and delivery was a very reasonable $20.  The other restaurants that I ordered from didn't offer delivery at all, so I was very grateful to be able to cross this off my list.  Everyone raved about the food, and I would definitely use the Chairman for any future event.
author: Christine H.

description: Went to this truck both times I visited SF with my boyfriend! We've tried both the steamed buns and the burgers, and I definitely prefer the steamed buns because they are more delicate and since they are smaller, you can also try a lot more of the buns! I love the miso cured tofu with baby choy sum - the tofu is delicious but the choy sum did taste a little funny because of the sauce and I would have preferred it just as it is. Both the braised pork and the pork belly are to die for - really tender and flavorful and not oily at all, although the daikon may take some getting used to. The spicy chicken was way too spicy for me unfortunately. I took one bit and gave up so I can't say how yummy (or otherwise) it is. If you can't really eat spicy food you should definitely stay away from that! The wonton chips with seaweed are quite good but very, very salty. Love this truck though!! Definitely check the website for where it is as its location changes daily.
author: Annie Z.

description:
I have a love-hate relationship with Chairman Bao.

I'm excited whenever I see it, eat it but then I'm also like "eck, it really isn't THAAAT good..." Like after awhile it's just totally over-hyped.
Maybe I'm just in denial, but whatever it may be... FRESH chairman bao eaten then and there is the way to go. A little dash of sriracha... The clash of flavors, texture.. is just "BAM!" in your mouth. I love how they have pickled daikon, it really completes the whole bao.

But then you start to feel a little remorse after you're done even though you're so satisfied with all that pork belly you just scarfed down, you look at the paper box it comes in and all that oil that's in the box... It's really just such a simple fattening bao is what it comes down to. Nothing more, nothing less.

Would love to try their drinks but they never seem to have any of the fancy ones that people post pictures up on yelp...
author: Jenny Y.

description:
THE CHAIRMANS BUNS WERE SO DELICATE WHEN I TOOK A BITE TO EAT IN BETWEEN

Amazing buns that melts in your mouth. Friends and i were at Off The Grid and was recommended from a friend's past experience that we wait in the long line to get some. The line is always ridiculous rapping around each other and randoms trying to cut. Its all worth the wait but when you get up the front of the line... ORDER EVERYTHING. thats what we did.

We ordered every single bun and shared it amongst our group. Why only order two or three... why not alot. You obviously waited in a long like for oh... 30 - 45 minutes, you might as well go all out.

ALWAYS GET STEAMED ($2.95 per bun)
- Tender pork Belly with pickled diakes, very delicious but the pork belly was kind of fatty and fattening
- Red seasame chicken with Scalion and Bak Choy, flavorful and delicious
- Chinese Spiced Duck with Fresh Mango Salad, uhm i dont eat duck.
- Lions Head Meatball with fresh kim chee, not available
- chinese sausage and egg sandwhich with Hoisin, was not available
- Crispy Garlic Tufo with Miso greens, was not available

I can eat the bun by itself.... its so damn good.


Will i be back? Yes to get me some "Lions Head Meatball with Fresh Kimchee" bun, if available.

Until the next review.........
author: Jane A.

description:
OMG. Quite possibly one of the BEST food trucks out there. During my first trip to Off The Grid, this was our last stop. I lucked out and a friend had the hook-up at this place. We got the braised pulled pork baked bun, the pork belly with pickled daikon baked bun, along with four different steamed buns.

I tried a little bit of each and each one was AMAZING. The meat in the braised pulled pork bun was flavorful and had a tasty coleslaw topping. The bun itself was soft, fluffy, and slightly sweet. The meat on the pork belly bun was also pretty good. I'm not a big fan of fatty meats like pork belly, so I only had a small bite, but it also was quite tasty! I didn't get to try any of the steamed buns except for the tofu one, but the bun on that one is also nicely balanced. It's pliable, yet firm enough to hold in the good stuff. The tofu is also very flavorful, though, slightly salty.

When we got our items, they were fresh and still mighty hot, but that is the way to eat it! Even when I decided to pick at some leftovers later that night, it was still heavenly! I'm so glad we got to try this food truck because it's definitely one I would go to again and recommend to friends!

GO GO GO! But be prepared to either make that your whole meal, or bring friends to share, because it's just THAT much food!
author: Leana L.

description:
Once again back  again at OtG: Fort Mason, but early this time.  This time around the Lenten season was over and now to tackle the rest of the menu. The line for the truck was still pretty long even though OtG just barely started. I would say I waited in like for about 30 minutes. This time I made sure the full menu was going to be available. The last time I was here, choices of menu items became very scares. 

When I got to finally order, I ordered: 2 Steamed and 1 baked bun pork belly with pickled daikon. And 1 Baked bun with braised pork. Oh yeah, they  had a six bun maximum order.  Good thing I was in the limits of the order. The order was made fairly quickly, I'd say about 5 minutes. 

When I picked up the order and distributed  them among our party, the buns looked and smelled very good. The braised pork bun I order did not lack any meat all. As took the first bite of the bun, the pork  was tender but a bit to salty for my taste. As for the other orders, I sampled them as well. The pork belly tasted pretty good but didn't eat much of it. I'm not really into eating animal fat since I was raised on trimming fat off all the food I ate. Plus, if you ate this everyday you'll be cutting your life expectancy very short. I just had to try this place out. My overall verdict is Over hyped.
author: Jay G.

description:
With a vaguely Communistic aesthetic, The Chairman is a food truck for the brave of tongue.

Read more at http://asmalltrip.com/v/a-few-hours/the-finger-lickingest-food-trucks-of-san-francisco#k7uCcJ0qBxoIPjSH.99
author: Grant G.

description: Bomb food, rude customer service (specifically the caucasian male cook that wears a bandana). What a shame. Oh well, you can't have the best of both worlds.
author: Em M.

description:
Came for the hilarious(ly offensive) pun, stayed for the great food.

My first reaction when I saw the pricing on the truck was "who the hell decided to charge that much for a bun?!" Coming from NY Chinatown, I'm used to $1 pork buns, so it was a bit of a shocker. Despite that, the cute panda and funny pun won me over, and I gave their classic steamed pork belly bun a try.

It was a good decision. The combination of soft bun, juicy pork and crunchy daikon was amazing, not to mention a bigger portion than an average bun. The bread:meat ratio is also better!

The only bad thing about the buns are how messy they are. I'm not sure it's possible to eat them without getting sizzling meat juice all over yourself... but trust me and do it anyway.
author: Grace K.

description: They say they will be somewhere, and they are not 2 days in a row, and they don't pick up their phone.  I guess I'm not eating here anymore.
author: john h.

description:
YUCK.  i had to update my review because my experience with chairman bao at OTG tonight was extremely disappointing.  

the perks of a saturday night OTG?  no line.  woohoo!

anyhoo, we didn't try the baked bun the last time we tried chairman bao's...so of course, we wanted to see what this extra $3 for the baked bun was all about...and it was horrible!  i ordered the duck confit baked bun and blah...i ended up throwing more than half of it away.  the bun was super hard, the duck was cold, and the mango salsa was tasteless.  everything about it was all wrong.  

off day at off the grid?  possibly.  but i doubt i will every go back to chairman bao again...i'd rather not take that chance with a very disappointing dish.
author: Jen W.

description:
Ever been to a Chinese or Vietnamese wedding banquet? Well then you know what I'm talking about when I say that out of the multi-course dinner extravaganza, the roasted Peking duck smeared with hoisin sauce and tucked into a white, steamed bun is one of my faves.

Who knew the Peking duck version could be topped, let alone by a food truck? Thanks to the Chairman, I don't have to wait to be invited to an Asian wedding to get my hands on these hot buns. Chairman Bao's savory buns are stalk-worthy.

I had my first taste at the Eat Real Festival and now I can satisfy my cravings whenever they park their sweet little buns over on 8th and Folsom Streets. The steamed buns with Chinese spiced duck confit with mango salad and the pulled pork with cabbage and mustard seed are good, but the pork belly with pickled daikon is THE ULTIMATE.

Baoism is one ideology I can support and the Chairman has officially converted me into a Baoist.
author: Sylvia D.

description:
Pretty good Bao.  The belly is better than the spicy chicken but both are good.  The sandwiches are small so it takes a few to make a meal. 

The line for this truck in the Marina off the Grid is way too long, much shorter in Marin.  The line to order takes longer than waiting for them to prepare your order.
author: M S.

description:
Your wasting your money if you get the steamed bun options. Unless your a hippie or vegetarian you'd enjoy the tofu thing.

They have the best pork belly between a bun.
author: Chris L.

description: I'm updating and adding a star for sure! The pork belly is off the hook! I will go for a bun for sure from now on, I also add carrots to the pork belly. I can't get enough of those pickled carrots!
author: Jackson D.

description:
when you come here and look at the prices, you may be thinking: WTF?! it costs THAT MUCH for a bao?!!  i can get bao's in chinatown for one tenth of the price!!.  

but oooooh no, don't let the price discourage you.  this is not just any bao.  this is AMAZING!!

Coca Cola Pork
- the better of the bao's that we tried.  crispy, tender, juicy, fresh, fatty, flavorful, a lil creamy.  ALL in 1 BAO.  sooooo goood.  it's like a fancy bao, i would probably say this rivals NYC's Ippudo's pork bun.  and thats saying something

Pork belly
- well marinated but a little too fatty for my taste.  this is a great bao either way

this truck is definitely is worth all the hype.  you gotta try it at least once
author: Tina A.

description: Amazing lov this place, we had coke cola braised short ribs and my 5 year old loved this pork bun!
author: Ribec F.

description: Taiwanese Taco!!! I had the Spicy Chicken  steamed bun. My boyfriend had the pork belly. Both of us went back for more. They were delicious! The chicken bun was a spicy party that was suppose to be in heaven, but instead, it was in my mouth!
author: Cheeky S.

description:
The Justin Bieber of food trucks, Chairman Bao was easy to spot at the Friday Off The Grid event at Fort Mason due to the crazed, bun seeking line that was at times 75 people deep. Business is so good here that they have to enforce a six bun max order limit!! If there ever was an illustration for excessive exuberance, this would be it. We were smart and a bit forward looking and got there way early when the line was only 10 people deep. We still had to wait a bit, and yes we did each order six buns. Sometimes I think the six bun limit is just a marketing gimmick to get you to order the limit.. sigh. 

I got two of each : Pork Belly with Radish, Duck Confit with Mango, Sesame Chicken with Scallion/Bok Choy. My favorites were the Pork Belly and Duck buns. The Pork Belly matched extremely well with the pickled radish.. the fattiness is fended off by the radish - amazing. The duck was very tender while the sweet mango paired with it quite nicely. 

Oh and if you're wondering why the baked bun is almost twice as much as the steamed bun, its b/c the baked one is like more than twice as big and its baked (duh). All I know is that there is a baked Pork Belly Bun with my name on it come next Friday.
author: Henry W.

description: Pretty tasty!  Had a chance to try the pork belly bun with pickled daikon at Off the Grid in Berkeley recently and it was tender, fatty and loaded with flavor.  It was nearly too salty, but rode that fine line nicely.  Very friendly staff too.
author: Eric F.

description:
I have found by chance the truck at Stanford.
Food is good but overpriced. You will need 10+$ to fill you up. A bit too much for a food truck.
author: Fabio C.

description:
3.5 stars because I wouldn't say that I'm a "fan" (which is 4 stars) and it's better than "A-OK" (which is 3 stars). I could eat here again but I wouldn't crave it. And I think it's pricey. 6 buns max per person. If you're getting some for friends bring a bag just in case you can't hold it all by hand. I got the Baked Tender Pork Belly w/ Pickled Daikon $6.75 and Steamed Crispy Garlic Tofu with Miso Greens *Vegetarian* $3.25. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sT8TRzofJym5w0khZkOJhw?select=-uxJuUBbXGU3DEK8jzPTSQ 
They were messy to eat but that could just be me. Given the price and other options for a $10 lunch around San Ramon, I would skip it but if my friends were already ordering from here next time, I want to try the Baked Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage and Preserved Mustard Seeds $6.75.

Truck Menu http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sT8TRzofJym5w0khZkOJhw?select=4-zqHAxNdxKb0-qF75b8Mg


Every Wednesday, there are 4 food trucks at Bishop Ranch 3 (San Ramon, CA). When we arrived today, the lines were long but Bao's wasn't too bad. My friend was going to this one already and we only had 30 mins so I ordered from here too. 

Baked buns appear to be the size of an average hamburger. 
Steamed buns appear to be the size of the buns you get when you order peking duck at a chinese restaurant.
Don't forget to squeeze some sriracha in a cup to go with your buns while waiting for your order.

Baked Tender Pork Belly w/ Pickled Daikon $6.75 (Steamed is $3.75)
   It was good but it would've tasted better if it was cheaper. Pork belly is fatty and I hate fat from any meat but since I was giving this a shot, I tried to forget that I was eating it and just enjoyed the flavors. They didn't skimp on the daikon and I think I had 3 pieces of pork. I wish I took a better picture of it.

Steamed Crispy Garlic Tofu with Miso Greens *Vegetarian* $3.25 (Baked is $6.00)
  The rectangular tofu was a little thicker than half an inch. The tofu was good. I didn't really taste garlic and it wasn't that crispy. The miso greens were bitter so I would skip on this one next time. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sT8TRzofJym5w0khZkOJhw?select=eSyT7UTUlrk4FvVxnNXTSQ
author: J T.

description: There's a reason why there is always a long line for this truck.  The steamed pork belly buns has 2 big pieces of tender pork topped with sliced pickled daikons which is a nice twist to the normal cucumber.  Running from $3.25 for the spicy chicken up to $3.75 for the pork belly for the steamed buns and over $6 for the baked ones, get a few to share.  Even if you're full, it is a nice snack!
author: Joyce Z.

description: First time trying this at the makers faire last weekend. We waited at least 45 mind just to place the order, but it was well worth it. It was relatively fast to get our food considering the line was around the corner. We ordered the pork belly and the tofu spinach. I normally don't like dycons but maybe it was the way it was prepared or the combination of the pork belly that made it super delicious. I don't know where they pack so much food and supplies in that little truck to accommodate hundreds of people. Come to San Jose please!
author: Mel D.

description:
Yeh the line was long but it was worth it when I took that first bite into the tender, moist pork belly and bao. The pickled veggies were perfect to cut through the meaty fattiness of the pork, and the bao was thick enough to make it a hearty and scrumptious bite. Ahh....

God I want another....

Right now....
author: Vittorio L.

description:
A few things you should know about Chairman Bao:

Yes, their buns are expensive. You are not shopping in some hole in the wall in Chinatown. If you want something in your bun that doesn't resemble the reject meat pile at Ranch 99 that they charge you $1 less per pound for, then you'd better show up knowing that you're going to shell out a little more. Deal with it.

No, this isn't "real" bao. There is no one making these buns with love. They come from a package. Yes, they are delicious, no, they are not bao.

Now that we've cleared up those misconceptions, let's get to the good stuff. This place is delicious. Their full menu wasn't up because I was at Sunday Streets, but I had the steamed buns and they were delicious. I split the meal (2 buns + drink) with a friend, and we got the pork belly with daikon and the duck with mango. Both were really tasty. The pork belly had an exceptionally fatty cut of pork, and with the daikon, the combination was unbeatable. I loved the duck with mango, and even though I thought the combination was odd to begin with, I took a bite and all my doubts disappeared. Nom.

They get extra bonus points for having delicious shaved ice drinks. I got the Ginger Lychee and it had chunks of lychee in it with some boba. Easily worth the money we paid.

If this happens to be in the vicinity again, I will most definitely pay it a visit. The wait was a little long, but it was well worth it.
author: Angeline P.

description: I had the chicken sandwich without the sesame puree. It made me throw up. Nuff said.
author: Luna S.

description:
My experience with the Chairman Bao Bun Truck was a total cock-tease.

After being spurned at the lunch session of SJ Eats, we came back at 4:30 to see what the scene was (it was supposed to start again at 5). The truck was gone, but we noticed a couple people enthusiastically waiting where it was.

"Well, we'd be practically first in line."
"Okay, but if it's not here by 5:15, we're out of here." 

6 o'clock rolls around, and we're... still in line. In the interim, the line had moved to a different spot, and we were fifth. Some sketchy dude managed to sneak in behind us, but that's not our problem. When I'm starving, I don't fight for justice.

The truck had already pulled in around 5:20 or so, but it just sat there for a while. Then the main Bao dude pulled open the flaps, and we thought we were good to go. But then he flipped the "Closed" sign up, so we waited. They also had a sign saying you could only order up to six maximum, thus shattering my dreams of buying 100 buns and re-selling them to everyone in line for $10 a pop. Think about it: that's $1000 dollars... sigh.

Anyway, eventually we got to try these $3.75 buns of joy. Overall, the pickled vegetables that top these buns are good. I've included a picture for your enjoyment. 

Overall, the picked vegetables that top these buns are good. Skip the sesame chicken bun, as it pales in comparison to any of the pork buns. Of the two types of pork buns, get the pork belly one. Lastly, the tofu one is surprisingly good. We just got that one for completeness, but I rather liked it.

Good, but not worth waiting 1.5 hours.
author: Huey K.

description: HUGE flavor in a small (steamed bun) package!  Tried The Chairman at the Menlo Park "Off the Grid" venue and it was fantastic.  I had the pork belly and spicy chicken, both with the steamed buns.  I'm usually not a fan of steamed buns from dim sum joints, but these were excellent and just the right size.  The richness of the meat is nicely balanced by the pickled vegetables on both these buns.  The line was longer than at any of the other trucks, but it was well worth the wait.  Looking forward to going back again to try the coca cola braised pork bun and the tofu bun.  Will reserve the 5th star until I've tried the rest of the menu, but if the other items live up to the standard of these two, then 5 stars is a no-brainer.
author: Franklin G.

description:
Chairman is bomb! 

Pork Belly Sandwich is bomb!

I don't usually like tofu, but their tofu is crispy, has great taste and once again, bomb!

Never had pickled diakon, but guess what, bomb! especially with the flavors of the meats and the bread they use (steamed buns).

Staff on the trucks are as friendly as can be.  Shout out to Don!

Get yourself some Chairman, You'll be happy you did and your stomach will thank you!
author: Tom L.

description:
Okay first off, I had one of everything off the menu, steam bun style and all of it was D-E-LICIOUS! Just thinking about it is making my mouth water. I want to have a foodgasm again!

I prefer steam bun than baked because I like the texture and sweetness. I did try the baked bun coca cola pork and that was realllly goood! 

Off the Grid Fridays: The lines are SUPER long but totally worth it. Get as much as you can! 
Off the Grid Sundays at Larkspur: Super short lines and still totally worth it. 

Overall, 5 stars!
author: Diana P.

description:
Part of the Off The Grid food trucks team, which is part of the movement to bring more upscale foods to people for a down scaled price. The atmosphere is great a mixture of lowbrow and highbrow people mixed together all looking for a cheap place to get good food. 

About this truck in particular, Crispy pork belly in a bun? whats not to love. 

I ordered 2. 1 for me and 1 for my pops...ATE BOTH...then ordered a 3rd and ate that one too, sorry Dad. 

Don't judge me! I work out!
author: Colin F.

description: After years of waiting, I finally tried The Chairman. PORK BELLY on a baked bun is all you need to get. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. The baked bun costs more than the steamed bun, but it is OH so worth it.  So is the wait. The line usually goes by pretty quickly.
author: Andrew L.

description: I had the tender pork belly, and the pickled veg was off the chain! The spicy chicken was awesome too. I will definitely be following this food truck around!
author: Dylan W.

description:
My friend and I have been looking for a West Coast version of New York's Momofuku pork buns, so we decided to hunt this truck down.  I was a little disappointed in this one.  The pork didn't seem as fresh and  well prepared.

One star is taken off for the price.  I guess the baked buns would be the item of the best value but i wish they had a steamed alternative that size.  The steamed versions are overpriced (3.75 for a small bun).

I guess this is an alright alternative, but I don't think I'll be going out of my way to find this truck again.  In the mean time, if anyone finds a place in the bay area that has momofuku-type pork buns, please contact me.
author: Alison L.

description:
I had a vivid hallucination that I should fast all day at work before attending, as I was slapped by the gnawing panic of possibly getting too full too quickly and not visiting enough trucks for variety. This plan worked wonders for me, as upon my arrival I was teetering on the verge of chewing my own tongue off for nourishment.  

Hapa SF: very quick line, 7 pieces of thumb-sized Lumpia Shanghai rolls, tender grounded pork, water chestnut, shredded carrot, served with sweet chili plum sauce.

Magnolia: I had both a sippable IPA and later a dark Porter that was well hopped and was colored as between a medium-Oak and dark-Walnut in appearance.  Very refreshing, the line looks intimidating but it moves rather quickly.

Koja Kitchen: is centered in the ring of trucks, so they had a bit of a line.  It was about a 20-30 minute wait-time, but with my IPA in hand from Magnolia it was easy-peasy-lemon-squeezy.. and their Tiramisu alone would've been well worth the wait.  But of course the short ribs with chives over a bed criss-cross fries tasted amazing.  I saw a couple eating the rice cake version which looked a bit difficult and messy, so we opted for the fries.

The Chairman: the creamy clam chowder was the perfect choice to warm myself up with the dropping temperature.. all the Gua Bao steamed buns looked amazing as well, but I wouldn't have been able to take more than a bite of one.  I already made a note to find this truck again, for the duck confit terrine with green papaya, and orange picked mint + onions.  It sounds and looked amazing as it was being dished out to others ahead of me.  This truck has coconut water!

Fat Face: strawberry coconut popsicle was the perfect last note, and amount of natural sweetness to end this eating-spree on.. Especially on the walk back to the car, the subtle coconut flavor melds very well with the fragrance of the strawberry. 

All the food was great, inexpensive (most ~$5-7 range), sizeable portions (perfect for sharing), heavenly smells.. but be warned you will leave smelling char-broiled / post-camp fire.
author: Ty T.

description:
Glad these guys made it down to San Jose for Movable Feast.  I have been wanting to try them for a while, and was not disappointed.

We had both the braised pork and the pork belly bun.  One was baked, one was steamed.  There is a huge difference between the two.  The steamed is kind of mushy, and a lot smaller.  The baked is way more flavorful, and bigger!  

I can see why these guys are popular - They definitely have something "different" going on in a saturated food truck market, and they have quick, friendly service with very good food.

Only downside was not much selection (two pork, one chicken), and it was a little expensive.  But, I would definitely get a baked bun again if I saw the truck.  Pass on the steam, though.
author: Robert K.

description:
The Chairman is my all time favorite food truck. I play with the ida of having food trucks at my wedding...and if ever I were to execute such a 'hipster' concept the CM would be at the top of the list!! 

I'm a vegetarian so I usually get their tofu sandwich. Perfect size, I always feel satisfied but not stuffed :).
author: Janine J.

description:
Sorry to have to rhyme... but I think A Tribe Called Quest said it best:

"Chairman of the board, the chief of affections... 
You got mine's to swing in your direction"

Seriously, I'm a big Sriracha fan -- and filled up two little containers and hit the road back to the office with my three buns and hot sauce in hand.  Barely used the Sriracha as the flavors were on their own pretty near perfect.  Nicely done.  

Hopefully they'll have the duck next time as they were out or not doing it today.  I'll be back either way!!
author: Christopher C.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this food truck. 

My favorite is their pork belly, both baked and steamed. But I might like their steamed one a bit more, The pork belly is nice and juicy and the daikon adds just enough flavor (and I love daikons too, hehe) I always wish I have room in my belly to eat more since they're so good. 

I'm always excited to stop by this food truck and I can't wait till the next time I spot them :)
author: Harriet W.

description:
Ever since I seen this truck featured on Eat St, I had to try it to see what the hype was all about.  I got the chance to try them at the ERF this year at Jack London and really enjoyed the pork belly and 5-spice steamed buns.  

I saw that they were in SF close by work and since I didn't get to try their baked buns, I decided to check them out once again.  I got 3 buns (2 baked @ 6.75 and 1 steamed @ 3.25) totalling almost $18. That's super pricey for your average chinese bun but it is packed with a lot of  meat and/or filling. One baked one will get you full.  I'm a fan of the tender pork belly with pickled daikon in a baked bun.  The pork cubes really are soft and flavorful.  I don't even know what daikon is but it's sweet and tangy that gives the bun good texture with it's slight crunch.
author: Resa N.

description:
Such a good looking truck..

They have steamed or baked bao. I didn't specify and got steamed. The ingredients are good separately and then amazing together. Great combinations in a pillowy bao. 

My favorites thus far and totally recommend:
Pork Belly w/ Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso
Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic, Mayo, and Baby Choy Sum

The pork belly bao is also #32 on the 2011 7x7 100 Things To Try List!

It's filling. It's tasty. Served in a to-go box. 
..Definitely something to try. It's not your average Asian market bao.
author: O M G.

description:
I tried Chairman Bao Buns at my first Food Truck experience at Off The Grid at Fort Mason and I was HOOKED!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  I bought 5 different steamed buns to share  w/friends.  Their #1 Seller: Pork Belly ended up being my favorite and the Braised Pork steamed buns were my second favorite. 

Now, can someone please tell me why I cannot, and I repeat CANNOT find any Food Truck that beats Chairman Bao Buns in Flavor?  

Almost every week, I kept going back to Off The Grid to try other trucks just to get disappointed Again and Again, so I vowed never to Waste my Time lining up at other trucks AGAIN!!!
author: Caitlyn C.

description:
Crispy garlic Tofu with miso greens steamed ($2.95), add a splash of sriacha. The best food truck in SF. 

Smooth tofu, soaked in buttermilk over night with perfectly cooked greens. One is a snack, two is a small meal, three is a party.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
Went here for the 2nd time and even though there was a long wait (45 minutes), I was not disappointed (or maybe because I wash't starving during the time). Ordered the spicy chicken bao and it was delicious. 

If you do not mind waiting for 45 minutes and have the time, give this place a try.
author: Anthony N.

description:
We were lucky enough to find Chairman Baos at a food truck event in Sacramento.  Had the pork belly with daikon, steamed and the Spicy chicken with pickeled carrots, baked.

Happened to be in the City and saw the truck drive by and followed it.  Does that make me a stalker??  Don't care, it's worth it!!
author: Teri F.

description:
4: Pretty yummy, and I'd encourage anybody who hasn't tried steamed buns to try it out! But, the food isn't perfect. 

Food: Well, since my mom and dad are Taiwanese, I've had a couple chances to eat these types of steamed buns before. I ordered the pork belly and coca-cola pork steamed buns. The pork belly was made well! Juicy, crispy, not too fatty, but pretty fatty haha. The buns also held up fine (were maybe a taad bit thin) and had that nice, slightly sweet taste. But what I was confused about was the overall bun. Most buns I've had also included some small slices of cucumber, or some relish, or some light powdery nutty topping. The daikons were kind of overpowering, I'd have preferred a lighter veggy instead. The coca-cola pork was standard. 

Price: A combo deal would be nice? $3.75 per bun is alright as a snack, but to get a lunch's worth, becomes pricey. Buns aren't supposed to be expensive!

Service: Everything was pretty quick and great!  The truck came to my work area in Brisbane, where there aren't TOO many people.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I first saw this food truck at The Truck Stop but there was too long of a long during lunch time to wait. But I stumbled upon it again at Off The Grid and the line wasn't too bad, so we decided to give it a try after hearing great raves. We ordered the steamed buns with the pork belly and pickled daikon and the braised pork belly. Both were really delicious as the pork was melt in your mouth and the garnishes complemented well to make the sandwiches not too heavy. A steamed bun is still reasonable for $3.75. The staff is friendly and if you catch the truck at the right time then there won be too much of a wait. This is one of my favorite food trucks!  A must try!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Everytime I hear or think about the Chariman truck, I always picture my friend Mary K. going OMG. 

Today I felt like the n00biest of the n00b at my first OTG in Alameda! I was so glad to get there at 11 am right when it opened and The Chairman already had a bit of a line, so I hopped right into it! It was a decent wait if you have the bingo app on your phone. Why did I feel like a n00b? I ordered two. Just two. Some guy 2 spaces in front of me ordered one and people made him sound crazy. There were people ordering 10-20 of them, and I've got to hand it to them, they work pretty fast for orders that crazy!

The food is amazing, like many others, there is no way to describe the mixture of flavors. I knew the moment I Yelped Chairman Bao that I was a steamed bun kind of girl and my instincts did not let me down because the size and texture of the bun is perfect for the fillings they offer. I really appreciate all the flavors they have! Daikon with pork bely, mustard seeds and coke-a-cola braised pork. I'm SO ready to try more of them next time. 

Definitely not a n00b anymore, thanks Chairman Bao!
author: Dor H.

description: I find most food trucks to be overrated and overpriced, but this truck is awesome. I never had pork belly until I tried their pork belly steamed bao and it is one of the greatest things I have ever eaten. The meats and sauces go very well with the pickled veggies they use. You can tell all of the baos were very carefully designed and the ingredients were meticulously paired with each other. The steamed baos I think are 3.75 each, some might say it is expensive, but I think it is worth it. Personally I find 3 1/2 steamed baos to be a perfect amount of food. I have not tried the baked baos yet because I like the steamed ones so much.
author: Ryan C.

description:
You can get a little taste of communism at Chairman Bao's by waiting a long time in line for a little bit of food.  The filling choices are fresher and tastier than anything you'll get in Chinatown, but there is a price premium for that!  If you get a bunch of the smaller steamed buns it's like your own personal curbside dim sum.

Buns: You have two choices.  The steamed buns are like the ones you'd get served with Peking Duck, overflowing with the filling.  The baked bun is NOT like the one you'd get at a Chinese bakery with BBQ pork hiding inside, it is more like a brioche sandwich roll cut in half with a double serving of filling.  The baked option is more filling, but I prefer the steamed bun because the flavor is subtler and lets you focus on what's in the middle.

Tender Pork Belly: Large slabs of pork belly and lots of them.  Very tender unlike some tough pork bellies that are cooked too fast.  Soft all throughout, sadly no crispy outside though.  The pickled daikon does a good job of pairing tart with the rich fatty pork.  Definitely my favorite.

Braised Pork: Very soft pulled pork with a creamy mustardy sauce.  Seemed more like Southern BBQ than Chinese influence.  Kind of like a slider, so I wasn't too wowed.  Maybe they should try Chinese Hot Mustard instead?

Red Sesame Chicken: Thankfully it's not that deep fried chicken in a sticky sauce you get from greasy Chinese restaurants with numbered menus.  The whole thing had an overwhelming taste of tahini.  Not as rich as the pork options so it went down very quickly.

Crispy Garlic Tofu: I was shocked that the tofu tasted so good!  Many times tofu from street carts tends to be an afterthought to assuage the whiny vegetarian/vegan co-worker in the lunch group.  It was lightly fried; think chicken milanese not the Colonel's.  HEAVY garlic taste which is totally yummy, but best for a day when you don't have any client meetings in the PM.

Bao Chips: Too much nori!  I appreciate that they are trying to spice up the stereotypical wonton chip, but it was so heavy on the seaweed it tasted too fishy.
author: Adam B.

description:
Like others have said--great concept. But as many brownie points they get from me for that, they still haven't won me over with execution.

I had the Chinese Sausage and the Duck Confit because they ran out of the Pork Belly. The Chinese Sausage needed more sausage and less hoisin sauce. It's WAY too much hoisin sauce for healthy consumption--probably enough for a whole month. And it really pulls away from the flavor that's supposed to stand out--the chinese sausage!! The duck confit was alright--I'm not crazy about the spicy sauce (a bit too thick and creamy for me), but I guess it goes fairly nice with the mango.

I also had the green tea matcha mango iced drink... this was the best thing I had but it's no new concept--there's a place in Oakland chinatown that does this really well already.

I think this place has potential, but for now I haven't bought into the hype. I'll be back sometime--until then, Chairman Bao, keep on truckin'...
author: Joanne Y.

description:
Chairman, thank you for making my day just so, so much better!

I was at the Treasure Island flea market today, and just around closing time my stomach started to complain. I had a $5 food voucher in my hands for participating in a survey at the flea market, and a row of food trucks that would take it off my hands. Wild game sausage? Tempting. Curry truck? Long line. Empanadas? Oh no, they're closing up with the market! I've gotta hurry up and spend my voucher...

The Chairman? Sure. They have a short line, and are the cheapest of the bunch, I'll get almost 2 buns for my litte voucher. Give me a pork belly and spicy chicken, please?

Oh. My. God. These little buns are too good for just a simple OMG. They require the full OH. MY. GOD!!! Or maybe it should be OH. MY. BUDDHA!?

Either way, this was one of the best food truck experiences I've ever had. I almost went back for seconds, but felt a little silly. Of how I regret it now. Chairman, someday our paths will cross again, and I will sample the rest of your tasty treats.

Until then, I'll let the lingering taste of your perfectly pickled daikon tide me over.
author: Seth N.

description:
- all 3 steamed sandwiches we ordered were delicious.
- price $3.25 - $3.75 each

ordered:
- Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro (most favorite)
- Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso
- Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum
author: Nadia Geddi T.

description:
Food: 3
Decor: 4
Service: 4

Got a steamed pork belly bun here at Stanford. 

It was okay, but the duck baos I had at The Source in DC two weeks ago were cheaper and better. This steamed pork belly bun felt rather heavy, perhaps since it was quite oily.
author: David L.

description:
Generally great food here, but it's not cheap for the amount you're getting.  I've been coming here for lunch and dinner and here are my pros and cons:

Pros: Great food, very tasty... my favorites are baked short rib and noodle salad with braised pork

Cons: the bun can sometimes be dry or stale tasting, prices are not cheap for the quantity you're getting, the drink is way too sweet (I tried the lemonade).
author: Max M.

description: Steamed pork belly bun was cheap, yet amazing. I can see why this food truck has so much hype to it! Yet another food truck added to the list of "food trucks that Sean's stalking".
author: Sean H.

description:
There are few food trucks out there that actually deserve to get caught up in the food truck craze. Chairman Bao is one of them. It does Chinese style "tacos" and "sandwiches" and it does it well. 

What you get is either a peking duck style steamed bun, or a baked (think Chinatown Bakery style) bun (or bow), and you got your fixings: Pork Belly, Braised Pork, and Red Seasame Chicken. 

Style-wise: I prefer the steamed bun, its a smaller portion and much easier to eat. When you bite into the baked bun, everything seems to gush out, and you're left holding an oily mes. Plus! It's cheaper. 

Fixings-wise: I prefer the Braised  Pork or the Red Seasame Chicken. The latter is a bit spicy, from I remember, which I like...think Thai-influence when you're eating it. The Pork Belly, unfortunately, its quite a fatty and greasy mess. Maybe it's just me, but I don't enjoy fatty pork. (I don't like Roli Roti's Porchetta either).

Forget about all the other food trucks jumping onto the food truck craze, Chairman Bao is the real deal.
author: Ray W.

description: Well, what else is there to say that hasn't already been said? Chairman Bao's buns are the real deal. Go for the steamed tender pork belly with pickled daikon. You will not be disappointed. The pork belly is bold and flavorful, yet super tender. It is topped with the perfect amount of pickled daikon, which provides contrast in taste and texture and sandwiched between a warm pillowy steamed bun. It rivals the pork belly bun from Momofuku Milk Bar and is more tender than the one from Ippudo, both in New York City.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
I do not know why it took me that long to have the cola pork, but that is my new favorite item!

I will truly miss their food once I move out of state.
author: Shaun C.

description: Tender pork belly was delicious. Baked version which is a good portion size. The coca cola braised pork was ridiculously good. Steamed portion which is rather small if I absolutely have to find a negative. Worth the drive wherever they are.
author: Michael D.

description: Saw the Chairman roaming around in Japantown and I just had to make a detour to try their famed steamed pork belly bun. The pork belly was thick cut and extremely savory and stuffed into a tiny bun (similar to the ones served with peking duck) and topped with picked radishes. The radishes were crunchy and foiled well with the pork belly which was beyond fork tender. All in all, great meal....well worth my $4.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
This was one of the rare times when I saw the Chairman Truck having no line. I took advantage because I might never get this opportunity again.

Amongst my asian friends we would always scoff at the prices. "I could go to Chinatown and get an entire box for the same price!" I hoped my experience would be worth the cost.

I ordered the baked bun with pork belly for $6.25. The food came pretty quick. It seems like they create in batches because everyone got their food at the same time. Impressive. I guess they do have a lot of practice. Opening my biodegradable compartment my sandwich-of-sorts looked a little small yet you could tell from the pork belly and perfectly golden bun that it was rich.

I have to hand it to them. Their baked bun is awesome. It's incredibly soft and the golden crisp of the edges have a nice tooth to them. The pork belly is good although just a hair dry. They also put pickled daikon for crunch. I would have liked either more daikon or a more intense pickling. There's not enough acid to cut through the fat and richness. I think they put a sauce on it??? I couldn't really tell but they could have used some (more).

So why the low star score? This is too rich for me! I took three bites and I was full. I microwaved it for lunch the next day (holds up really well in the microwave). It looked so small but after eating the rest of it my stomach was squealing. It's probably the bun and the pork fat doing high-fives with each other.

____

Going down it tastes great. But my stomach can't handle the grease and fat. It's almost like eating donuts with pork belly. If I get a chance I'll try the steamed buns yet I hope it doesn't kick me in the stomach. More daikon please.
author: Michael H.

description:
Omg. If I could eat their pork belly buns everyday without turning into a little pork bun myself, I totally would! The pickled daikon on them is the perfect touch for the sweet and savory taste of the pork belly.
I've tried chairman a few times and I'm never ever disappointed! 
The pulled pork with cabbage and mustard seeds is also another favorite of mine. The flavored are really strong, which is fantastic! 
Service is quick, people are friendly. I really want to just follow them around everyday.
author: Debbie P.

description:
I stuffed my greedy little pie . . .err . . . bun hole with The Chairman trucks bao. I typically get tow and sometimes three if I feel especially piggy. I love the chicken. I recently tried the coca-cola glazed pork and it was just as satisfactory. I was forced to eat the tofu and was super impressed.
never misses!
author: Alexander R.

description:
For someone use to growing up in the Richmond district and going to the local Chinese bakery for breakfast/char siu baos deliciousness, it was definitely a weird feeling going to Chairman Bao Bun Truck. It was like hmm...is this what people do when they become adults or young yuppies? 

My cheap Chinese sense of self felt offended by the price until I received my bun and started realizing this is not Chinese American food. This is Asian fusion food and realized that no part of my Chinese American self could really compare the two. Instead, it was time to say bye to my Chinese American cheapskate and for my foodie self to inhale...and enjoy. And enjoy, I did. 

The pork belly bun is like a Peking duck without the Peking duck, but the pork belly with its tenderness and savory sauces is a lovely substitute. 

I'm not sure if I would try some of their other combinations as one of the meat buns had mustard seeds in it, but this truck is definitely something worth checking out.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
I've been seeing so much hype about this truck and I finally got around to trying it today. I thought it was pretty good, but there were a couple mitigating factors.... First, the line is always super long. If you wait that long in line, you'd sort of expect that the food would be worth it. Second, the prices are high for what you get. The baked bun is $6.75 and is only a little bigger than like a slider you'd get at a bar. It doesn't really get you full, and I think it's too overpriced. 

I got the coca-cola braised pork in the baked bun. I really enjoyed it, but like I said earlier, I don't think it's worth the weight or the money and it doesn't fill you up. I'm glad I tried it, but I don't think I'll be coming back!
author: Jamie C.

description: Pork belly bun is great.  Love the daikon.  The other buns are boring.  Just eat 3 of the pork belly daikon bun.
author: Niniane W.

description: Really great; worth the wait. They take orders with a pleasant attitude no matter how long the line.  The food was great!
author: tina m.

description:
Had the chance to stop by here during Off the Grid. Got the steamed bun with tender pork belly and steamed bun with red sesame chicken. Both were delicious, but I find myself preferential to the tender pork belly. But holy crap, were they expensive! I paid a whopping $7 for two buns that were too small for what they were worth.
