I could get a more filling burrito with that money. The baked bun looked like a more satisfying alternative, but it's basically like paying $6-$7 for a burger...

The buns were delicious, yes, but not special enough to warrant such a high price. I won't be coming back often.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Pretty darn good if you ask me! This place sets a high standard for food trucks. They have a creative concept, tasty food, friendly service, and a cool lookin' truck (:

I ordered the braised pork, pork belly, and spicy chicken, all steamed. Not paying attention to the pictures on the menu, or checking Yelp before hand (which is unheard of in my daily life), I was expecting a regular looking steamed bun like you get when you eat at a dim sum spot. My food came out and it looked more like an Asian taco .. Haha. Very interesting! All three had really good flavor, the buns were sweet, and the toppings just made everything extra yummy!

They were pretty busy but the food still came out fast. They also take card, which is a huge plus since I never carry cash. It is a bit pricey, but I feel like that's a given since it's a food truck. Either way, I didn't mind since it tasted good. I will for sure come back again!
author: Malyssa C.

description:
I've only had the pork belly buns here... I can't seem to stray in case the rest of them aren't as good. 

I've had both the baked bun and the steamed bun... I love the steamed bun a lot. They are incredibly fluffy and soft... and the pork belly just works so well. The baked bun comes out looking like a burger and is filling enough for me to call it a day after one. The flavors are intense and the pork belly is cooked perfectly. 

I toss a ton of siracha on top to add the spice factor... I only wish they could give an option of tossing some spice on top. 

I think this food truck lives up to the hype and that's why I am willing to stand in that ridiculous line.
author: Jeannie L.

description:
Great food, but probably not worth the hour+ wait.

I personally waited 3 hours for my baos at the SactoMoFo festival. I wish I had gotten it before at other festivals when they weren't so crazy popular yet. =P Oh well.

By the time you get to the front you want to order as much as possible after waiting so long, and they have a 6 bao limit. The long wait coupled with a maximum order is a great marketing strategy that makes almost everyone order the maximum amount. Smart!

Seems they have different baos sometimes. I really liked the pork belly and tofu out of the ones I tried, but I'm reading about other baos in other people's reviews that weren't even on the menu when I went!
author: Esther Y.

description:
The food from this truck is so good. I will follow it anywhere!!
I always get the tofu in green, either baked or steamed.  I've heard the other meat dishes are very good also. You must try this place
author: Isabella E.

description: They refused to make a vegan sandwich even though they have tofu were unwilling to not butter the bun. I asked to just get the tofu and no bun. They refused. It was pretty surprising and kind of rude. Wouldn't recommend it at all but to be honest never actually got to taste anything
author: Ryder M.

description:
I only swung by on a whim. Could not be happier that I did! Their vegetarian steamed buns are little fluffy, crunchy pillows of deliciousness. And they're only the second tofu dish I find myself actually craving. The baked version is almost as good, but more like a burger bun, and humongous.

The wonton chips are nothing to write home about. But who cares? Order another bun.
author: Brian W.

description:
This truck is legit.

I've heard the rave reviews...but have never been at the right place nor the right time..until today..my cube mate Kit announced their whereabouts...YESSSSS! (who needs twitter when you have friends?)

Growing up buns have always been my comfort food..these guys have mastered the buns with brilliant flavors. 

I got the garlic tofu with Chinese bok choy and the pulled pork with napa cabbage and mustard sauce....but seriousely..all of them are amazing.

They now make a stop infront of John Colins every Thursday during HH.
author: Mimi T.

description:
I love the pork bun taco thingys! I crave them all the time...

When at a moveable feast if this truck is absent I am highly disappointed!

Can we please clone this truck and permanently place one in the south bay???
author: Joey V.

description:
We waited over 1/2 hour in line @ Off the Grid at Fort Mason, but it was worth the wait.  Ordered all 4 steamed bun items off the tiny menu posted on the truck - the pork belly; braised pork shoulder; red sesame chicken; and the garlic tofu.  Favorite hands down was the pork belly.

The wait was tolerable since you can order and eat from the other food trucks while waiting in line.

The steam buns are shaped the size of the buns served in Chinese restaurants when you order Peking duck.

Didn't try the baked bun version but it's resembles a hamburger bun and double the size and double the price of the steamed version.

Will definitely go back and stand in line again since it's that good.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Verdict: My favorite communist pork buns. The food here is amazing; always good and a great combination of flavors. 

Also: According to the website, it was votes "Best Food Truck" by San Francisco Magazine! Impressive.

I've come here twice and gotten the same things because they were just that good. The chicken (with sesame sauce, carrots, cucumbers, and cilantro) was really tender and flavorful. The pork belly (with daikon) was even more tender and juicy. I love how when you eat it, the sauce and meat juices start to run down your hands. Messy hand food at it's best.

They have two options, the steamed bun and baked bun. While the baked bun is larger and more filling, I think the steamed bun is the best way to fully experience Chairman Bao. The smaller, slightly sweet, fluffy steamed bun is the perfect base for the marinated meat and pickled vegetables.

The food comes out pretty fast here, and while it's a bit expensive at $3-4 for a small steamed bun (a 3-4 bite snack), the innovative flavors are more than worth it!
author: Cat W.

description:
My favorite food truck by far!! I must say, I was honestly drawn to the truck by the unique design. 

Although the wait at Fort Mason may be long, IT IS WORTH THE WAIT! My favorite items would have to be the pork belly and chicken on the steamed buns. 

A must try next time you see them. Keep up the good work guys!
author: Sandie L.

description:
SO good!  I tried the tofu bun today after a recommendation from a coworker and it  was soooooo good. I'm not a huge tofu fan, but it has just enough garlic in the slaw on top and punch to fill you up.

*Yelp says they accept credit cards. They don't. At least the truck on Ritch Street doesn't. 

A definite must try truck. Two thumbs up.
author: Theresa N.

description:
Mmm not bad at all! Don't know if it was worth the wait but it was pretty good!

I had the chance to try Chairman Bao at the SactoMoFo event, and let me just start out by saying the line was crazy long. It was like Disneyland on crack! I was a little disappointed in the food for such a long wait, but oh well.

I got:
Red chicken steamed bun: my favorite!! Loved the sauce in it!
Pork belly steamed bun: Meh. not a huge fan. Tasted too fatty for me.
Crispy tofu steamed bun: Yumm!!! The tofu was so good!! Wasn't overwhelmingly greasy, either.
Even my friend, who's vegetarian & HATES Asian food enjoyed the tofu bun. That's a good sign!

Definitely worth a try, especially since it's unique!
author: Janet H.

description:
First time at Off the Grid in the Haight...got here around 4:45 on a Thursday and found parking about 2 blocks away...Yay! Tried the Chairman Bao Bun truck due to the reviews and suggestions...i was so looking forward to the duck bun but unfortunately, all they had was the pork belly!  Bummer....if anything, this helped to moderate my food consumption because after eating one, i had to have another...even my friend went back and ordered 5 to go...

Description of the pork belly bun:
* pork belly juicy, tender with an outer crispness
* the bun was the standard steamed pork bun (without the filling)
* pickled thinly sliced yellow daikon

Very simple ingredients but full of flavor.
Note:  as soon as you get there, reserve yourself some chairs to sit and eat...otherwise, you'll be eating standing up! not optimum
author: Cheryl M.

description: I forgot to review this place last week when they were at SFSU. Grabbed a Coca-Cola pork steamed bun, spicy chicken steamed bun and a pork belly baked bun. They definitely do not skimp on the filling. The baked buns are huge and filling. Order a couple steamed buns for a meal and just to try the the different proteins. My favorite was the pork belly, so full of flavor and tender. Next time I'll stick to the pork belly and ask for them to go light on the daikon it can be a bit overpowering.
author: Julie C.

description:
Tried this place for a work function a bit ago.  I remember they offered up a handful of different fillings and you could choose either a steamed or baked bun.  Sadly they only had steamed buns when I rolled around so bear that in mind.  Now onto the food.

The buns that stood out for me:
1. Pork Belly
Come on of course.  It's freakin pork belly.  Sorry people...fat is good for you!  Eat it!  The pork belly is crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  I also liked the homemade daikon pickles that go on top of the pork belly...cripsy, sweet, sour...yum.  Gimme a jar of that to go.  You can throw in a jar of pork belly too while you're at it.

2. Tofu
Yes!  I know it's not paleo, but I had to try it...and I actually liked it 2nd best.  Hats off to you Chairman Bao.  If I had to bet on my order of buns I would have lost due to this upset.  The tofu was very flavorful.  Way Awesome.

3. Braised Pork
Oh Braised Pork...you were supposed to be #2.  It was good, but just didn't have the same flavor impact as the Pork Belly and the Tofu.

Rest:
Didn't really stand out to me...besides at these prices do you want to waste your time with anything lower than 3rd place?

So if it were so good why 3 stars?  I want to be fair and personally if I had to pay for the meal I had I'd probably have a little sticker shock.  I could easily eat 6 to 8 buns for a meal.  That adds up fast.  Great buns, but not an everyday kinda thing for me.
author: David K.

description:
LUV IT!
the boa is wonderfully delicious all things considered. if they have tofu I get the tofu and it's beautiful on the tongue!
Eating from trucks is great as long as there's not line and this truck has typically got a long one. No fun when you only have an hour for lunch. My coworker will buy about four buns but I can only do two.
They always smile at me and that's a nice bonus.
author: Lizzy M.

description: The Chairman truck comes to our office about once a week and it is hands down the best food truck that stops by. I always get so excited when I see that they are on the truck schedule because it is just one less thing to have to worry about during my workday. I've tried a few things on their menu and they've all been good but my favorite is the spicy chicken on a baked bun.I'm a fan of the baked buns because I really like the size; the steamed ones are a little small if I just order one and are too much food for lunch if I order two I have found. Be warned the chicken is quite spicy but the pickled cucumber and carrot over the top balance it out really nicely and cool things down. On top of the great food the people are always really nice and they get the food out really fast which is awesome. Overall a great experience!
author: Christy D.

description:
I second (or third, or fourth) the recommendation for the pork belly bun.  It's really good here.  I also tried the red sesame chicken bun - which was spicier than I expected but still good.  I got two steamed buns, which are smaller than the baked buns but it was filling enough for me for lunch.

Pork Belly = $3.75
Red Sesame Chicken = $3.25

The most impressive part of the buns to my surprise were the pickles on top.  Wow.  Those pickles are really really good!  

Although I wouldn't eat here every day, it's a great way to treat yourself.
author: Jean K.

description:
I get so excited when I see the big panda truck outside my office.  First of all, who doesn't love a panda anything?  Secondly, yummy food.  And lastly I discovered today - pretty fun drinks as well!

The duck is my favorite.  I've tried the steamed chicken, the steamed pork belly and they were both just "eh" for me.  But the duck....oh..the mango and the duck and the sauce...*drool* so good!  The baked bun duck is actually the best, but the steamed bun duck is good too - I switch back and forth depending on my mood.  Today I also tried the strawberry coconut drink and though it's not like the best drink I've ever had, it is still a yummy little after lunch snack to get me through the rest of the afternoon.

For $9 you can get:
2 steamed buns + icy bevy -or-
1 baked bun + icy bevy
author: Doris L.

description:
The BF just haaaaaaaaad to get this when we saw them at the Treasure Island Flea in May. I was not convinced (seriously, steam buns?) and went and got food from another truck.

I'm going to be fair and say the reason I'm mostly not impressed is because whoever was working this event (cash register person, I'm talking to you!) just plain-out SUCKED. Dude, get it together. There was probably about 20 people in line here, as well as in the line I waited in. We both got in line at the same time. I ordered, wait in line with my bf, went back and got my good, got back in line with my bf, watched him order, and waited for his food while trying at this point not to inhale everything I had gotten from the other place because I was starving! That kid had no idea what was going on.

Anyway, the bf got the pulled pork steam bun and the tofu baked. The baked buns are huge! But the tofu was pretty bland. We put helllllllllllllla sriracha on it and it was still bland. 

The bf really enjoyed his pork bun, but his opinion is kind of sketch because I'm not sure he actually even chews his food before he swallows it. Bahaha...busted!

All in all, I won't be back; but I wouldn't bad mouth them to anyone. With all the food trucks out there in the world these days, I see no reason to go back to one that was mediocre.
author: Courtney S.

description:
Pork belly steamed bun is a must try. A three-to-five bites bun. It melts in your mouth and even tastier with a touch of pickle. I would totally put it to the something to eat before you die list.

Friendly service. I usually get it from SF Lunch box, 246 Ritch St. Only few minutes wait before you can start biting it. One, two, three... gone!

Track this truck down, worth following.
author: Khwan L.

description: I've been to off the grid a lot of times and wasn't too blown away by it until I met the Chairman. I thought I wouldn't like the food because I thought it was fusion but I was wrong. I got the porkbelly bun and OMG my mouth was blown away!! I was drooling and everything. Please do yourself a favor and get this bun! It may seem a tad overpriced but its worth the experience!
author: Grace C.

description:
Great idea, but still over-rated and over-priced.  $3.xx for steamed buns and $6.xx for baked buns.  Definitely overpriced for the baked, but apparently, people are still willing to pay a premium for a yuppie pork bun.  Yes, the flavors are different, but you do get more bang for your buck paying $1 or $1.50 for a pork bun at your regular Chinese hole in the wall.  

I tried the pork belly (steamed) as it seemed to be the popular one.  I had no idea what to expect as I imagined a chewy meat, as that's what pork belly usually is.  It turned out different - it tasted like chicken, although it was a bit rough on the outsides like overcooked meat.  It wasn't bad, but it wasn't super drool in your mouth good either.  

I think I'll go back to my old school pork buns.  BTW, a lot of people aren't aware of baked pork buns (everyone knows of the steamed fluffy white version) - definitely try the baked ones the next time you're at a Chinese bakery.
author: Laura C.

description:
The Chairman is the reason why I like Food Trucks. Interesting and exciting. 

Served in a bun - baked, not in a bao like you find at Dim sum, with a nice big slab of pork belly along with the crunchy pickles. Delicious and memorable. 

Wait time? Less than a min. Yes.
author: Ken C.

description: I absolutely love this food truck. I frequently got to Fort Mason and Upper Haight locations.
author: James F.

description:
Sampled the Chairman's goodies at Off the Grid. The line was pretty long but the wait was worth it. I was famished so ordered two baked buns, one braised pork, one pork belly. In reality, it was a bit too much food. Will go with the smaller steamed bun versions next time.

I preferred the pork belly bun, and not just because it was less messy to eat. The meat was tender, flavorful, but not oily tasting. The pickled onions and daikon added some sweetness and texture. I wolfed down that thing like I just walked out a prison camp. 4.5 stars

The braised pork bun was good, but maybe due to the fact that I was almost full, wasn't as tasty as the pork belly. The texture of the meat was soft and not stringy, although I wouldn't say it was buttery/melt in your mouth goodness. The pickled cabbage added a punch. I felt like the sandwich lacked something and dipped it in some sriracha and it was an instant pick-me-up. Note to self, always dip the chairman in some spicy chili sauce. 4 stars

All in all, I really like the offerings at Chairman Bao. Hopefully he'll call back and we'll have another date.
author: Alice W.

description:
The Food Truck cultural revolution is here.  The  "liberal bourgeoise" elements are permeating the "party" and "society at large" and want to restore capitalism.  I say FUCK THEM - with Chairman Bao on our side, we can't lose. 

It is time, ladies and gentlemen, to embrace "the four great rights of great democracy".

1.  Food trucks will be free to circulate - wherever they choose to go!  
2.  Food trucks will be freely praised on Yelp and on Twitter. 
3.  Food trucks will be colorful and well designed - big poster style. 
4.  Food trucks will be the subject of "great debates" regarding which one is in fact the tastiest.

As a corollary, everyone who does not believe in the food truck will be charged with bad taste and executed or sent to prison.  It's cool tho, don't worry about it.   

In conclusion, all hail the godlike Chairman Bao.  Coming soon to a peninsula location near you.
author: Leon K.

description: Of all the food trucks here, the Chairman is the best bang for your buck.  I started following the food truck trend when I worked in the city, but after trying out almost all, I realized that the food isn't that great and for the price, I'd rather go to a real sit down restaurant.  When it comes to food trucks, I would recommend finger food like Bao, otherwise everything is kinda unsanitary and doesn't taste great consistently.
author: Katie N.

description:
I've tried all the buns on this truck.  They're good.  

But, the shining star is the STEAMED pork belly with turmeric pickled daikon.

O. M. G.  Party in your mouth!

The bun is fluffy and melts in your mouth, the pork belly is tender and juicy, and the pickled daikon enhances the flavors with a refreshing crisp.  

$2 for asian coconut water is a rip off, isn't that like 60 cents at Ranch 99?

Note: The line at the SF off the grid on Fridays is outta control after 630pm.  Not gonna lie, I have waited through it before because the chairman is that good.  (The line at the Berkeley off the grid is child's play compared to fort mason...I would recommend coming here if you are not good at waiting)
author: Susan L.

description: Pretty good.  I ate three, now i'm gonna pass out.
author: Michael E.

description:
When next I go for a pork bun I'll be sure to wear my kangol mao cap and stalinist shirt. I felt all campy and red ordering here but after a bite of pork belly I knew that I had left the camp tent and walked onto Tienanmen square.

The pork belly is greasy mushy soft tender crack, seriously, I'd like just a pound of the belly forget the bun, throw the pickle on there, maybe a little scallion and I'll go to town on it like 1917. The chicken was tasty and had a nice kick to it but paled in comparison to the pork. 

I wasn't terribly impressed with the bun, it was just, well a bun. There are some crazy good buns at dim sum shops on clement, it made for an interesting sandwich but didn't make me week in the knees like the belly. I hear there's duck but they were out, so I'm holding off final judgment until I have ze duck.
author: Len S.

description:
Oh. My. Goodness. This was the greatest choice I've made in a while! 

I've been a huge fan of food trucks, so I was very excited to see the corral at the Creator's Project this past weekend. Searching around for vegetarian options I found the crispy garlic tofu with miso greens and was intrigued. Standing in line I started speaking with the people around me who declared that the Chairman was probably the best truck there.

I decided to go with the steamed option since it was smaller (and less expensive). It arrived within a few minutes and was the perfect temperature. I am almost positive it was love at first bite. Tofu hasn't always been my favorite, but they found the perfect way to prepare it. Seriously, it was phenomenal. I would rather not admit how quickly I devoured it.

I will definitely be stalking The Chairman this summer...
author: Michelle K.

description:
Whenever The Chairman Truck is in my neighborhood I go running.  Later, I'll lie in bed at night still savoring the succulent pork belly.  It's just that delicious.

The menu is very simple--basically you choose your "bao" (bread) and then choose a filling.  But, since it can be a little intimidating your first time here, especially when it comes to gauging appropriate portion size, I've written this brief guide.

Bao Options: 
Steamed Bao - like a thick and fluffy Peking Duck pancake piled high with meat, veggies, etc.  They run around $3.75 and 2 of them make a small but satisfying lunch.

Baked Bao - like the bread from a roast pork bun, slit open with a knife and stuffed with filling.  They're larger, and cost around $6.25.  If you're hungry, get one of each.

Filling Scorecard:
A+  The juicy Pork Belly just melts in your mouth.  It's by far my favorite in the line-up.
A+  Miso cured fried Tofu - Not just for vegetarians!  Lightly fried (not crispy deep fried), moist and tender in the middle. Topped with lettuce, pickled radishes and a tasty sauce.  Add shiracha to kick it up a notch.
A    Coca Cola Pork - Delicious and mildly sweet.
A-   Spicy Chicken - Spicy and delicious.

Lunch portion/price guide:
Light to Medium Appetite: Order1 baked or 2 steamed bao ($6.25 - $7.50)
Medium to Large Appetite: Order 1 of each (~$10)
Huge Appetite: Order 3 steamed or 2 baked (~$11 - $12.50)
author: Zach B.

description:
I will be very, very short & sweet with this review, so here goes.

Holy crap.

Pork belly, duck and braised pork "tacos," what the eff???

I don't mean "WTF" in a surprised, "WHAT WILL THEY THINK UP OF NEXT?" way, but in the way that it was one of the most delicious things I've ever tasted.

One of my favorite food trucks in the bay, too bad I'm way down in SoCal =[
author: Patrick K.

description: This place is absolutely amazing.  It is by far the best food truck in the bay.  I usually get the tofu or chicken steamed bun which melts in your mouth (don't forget to add sriracha sauce for an extra kick).  It's a traveling truck so make sure to follow them to find out where they will be.  A must try!
author: Palwasha A.

description: oh man, everything they say is true. do yourself a favor and try this truck a few times. The first time I tried a bun steamed and wasn't too crazy about it, and the next time baked and I was sold. The pork! Nom nom!!
author: Christina M.

description: I have had the coca cola pork, the sesame chicken, the tofu steamed bun.  All are delicious.  When I see this truck at any event, my meal decision has automatically been made.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Growing up with authentic and tasty Chinese food in Hong Kong and Vancouver kinda ruined me for Chairman Bao. The first time I saw this truck I had no desire to try their buns, but after reading the great Yelp reviews--and in my effort to sample all the food trucks the Bay Area has to offer--I made it my first stop at a recent Off The Grid at Fort Mason. (It was a good thing I went there first as the lines were humongously long soon after!)

I'd planned to try a steamed and a baked bun but changed my mind when I saw the prices (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sT8TRzofJym5w0khZkOJhw?select=n2ppbhXNKoAOB19OTE1Zdg). $3.5 for a steamed bun was steep enough so there was no way I would pay $6 for a baked one. (Though I saw someone else eat one and they were the size of burgers--not exactly small eats. Still, you can get a baked bbq pork bun in Chinatown for 70 cents.) I got the red sesame chicken and braised pork steamed buns (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sT8TRzofJym5w0khZkOJhw?select=D8l2LToZj5azA6XRpbIVVg).

The chicken was flavourful but really really spicy; the bok choy helped and provided a nice crunch. I liked the braised pork better; it was flavourful but not as intense and very tender (kinda like pulled pork). I wasn't a fan of the steamed bun itself though. Chairman Bao doesn''t make them fresh so by the time you get them they're cold and stale. Steamed buns should really only be eaten fresh--while there's still steam coming off and the skin still slightly sticks to your fingers.

Overall the buns were just meh and the inflated prices didn't help. I'd much rather have the authentic stuff for only a small fraction of the price.
author: Steph L.

description:
OVERALL:4.0   FOOD:4   SERVICE:4    AMBIANCE:N/A   VALUE:4
Hell day at the office, and then......FOOD TRUCK SURPRISE!! Happy day! Stepped outside to catch a few specks of natural daylight & fresh air, and was instead swept up in a wave of herd mentality and yummy smells wafting down the street.

Didn't stop for Kara's frosting, the smokey burger assembly line, or Scream's sample train...just made a b-line for the shamelessly flamboyant Communist panda truck.  Please to give me dutiful steamed buns, comrade!

*Pork Belly & Pickled Daikon: OMG, this is some good sh**. All their steamed buns are really mini 'man tao' sandwiches stuffed with seriously tasty ingredients....so warm, fluffy and scrumptious!  Pork was tender, moist and fragrant, very high quality meat!  Could eat these for days!

*Roast Duck & Mango:  Surprisingly zesty, with fresh shaved shallot & maybe ginger?  Tasted like Asian persuasion jerk sauce, just mellowed out by the rich duckiness & far east flavors.

2 steamed buns + crazy fruit drink = $9....solid for super gourmet, spiffed out comfort food!  Next time I'm skipping on the fancy slurpee and going exclusively for more hot bun action!
author: Amy K.

description:
Probably one of my favorite food trucks that I frequent at OTG Larkspur. Awesome looking food truck that serves up delicious food. 

I think the steamed clamshell "bao" (normally reserved for peiking duck) is an ingenious vessel for packing the flavor in. It's fluffy and chewy, without being mushy. It's slightly sweet and is soft enough to soak up all those residual oils and juices and sauces from the meat. 

Their pork belly is just ridiculous. Pork belly by itself is an insanely delicious cut. It is fatty, juicy, tender, crispy, basically every type of flavor/texture you could ever want. The Chairman heaps on generous chunks of pork belly and tops it off with some sweet/sour pickled daikon. It adds a nice visual touch, as well as a nice crunch and cooling bite to level out the richness of the pork belly. 

I also tried their coca-cola pork shoulder. It's flavorful and tender and almost reminded me of a fresher version of the dried pork sung that you find in chinese grocery stores. The mustard seeds on top are a nice touch.

Still haven't tried their baked versions, but I'm sure they will be just as good.
author: Tim W.

description: Checking in on the new shop on Larkin. Great baos, add on the chips to share and try the excellent house-made sodas.
author: Tom D.

description:
Heard a lot of huff and puff bought these guys so I had to try it when they came to SJ EAT 2011 in DTSJ!! The SJ EATS is a whooooollllee 'nother story in itself.... "/

Aside from that crowded madness, this truck is typically in the SF area so my expectations and anticipation was HIGH! I had hopes to try everything on the menu except the tofu cause.. I EATS MEATS FOO!!! They had Char Siu, Spicy Garlic Chicken, and Crispy Tofu, however no Duck Confit which I was really hoping for :( 

Got both there Steamed and Baked Version of Char Siu and Garlic Chicken with a cost of about $20 in total. There is a large difference in price, but there is a REASON for it, the Baked ones are about 3X the size of the steamed; its like eating a larger sandwich/burger.

The food was great, tasty buns and chewy buns, well seasoned/spiced chicken and char siu. The savory meat flavors went well with the soft dough and crunchy sourness from the pickled veggies stuffed inside (daikon/carrots/bok choy). Portions were decent, but being Chinese and knowing that SF Chinatown has the same stuff for a millions times cheaper holds me back. Its awkward to pay more than a $1 for a bun...seriously man, go eat some bomb dim sum.

The only things that turned me off was that the truck/workers/foodboxes were just dingy and greasy at the time...like I don't want to wear white clothes and be near it greasy; however this was the SJ EATS shindig so the masses obviously wore them down.
author: Randy L.

description:
I've been dying to try the buns forever. I finally got a chance to try them this past Saturday at Off the Grid.

You have your choice of baked or steamed. Baked is your typical round bun with stuffing inside. Steamed buns are like the pancakes you get when you order Peking Duck. I personally prefer steamed, I just like the taste of the dough. It's like a chinese taco. :)

My bf and I ordered 3 buns: braised pork with cabbage was so delicious, pork was juicy, tender, and savory cabage was good contrast to slight sweetness of braised meat. Tofu was a thick slice with greens, good flavor, they had run out of this one before we left. My other half liked the duck, I don't eat duck so can't say. 

I will definitely eat off this truck again. The steamed buns have become one of my favorite food truck items ever. 

And the logo is so cute. :)
author: Maria M.

description:
Really good food truck. Advanced flavors for a simple sandwich. Line was super long on a hot day, almost making me give up, but I'm glad I held out. The Baked roast pork sandwich was great.

Definitely coming back to try other options soon!
author: Karen C.

description:
From what I am reading by other reviewers, it seems like your food is pretty good. It actually prompted me to try out your truck this afternoon. As a vegetarian, I'm always looking out for interesting eats and your Miso Tofu Bun really seemed intriguing. After a  five block trek and a fifteen minute wait in line, my hopes were quickly dashed as you were "out of tofu". You're out of tofu at 1:00? No signage to warn the other hungry vegetarians? Time is money when you're on lunch break. You didn't get any of mine.

I'll give you one extra star for offering to make me a bun with spare parts, but to be honest, I'm a spiteful prick and I'd rather give my money to someone else.

Bring more tofu next time or change your name to Chairman No.
author: Go Cat Go G.

description:
BAKED PORK BELLY BAO is soooooooo freaking GOOD. I've been wanting to try The Chairman for the longest time and I finally got to this past weekend while my boyfriend waited in line for KoJa Kitchen. 

Since we were both starving, I ordered the baked pork belly bao, steamed braised pork and steamed spicy chicken bao. Pork belly was hands down my favorite and totally worth it for $6.75. Like I've mentioned before, food truck food can get pretty pricey sometimes so I wasn't too surprised about the price. The pork belly was so tender and flavorful. The pork was chopped up in many pieces and there was so much that the meat kept falling off with every bite. A in my book for not being stingy on the meat!

Spicy chicken was pretty good but didn't blow my mind. I couldn't really taste the spiciness of it which was a bummer. The steamed baos were warm and yummy though! There was a decent amount of meat on it but I'd rather pay another $3 for twice as much.

The coca-cola braised pork steamed bao was delicious! The pork was braised, pulled and put into a tiny little steamed bun with lots of meat. I guess you can say I have low standards so I'm not disappointed in overhyped foods but I really liked the flavor in the pulled pork. It wasn't try at all. 

For my first bao experience, I left a happy, happy girl. I'm also glad that The Chairman is coming down to the South Bay more often so I could indulge in this pork goodness.
author: Tammy N.

description:
I was really wary about the food here since a couple of my friends said their food was too salty.  I was down the street from john collins for an event and since I haven't eaten dinner I decided to go try the baos.

I walked on over to chairman bao and asked "eric" what was the most popular.  their two most popular was the pork belly and duck confit which were both sold out.  dangit!  oh well, so I decided to try the lion head meat ball and the sesame chicken on the steamed buns.  the lion head meat ball was my favorite out of the two.  I really liked both items, both had full flavor and wasn't salty at all.  there was a nice mix of textures to them.  the meat was nice and moist while the veggies were crunchy on a soft bun, a nice compliment.  

plus, eric was really friendly.  he came out of the truck and talked to me about "street food business".  I'll definitely come back to try their other items, hopefully the pork belly and the duck confit.  

chairman bao, I "BAO" to you!
author: Samson M.

description:
First tried it at OtG:Serramonte. Long ass lines but food was well worth the wait. 

Vegetarians try their Crispy Miso-Cured Tofu Bun. So good. Their wanton chips are pretty badass too but they are all deep fried so beware the calories and oil.
author: Fiona M.

description:
Had the baked pork belly sandwich with pickled daikon tonight.  
Was the best of all the food trucks that showed up.  LOTS of delicious pork belly, bun toasty goodness and the pickled daikon the perfect accompaniment.  Definitely must have again!  Guy working the truck very cool.
author: Mishy N.

description:
The steamed chicken bun blows my mind!  The first time I had it, I wanted more!  And to be sure it wasn't one of those things that I like one day and not the next, I had it again two weeks later and it was equally as mind blowing.  

I've also got my friends onboard who now think the Chairman food is equally as delicious as I do.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Found out that the truck was going to be in the alley behind my work today, and despite having brought my own perfectly serviceable lunch, I went for it - and I'm glad I did! That other lunch will be fine for tomorrow, today is Bao Day!

Sure, the line looks a little intimidating, and you worry that it's going to take forever. Well, it may take a few minutes more than some truck with no one in line, but I still felt like the line moved swiftly and the buns came quickly. And oh boy were they great!

I was told I had to try the pork belly, which by the name makes me a little skeptical, but it was honestly delicious. I trimmed a bit of the fat, which made me realize there was less than it seemed when I first peeked at it. And the sauce is the perfect blend of fat and amazing. 

They had four different bao available total, each one coming in both steamed and baked. None of the four failed to impress, even the tofu. I didn't think it could have much flavor, but it really did! A pleasing, savory miso-ness with a bit of sauce to highlight. There wasn't a one I didn't love. 

Well, now I'm even more excited to work in the Financial District - it means more access to the Chairman (Bao)!
author: Marie S.

description:
Alright last year I got super into Food Trucks as did everyone else I feel like. I was stoked when I moved to SF to find that there is an actual Food Truck Stop on Mission St.  They change up their trucks every day and post on a website. Boy was I lucky to have Chairman Bao on the day I went to the truck stop. This place is awesome. Probably one of my two favorite trucks next to the "Kogi" Truck in Los Angeles.
You can either get a steamed or baked bun. The baked is essentially a hamburger and the steamed is essentially a taco. The prices are a bit steep than in Chinatown but man the flavors are solid here. They took something traditional and added a nice twist to it with the ingredients that they place into it. The pork belly is my favorite by far here. The pickled daikon adds a solid contrast both flavor and texture wise and the pork belly is super tender and flavorful. I also had the spicy chicken also which was solid but nothing beats the pork here. Definitely use siracha sauce if you like a little kick but trust me, even without it you would love it. 
If you have not tried the Chairman yet, find it and get some. You will not regret it.
author: Dan M.

description:
for all the haters out there. unless you can do it better. just stop b-ing & moaning.
I love the pork belly bao. nice flavor. texture and temp are also spot on.
spicy chicken was nice with good heat.
yes, they use the small steamed buns but when you have two of them, that should be good enough for a quick lunch. 
this food truck is in the soma once a week and i am so thankful!
author: Jeff W.

description: I've had the Pork Belly Steamed Bao, and I must say that was a couple of bites of perfection.  The pork was tender and flavorful, and the pickled radish was a perfect complement.  The bun was not soggy and was firm enough to hold it all together.  I've always loved "quapaos" back home, and this to me is a awesome version of it.  I would've given it 5 stars, but at $3.75 each, it held me back.  Opportunity cost....is $3.75 worth two bites of yummyness???? You be the judge!
author: Raymund S.

description: I have eaten at Chairman's truck a hundred times since my last review. I was never disappointed. All four offerings on the menu are worthy of a king and a pauper. My vegetarian friends LOVE the miso cured tofu on steamed bun.
author: Balu V.

description:
Visited the Chairman Truck at the Fort Mason Off the Grid a couple weeks ago during my vacation. Off the Grid is quite the spectacle and the Chairman Truck is really the centerpiece of the whole event. I ordered a selection of their buns (2 baked and 2 steamed) not knowing exactly what I would be getting with that but excited to smaple their wares.

Ended up with 2 of the pork belly (1 baked and 1 steamed) and 1 each of the chicken and the braised pork and quite satisfied. The steamed buns were everything I've grown to love in a steamed bun (tender, slightly sweet) and the baked buns really packed extra stuff inside (making the extra cost well worth it) and held up to the ingredients both texture wise and flavor wise. 

The pork belly in the buns was fantastic and all of the toppings were really tasty and matched each of the meats appropriately. The neon picked radish really cut through the richness of the pork belly and despite my general hatred of mayo, the Kewpie mayo on the braised pork really worked in the context of the mustard seeds and the cabbage. The chicken was really tender and probably my 2nd favorite after the pork belly buns.

Highly recommended if you end up at one of the Off the Grid events or are lucky enough to grab the truck at another location!
author: Chris L.

description: After eating a pork belly sandwich from the Bacon Bacon Truck, I saw how long the line was for Chairman Bao. I decided to head on over and see how amazing these buns actually were. I had the duck and the coca-cola ribs, both were awesome! I recommend ordering the duck when stopping by this truck.
author: Sheree C.

description:
I feel dirty for liking this. Dirty like a occupy protesting, Chrome messenger bag carrying, skinny jean wearing hipster. I drank the proverbial Kool Aid and hunted this truck down for months. Each time found it, the line was ridiculously long so I end up eating elsewhere... 

Fast forward a year later and I accidentally drive by the Off the Grid event in Marin. I've always wanted to go to an Off the Grid food truck event, but can't stand the thought of being in SF. 

Anywhooooo, I hit the brakes when I spotted the trucks from the corner of my eye and back my car up illegally. Run up the hill and find that I'm second in line (the stars and moon have finally aligned!) Thinking the little bao would be small, I ordered one of each AND a baked one. These suckers were HUGE! Very generous portions of protein and soft/fluffy/slightly sweet bao. The baked one is actually the size of a burger. Everything was prepared perfectly, great marinade, and very tender. The clear standout was the pork belly, but everything else was pretty good.

Hands down the best value out of any food truck I've been to in the Bay Area. 

Score: Hipsters +1, Average Normal Jeans wearing person 0.
author: Noky C.

description: A couple of months ago, I was able to try Off the Grid for the first time at Fort Mason. And on that day, I had the best bao of my life. It was a steamed Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso. Simply amazing. One of my favorite meat pastries from anywhere in the world is a bao. And this particular bao was one of the most delightful things I have ever had in my mouth. Pure excellence.
author: April D.

description:
Hmmm Chairman Bao is now The Chairman Truck. Could it have anything to do with Eddie Huang (of Baohaus NY) threatening a lawsuit of copyright name infringement? Who knows. For now Eddie has rights to a Chairman Bao truck. And at least we know Eddie's Chairman Bao is based on his homeland's Taiwan style "hamburger" or gua bao, which got bastardized by David Chang and ended up making million$.

But anyway for this Chairman,  it is a good thing that "Bao" isn't in their name anymore. Phew.

Because what I had off the Chairman Truck was an ab$$$$olute aBAOmination. Especially to real Chinese food.

Perhaps I'm a traditionalist (re: a real a$$ $nob) at heart. I've had  mantou before (plain steamed buns) from Northern to Shandong style in Taipei and Hong Kong, Shanghainese steamed bun version in Hong Kong (including the pan fried one), cha siu bao (been eating those mofo's since I was 2 or younger, no joke), and in the last 5 years have had Taiwanese version of Shen Jian Bao, xiao long bao, Northern style baozi (pork and cabbage steamed buns), as well as some of the very best Taiwanese gua bao in Taipei, that ruined me for life. For example, Lan Jia Gua Bao in Taipei, a relative newcomer competitor to Shih Jia Gua Bao (30++ year old shop near Tong Hua Street Night Market) that is one of the greats

http://beefnoguy.blogspot.com/2010/01/lan-jia-gua-bao-pork-belly-burger.html

And thus ruined me so much that no commie Panda on wheels, even if customized by a Japanese chef (gasp), could impre$$ me no more.

If Chairman's steamed pork bellay bunz taste anything like NYC David Chang's MomoFuk-U's then no thank u.

Ok so the Commie Panda on wheels the other night had:

"Tender pork belly with pickled daikon" - was told the pork belly was braised then grilled or was it fried. A miniscule portion that I could hold with two fingers, pretty much gone with 3 medium sized bites. $3.75 poorer....$hit. Two flavor profiles....SALT and SOUR, not much going on there. This pork belly prep definitely caters to the American palette, but those who've had Cantonese, Taiwanese, Hangzhou style pork belly (in Asia and at the competent North American Chinese/Taiwanese restaurants) will find it on the dull side. Even a shio butabara (pork belly skewer) or tontoro (pork cheek) grilled skewer at a good yakitori joint executes the salted swine even better. Hell even Ramen Parlor's buta kakuni which I'm not a fan of has more flavor. As for charcoal grilled pork belly in a bun off a truck, guess this won't work, unless the truck itself is powered by charcoal....maybe on a choo choo?

"Braised pork with savoy cabage and mustard green seeds" - similar thing, except it was tender lean meat...again two very similar flavor profiles, almost one dimensional. The cabbage and mustard green seeds was however a nice touch texture wise, but a lot more was missing to make this easier to swallow in terms of worthine$$. Spicy rooster sauce would not have made this any better. Another $3.75 gone.

Oui oui je comprende....this is "food truck mania" and supposed to be trendy. And no, not everyone is a traditional$t $nob and if the real thing were offered by the Commie Panda at the same price at the same size, they would not like it. And plus most of you probably prefer CP over the rendition done by Joy in Foster City (that charges pretty much the same price for TWO similar sized items, but way more delicious and closer to the real deal than this trendy slider wackadoodle). And yes now I know why some Vietnamese expat yelpers (or those who know real Vietnamese food) look at Charles Phan's projects (or Chris Yeo's or basically most Asian fusion gone hip) and think he $old his $oul for rock & roll. But at least I have more respect for Charles Phan... than some fu$n simplified bao wannabe :-o

I'm definitely not sold on this hype, sorry. A single Lan Jia Gua Bao is NT$50 or a shade near $1.60 for something that's completely amazing that has texture, multiple tastes, fragrance, and just visually impressive. $3.75 for something that's 1/3 of the size, more than x2 the price, that has ridiculously few condiments (I mean yeah Sriracha is there but WTF? No shaved peanut powder, no cilantro, no kimuchi, and the pork itself has little flavor other than salt or soy?) make this overrated and overpriced.
author: Ken K.

description:
CASING THE JOINT...

I rolled up on my scooter to Chairman Bao's in front of the Restaurant Fixtures shop at 1:40pm. The truck is colorful, red, modern, clean, sparkly, fun graphics. The cook said.. it's closed, apparently they're only open from 11:30AM-1:30PM for lunch! However, they had a few sandwiches left.

Extras: Chairman Bao's has gotten a bad rap from Taiwanese bun maker of Baohaus for "stealing" his name for his top-selling bun, but in all honesty it doesn't bother me. The name was never trademarked to begin with. 


THE SCORE:

I ordered a Baked (not Steamed, probably 2x size) Duck Confit with Mango Salad for $5.75. It looked delicious, with a bit of the yellow mango peeking from outside the bun, topping strips and chunks of succulent duck. Ooh baby this looked better than I imagined.

I was starving hungry, and devoured the thing in multiple bites, sitting by the side of the truck. I didn't care I looked homeless as this Baked Bun was tender, flavorful, eye-opening flavor combo. Well-worth the jaunt down there to get this sandwich, and $5.75 for a pick-me-up and culinary inspiration was well worth it for me.

I went home and this sando inspired me to make me a mango salsa for my pulled pork for a party I catered.


THE GETAWAY: 

I'm excited to go back for the unusal boba tea flavors and for more samples of their meats. Will be back for a Steamed Pork Belly (smaller portions, I was told for the fatty nature of this delight). And for the Five Spiced Chicken. And the Duck Confit, of course.

Food: 5 Stars
Experience: 4 Stars, Multiple people turned away after 1:30PM, it's a shame they tried so hard to get their baos, and the truck was off-duty
Will Return: Hell Yea
Will Recommend: Already did
Overall: 5, Baby
author: Eric C.

description:
This is the old standby now for when we go to food trucks.

I have had the pork belly and the coca cola braised pork varieties (always steamed).  if you are not a fan of the vegetation on top (pickled daikon, cabbage, etc) just pick it off and enjoy.  The pork belly is definitely the best choice in my opinion.  

Good food, good service, good times
author: David G.

description:
My fave buns here are the spicy chicken and cola braised pork; the pork belly buns are good but really incomparable to Momofuku in NYC. Yes, i know they're in NYC, but honestly, once you've had those, you'd be spoilt for life. 

Friendly service and if you catch them in Hayes Valley on Wednesdays, hardly any lines.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Yep, I'm now happy that you make a weekly visit to San Carlos!  

Came here to grab some of your infamous Pork Belly buns!  Of course, you made me wait 20 minutes until you were ready to take my order, but I've shrugged it off for the lunch meal!  

Mmm, the pork belly bun were great as usual, with the added sauce and the picked daikons.  

I tried your spicy chicken bun, but, for me at least, the chicken was a little dry, so it wasn't as inviting for me.  

However, I will be back soon to visit!

And, I'll be wearing my Chairman t-shirt to represent the fact that 'I eat Chairman Bao'!  

Recommend!
author: Edward L.

description: I was lucky enough to bump into The Chairman Truck while getting some Blue Bottle Coffee at the Mint Plaza. Seriously, these were the best baos I have ever tasted (the pork belly one was the best of the three meat choices) and I got one of each for the trifecta. These guys set the bar high for food trucks. Great stuff. Highly recommended.
author: Jared C.

description: The tofu steamed bun is so addicting! My favorite food truck of all time!!!
author: Will D.

description:
I first saw the Chairman Bao Bun Truck at Off the Grid at Fort Mason and I was wondering what that loonnnnngggggg line was for. After finding out what it was for, I yelped it and found what they were serving to be very interesting and was very happy to see that they make weekly visits to Emeryville

I didn't pack a lunch today and finally had cash on me so I was able to venture out to finally try this ever so popular Chairman Baos. They do accept Visa and Mastercard by the way. I got to the spot around 12:10 and there was a wait for my buns. After about 25 minutes, I finally got my hands on three different buns and a drink. I was not disappointed by everything, but I was not impressed either.

Strawberry Coconut Icy Drink - it was really good to have something cold today because it was sooo hot! Flavorwise, I did not taste the strawberry or the coconut. I felt like I was drinking a cup of water with a lot of crush ice and a very slighttt taste of sour strawberry. 

Crispy Tofu with Garlic Sauce and Mustard Greens bun - I love tofu, I love mustard greens, but I did NOT like this bun at all. The mustard greens were good, but the tofu was not crispy at all. In fact it was really mushy and did not go well with the soft steamed bun. I love anything with garlic, but this particular garlic sauce was sour and not pleasant to eat.

Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon bun - I liked this one. The pork belly was very soft and well flavored and went well with the crunchy daikon.

Spiced duck confit with mango and onion - This one was my favorite because it had the best combination of flavors, with the soft spiced shredded duck with the sweet mango and that little kick from the onion.

It did not live up to the hype but I am still glad I tried it. The only food I have gotten from trucks before were just original Mexican taco trucks and I appreciate all the creatively people are having with food. It was an interesting experience but I don't think I would be waiting in line for these buns again.
author: Katherine C.

description:
Heres another 5 star review Mr. Chairman.
The BEST truck in SF. All 4 buns are freaking amazing. One of the best truck veggie options I've had...I loves that bok choy with the crunchy on the outside soft on the inside tofu. My personal favorite is the braised pork...it is the perfect food.
author: Lauren T.

description:
One of my favorite food trucks and my go to place when they are at the Truck Stop.

The lines are usually the longest for this truck but the wait is worth it.

I definitely prefer the steamed buns over the baked bun (although larger, these are also more expensive).

I recommend getting both the duck and pork belly steamed buns. The pickled vegetables included with both of these are a great compliment to the saltiness of the meats.

I didn't think that either of the braised pork or crispy miso cured tofu buns were that great. I probably wouldn't order of these again. The flavors just aren't there and the tofu is not crispy enough.

You'll probably need about 3 buns for a full lunch.
author: Lester W.

description:
I had the pleasure of trying out The Chairman last Tuesday for the very first time @ a fundraiser at James Logan High School parking lot on a rainy night where 9 food trucks gathered from the Food Truck Mafia, who put this all together.

I had just eaten a cheese steak sandwich from Grillaz, but had to make room for a steamed bun from the Chairman. I had seen The Chairman at various food truck events around the Bay Area, always with very long lines so I always passed them up, until now. It was raining that night so lines were very short and I jumped all over the opportunity to try The Chairman's tasty buns....no, no not those buns!, the Gua Bao, or a bun sandwich, a tasty traditional Taiwanese snack.

My mouth immediately started to water when I spotted the Tender Pork Belly bun on the menu  ($3.75 steamed bun, $6.75 baked bun)

I ordered one Tender Pork Belly steamed bun (with tumeric pickled daikon and green shiso)

Other options include:
-Coca-Cola braised pork with savory cabbage and preserved yellow mustard seeds
-Spicy chicken with toasted sesame puree, pickled carrots, cucumber and cilantro
-Crispy Miso cured tofu with garlic-tofu mayo and baby choy sum

Can't wait to go back for more!
author: Craig F.

description:
Don't you know that two bellies are better than one? 

In this instance, the pork belly at Chairman Bao truck is better when it meets mine!

The food here is amazing, given I have only eaten here twice. Both time at the Eat Real festival in Oakland, 2011 and 12. And I think that is probably why I think it is so good. It sort of become a tradition and treat for me. To think if I had access to Chairman Baa everyday. I don't think my stomach have the ability to stretch enough to fit like 10 baos a day. 

I really have no clue what the prices are because at Eat Real festivals, the prices are capped to around 5 bucks. But either way, it was very affordable and I left the truck with no complaints from my wallet or stomach. 

What I think makes the baos here so good, is balance! The meat is savory and juicy, the bao is a perfect vessel and what I think is the most important component, the pickles! Daikon, carrots, radishes, cucumbers, all of them cuts right through the fattiness of the meat and provide your mouth with the necessary crunch. Topping your baos off with siracha is a must! The spiciness adds a whole new dimension. I'll stop talking out of my butt and let you guys go try it for yourself!
author: Tung T.

description: This place puts crack in their food. Why else would I stalk where their truck is going to be next? I mourn the Sundays that they are not in Pleasanton when I can make it. I have tried everything but the duck, and that is only because I have not seen it on the menu. Every item I have had is flavorful. I prefer the taste of the steamed to the baked buns. This is a plus as it means I can eat more variety. I don't even look at the other food trucks when The Chairman truck is around.
author: Bea R.

description: Came back when it was a different location and was able to try all the flavor (well minus vegetarian).  Really liked the spicy chicken, had a great flavor.  The cola marinated pork was good too, but the pork belly definitely wins out for me.  Still think this place can get pricey though, but definitely worth a try if you can't had it.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Hands down my favorite truck in the city. The baos on this truck are amazing! I've tried 3 out of the 5. The pork belly, miso tofu and coco cola pork. The pork was just okay. Not very flavorful. The miso tofu was delicious. I'm not a big tofu fan but in this preparation it was delicious. The pork belly is the star! It's tender, delicate, flavorful and just unadulteratedly rich! The sauce and daikon added ties all the flavors together. Whenever I go off the grid, this is a must! I've never tried the bake only the steamed. I like the idea of something I can eat with one hand. If you've never been find out where they are, hunt them down if necessary. You won't regret it!
author: Karina V.

description:
i had the baked bun with crispy miso cured tofu and overall, it was pretty good.

the bao was huge, cut in half, and inserted with pan-fried tofu, baby bok choy, and seasoned with garlic tofu mayo.  the combination was very savory and yummy.  i did feel it was a bit too much bread, as i couldn't finish it (but i ate everything inside).

at $6 for a vegetarian bao, it is a bit on the steep side.  you can get the smaller version of this, steamed bun, which is a smaller piece of bread & half the filling, for $3.25.
author: Ellen L.

description: mmmmm mmmmmm! :) So delicious.  I had the pork belly on the steamed bun and it was amazing.  My husband had the Coca-Cola braised pork on the steamed bun.  The baked buns looked good too but I can't pass up the steamed ones... it was so delicious.  Perfection in the melding of the tastes, super quick, super fresh... We will be returning.
author: Lyndsey C.

description:
Tried this place with a friend of mine and ordered veggie option of steamed bun. (Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum) 

totally loved it. Will come back for sure!

Tip: Add Sriracha and that takes it to another level :))
author: Rohini M.

description:
Over time this awesome food will significantly shorten your life span. However you will die happy eating it.

My personal favorite is the Baked Pork belly Sandwich without the daikon.
author: Michael W.

description: This used to be my favorite food truck. I'm not eager to try food trucks now, as I usually find them to be overpriced and overly hyped. I came back to the Chairman for my fourth visit last week. The line was still pretty long, but it moved a lot faster than I remembered, probably because they didn't have their shaved fruit drinks that I loved. I asked about them and was told that they only serve them on "special days." I also didn't see the duck confit bun on the menu. Since it was a Friday during Lent, I could only order the garlic tofu bun ($3.25 for steamed). It did not hold a candle to the pork and duck buns. I wouldn't order them again, even on a day when I am not allowed to eat meat. I don't know, the meat buns have such interesting flavor and texture profiles and the tofu one was sort of soft and mushy, with the garlic overpowering and the miso in the greens nowhere to be found.
author: Jenn C.

description: I stumbled upon this place randomly not even realizing how amazing it was or how many people knew about it. I was meeting clients at the Commissary and partway through we were all starving, and luckily there were tons of food trucks across the street for Off the Grid so one of my clients went to go scope it out. He came back with one of each of the steamed buns, and I had the pork belly with pickled daikon. So freakin' good, I wanted to go back for three more but didn't want to interrupt our meeting again. They had the other pork belly option and the chicken, and said both were amazing as well. I'm not sure about the service, but he was back pretty quickly so it seemed fast. I made sure to find the name of the truck before leaving and will definitely be tracking it down the next time I'm in the city!
author: Kim J.

description:
Wowowow!! I've heard people talk about Chairman Bao at Off the Grid, and I never found any of the food at Off the Grid (N Berkeley) particularly great the last two times I went... but that's because the Chairman wasn't there!!

The last time I ventured to Off the Grid, they were here... the line was long! (probably longer than any of the other lines) but so worth the wait! I got the baked pork belly (steamed one looked tiny and sad) and I would describe it as more of a burger than a  bun... either way I've never had such delicious, flavorful, and tender pork belly. The picked daikon complements the pork belly really well and adds a bit of a crunch. 

Definitely recommended, and I'd come again. And $7 for this pork belly bao? Not bad at all!
author: Debbie L.

description:
I had a couple of baos at Edgewood Eats.  They were both delicious.  I can't remember the exact price, but I know they were around $3 for the steamed ones.  The baked ones were more, but I did not have any of these.

The two I had were the crispy garlic tofu with miso greens and the pork belly with pickled daikon.  Both were good with the pork belly one winning.

Naturally, the pork belly was very fatty, but the pickled daikon helped to cut it a bit, providing a nice balance.  Make no mistake though, it was not diet food.  But it was dee-lish.

I thought the price was fair and service reasonably quick.  I would get food from here again.
author: Brent T.

description:
Finally got to a Sacramento food festival early enough and were the third people in line. Ergo, finally got to try the Chairman. Course, the first guy in line had to go and order for like 30 people. People, don't be a jerk and abuse your position like that. It's obnoxious. Still, the wait wasn't as long as it was later in the day.

We got 2 steamed bao - one pork and one pork belly, about $3 each. (You can also get baked buns, which are larger and around $6 but look like they could fill you up pretty good.) Both were delicious, but that pork belly was a little package of heaven. The pickled veg on top were the perfect compliment to the savory meat filling. This is a new favorite food truck for us!
author: Stacy G.

description:
Pork Belly Bun - best thing since god invented ... well you know.

That's really it.... My review... get it, eat it, feel guilty, then go get another.
author: Topher C.

description: my pick at The Movable Feast this past weekend in San Jose at Canoas Garden.  I wish I lived closer because I could so easily eat a couple of these every week!  I tried 1 of each of their steamed bao.  They were all so tasty and full of flavors that literally ignited my taste buds!!  The tofu, the braised pork, spicy chicken and pork belly. ALL of them had their own personality.  My favorite would be the Spicy Chicken, then the Pork Belly and Tofu tied at 2nd and 3rd the braised pork.  I truly can't wait to eat them again!  Def give them a try if the opportunity presents itself.  YOU WON'T REGRET IT!
author: Kiki R.

description: One of my favorite foodtruck. Both baked and steamed buns are delicious. Mmm..mmm... Mouth-watering. Like having the wild thaaaang in my mouth.
author: Cryszilla G.

description: I could try to recommend a specific item, but I've tried everything and it's hard to pick a favorite; everything is amazing.  If you have a fancy for pork, they've got braised pork and pork belly.  Vegi?  They have an awesome tofu option that's crispy and creamy at the same time.  I usually get 1 baked chicken and 1 steamed tofu because they're the less expensive options and I'm a cheapo.
author: Carlin F.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE....the steamed pork belly sandwiches. All their food is great....I love what they do with the pickled add on's. Don't miss out. Staff is helpful and nice.
author: Steve F.

description:
First time trying them via SJ Food Truck Fest, pretty pissed at the fact that after 3 hours of chilly wait in line, they ran out of almost everything except tofu.  So we ordered both the bake bun and the steam bun.  My sympathy to the other 30+ people lining behind us that was told nothing was left after waiting in line for however long.  There were no warnings on what items ran out throughout either, you just got to see what you can choose when your turn comes.  No star for service, the 4 star is just for food.

The quality is pretty good!  The baked bun is soft and fresh, the steam bun is also nice.  The tofu steak inside was good in texture and nicely flavored with mayo and pickled daikon.  

Not overly cheap as a steamed one cost $3.5 and a baked one $6, but the baked bun is as big as a sandwich.  I do hope I get to try other more popular flavors next time.
author: LeeLee C.

description:
Mt favorite gourmet food truck so far. Great concept and great execution, at a very very reasonable price. The steamed buns comes at $3-$3.50 and the baked ones around $6. $10 will fill you up and a chance to taste all they  have to offer. 

I personally like to go for the steam buns, just because I can get 3 for $10 and be totally satisfied. They really put effort into each ingredient, which totally shows in a seemingly small bun filled with just a few pieces of meat and veggies. The meat is marinated in wonderful juice, done to perfection. But I mean, how can do you go wrong with pork belly?! Still, it's good. The veggies that accompany the meat in the buns are no afterthought, they're also carefully seasoned to enhance the meat in the bun, making the whole thing a symphony in your mouth. 

So far I've had the pork belly (duh!), the pork braised in coke or something, and the tofu. Everything just melts in my mouth and tastes so good. Even the tofu was wonderful, given that it has to compete with pork belly in my mouth. 

Now I don't think they make their own "bao", steamed or baked, from scratch. They probably buy it from some chinese bakery. But no matter, it's the fact that when they put everything together, it tastes wonderful.
author: Lisa Z.

description:
I had the following: 

Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso - I give this 5 star, the bun was soft, the pork belly just melted in my mouth 

Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro - I love it when people add cilantro to things . . . however, I found this a bit too spicy for me but it was still great! 

Note: VERY VERY LONG LINEUPS
author: Crystal L.

description:
I just can't shake the fact that Chairman Bao Bun Truck is so pricey. Each small morsel will run you $3.75. It's kind of sad for me to take down my rating a star because of price since the product they sell is quite tasty. The reality is when it comes to rating a joint you got to take into account expense to taste ratio. 

1st Bun (Steamed with pulled pork, savoy cabbage & preserved mustard seeds): Not sure if I was in love with it especially the topping combination, but I have to acknowledge the unique taste it had. The pulled pork was delicious. 

2nd Bun (Steamed pork belly bao with pickled daikon): The pork belly was divine. mmmm I loved the texture and juiciness. Pork belly in MY BELLY. I'll fork up $3.75 for this, damn it. Not for the first bun tho.  

Overall I'll say it's solid and novel. You can probably head to china town and get something cheaper and lots of it, but the quality and flavor won't be nearly as good. The truck has a real cool design. The people are friendly. No reason not to try it. All about expectations I suppose.
author: Jack C.

description: Coca cola braised pork on a steamed bun! Sooo good!!! They are small so you'll eat more than one. Dreaming about it...
author: Tina D.

description:
BOOM CHICKA BAO WOW. 
CHAIRMAN BAO- HES GOTS THE BAOS TO MAKE YOU GO TAH DAO.
OH YAO.

Funny thing was that there were no asians to be found in the crowd. Well they were stationed right outside Bloodhound on a Wednesday night in the middle of SOMA on Folsom and not Chinatown. And also because your buns are pretty darn expensive. 

Let me break it down:

Peoples Buns:
Baked $6.00
Steamed $3.25
Red sesame chicken with scallion and bok choy
Crispy garlic tofu with miso greens (veggie)

Chairmans Buns:
Baked: $6.75
Steamed: $3.75
Chinese spiced Duck confit with fresh mango salad
Tender pork belly with pickled daikon
Pulled pork with savoy cabbage and preserved mustard seeds

They ran out of the pork belly and pulled pork, so we shared a duck confit. The steamed bun was like a peking duck bun but not fluffy or pillowy. It was more flat and dense. It was flavorful and juicy, so much so there our lil taco was sitting on a pool of juicyness.

You'd need a whole lot of steamed suckers to get you full, but this is more of a snack. And you won't necessarily find these guys at your friendly neighborhood Chinese joint.

Their Mao Bao shirt with the Bao panda head and a Chairman Bao food truck logo on the back is $20. They will even wrap in an authentic pink plastic bag for you, like the ones you get grocery shopping on Irving, Clement, or Chinatown.
author: Angela W.

description:
OMFG. Think of any superlative to describe how good the Chairman Truck's baos are and they're still better. If you're reading this review, stop now, go to their twitter feed http://twitter.com/chairmantruck and go get some! 

The flavors in the pork belly, the Coca-cola braised pork and spicy chicken baos are simply beyond words. The meat is a fantastic combination of sweet and savory. The baos are moist from the fat but also from the other secret toppings that complement the meats and pickled veges to perfection. Who knew pickled daikon could taste so out-of-this-world good? Speaking of which, a bite into the sandwich, your mouth explodes with flavors it's never known, followed by your body leaving this world for that brief moment. The buns, whether steamed or baked, also work superbly with the meat and toppings. Eat the steamed bao that day (like you can wait) and the baked bao to save for later (if you even have that willpower - practically impossible).

Thank you Chairman Truck. My mind has been blown.
author: Norman S.

description:
I just can't get enough of their buns!!! My favorite has to be the pork, mustard seed, and cabbage bun. Incredible. Soft, chewy, crunchy. I wish I had it in front of me to further describe its tastiness! but anyway, thats the one I recommend. If you want something sweet, get the duck with the mango bun. I don't know if they have this all the time, but if its on the menu, get the butternut squash miso soup. I can't believe how perfect it was for a brisk cold sunny day (in Emeryville). That day, I ordered one pork bun, and I finished it, and thought that I needed another one. So I went back to teh truck but they ran out of the pork. instead, they told me they can put duck in there, and they did and HOLY mother it was pure perfection. They also have a convenient bottle of Sriracha sauce if you need some spicy to your bun. 

I do agree that it gets a bit pricey for their buns but after tasting them you won't care how much you pay. I wish they had more days in the East Bay, but one day is better than no days! hands down one of the best trucks in the Bay Area, and I feel that we are so lucky to have this truck..not only for their food, but for having a really unique graphic on their truck that really stands out (if you are at Off the Grid you know what I mean).
author: Mary K.

description:
If the steamed pork belly buns at Momofuku Ssam Bar are the New York Yankees of the pork belly bun world - outsized reputation matched by outsized price tags - the pork belly at The Chairman is the Toronto Blue Jays - a perfectly respectable mid-market team suffering in a division with just too much competition.

The pulled pork buns are, to torture this poor sports metaphor well beyond all reasonable limits, rather like the Toronto Argonauts* - not necessarily better, but fewer preconceptions to measure up to.

Anyways, they're good buns.

==================
* Don't worry, I'd never heard of the Canadian Football League either until I ended up watching the Grey Cup in a Canadian expat bar** in Belize.

** Actually a redundant formulation. All bars in Belize are owned by Canadians.
author: Amy L.

description: Hands down the best food truck! The menu is very simple there are 4 options (1 chicken, 2 pork and 1 tofu) and each option comes in a steamed or a baked bun. Baked bun is the size of a burger and steamed bun is the size of a small taco. If you are really hungry you should get a baked and a steamed option. I got a coca-cola braised pork bun; the meat was very flavorful, the bun was delicious and there was a nice addition of mustard and mayo. The only downside is the long wait in line, because this place is popular!
author: Leon R.

description:
I think their prices are just a little too high, but the line they attract animately disputes that opinion.

You are gonna need to eat at least two baked buns to get full.
They taste great and if you compare them to the 1.25 buns you can get at Chinese bakeries you will see that they are 5 times more expensive.  However they definitely taste significantly better and contain a variety garnishes that add a nice combo of flavors.

I got the baked chicken and pork belly buns.  The chicken was good, but the pork belly blows it out of the water.... so if you get both eat the chicken first.
author: Steven F.

description:
Chairman Bao Trucks is right outside our office at 7000 Sierra Point Parkway near the Walmart.com Building. It will be here every Tuesday!

I have been waiting in anticipation and I was not disappointed.  

I sampled:

The pork belly steamed bun with daikon and red onion = melt in your mouth delicious. The daikon added a nice crispness to the pork belly.

The chicken with chinese spices, green onion and bok choy steamed bun was flavorful and had a nice contrast to the sweetness of the bun.

The Strawberry Coconut Ice was refreshing even on a windy day.

Overall, I really enjoyed my experience here. It was fast and friendly.  The cuisine is unique and flavorful.  Much better than your typical sandwhich and chips lunch.  And at $3 a bun and $3.50 for a shaved ice, it won't break the bank.

See you next Tuesday!
author: melissa l.

description: I got to try this truck at the giants vs 49ers game at the stadium. Its a good thing I didn't have to stalk it.   I had the pork belly burger and it was really good.  Even my non asian boy toy friend liked it.
author: Chloe K.

description:
Chairman Bao's never fails to deliver.  

I spoke to the last chef awhile back when he was leaving & of course was a bit skeptical as how the quality of food would be after his departure.  

The truck was at The Creator's Project at Fort Mason, SF.  

If you have a large appetite, you'll have to order a few of the "bao's"; think dim sum but on a larger scale.  Bun/Bao options: steamed or baked.

I savored every moment of the:
1/2 of a steamed crispy garlic tofu with miso greens & 
1/2 of a baked tender pork belly with pickled daikon

The ingredients taste fresh and are true to their descriptions.  When they say crispy they mean crispy, when they say pickled, they mean pickled.  

I could live off of Chairman Bao....
author: Jing Z.

description: I follow this truck like a stalker.  The steamed buns are legendary status.  I get all 4 at once.
author: Dan B.

description: Went and had some food from the Chairman Truck at the Larkspur Landing Location. Since it was my first time ordering from them I ordered 2 Tender Pork Belly on Steamed Buns for my fiancee and myself.  It was so goooood.  It was fatty good.  The line wasn't too long when I was there, but did get long after I ordered.  They're really fast at dishing out the food though so it wasn't a long wait.  I will be back to try their other items as well as the Tender Pork Belly.
author: Linda M.

description: I love their pork belly bao (both steamed and baked) and their coco cola braised pork. I love them so much that one day I drove all the way to Alameda and paid the $5 entrance fee for the market just to stand in line at the truck. Then I went home.
author: Walerz B.

description:
Alright *sigh* full disclosure: I'm on this detox thing of no alcohol, no sweets & limiting my eating out thing (if I had a gf, she'd be very sad to hear that last part...I joke...my yelp homies know what I mean!) So, as a placeholder, I'm reviewing food trucks I've tried. I don't want to drop off the face of the Yelp just because I'm dining out less, so I'll just catch up on old-ish reviews. You guys don't mind, do ya?!

So, everyone has seen the insane lines snaking around the red & yellow food truck known as Chairman Bao. Asians & Non Asians alike, waiting 30 minutes for those moist, tasty buns. It's a little odd for me (& probably for other Asians) to see the commotion because this is stuff we grew up eating. I'm glad it's getting its propers!

Over the course of several OTGs, I've tried:
-- steamed garlic tofu ($3.25):  no surprise, my favorite bun is the veggie one. Crunchy, garlicky & very satisfying. went well with the fluffy, thick bun. 
-- steamed red sesame chicken my least favorite. Shredding chicken texture was not pleasing. Flavor was bland. 
-- steamed pork belly ($3.75) the bf held it out to me & commanded me to 'bite!' He knows how picky I am with meat, but he was right...not bad! Defeating the purpose of pork BELLY, I picked off the fat & the meaty part was good! 
- baked braised pork ($5.75): didn't love the baked bun, fell apart easily  There are definitely better ones out there but the filling was great; didn't taste 'porky' at all & was very juicy & flavorful.

Get in line with the rest of us & try what the Chairman is dishin' out.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Definitely better than all the other food trucks I've tried who come during lunch to the Brisbane/South San Francisco area.

I had the baked pork belly and the steamed coca-cola marinated pork. Both were just yummy and packed to the gills with yummy goodness. Sure, at $6.75 for the baked bao and $3.75 for the steamed bao, it was a bit pricey...it's above average compared to the price/portion of most food trucks I've tried. At least The Chairman's food was delicious, good and filling...others, not so much.

Will definitely have it for lunch again the next time they come around!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
Despite the long lines and the somewhat ok prices, Chairman Bao is quite good. They have come up with this wonderful idea but something is missing. Something that could make this truck better than it already is.
Oh well, it doesnt matter...what does matter is the pork belly and I'm enjoying it!
author: phillip w.

description:
Went to the Treasure Island Flea and found the Chairman truck, the line was long and for good reason. My boyfriend and I ordered the pork belly bun and it was freaken DELICIOUS! The pork belly was tender, and the daikon and onions blended perfectly inside the bao. The bao might be a little overpriced but it's well worth the experience.

OH! they also accept credit cards! YAY!
author: Jessica T.
