description: Good.  Slightly expensive, but worth it.    Get the steamed / taco style, its better than the larger buns.
author: Mike R.

description:
I had the opportunity to try The Chairman truck while they were in Vegas for a food truck festival.  They were one of the few trucks that offered a veg option so I had to make a stop.  Two Crispy Miso Tofu bao, please.

I loved the texture of the tofu and it had a lot of flavor.  The greens added some nice color to the bao and complimented the tofu well.  The steamed bun was good, but it could have been a little lighter.

Sadly they were not offering the baked bun for the festival.

A little more than I'd like to pay for a bao, but a solid food truck with a yummy veg option.  Hope to see them in Vegas again!
author: Nicole W.

description:
I finally got to try Chairman Bao at Off the Grid in Berkeley. 

I wasn't really sure what to expect because none of the buns sounded appetizing to me when I was reading the menu. I ended up ordering the coca-cola braised pork steamed bun and was pleasantly surprised at how good it tasted. The meat and cabbage had so much flavor and complemented perfectly with the bun. The steamed buns aren't too big so if you're really hungry you should order two, OR you can under the baked bun which is bigger. I'm kind of sad that I didn't order their other buns, but I'll definitely have to come back and try the other options on their menu!
author: Patricia L.

description:
Super amazing. Have now had the chance to try four different steamed buns (once at Alameda flea, and once at Off the Grid). Super tasty. Spicy chicken was my personal favorite, but they were all wonderful. 

Open a storefront!
author: Jenny H.

description:
Went to moveable feast this weekend and the BF really wanted to try this truck out. I read the menu and wasn't feeling it so I decided to go elsewhere. He got this spicy chicken on a steamed bun that was delicious I was instantly jealous that I didn't get one myself and by the time I realized I wanted one the truck was closed :( Luckily my BF shared with me and I was able to enjoy this delicious creation. 

I am seriously craving one now and can't wait till Chairman is back in my area (San Jose!)
author: Cheri M.

description:
I had seen the Chairman around town, but the line was always too long so I never wanted to wait in it. 
I finally had my chance at the Treasure Island Flea Market. I got the Tofu Sandwich because it was a special. I wasn't sure what to expect, but I didn't think I would be in love with it. Much to my surprise, it was really yummy. I think it was the sauce that they put on it (whatever that may be). Next time I see the Chairman and there is a short line, I will definitely try something else on their menu.
author: Alycia N.

description: Yummy! Good pork belly! Liked the idea of food truck, kind of like Asian street food at a new level.
author: sherry g.

description:
I've seen this truck at a few mobile food events but the line was always too long and I was always too hungry and impatient to wait in those lines. 

Lucky for me, I was with a group of people this time around for the food truck event in San Carlos and we all split up into different lines. I got my Nom Nom tacos and my gf waited in the longest line for the Chairman Truck. It took her 30 minutes to get our food but when it finally arrived, it was worth the wait. I got a Pork Belly Steamed Bun, which was filled with fatty pork meat, sauce and pickled yellow daikons. It was a perfect blend of texture and tastes. The baked buns looked good too but I always prefer the steamed ones. The bf will definitely love these buns and I can't wait until Saturday to get one with him at the Moveable Feast by our place. The Chairman Truck usually has the longest lines and now I know why.
author: Chi N.

description: Oh the pork belly. So so so good. Perfect crisp and nice coca cola braised flavor. Awesome!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Uh oh, I think I might have found my favorite SF food truck...

Chairman Bao is creative, flavorful, fast service, and worth every penny & second that you're waiting in line. Sure, it's a bit pricey for a tiny bao, but once you bite into that pork belly topped with fresh daikon nestled inside that soft bun, you'll wish you ordered another one.

Both pork options are excellent and offer two very different flavors. Order the braised pork if you don't like the tanginess from the pork belly's daikon partner. Eating these bao's were the least guilty I've ever felt about eating pork.

The other bao choices are also so good and have the best combination of flavors, even the tofu which is probably the only option for vegetarians/vegans (another reason why I'm glad I haven't converted to veggies. no offense.) The chicken is uber spicy so I probably wouldn't order it again but if you like that hot kick I'd recommend it.

This is the type of food I'll crave for breakfast lunch dinner and after hours.
author: Colleen V.

description:
i've been to less than 5 food trucks and they all left me disappointed 

heard good things about chairman's baos and wasn't disappointed at all

ordered:
-steamed pork belly w tumeric pickled daikon and green shiso
-steamed coca cola braised pork w cabbage and mustard seeds

both were really good and i'll gladly come back to this food truck
author: Raquel T.

description:
Very tasty. The line moves quickly.

I had a chicken baked bun and a braised pork steamed bun.  Both excellent!  A single baked bun or two steamed buns would probably be enough for most appetites.

The line was pretty long, but it moved quickly.  The service was cheerful and efficient.
author: John D.

description: I have been eating Chairman Bao twice a week for months now.  These people are true chefs and proof that quality, consistent, mouth watering food can come from a food truck. $3-$4 a bun is amazing for such goodness. Two buns fill me up and I can eat a lot. I really can't believe people on here are complaining about the price!
author: Regina E.

description:
I've heard so much about Chairman Bao and how their Baked Pork Belly Bun is to die for.  Well, I finally got to try it for myself today.  I went to Off the Grid Upper Haight with my coworker today and we shared two of the Chairman's Buns (the Pork Belly and the Duck Confit with Mango Salad).  Perhaps the Chairman is trying to be a little healthier or I just got an odd one, but the pork belly bun wasn't as fatty and moist as what everyone claims.  Even my coworker who tried it before admitted that.  However, I did get a couple of bites where the meat was a little fattier and it was tasted sooo much better.

However, I loved the Duck Confit with Mango Salad one.  I loved the spicy sauce that came with it and the mango salad added the right about of acidity to it - yum!  I will definitely be back to get more of these and perhaps try the pork belly one again and keep my fingers crossed for a fattier piece of meat, haha.
author: Katelynn L.

description:
Chairman Truck is slowly becoming my favorite food truck... even over Senor Sisig! (Sorry guys).

I don't really know what a 'traditional' Chinese bun is, but I'm not really concerned about that.

Very flavorful and not over ingredient-ed. Baked rolls are soft, just the way I like my rolls.

One of the more unbelievable things is that its hella cheap. HELLA. One baked roll is good enough for a meal, but if you're feeling sassy, get a baked and a steamed.

I've tried both the braised pork and the pork belly, I'll move on to the other items soon, which I'm sure are just as excellent.

Kinda greasy... but what do you expect, you're eating shit like pork belly.
author: Harold C.

description:
So what the bao is a bun? FREAKIN' DELICIOUS, that's what!

This food truck frequents my workplace,and I couldn't be happier about that. Definitely try the Spicy Chicken Sandwich with a baked bun. My personal favorite is the Crispy Miso Cured Tofu Sandwich with steamed buns. Speaking of steamed buns, if you're going that route, be sure to order two sandwiches, or even three. Those things are TINY! 

Look for this truck in and around SF, and at Off the Grid. Enjoy!
author: Jen O.

description:
Chairman Bao rocks my socks! 

In July my bestie and I went to SF and on the way home she made me detour to Treasure Island to pick up a bun from this truck. I was stuffed so I didn't get anything and when she gave me a bite later I was kicking myself for not getting something. We decided to go to the SactoMoFo Trucktoberfest in West Sacramento saturday night and I was thrilled when I saw the Communist Panda set up next to the mainstage! 

I ran right over and ordered a baked Coca-Cola braised pork bun and a steamed spicy chicken bun. I knew the pork was good because that was what my friend got last time. I reaffirmed that it was delicious! The pork was super flavorful even just eaten by itself without the condiments or bread. The baked bun is super delicious on its own too. I really enjoyed the spicy chicken as well, especially with the abundance of pickled carrots and cucumbers, which are my favorite things about Vietnamese food. I would have prefered it on the baked bun, however, there is no way I could eat two baked buns. A baked and a steamed was just about the perfect amount as the steamed buns are about half the size of the baked (and about half the price).

I love The Chairman, I need them to have a permanent truck in Sacramento!
author: Lisa H.

description:
They were off the grid in San Ramon today.

Truly delicious. I would have to say that these are more like bao sandwiches than the bao i was picturing in my head, but nonetheless they were absolutely yummy.

They don't get 5 stars simply because it takes FOREVER to get your order. I don't know if they were just overwhelmed with customers, but I had to wait about 15 minutes for my order. So just prepare to wait. They are quite good.

The steamed versions cost around $3 and the baked ones are  around $6. The steamed ones are in what look to me like peking duck buns filled with yummy savory goodness (pork belly with pickled daikon or duck confit with mango salsa or chicken with bok choy and scallions...). So they are considerably smaller than their baked counterparts. The baked ones are about the size of a hamburger bun sliced in half and filled with the filling of your choice. Not sure the steamed ones are worth it...

The duck confit was moist and flavorful and perfectly matched with the mango salsa. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. I'm so glad I got another one to take home for dinner!!

They also have specials where you can get a gourmet boba drink with your baked bao for $9 (flavors I saw were mango with matcha green tea, pineapple with salted caramel and strawberry coconut) - i didn't get one, but they looked pretty tasty and popular.

I am hoping they will come back out the east-east bay again sometime soon!!
author: Amy T.

description:
Had lunch today with the Chairman and it was DELICIOUS! I ordered the spicy chicken steamed bun, ate the whole thing and between bites said "this is what it's about!" My best friend said "what good food is about?" and I said "What it's ALL ABOUT!" 

The chicken was tender, spicy, flavorful! The bun was steamed to perfect! The perfect amount of doughiness! I wish I had gotten two buns but unfortunately I had wasted, WASTED!! part of my stomach on a stupid taco from another food truck (Twister Food Truck...you know you wanted you know) I will NEVER do that again! EVER! I'm gonna save my whole 'tumic for the chairman and I probably will fast so I can eat even more. 

It was so good.
author: jen b.

description:
So, I keep hearing all the rave about this place and decided to give it a try. They are in San Ramon on Wednesdays. 

the coca-cola pork is great; however, their service is horrible. The workers there are a tad snotty for me. And I agree with some of the people on here, they are a bit overpriced for what you get. Seems cheap at first, but after you discover it is gone in three bites, kinda not worth it.
author: kathryn l.

description:
Funny thing is, we looked up Yelp reviews for this place while waiting in the long line to order.  Two definite must tries... the steamed pork belly bun with pickled daikon, and the baked braised pork shoulder bun.

OMG - I could eat 10 of the steamed pork belly buns, and then still try to shove in a couple more of the baked pork shoulder ones.

The steamed buns are small - not traditional bun with the a stuffing.  It's an open faced bun with toppings.  The steamed buns are a little bigger, but same idea - open and stuffed.

Thank you Yelpers!
author: Denise M.

description:
Had both the steamed and baked version of the pulled pork bao at Off the Grid.  The baked bread is very similar to what you might get in Chinatown.  The steamed bread version is very similar to what you get with Peking Duck in a Chinese restaurant, but not the steamed BBQ pork bun you get in Chinatown since those are raised with baking powder, not yeast.  

The pulled pork with cabbage bun interiors were OK.  I'll have to try the pork belly next time and hope that the fat is grilled and not baked.  

I was told that the food truck was called "Chairman Bao" but it only said "The Chairman".  Are they two different food trucks?
author: Doctor G.

description: Wow!  First off the golden grilled bun is insane ! We tried the Chairman at the Treasure Island Flea market which is held on the last weekend of every month. We tried the Tofu sandwich which was so amazing , that I am now on a personal mission to try and  recreate it at home. I can't wait to try something else.
author: L B.

description:
Shoutout to my homie Tim, who has been supplying me with a steady flow of OFF THE GRID goodies & bringing it to my workplace.

When he showed up today with some Chairman Bao pork belly buns, I took one look at it and began drooling already. At first I was a bit weird-ed out by the mustard seeds on top, but after one bite I found myself unable to stop eating..mustard seed and all. 

The buns are similar to the buns you get with Peking ducks in Chinese Restaurants, but their fillings are a little less orthodox. Inside this steam bun, was a huge heaping of pork belly topped with some sort of sauerkraut looking like topping with mustard seeds on top. Don't judge the buns by its size, a small little bun filled me up!

I've personally never been to OFF THE GRID (mainly because I'm never in the city or is working during the times in which it's going on) but I've had the chance to sample quite a few of their famous goodies. One bite and I understood why there are long lines for Chairman bao. Plus they have a cute truck to boot! i can't wait to try some of their drinks next time!
author: Jess s.

description:
This truck's portions are small for the price, that's for sure. But it's okay, Chairman Panda-Bear Guy. Size isn't everything.

I was ravenously hungry when I stumbled across this truck in UN Plaza today, so threw myself on its tender, juicy mercies. I ordered a pork belly bun and a spicy chicken bun, and when I opened up the container I had the distinct impression that I was not going to be satisfied. But when I found a comfortable place to sit and got down to business, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the business was juicy, subtly spicy and with just the right amount of bite from the pickled vegetables.

I love my big American portions, but sometimes you don't need to be full to be satisfied. So give the Chairman a shot, and I hope it's good for you too.
author: Ben G.

description:
The pork belly steamed bun is heavenly.  My friend N introduced me to the truck in Emeryville and I introduced another friend, Y.  I thought of the bun as a treat to have once in a while.  However, my friend Y has us chasing the truck all over town.  Y tracked the truck down to San Jose and went there with her boyfriend.  

Y and I stopped at the Chairman Bao truck on Octavia and last Thursday near Stanyan.  I usually get the pork belly, but this week I tried the duck confit.  OMG.

And, the people who work at the truck are super nice.
author: Rachel M.

description: Omg. Pork belly on a steamed bun is to die for. Spicy chicken not bad either but doubling up on the pork belly next time! Two steamed for $7. Not bad!
author: Brandon T.

description: Great bao bun, great filling. My gf brought back a pork belly baked bao back for m. It was still lukewarm when I started eating it but even so, it was delicious. The bun was fluffy and soft while the pork belly and toppings were savory, juicy and flavorful. I'd definitely get it again next time at Off the Grid. Not a bad price either at 6 dollars a backed bun.
author: Ruobin W.

description:
Finally had  a chance to sample Chairman Bao when the truck was stationed in Off the Grid Haight last night where the lines were short.

Known for their mini steamed buns, I just got one (so I could save room for other trucks).  Went with the Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage, Yellow Mustard Seeds and Kewpie Mayo ($3.75).  

Amazing. The meat was generously marinated and the slaw added a nice tangy touch.  Can't wait to try the others next time.
author: F. P.

description: All I dreamed for and more.  This was the one truck I wanted to try at the South Point Gourmet Food Truck Fest after many of the my friends from San Francisco not only told me I had to try this truck, but alerted me to its presence in Las Vegas.  The spicy chicken, pork belly, and miso tofu steamed buns were all outstanding.  Exceeded all my expectations.  Bravo.
author: Holly C.

description:
For the last few years, I feel like I've seen the Chairman Truck everywhere. Hell, I've even seen it driving along the freeway. I've put off trying out the food because every time I'd seen it at Off the Grid of any other major food truck meetup, the line was always ridiculously long. As a result, I've spent the last few years wondering if the bun there could really be worth a wait like that. 

Lucky for me, the truck's made an appearance at the last few Earthquakes games. While there has always been a line, it has never been nearly as crowded as I've seen it anywhere else. 

I've only really tried the steamed buns and for the pretty small buns, $4 is pretty expensive. They really aren't the most authentic buns I've tried either. I'm admittedly no expert, but it's nothing like the buns I've gotten anywhere else. 

That being said, the steamed buns are absolutely delicious. I've tried the braised pork, the chicken, and the pork belly buns by now and have been impressed by every single one of them. For their size, they are jam packed with flavor. My favorite was probably the braised pork. It made me wonder why it's taken me so long to try these buns out. 

Maybe one day I'll try the steamed buns, but at $8 a pop at Quakes games, they're kind of expensive. 

The only reason I give the truck a 3 rather than 4 star is that while it was delicious, it's not a truck that I would go out of my way or brave the long line for.
author: Alea G.

description: I'm downgrading... it seems like the baked buns have changed. The last 3 or 4 times, they've tasted slightly stale and lacks the sweetness on top that usually made their buns oh so good.
author: Salina Z.

description: The Chairman Truck was pretty good.  Interesting twist on the standard pork bun.  I'd go back.
author: Brian B.

description:
We each had two of the Steamed Buns at the Treasure Island Flea, where the Chairman Truck was parked. Both the Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso and the Coca-Cola Braised Pork Butt with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds were excellent. The meat was super tender and flavorful, and the veggies were a great crisp and tangy contrast. My girlfriend had the Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro which she thought was equally good.

Two Buns and a drink make a very filling lunch, and a light eater could probably get by with just a bun and a side of some sort. I wish these guys came down to Fremont, because the food is awesome!
author: Andy S.

description:
Pork belly, mmmmm don't mind if I do... DON'T MIND IF I DO!

Friday night. Off the Grid. Sweet tangy daikon. A piece of pork belly. Soft sweet fluffy steamed bun. Definitely, don't mind if I do. And I would so do it again. And again. And again. And again. And again. To the power of 6.

Short review, a rare treat for those who brave through my usual long boring zzzzzzzzz reviews.
author: Betty C.

description:
Ahhh, the much-hyped Chairman Bao bun truck. After reading the reviews and braving the long line, I finally got my grubby hands on the pork belly with pickled daikon and lion's head meatball with kimchee steamed buns.

The steamed buns are the same type you get when you order Peking duck at any Chinese restaurant. The pork belly bun came with two small pieces of tasty pork belly, topped with some pickled daikon. I thought the combination was interesting (in a good way).

On the other hand, the "lion's head meatball" bun was a complete disappointment. The meatball sucked (do yourself a favor and try a lion's head meatball in any Beijing or Shanghai Chinese restaurant - even the mediocre ones we have in SF will give you a better idea of how a lion's head meatball SHOULD taste) and the bland cabbage they call "kimchee" is an insult to Koreans.

I don't mind paying premium prices for premium products, but Chairman bao is not it. I think it's ridiculously overpriced for what you get.
author: Steve L.

description:
I like nice buns. Two visits to The Chairman Truck = 3 buns consummed, more to go!

-Pork belly, Baked: Delicious! More bread/bun comes with this one, so it fills you up more than the steamed one. Had to eat the top part of my bun separately as it was a little big. Must eat it all together as the pork belly, pickled veg, sauce, and bun are a fantastic combo!
-Pork belly, Steamed: Delicious! See above. Smaller sized bun. Will allow you to leave room for other tasty treats.
-Coca-cola braised pork, Steamed: Good, but the accompanying veg/topping (forget what it is exactly) didn't quite hit the spot for me.

Do not fear a long line - it moves fast!
author: Veronica H.

description:
I'm just going to file this under, "Things that go in my mouth". I have sultry, spicy dreams about the Chairman Truck. 

The Chairman brings his buns to my work place about once or twice a month and it's like Christmas morning when I see that sexy red beast pull into the front. The clouds part and the sun shines and the birds sing... It's wonderful. 

I love everything on their menu - even both the baked and the steamed buns but if I won a contest and could eat only one menu item every day for the rest of my life - I would pick the spicy chicken on a steamed bun. The only item I have yet to try, and it's just because I don't want to look like a total pig by ordering one of EVERYTHING each time, is the Tofu bun but I hear it's amazing. 

Last year, when I tried those spicy, saucy buns for the first time, they also had an amazing drink available - the Lyche slush and I still have dreams about it. They don't offer it anymore but I still ask every time I order and I've made some very suggestive suggestions on their Facebook page about it. 

I might have to write another 5 star review of the Chairman Truck, just so I can give it 10 stars!
author: Karen K.

description:
The pork belly bao is just heavenly... I can't get enough!  The pickles compliment the pork belly so well.

Chicken bao is good too but pork belly will always be my first choice.

I always want to eat everything on the menu all at once, but my wallet doesn't like it.
author: Sylvia W.

description:
If you see this truck, chase it down!
I'm not kidding, seriously, get yourself in gear and go!
The bao are freakin' delicious. I had the chicken buns and it's so incredibly flavorful, especially with the pickled carrot relish topping.

Seriously, what else do you need to know, go find this damn truck. Hell, make a twitter account just to follow it around!
author: Muz H.

description: I want some Chairman Bao, Now!  I got the sesame chicken in a steamed bun.  I like the steamed bun more because of the texture and the fluffiness.  The contents inside the bun were sweet and spicy, which created a party in my mouth.  I wish I was not so full when I ate this, otherwise I probably would have enjoyed it more.  Will definitely try again.  Hope the line is not out the wazoo.
author: Victor L.

description:
CASH ONLY

Chairman Bao made a trip out to San Mateo, so I decided to give them a try.
I had the steamed pork belly w/daikon buns. The buns were so soft and the pork belly so succulent, that when I took a bite, it went well together,was not too salty either, the pickled daikon gave it that salt it needed. A little on the pricey side, but they are ok in my book.
author: Valerie P.

description:
The pork belly with the pickled daikon is HEAVEN!! The truck always has the longest lines and you know its good when you see everyone else lining up for these delicious buns! They also have a new one! (Red Sesame Chicken with paper thin carrots and cucumbers)

I always try to find the Chairman Truck in downtown for lunch or at OFF THE GRID! :)
author: Karina C.

description:
Yeah, I think I'm done.

I tried out this truck again for another go at the vegetarian bao, thinking that I may have been too hasty in calling this truck overrated. Not so: Like I said in my first review, nothing about the food itself was actually downright BAD, and for the novelty/fusion factor it was fun to try, but for the price-to-portion ratio and overall value this just isn't worth repeat visits. Sorry Chairman, but this member of the proletariat is skipping your truck in the future.
author: James L.

description:
Even so close to bed time, I didn't stop me from eating 4 of their buns! Yes, I tried all of them and they we're all super delicious!! 
Braised pork with mustard seed: pretty good. The least flavorful out of all of them but at least the meat wasn't chewy!
Garlic Tofu w/ Greens: As a meat person, this vegetarian option surprised me! I think partly why the tofu was so good was because it was fried but also with its flavors and the sesame oil bok choy, it was the perfect combination of crisp. 
Red Sesame Chicken: Wow, that was such a kick of flavor! Chicken was good and really spicy! But it wasn't overwhelming... just the right amount of flavor balanced with some leafy greens.
Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon: the best one yet! Nice and tender and full of flavor with the slightest hint of spice. It was simply perfect. Even with all the juice, the bun still didn't get soggy!
To top it off, the cutest Asian girl took my order! Will definitely have to check this truck out again.
author: Stella Y.

description:
Straight legit.

Just when I began to loose faith in the food truck madness, Chairman Bao leads me on a path of unctiousness.  Following a path laden with steamy buns and porky goodness.

Yeah, ViTech is right. At three and three quarters its a bit steep for one porky bun.  So do yourself a favor and get TWO because it just works out in the end.  No, there is no discount if you get more.  Just saying.

So that's what I did.

The first was the pork belly and the second the Coca-Cola marinated.  Both with the steamed bun.  You can choose baked, but wtf?  A baked bun would really take away from the experience.  This is what I mean.  The steam buns fold nicely around the generous amount of meat and topping.  You get the right amount of each.  The topping is a slightly astringent pickle and parsley.  Respectively each complimenting the pork belly and Coca-Cola meats.  Both give a stunning presentation and contrast in flavors and textures.  Put the same combo in a baked bun?  Nah.

Condiments?  Siracha and thingy cups.  But do yourself a favor.  The flavor combinations stand on their own.

If the meats are that good, I'm sure the tofu variant is probably just as good as well.
author: Hummer W.

description: I recently hired The Chairman Truck to do catering for my wedding. I couldn't have made a better decision. Their event coordinator, Devon, always responded promptly to my emails and questions making the planning process a pleasure. On the day of the event not everything went as planned (there was a freak cold spell) but The Chairman was perfect. They were on time, efficient, friendly and all around the best! So easy to work with and AMAZING food! My family and friends all loved it. Their tofu option kept my veggie friends and family happy and they even accommodated my gluten free guests! I highly recommend The Chairman for any catering event.
author: Jenn B.

description:
I finally got the chance to try this place at Moveable Feast at WiIllow Glen. I tried three of their steamed buns. All of them were very tasty, a bit pricy at (3.75$ a piece) but well worth it. 

I tired the 
- Coca-Cola-Braised Pork
- Pork belly (BEST) so worth it. The pickled daikon made it even more mouth watering. AMAZING!
- spicy chicken

The other ones were good I just loved the pork belly so much! SOOOO GOOD!
author: Stacey L.

description:
They  might as well re-name this truck "Heaven on Wheels", because in all honesty, that's the only way to describe it.  And seeing the long line it always draws, you really can't help but think that they are serving up a little piece of heaven on a steamed bun.  A steamed bun of pillow-y & heavenly clouds.

And just to further back up my point - I've been eying, tweet-following, and internet-drooling over this truck for months now.  After 20 minutes of line-waiting and finally getting to sink my teeth into the pork belly steamed bun with the pickled radish,  I immediately knew it was well worth the hype.

But seriously, why is animal fat so damn tasty?  and damn you, 6 bun limit.  6 is not enough to feed a man.
author: Eric C.

description: Think the Chairman truck is a little overpriced. The steamed buns with pork belly and spicy chicken were pretty good, but the baked bun with coca-cola braised pork not so much. Probably the longest wait at OTG Fort Mason, but not worth it.
author: Sophia B.

description:
This is one of my favorite food trucks in the bay area. Wherever they go, the line is always long. The good thing is, they've got their process down so it goes pretty quick. After you've placed your order, it normally takes less than 10 mins before they call your name.

They normally have two styles of buns and 3-4 choices of filling. The steamed, open face buns are smaller. The baked, sweet buns are bigger and are about the size of a hamburger bun. The first time I tried their food, I made the mistake of thinking the baked buns were the same size as the steamed, so I ordered two... one was enough to fill me up.  So far I've tried their spicy pork belly with picked daikon, the pulled pork shoulder with chopped veggies, and the sesame chicken with pickled carrots. My favorite is definitely the pork belly, but they were all good.

I normally like trying different food trucks whenever they show up in masse, but it's sooo hard to pass on Chairman bao.
author: Jermaine R.

description:
So are these buns worth at least a 20 min wait AND a hefty price of $3-7?..the answer is YES!  (at least buy 1)
I tried their steamed buns with pork belly and also the ones with chicken..these are TASTY!  I've never tried anything like it.  The pork belly had a couple pieces of meat and some daikon in it...and the vinegar really balanced out the heavy pork taste.  My brother even liked this one and he doesnt even like daikon!  I also had the spicy chicken one..this one is tasty too and if you're not a fan of spicy food..dont order it because it's pretty hot!  I still have yet to try the baked buns...more to come once i try them!
author: Kristen T.

description:
I'm glad that access to Chairman Bao isn't readily accessible...I'm pretty sure that I would be chowing down on buns way more than the surgeon general would recommend!

By far, my favorite is the pork belly on the baked bun. The Chairman has me hooked people! I know there are a lot of complaints about the cost - $6 for the baked bun sammy...I have no problem paying this! There's something about the taste of the tender slabs of grilled pork belly, the pickled daikon and the tasty baked bun. So delicious!

I've tried every combo they make, and I still go back to the pork belly. The steamed buns are tasty too, but I still prefer the baked babies.

If you're at Off the Grid, they usually have a ridiculously long line AND they tend to run out fast. Make it your first stop ;)
author: Christy L.

description: The absolute yummiest food truck I have ever come across. I have enjoyed them countless times and it is always a treat. The cherry on top is their customer service: always kind, warm and accommodating. If you have never tried them, go find them now!
author: rosita t.

description:
I feel a little silly saying the name out loud, too, but it is delicious fare.

Just joined the Oracle crowd (so, late-twenties-early-thirties mostly asian americans) here for lunch - I took a wrong turn after Oracle Parkway so I had to pull a U but was very amused at the crowd of folks swarming across that big grassy field to get to the truck. Luckily I was driving so I beat the crowd ;) 

$9 is a little stiff for lunch, and a light one at that: two steamed baos (like everyone else says, it's a street taco size) and a fresh fruit boba drink, but wow, they do what they give you right.
 
I got the pork belly (savory, fatty, and delicious, although personally I'm not that into the pickled crunch of daikon and onions - do appreciate the effort for texture though) and crispy garlic tofu with miso greens, which was surprisingly tender for being fried, and the creamy sauce they use looks overwhelming but is actually really light. I'm as big a fan of meat as the next person but also love what people can do with soybeans and it shows versatility too!

The highlight, though, was the pineapple salted caramel drink. mmm... tangy pineapple chunks with a creamy finish over crushed ice and good chewy boba. I actually let this creation melt a little bit halfway so I could get the full creamy effect. It was amazing, and a good size too, so on second thought I actually did end up being more satisfied with the meal portion. The other drink offerings sound tempting but I really don't think I want to try anything else anymore. :0)

Thanks for coming out to the Peninsula!

ps. looking up this truck's facebook fan page is kinda fun. Facebook asks every time, "Did you mean: 'carman bao'?" no, not really.
author: Steph C.

description:
Question everyone is asking themselves? Is all the hype right and is this really worth it?

Short Answer? Yes.



Probably the fatal flaw behind this place is the fact that its expensive AZN street food (oxymoron, I know) but it is well worth it. Went to off the grid Friday and waited in the daunting line in front of the infamous Bao truck. 

As I waited in line, the smells intoxicated the air. The buns were getting ripped off the menu as they sold out, and my anticipation was killing me. When I finally got to the front (~15 minus later) I tried the pork belly and the fried tofu, and both were mouthgasmically amazing. Well worth the wait, and I'll do it again.

I'll probably regret reviewing this, because I don't want this place to get any more crowded than it already is, but it was just that good that I can't NOT share.
author: Samantha R.

description: I can't remember if I have already written a review for you, Chairman. But tonights meal was so damn good I just had to get on here and say....DAMNIT Chairman. If this isn't the best food truck ever. WOWZA. SO good. And if you aren't a cow you can actually eat here for dinner for less than $10. That is all. "Burp."
author: Melanie L.

description:
The preliminaries - the baked or the steamed? The baked is, as described on their menu: "A large Asian dinner roll-shaped bun, baked with a light sugar glaze for a golden brown crust and a fluffy center." That is accurate. The steamed bun is a steamed bun; a staple of China's venerable history, now ubiquitous due to several years of success at Momofuku.  
 
First, I wanted the duck - no duck this day; next, the tender pork belly with turmeric pickled daikon and green shiso (steamed bun); then, Coca-Cola braised pork with savoy cabbage and preserved yellow mustard seeds (baked bun); and finally, spicy chicken with toasted sesame purée, pickled carrots-cucumber, and cilantro (baked bun). 

The long and short of it? Delicious is as delicious does; while I might quibble about occasional bites hewing toward too much sweetness, I will not do so today. However, once you've had an Asian-fusion bun of excellent quality (Mission Chinese used to), as far as the palate-memory knows (10 years ago at Momofuku), you've pretty much had them all - it is up to the imagination of the chef to distinguish his/her goodness from all the other goodness doing the same thing. Oft times simplicity is best, but man cannot live on one note (sweetened pickled veg), or one song (said veg with fill-in-the-blank Asian flavored protein), alone (on a Chinese bun). 

Eat here and you will be happy to hum; but I promise no tears of pleasure.

I'll be back. Happily.
author: Brski B.

description: My favorite truck at Off the Grid.  the pork belly steamed bun was incredible, as was the spicy chicken. I will even (maybe) try the tofu someday.  But I found out the truck is near my office on Tuesdays. Guess where I'll be next Tuesday?  It wouldn't be a scientific Yelp review unless I tried it at least twice would it?? ;)
author: Amy W.

description:
Off the Grid visits UN Plaza near Civic Center Bart on Tuesdays and Thursdays.  It was raining so I was lucky to visit the Chairman Truck without having a long wait! 

WOW - the pork belly bun was amazing.  I ordered it baked (they provide two options steamed or baked - the former being smaller and cheaper).  A sweet bun is filled with fat chunks of pork belly and pickled daikon.  This meal nears the top of my list of the unhealthiest things ever eaten.  But who cares?  When your mouth starts watering before you take your first bite, you are not allowed to complain.  The pickled daikon provides a fresh addition to the fatty crispy goodness of the pork belly. 

They have a spicy chicken option that I can't wait to try as well!
author: Kimya P.

description: I thoroughly enjoyed the Chairman and would definitely eat here again.  I got three steamed buns: the pork belly, spicy chicken, and crispy tofu.  Oddly, my usual favorite thing, the pork belly was my least favorite of the three.  That's not to say that it was bad (it was very good), but it was overshadowed by the excellent tofu.
author: Andy M.

description:
DIRECTIONS FOR EATING HERE:

Order anything with pork
My favorite: Pork belly bun not fried.

THAT IS ALL! THIS PLACE IS DELICIOUS!
author: Nathan B.

description:
Sweet baby Jesus! I think I could easily be persuaded to be vegetarian, until I come across something like the pork belly with pickled daikon in a steamed bun served out the window of a mobile kitchen! Vegetarianism can wait!

I ordered the delicious pork belly in a steamed bun and a spicy chicken in a steamed bun. They are pretty small, like palm of your hand small. I think four at any one setting is reasonable. Fine, three would be more appropriate. I only ordered two this time around and it took everything I had not to walk back over there and order another...or ten. Both were tasty, but the pork belly was exceptional. The pork is so succulent, juicy, crispy, yet tender. It melts in your mouth and when paired with the pickled daikon it is a match made in gastro heaven! 

I understand the baked buns are more normal size, but I'm not sure I will ever be able to tear myself away from the light, airy steamed buns! They let the other ingredients shine. And by shine I mean explode in your mouth. 

I've been back and basically I have eaten their menu - well, the steamed bun options at least. The pork belly remains hands down the favorite, with the braised pork bun and the crispy tofu bun tying for second and the spicy chicken holding a solid 3rd. I did order 3 this time and it's a very filling lunch, but 2 just isn't enough. 

The steamed bun with pork belly and pickled daikon is one of the best things I have ever eaten on this earth. Not even joking. 

I strongly urge you to stalk this truck via its website, twitter or facebook and track it down. STAT.
author: Shannon K.

description:
WHY HAVE I NOT TRIED YOU BEFORE?!

I had my first Chairman bao roughly two weeks ago at the Garden City Moveable Feast.... We got there right before they opened.. and they already had a pretty long line! I knew I had to try it.. It MUST be worth the wait if people are willing to line up for it... I didn't know what to get.. but there was a gentleman behind me who told me that the pork belly was a must have... I mean.. I would have ordered it anyway.. but his suggestion just made me get more (to share--but I probably could have eaten them all)...

I was not disappointed! It was very tasty! I also tried their other ones (all but tofu -- I think they only have 4 types?).. the pork belly is definitely my favorite! 

The steamed ones are $3.50 each... (a little pricey.. but TOTALLY worth it to try).. I haven't tried their baked yet... 

Oh, and although the line was long... it moved pretty quickly!
author: Wendy W.

description:
Ate a steamed bun with pork belly and nearly pooped my pants because this was so good. 

My aunt and I each had one and we both made sounds in public...which probably made others uncomfortable.

I could eat at least 7 of these heavenly buns.
author: Angela K.

description: I finally found the Chairman truck in North Beach's Off the Grid. It was pretty quiet over there, but the Chairman truck was busy. I have heard so much about the pork belly buns and so forth. So we ordered two pork belly baked buns. I scarfed it down in minutes as the pork belly was so juicy. The sour green vegetable in the bun open up my appetite more. Overall, it was a delicious baked bun. I would definitely order again. Maybe I will try the tofu next time.
author: Elaine C.

description:
They were parked outside Economy Restaurant Fixtures on 7th and Irwin.  I got the $10 deal - 2 steamed buns and a drink.  

Bun #1: pulled pork , I think with some bok choy?
Bun #2: red sesame chicken, I think with radish/ginger?
Drink: ginger-lychee pearl ball tea

Sorry, my memory is hazy cos I wolfed them down fast whilst sitting on the sidewalk flipping through a magazine.  The overall impression they left was 'mmm simple comfort food.'

I forget which toppings went on which but there was a bit of bok choy (?) on one and some radish/ginger on the other... at least I think.  My memory of the buns is hazy -- mainly remember thinking 'mmm filling comfort food'.'  These are certainly not the best buns ever-- the flavors were good but didn't completely come together-- and they're not cheap.  But it's a great idea for a food truck and when combined with the nice graphic design of the truck itself the proposition becomes irresistible.  Who could walk by this truck and not buy a bun?!   You'd have to be a zombie or something...  or maybe Robocop...

I don't recommend the ginger-lychee tea.  It was cloying sweet and I didn't finish it.

Next time I'ma try the baked bun-- it costs twice as much and the lady told me it's much larger.

Yay foodtrucks
author: Amar P.

description:
I went to the moveable feast event on a friday night in san jose.

The spicy chicken baked bun ($6 at the time of this review) was nothing out of this world but it was delicious. Reminded me of korean spicy chicken. The daikon in it was just like any other daikon you would get from a japanese restaurant. The sauce in it looked like a mixture of the oil from the spicy part of the chicken mixed with some kind of white sauce, maybe mayo, maybe ranch, or something else. I feel you get a lot more meat and your money's worth with the baked bun, but since I did not get the tofu or pork belly baked bun, not really sure how it would compare.

We also got the tofu steamed bun ($3.25). Tofu was not just tofu, it was a little crusted.  Definitely different from what I expected.

The pork belly steamed bun ($3.75) had a really good crust around the pork. It was also very tender and not the juiciest but still pretty good.

Nothing to special about their buns. The baked buns are just like the bbq pork baked buns you can buy at any chinese deli. For the steamed buns, they are just like the buns used when eating peking duck.

Service was fast and average friendliness.

Lots of parking at the VTA parking lot surprisingly.

Stars summary:
Spicy Chicken baked bun: 4 stars (4.3 stars for the price)
Tofu steamed bun: 3 stars
Pork belly steamed bun: 3.5 stars
Service: 3.5 stars
Parking: 5 stars

Overall food score: 3.6 stars =]] Definitely would come back here. Also my yelp rating is based on the food alone because if the food is good, i dont care about the service ;p and since this was an event, parking will vary depending on where the truck is.

Recommend to bring your own water and hand sanitizer as these buns are pretty messy.
author: Sean L.

description: After skimming through the other reviews, I'm not sure if we even went to the same place! I got the pork belly steamed bun at Off the Grid, and I didn't think it was great steamed. I was super excited for the pork belly, and while it was okay, I got tired of the bun a couple bites into it. Not the right flavors, and they didn't mesh well in my mouth.
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
Don't get me wrong, I love Chairman Bao.  When I first started eating from this truck a year ago, I was amazed that a food truck could deliver such amazing cuisine.  Hey, sometimes you can't get restaurants to cook food this good.  

My favorite is the pork belly and the duck confit.  The sesame chicken is also quite tasty.  Love the steamed buns but the baked bun is just as yummy.

So why the 3 stars?  The price.  It was already expensive when I first started eating there.  Then they hiked up their prices a few months ago.  It's just way too overpriced now.  I understand that quality ingredients cost a lot.  But in conjunction with the price increase, they also reduced the quantity of the meats on the buns.  I'm sorry but I can't give it more than 3 stars based on the cost.  It's worth a splurge here once in a blue moon but the pricing is a deterrent.
author: Chrys S.

description:
Imagine my surprise when I saw this truck pulling up outside our window in Menlo Park. Been meaning to try this for ages but the line was always so long.

Anyway... it's... amazing...... and doesn't need another 5-star review, but here it is anyway.

Had the Pork Belly and Coca-Cola Pork. Both were great. I was debating whether to walk back there and try some more but both my wallet and my belly probably need a break. They accept credit card via square which is also good. I hope that they make coming down here a regular occurrence!
author: Leo C.

description: Great pork bun. Better than great. David Chang of NorCal. Seriously good stuff.
author: Tom R.

description:
The first time I tired Chairman Bao was this year at the Asian Heritage Street Celebration. There was no line at the truck because I came around the time it was still setting up. I ended up getting the steamed pork belly.... MAN OH MAN... the pork belly!! DELICIOUS! I even had to get one more so my bf wouldn't eat all of mine! haha The pork belly fat soaked into the steamed bao and it just made the whole thing much more flavorful. The price for these are way overpriced and I wouldn't wait in line for hours for it (unless I happen to be at Off the Grid on a Friday and have nothing better to do but eat and stand in line). 

I also came to this truck one Friday night at Off the Grid, the wait was actually not that long and this time I ordered something different. My bf ended up getting the baked bun with braised pork and I got the spicy chicken on a steamed bun. I do not recommend the braised pork, it was way too salty and it just didn't taste good. The flavor just didn't work with the baked bun. So stay clear from it! As for the chicken, it was pretty good, but not as good as the pork belly.
author: Erica T.

description:
The people who operate Chairman Bao are GENIUSES.  Plain and simple.  When I think of traditional pork buns, my mind travels to dim sum restaurants.  This truck throws familiar out the door, and what results is a bao that's fresh, and new.  Did I mention it's fresh?

Baos are the specialty here, and they come in either steamed (around 4$) or baked (around 6$).  Their pork belly is the priciest item on the menu coming out of your wallets at 6.75$ each, and is also the most talked/yelped about.  They also offer other items, such as chicken.

The pork belly bao is especially amazing.  It melts and oozes deliciousness.  The bao is comes with slices of pickled vegetable (pretty sure it's radish, sorry if I'm mistaken), which balances the sandwich with crunch and acidity.  Be forewarned however, as your eating experience will be helped with a few napkins.

NOTE:  The line for Chairman Bao was virtually non-existent at OtG: 5M, as me and my friend went right when they opened.  Even after leaving a little past noon, the lines still seemed decent.
author: Louie L.

description: I'm a bun snob and was surprisingly impressed with the pork belly steamed bun. Also had a few bites of the chicken baked bun. It was tasty but paled in comparison to the pork buns.  Def should be top of the list of food trucks to hit up!
author: Jackie D.

description:
Awesome. If you see the chariman truck... just stop and get yourself a little pick me up.

No, it's not authentic and no, it's not cheap... but it's delicious. I love the combo of the salty pork belly and the picked veggies. I might be a tad biased, since I love pork belly in any way/shape/form. When cooking pork belly, it can get mushy and fall apart but the one at chairman truck has a nice crisp to it. 

Just go try it.

EDIT:: I hear there's a new owner? Gotta go retry to see if it's still as good as I remember.
author: Karina G.

description:
Your truck is awesome and thank you for always greeting me with a smile and great service.  

I am a vegetarian and I absolutely love the veggie, tofu bun AH-MAY-ZING.  The tofu is the perfect creamy texture inside and nice and crispy on the outside. Omg and the sauce, wow!  I've tried both the steamed and baked and both are yummy.  Although the baked is more filling.  
I've also heard the pork belly bun is the the BOMB!  But, since I am vegetarian I can only go by what my carnivorous friends tell me.  I highly recommend this truck!
author: Molly M.

description:
Don't get me wrong, I like this truck well enough, and I'm definitely glad to try it, but I can't believe how expensive these are for what, by their own admission, is a snack food. Almost $7 for a mini pork belly sandwich is a pretty high price to pay from a food truck. The flavors are good, but not 5-star good. If the prices were more reasonable and the service more expedient, I would probably give this a 4-star rating.

My favorite was the spicy chicken, and the tofu was also good. I was a little disappointed with the pork belly and would not get that again. My friend tried the braised pork and said it was his favorite, so that would also be a good choice. Duck was not available the day we went, so I can say nothing about that. On the whole, this place is worth trying when the line is short. With a long line, I say give it a pass, and try again another day.
author: Lance J.

description:
Little steamed pork belly....get in my belly. Tiny steamers of delectability that are too cute to eat. almost. 

The Marin OTG near the ferry landing today (Sundays) is sorta sad - not many trucks, but score for me today on seeing the Chairman. I was hoping he'd be there, and the good part about the anemic location was NO LINE!!!!!
author: Keri B.

description:
Chairman Bao showed up at the alley next to my work where all the food trucks chill. Id heard of them, seen the pictures, and was delighted to get a chance to try. Anticipating lines we stepped outside the office at 5pm and waited 15 mins to be first. I'm glad we did this because the line quickly grew to 15 people within 30 seconds. Word of Chairman Bao in the Tehama alley travels fast.

Upon recommendation I got the Tender Pork Belly with Daikon and the Garlic Tofu with Miso Greens - both steamed. They. Were. Delicious. Light, tender and juicy - I am in love! Definitely worth trying!

Chairman Bao, please bring your Bun Truck back to Tehama. I need to try your Duck, Sesame Chicken and Meatball buns.
author: Sonya T.

description:
I finally got a hold of the famous Chariman Bao Bun Truck! It really is too bad that it had to be during the infamous and notorious SJEats Movable Feast Failure...

--------
Food: Out of four possible stars: four stars.

Having grown up on Taiwanese buns and bread, I've searched long and hard for steamed buns of equal caliber. I finally found night market style buns at Chairman Bao.

On top of that, the bun I ordered had pork belly and pickled daikon. What a perfect balance. A subtle sweetness from the bun, savory pork belly and cool crisp pickled daikon? I see where Chairman Bao's fame comes from.

--------
Miscellaneous: Out of one possible star: one star.

I had to try very hard to hold back my utter distaste and hatred for that bastard devil Mao... but Chairman Bao's decor is beyond cute! And I'm a guy, so you KNOW my usage of "cute" is appropriate. I mean, it is a panda!

The line was stupid long (one hour long wait), but that wasn't Chairman Bao's fault, but rather SJEats fault. If I could review SJEats, that is where stars would be docked.
author: Bryan S.

description: I'm giving this truck respect because years ago it was my first food truck outside of the taco truck experience.  My nostalgia falsely raises my hopes that this next morsel of bao is going to be as good as my first.  Like narcotics it's never the same.  Now that there are so many great food truck options my love of The Chairman's bao has decreased.  Occasionally I would come back for their vegetarian option, tofu bao.  But I hesistate thanks to the understandably long lines or those guys that order for like 20 people in the office and hold up everyone else.
author: Christine L.

description:
Oh my Gawd!!!!  I had never had a pork bun before and decided to order the Coca-Cola braised pork and it was probably the best thing I have had for lunch in the city in years.  It's absolutely amazing.

If the Chairman is in your neighborhood go, nay RUN, to the truck and order one of their very well priced pork buns.  It was absolutely a 5-star, 10 on the scale, two-thumbs up and whatever other type of measurement you can think of.  

If the chairman is outside my building I will ALWAYS go get a pork bun from now on.
author: Bradley H.

description:
If nothing else, I am a faithful Panda. 

While I can't review the full range of Baos, the tofu variety, both baked and steamed are delicious. I like the baked just a little more, but they both have deliciously crispy tofu and greens and sauce that do not fail to delight. I've been heading out to the various Movable Feasts (food truck mini-festivals!) and other gatherings, and this is a fun way to chase down food and enjoy it. Somehow, my vegetarian hunting instincts have been engaged. You won't escape me, little tofu Baos!
author: Kuro N.

description:
Was lucky that this truck was in an alleyway on Mission/Fremont by my work. The line was manageable, so I decided to wait the 30 minutes.

I also was lucky to snag the last baked bun.  Got the braised pork baked bun (which is bigger than the steamed buns, hence the price difference) and the garlic tofu steamed bun.  I really enjoyed the braised pork baked bun.  Hearty, good portions, cabbage nicely pickled, and the pork not so "hitsukoi" or "too much flavor"; perfect.  I added sri racha sauce to both and it was fantastic.

Yum! Try it, at least to try it once.
author: Chieko H.

description:
Finally got a chance to try Chairman Bao during Off the Grid at Civic Center. They had a short line when I was there and I opted for the special - duck confit with papaya salad on a steamed bun for $4.50.

The steamed buns are like the buns you get for Beijing/Peking duck, but larger. They're shaped sort of like a taco shell and are made of white flour and have a fluffy but sweet taste to it. Chairman Bao offers their menu on either steamed or baked buns with the steamed buns being around $4 and baked being around $6+. The special I ordered was only available on a steamed bun though.

Now I have no idea what confit is but the duck confit was amazing! Imagine skinless duck meat that has been hand pulled and compressed into a dense rectangular patty topped with just the right amount of sweet sauce and papaya salad. It seemed like a tiny portion but the dense duck confit actually made it fairly filling. I definitely want to come back and try one of their baked buns.
author: Monica W.

description:
I got a chance to head over here after so many good things that I've heard/read about the truck.

I grabbed an order of everything that was steamed.  All were really good, but the one that definitely stood out was the coca-cola pork, which was sweet and delicious.  I didn't get a chance to try the other variation of "bao" that was offered, but I figured it was just too big for my appetite.  Perhaps next time though.
author: Ren L.

description: Been planning to go to this food truck for weeks since I heard it is close to my class. I went to the location on mission and 1st, and was disappointed when I did not see it parked on the street. Well, because they weren't parked on the street. It was hidden in a little food truck hub between two building. I got both steamed and baked version. They were excellent in their own ways. I think the style the food was presented is very innovative and was on par with the flavor. I was going to take a picture of my meal, but devoured it before I had a chance. Next time though...
author: Vincent P.

description: I've tried both the steamed and the bake. The pork belly does taste amazing. It brings pork belly to a whole new level! but I'm not going to lie, the baos are really really small. well the steamed one is. The baked one made me feel like eating a hamburger. Still good - just never really expected baos to cost that much... and i've eaten a lot of baos in my life. I'd still get it, once in a while when the line isn't freakishly long.
author: Kristina L.

description:
Okay, so I have to admit I had no idea what this truck was when I first saw it. My first time at OtG last year we were a little early and I was walking around reading menus. I noticed that a line was already forming for this truck...so I hopped in. Figured it must be good. I was fourth in line and it didnt take too long for the line to multiply. I wasn't sure what to get so I just blurted anything out. 

Baked Sesame Chicken with Scallion and Bok Choy- Eh, it was okay. I think the baked bun takes away a lot from the sesame chicken. I ended up eating it open face.

Steamed Tender Pork Belly (sans the Pickled Daikon)- WINNER! The bun is warm and soft filled with a juicy pork belly. I totally would have lined up for more if the line weren't so long.
author: Heather P.

description:
I have eaten hundreds of pork buns over the last few decades in San Francisco.  My preference being those with more pork and less bun.  However, I was taken aback by the steamed pork belly buns with pickled daikons at the Chairman Bao food truck.  The pork belly just melts in your mouth.  I was expecting this creative rendition from a chi chi brick and mortar restaurant with an organic vegetable garden out back.  This quality from a food truck is hard to believe.  I would give it six stars if it were possible.

After a 30 minute wait in line, make sure you order two or three per person as these are relatively small morsels but they pack a savory punch.
author: Hugh Y.

description:
I have a serious issue.  Is there a such thing as pork belly addiction?!

     I heard about this truck through a friend and gave it a shot at the Off The Grid one night before a Giants game.  Unbelievable!!!  Their food is outstanding, and the fusion of flavors is absolutely perfect.  I'm connected with their Facebook page now, and I'm the first one in line everytime they make their way to one of the Sacramento Mobile Food events!  Any time I head out to the bay area, I check out their daily schedule to see if I could squeeze in a quick trip for some buns!

     Favorites - The pork belly on the steamed bun, and the sesame chicken (also on the steamed bun).  I've tried everything on the menu, I feel like I could have 2 of each on a daily basis...I know, serious addiction. =P
author: Kenneth C.

description: It it's a very good food truck. The pork belly bun, bake or steam is something you should not miss if you are trying this truck. The sour veggies give an enhance flavor to the pork belly.  This being half fat half meat provide buttery taste on the palate, the marinate is the typical Chinese bbq.  In that simplicity yet it taste good all together.  With that said, I still will not wait one hour for that. It was only five people in from of me so it was part of the good experience. I also try the spicy chicken but it can not be compare to the pork belly.
author: Z G.

description:
Went to OTG at Fort Mason, and this truck definitely had the longest line! I have been wanting to try out Chairman Bao for a long time now, so I was happy that the truck was there. 
I really wanted to try what a lot of yelpers recommended, like the duck confit with mango, ginger lychee lemonade.. etc.. But they had a limited selection by around 8pm at OTG. Still, we tried the braised pork and pork belly buns, and they were so good! The pork was buttery, and the veggies that they came with complimented each well. The only downside is that at $3.75 for a steamed bun (the smaller of your options, the baked bun is ~$7, and looks like a burger bun), the portion you get is tiny! But I guess it's worth it since they're so good.. I only wish that this truck would go to the OTG events in Berkeley so I could try their other buns and drinks..
author: Janice W.

description:
The pork belly bun is delicious because it's basically a mouthful of fat in a bun with pickled veggies on top.

And I wouldn't have it any other way.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Tender pork belly is so delicious!!! 
I usually get it in a baked bun, the bread they use is so soft and good. It's more expensive than the steamed bun but that's because it's bigger. The steamed bun is good too but the flavor on the baked bun is still my favorite!
author: Daisy S.

description:
After waiting for over half an hour for a damn pork belly and tofu bun, I thought to myself: "this sh*t better be good."

And was it? Uh hell yes.

Would I wait 30 minutes in line? Sure why not, I have nothing better to do... I'd probably wait longer just for a pork belly bun alone.
author: Ro R.

description: Came by the office today and I couldn't get enough. Good, fresh ingredients. Prompt service. The bun is one of the fluffiest I've had -- get the curry tofu, even if you're not vegetarian
author: Peter G.

description: I was skeptical of this truck when I saw it last year at Eat Real.  I can get a ton of baos with duck for under $12 at a chinese restaurant.  There's a new food truck setup near my office and the usual suspects are out there.  My mgr tried chairman bao last week and it looked good so I tried it today.  I had the pork belly, spicy chicken and garlic tofu steamed baos.  The pork belly and chicken is good, the tofu was a little too moist and drowned out the bao taste.  I'd do this maybe once/twice a month.  There was no wait at all after 1:30 p.m.  Would never wait more than 10-15 mins for this truck.
author: Josh L.

description:
We love and support Chairman Bao.
My favorites are the steam buns, when I can I take one of each.

To know where they are: @chairmantruck
author: Yann K.

description:
Tasty enough to elicit my first review!
Got one of each of the steamed buns offered this day at Off the Grid Upper Haight: (now what do these Rating Stars stand for again?)

RED CHICKEN STEAMED BUN** Meh I've experienced better
     WORTH A TRY? SURE: Maybe this one was just out done by the other two but, left me wanting more "red" in my red chicken. Sriracha maybe?
     BUY IT AGAIN? NO
      
CRISPY TOFU STEAMED BUN **** "Yay! I'm a fan"
     WORTH A TRY? ABSOLUTELY! Even if you're not a fan of tofu. The patty was suprisingly creamy and full of flavor and crispy on the outside. Yum with the dressing and fresh greens too! Should've paid more attention, but it was gone too quickly. In my Bellay!
     BUY IT AGAIN? YES PLEASE! I'm craving it as I type.

PORK BELLY STEAMED BUN  ***** "Woohoo! As good as it gets!"
    WORTH A TRY? AND THEN SOME! My expectations were so high with this one, because #1. great reviews, #2. Pork Belly..nuff said #3. All the inticing photos on here! But I psyched myself out, cuz nothing breaks my heart like being let down by my treats. But alas I was saved! (emoting) Ok, so, loved the meat, loved the fat, loved the Char Sui flavor on the crispy bark. I fully agree with my sister when she said "I'm in heaven~ " Oh, and though I LOVE fat, it may have been too fatty had it not been for the pickled daikon & onions. PERFECT!
     BUY IT AGAIN? WE DID JUST THAT! Once we inhaled those three, we went back and ordered us each a Pork Belly for our very own. "MINE!!"
author: Kana N.

description: Consistently amazing food. When the Chairman Truck comes around to work, I drop all lunch plans and get one of each of their steamed bun baos. The pork belly bao has a nice mix of sweet pork belly and pickled cucumber; as everyone says, the pork itself melts in your mouth. Don't sell the braised pork of spicy chicken baos, either--they have their own unique flavors that contrast well with the pork belly. Service is fast and courteous, but expect a little bit of a line because this truck is so popular--for good reason.
author: Jerry T.

description: Finally took the plunge and stood in the long line at the chairman during a recent off the grid. Man oh man is it tasty. I think I prefer the steamed buns over the baked, but both were delicious! We had the pork belly, the braised pork and the tofu- and all were tasty. The pork belly and tofu were the best. I know it's hard to resist the delicious meaty options, but if you like tofu- you have to order the tofu bun. The chips are the perfect snack for while you wait for your food to come up. Only downside is that we got so excited in line and ordered so much, that we were too full for the other off the grid trucks.. but if I could go back and do it again, I wouldn't do it any differently.
author: claire c.

description: The vegetarian miso tofu bun is absolutely delicious.  I've tried both the baked and steamed bun and you can't go wrong with either.  Throw a little sriracha on top for a kick and you will be in taste bud heaven.  Long live the Chairman!
author: Rani V.

description:
SO I think I'm over this whole food truck thing after this last experience...

I tried Chairman Bao last week when it came to Mission Bay for the day. Showed up at 12:45 hoping to get lunch and take it back for my 1:30 meeting (I was all of a block away from my office). It didn't happen.

I was meeting some coworkers, and I got there first so I grabbed a spot in line and waited for them. There were probably about thirty people ahead of me in line. At 1:15 there were still a dozen people in front of me, and things clearly were not moving along, so I asked my coworkers to put in my order and bring it back to the office for me, which they were kind enough to do. My meeting was done (at 2:00) before they got back. WTF?

The buns were tasty enough, but suffered from major issues with being too messy to eat easily; if I had been walking down the street trying to eat this food instead of sitting down, things probably would have been a disaster.

Chairman Bao, this is not how you run a food truck. It shouldn't take forty-five minutes to get to the head of the line and place your order, and then a further half hour to actually get said food. ESPECIALLY not when your menu offers all of six freaking items. Le Truc, for comparison, offers twice as many menu items and managed to get me from standing at the back of the line to having food in my hand in 30 minutes, and this was on the day that the Food Network was there doing a special on them.

I'm massively disappointed with the service here, especially when the food is tasty and the truck is so damn hyped up. I won't be back until I hear that they've gotten a handle on their service issues.
author: Sam K.

description: I had the pork belly bun and it was amazing! Definitely recommend this food truck because their food tastes better than most restaurants.
author: Roger C.

description:
When i normally think of bao or chinese buns, i think a tender bread ball filled with pork or custard, but this place takes it in a different inventive step of baking flat baos and filling them like a taco.  Well it works!  Very tasty!

I ordered the chicken bao, and the warm soft fluffy bread was a great texture alternative to your standard taco tortilla, and the filling was tender and super flavorful with sort of an asian marinade on the chicken.

I would definitively go here again, there is a reason the lines are so long, its worth it.
author: Chris K.

description: DEAR LORD UP IN HEAVEN this food truck is amazing. I had the pork belly steam bun and the spicy chicken baked bun. Heavenly. Both had so many amazing ingredients explode in my mouth. I love, love this truck!!
author: Jennifer J.

description:
Who doesn't like chairman bao, right?

If it weren't for the fact that waiting forever in line is part of the general bao experience it would be my favorite truck. The buns are delicious, with amazing meat fillings and interesting sauces. I absolutely love their shaved ice drinks (when they have them) and would consider waiting in line just for them, they're so refreshing and tasty (coconut strawberry was amazing! 

Only once in a while will we get buns with just fat for the meat filling which sucks after such a long wait but that has only happened twice I think and the other times definitely make up for it. 

I would never wait in the long line for them, but if I find it before they start up I usually stop by. A little expensive for just buns, but worth it once in a while.
author: Sam H.

description:
SO GOOD. People have told me they like the tofu bao even more than the pork, but I wouldn't know about that. I only know that the tofu is smoky, savory, and so flavorful, with just the right grilled crunch on the outside. The buns are used like little tortillas to form a "taco" and they're light and fluffy and just a tiny bit sweet. The bok choy and sauce topping is juuuuuust right. I ate two of these but I could have easily eaten twice as many. 

The service was friendly and the truck is decorated with fun swirls and a panda in the fashion of Chairman Mao. Great stuff!
author: Jennifer d.

description:
My office manager inadvertently teased me again today about the fact that her and her husband were going to get Chairman Bao or perhaps her husband was going to go pick it up for her. "Would Ryan pick it up for me too and bring it to work?" was what went through my head, but that would've been kind of a bit much to ask. The catered crunch mode dinner tonight ended up being something pretty lackluster from Waiters on Wheels, so I grabbed John and Jon to go over to Curry Up Now. Lo and behold, I totally forgot that Off the Grid had started up again tonight and was right next to Curry Up Now AND the Chairman Bao truck was sitting front and center!!! What's better is that we got there early enough that there were no lines for anything!!!

SO, I finally got to try Chairman Bao. Oh man. I am still salivating and wishing I'd gotten two more buns!!! OK. Ok. Let me back up. The girls working in the Chairman truck are super nice and friendly. They took my order and then had my meal in my hands no more than 5 minutes later. I got the pork belly bun and the braised pork bun (both steamed). The pork belly was very tender and flavorful and had some yummy pickled veggies on top in a light, fluffy bun. The braised pork was a little bit like Asian carnitas with some big chunks of dark crispy pork and  a cabbage mixture on top. Both were insanely good!!!

Chairman Bao is probably the best food truck I've eaten at in terms of food, friendliness, and service. These girls deserve to be superstars with this kind of business and I can't wait to try all the other buns next time they're in town!!
author: Jason W.

description: Ok. The spicy chicken steamed bun is over the top good. I just went to OTG at the Presidio for the first time and tried one of these. I can't stop thinking about that bun. ;-)
author: kim w.

description:
I've heard so many good things about this truck and their food, and there was a huge crowd in front so they must be good, right? I was excited to try a new twist on a classic Chinese favorite. I ordered their most popular bao bun, the Pork Belly with pickled daikons. 

I wasn't too impressed because what I had was really greasy and over seasoned. It was just WAY too salty! The pork AND pickled daikons were just overloaded with salt! The little bun wasn't big enough to balance out the saltiness of the meat and veggies. I found myself reaching for any sort of beverage that I could find because it was like consuming a spoonful of salt. Later on in the day, I realized that there has to be some MSG in the food because I was constantly thirsty for hours after I ate the bun.

If the flavors were a little more muted, the food would be fine. If they could leave out the MSG, it would be a lot better. 

Overall, it wasn't horrible, but it's not something I would particularly look forward to consuming again.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Gosh, I can't believe I never wrote a review for Chairman Bao! Chairman Bao is one of a handful of food trucks that I return to whenever I am at one of the OTG events. 

I first tried their buns some time in 2009 when the food truck boom was just taking off and Chairman Bao was one of the trucks that I heard a whole lotta raves about. Frankly, I wasn't that "moved" after trying a few of their buns and quite baffled by what the hype was over.

Fast forward to 2011 and I must say, they've come a long way with the buns and I am definitely a fan. The ingredients and flavors are some of the best flavor combo I've tasted!
author: Soozie H.

description:
This is the only food truck I've gone back to again and again.

Baked buns are like the size of a small burger, steamed buns are like a taco.  One baked + one steamed = decently filling lunch for $10.

My favorite combination is the pork belly with the baked bun, and the crispy tofu with the steamed bun.
author: S L.

description:
I'll keep my review short & sweet. 
2 Words.... Pork Belly. 
Soooo Goooood!!
There is usually a long line and after eating here you will find out why. 
I definitely recommend coming here.
author: Mariel F.

description:
PORK BELLY BUN SO GOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOD!!!! oh gosh SO GOOD SO GOOD SO GOOOODDD!! kinda wish it was cheaper than 3.75 though cus its pretty small. but DANG its way better than what i expected taste wise. i was expecting a regular cha siu bao but it wassssnnnttt it was better!! so much better and greasier and tastier! sigh i wish to go try it again..

the red sesame chicken was alright though.. it was kind of spicy and not as juicy or tasty as the pork belly. maybe i should have tried the chicken first but i was not impressed with the chicken. next time getting 5 orders of pork belly because 1 or 2 or 3 or 4 is just not enough.
author: Rebecca K.

description:
We drove extra miles just to try their duck.
"We no longer have it, it takes a long time to make and it is not very popular" 
The cashier had no smile and offered no apology
My friend's pork bun was fat, the marinated veggie was good.  
Save yourself standing in line and the drive if you just want duck like me
author: A C.

description: Pork belly buns were disappointing :( I miss David Chang's momofuku pork belly buns. Obviously street cart food will not be at the same caliber as DChang's, but I still found it average, much like something I could find at a chinese restaurant in the city. Definitely not worth a 40 minute wait at OTG.
author: Joyce H.

description:
This truck frequents the SF area but it happened to be in the Motorola offices parking lot in Santa Clara one day.  The line wasn't long at 11:45am but quickly picked up between noon to 12:30pm.  If I were you, I would definitely beat the rush by feigning sickness to your boss to secure some edible treats.  Otherwise, you'll wait 10-20 minutes as the 4 cooks inside fulfill all previous orders.

The truck has two variations of each item.  You can opt for a steamed bun which looks like a white pancake folded in two but stuffed with veggies and meat or you can order the baked bun which acts as a hamburger bun with the meat and veggies in between.  An average person can be satisfied off one baked bun order or two steamed bun order.

My personal favorite was the steamed bun Coca-Cola pork butt with lettuce and mustard seeds.  The soda marinate gave the pork a sweet and tasty flavor and the mustard seeds gave it a weird taste in a good way.  The pork belly bun was mediocre which may be due to either the quality of the pork or the skills of the cook.  The chicken is .... chicken.  It's good and healthier than the pork but definitely not as tasty.  Don't get me wrong, it's still good but not orgasmic good as the Coca-Cola pork.  The hidden gem is the tofu.  The tofu had just the right consistency - not to firm and not too flimsy.  With the sauce they added, the tofu is a formidable opponent to the Coca-Cola pork.

I will definitely flag them down next time they are in the South bay.
author: Ronald L.

description:
Delicious. The pork belly baked bun (WAY bigger than the steamed bun) is amaaazing. The only problem is that once you order your food from a food truck, you gotta stand and eat it which makes you naturally consume the food 3 times faster than you would sitting down, so the wonderful flavors disappear too quickly.

Tis my only complaint.
author: An-Nhien L.

description:
A little unusual for my taste, but I was blown away. My first bun was eaten in Civic Center in front of the big screen when the Giants won the World Series. The people at Chariman Bao are great! How could one put together such odd ingredients together and make it a masterpiece? I don't know how, but whatever they're doing, it's working! 
My favorite is the Red Sesame Chicken with Scallions and Bok Choi.
They are definitely killing the food truck and asian fusion food game.
I can't wait till the next time I come across this Truck.
author: Monina C.

description: Pork belly dry and tough - nicely crisped on the outside, though.  Flavors good enough.  So what's the deal, really?  OK-ish food, sit-down pricing, wait in a long line, eat on the curb.  Not compelling.
author: Shib W.
