description:
Looking at the lines, one has to wonder how those buns are. After tasting a few, I realized that I've had this before - in any Chinese restaurant that has a decent buns dish. If you have to wait 5-10 min in line, it may be worth it. If it's longer, perhaps go to one of the many other trucks around or somewhere else.

Don't get me wrong, the buns are tasty. All the fixings and sauces work well in balance to give you a very tasty [few] bites. Pork belly is good and tender, the duck is worth a try as well. But for me, I've had my fill. On to the next one.
author: Ray C.

description:
YUM!!!!!

I love their buns! I would just stick with the steamed ones though. The baked ones are tooooo big and for that price you could get two different steams baos.

The combination of flavor is to die for. It's like Jesus and Buddha orgasmed in my mouth. Okay maybe that was a bad way to describe it, but they're GOOD!
author: Albert K.

description:
Wow what a BAO!  this is not your typical bao, as it's more of a taco or pancake type of dealio.  But it was good!!! 

I tried this truck last night at Off the Grid at Upper Haight and got the pork belly one as well as the duck one.  The duck one was their special of the night that was really good and unique, but the pork belly bao was the best.  I love pork belly because it has a little bit of fat in it, but it makes the meat taste so delicious.  The pickled yellow daikon on top was also really  good, and slightly sweet and pickled at the same time.

Oh, both were steamed, as you have the choice of getting a baked version or a steamed version.
author: Liz W.

description:
I saw this on Eat St.  and have been dying to try it.  I promised myself the next time I had up to SF, I will follow this truck.   

I am so HAPPY that I finally had the pork belly bao!  I tried all four baos and the pork belly was my favorite.  The steamed bao was light and fluffy, the pork was super tender with lots of flavor, and the pickled daikon was a great complement with the nice crunch.
author: Van L.

description:
A little too overhyped for me unfortunately. 
But here's a helpful tip: Always get the Steamed version, never baked. Much more worth your money and much tastier.

The best bun is the tender pork belly, hands down. The pork belly was melt in your mouth goodness. 

Only 3 stars for being ridiculously overpriced.
author: Julia K.

description: Wow, just had two of these for dinner in Hayward. Sooo good! A little heavy but tasted great and quicker service than most trucks.
author: Dean I.

description:
Fantastic buns but I won't eat here again until they get their public health rating up. go to the link below to see what I'm talking about. Rating of 70 out of 100. To compare, the food truck for Sunrise Deli has 100! 90 would be okay but 70???
Chairman, PLEASE PLEASE get things in order so I can eat your fantastic buns again. 

 https://101g-xnet.sfdph.org:4443/pls/eeop_htmldb/f?p=132:2:2348883047133282::NO::P2_LOCATIONID:67875
author: m j l.

description: Every time there is a Moveable Feast event, I check the list of trucks to make sure The Chairman will be there. Food is consistently delicious and the service is fast and friendly. The pork belly steam bun sandwiches are dangerously good and reasonably priced for food truck fare. LOVE this truck.
author: Amanda F.

description:
Wow.  Finally got to try the truck at Off the Grid in San Mateo.  One look at the crowd and you could tell which truck was the most popular, but now I know why.  Super delicious!  I loved the baked buns & the steamed pillowy goodness variety as well.  Large portions, melt in your mouth yummyness.  Get some.  

Definitely have to try Bao Bun!
author: Erin D.

description:
I've been to a few functions where the chairman was slanging his warm buns as if he was working a seedy corner in the tenderloin. My bad, i think every corner is a seedy one in the loin. I never knew what "bao buns" were, until yesterday. But yesterday was a glorious day. Birds were singing, the sun was out and Bao was serving up the buns at Off the Grid: Civic Center. I ordered the baked braised pork bun. My fiancee ordered the red sesame chicken. 

oh
em
gee

Suddenly everything made sense. The line that usually accompanies the Chairman Bao truck now, of course makes perfect sense. But after enjoying this hot, fresh, surprisingly light, perfectly cooked manna from heaven EVERYTHING made sense. Everything was right with the world and I found myself grateful for every blessing in my life. I love me some Bao buns. I've converted into the Bao doctrine.
author: Jarred D.

description:
Can't believe I haven't reviewed Chairman Bao. Or is it because they're now The Chairman? Doesn't quite have the same ring to it, sadly. Whether they did this to be PC or finally just caved to Baohaus NYC, they still serve a mean bao. After all, what's in a name?

The same thing that's in the baos. Awesomeness. I always get one pork belly on steamed bun and one cola braised pork in steamed bun. Sets me back under $8. If Cupkates is around, I add that offense to my arteries as well. 

They're the only baos I know of (where you can just buy a bao... I don't want to have to eat a whole Peking duck) in SF.
author: Erika C.

description: Quite surprised to be honest. The menu reads only one veggie option - tofu which came either fried or baked. I asked the lady inside what she'd recommend and she said the steamed is good. I ordered three and I don't regret it. The tofu is pan seared which makes it crisp on the outside and soft on the inside. With the garlic and other ingredients, its an amazing explosion of flavours in your mouth.
author: Varti S.

description:
Review #100 w0000t!

I've been wanting to try this truck for a while after hearing my buddy rave about the buns. What could be so great about these little buns?! 

I was able to catch the Chairman at MVBL Feast Garden City and there were only 4 people in line :) They had 4 different steamed buns on the menu so my fatass bought all 4 to see what the hype was about. ZOMGGG!!! SO GOOOOOOD!!! 

All of the buns come with different veggies(pickled?), all really fresh, crispy, and full of flavor. Goes perfect with the meats.

Pork Belly- Melt in mouth pork belly, MUST TRY

Coca Cola Braised Pork- ALSO melt in mouth pork with a nice touch of flavoring from the Cola

Tofu- Not that big on tofu but I decided to try it anyways. Tofu was just, tofu but the veggies on top made it worth while

Spicy Chicken- Chicken was tender, just a little bit on the dry side, really oily and messy, but still gave me a BAO-GASM

For anybody that hasn't tried this yet, TRY IT. It WILL NOT dissapoint. 

PS: ILY Chairman XOXO
author: Harry T.

description:
Honestly, I love steamed buns.  I was one of those kids who stole all the steamed buns off the platter when the family ordered Peking Duck.  I was the kid who would ask to buy just steamed buns from Asian bakeries and markets, and gorge on about 5 just to ruin dinner.  So when I stumbled upon Chairman Bao at Eat Real 2010, I was kind of excited (a la kid in a candy store, but in my case, kid in a steamed bun store).

The first thing I noticed while waiting in the kind of long line, was the unique design and color scheme of the truck with the huge panda who I assume is Chairman Bao.  Walking slowly, step by step, mouth watering and stomach grumbling, I could not wait to eat some steamed buns.  Finally, upon reaching the front of the line, I had to order as much as I thought I could consume (and carry in one hand because the other hand had a beer in it), so I got a red sesame chicken, pulled pork and crispy tofu steamed buns.

I got three knowing I would have to share with my fellow festival goers, so while walking around (and getting lost on purpose) looking for my group, I took bites out of all three.  Each one was delicious in its own right.  However, my favorite was the crispy tofu... but obviously, the star was the steamed bun which was perfectly soft, slightly sweet, and oh so good.  Join the revolution and get some Chairman Bao!
author: Thomas N.

description:
Will anyone read this since this place has garnered over a gaZillion reviews? Probably not. But the Prince of Taiwan needs to lay his two cents down nevertheless, much like how fat chicks have to lay down after walking one flight of stairs. 

Pork Belly Steamed Buns. Just buy these and your belly will thank you for it, not to mention your tastebuds. Perfect bites of pork belly goodness. it is fatty, moist, tasty, oh heavenly indulgent goodness. the peeps that I saw in line eating these buns looking like they were performing fellatio on the damn buns. Needless to say this is a winner. At 3.75 not too pricey either..but these buns are small, about three bites tops.
author: Jerry C.

description:
When I think buns, I don't think of the Chairman....they're more like sandwiches to me. I'm a fan of the steamed little pockets of porky goodness, others prefer the baked. They're a little pricy for what you get, two steamed will be my lunch and will set me back $7ish, but the hungry could easily spend $10 or more.

You can't go wrong with any, I've tried all the meat options and I always find myself going back to the porky options...mmm...pork belly and coca cola braised pork...mmm.. till next time!
author: Wendy L.

description:
They have some bomb ass pork belly buns.

Caught them at "Off the Grid" on 6/17 and thankfully we were there right when they opened, cause within 10 minutes, the line was already backing up into other food truck spaces.

Ordered some steamed pork belly buns, the braised pork, and the crispy tofu bun.  All were good but they ain't got shizznit on the pork belly.  I would marry that piece of glob if I could.  The fat just bursts into your mouth and get's the party kickin' in there.  Highly recommended.  Just make sure you get there early and don't go too late bc they run out of this stuff fast!
author: Chai S.

description: Still one of the best food-trucks out there. I always get a trio of the steamed buns. So tasty!
author: michael k.

description:
Finally decided to wait thru the 30 minute line at OTG Fort Mason to see what all the hype is about. (I think the line was abnormally shorter because NomNom was making their debut at the event) 

Tried the pork belly, the sesame chicken, and the garlic tofu. The stand out winner in my mind is the chicken. Spicy and sweet. Plenty of filling to bread ratio and was worth the wait. I didn't notice any limitation signs on how many you could order this time. 

Definitely going to be imitating these little buns at home!
author: Tina P.

description:
Expensive and inauthentic.  It tasted fine, but was a taco, not a bun.

But, I also don't get the whole "Chairman" deal.  Since when was it kitsch to celebrate/make a play off of a genocidal dictator responsible for the death, torture and imprisonment of millions.

What's next, Pol Pot Stickers?
author: James S.

description: I was on my way to golden boy pizza and saw chairman truck so I decided to order some steamed pork belly with pickles buns for appetizer.  The pork belly was so tender and smoky and the tangy pickles were so good with it.  It was heaven!  Great street food!
author: Fenny L.

description: Not sure why this place is so popular, but after waiting 15 minutes in line, the sandwich was very very greasy and not tasty at all. Cost was above average too. Very disappointing...
author: Serge U.

description:
This place comes to my work about once a month, which I'm very thankful for.  I actually waited in line for them for a full hour this week (they were a bit late setting up and a huge line had formed), that's how much I love their buns!  They are super quick putting together your meal once you've ordered.  Normally I'd take that as a bad sign, but their food is very fresh and perfectly prepared.  They're just on top of it!

Like pretty much everyone else says, you have to get the pork belly.  Just do it.  I didn't think I'd like it, as I'm normally not a fan of fatty meat but... yes.  Wow.  I've also had the spicy chicken a couple times, which is great too.  The pickled veg they put on top (daikon for the pork belly and carrots/cucumber for the chicken) adds some great crunch and flavor balance.
author: Katelyn M.

description: The pork belly bao was legit.  Really full of flavor and the meat was very reminiscent of char siu so the homage to the chinese flavors was much respected.  I enjoyed the bao chips as well....the seaweed gave it an earthiness w. the togarashi spice.
author: Ricky C.

description:
Oh *HELLZ* yeah!  This is *my* joint, bad edgy pun and all.

The kale and marinated tofu on soft rice bun is delicious and refined, although I prefer to go for their masterstroke of gustatory genius: a brick of savory pork belly and a handful of crispy pickled daikon slices in a soft golden bun.  Abundant sweet and sour and salty and umame in every bite.  Cannot fail to delight.  Your best source for a quick porkbelly fix.

Expect big lines.
author: Tee Jay R.

description:
PORK BELLY BAO.

DELICIOUS - - - - - - - minus the bright yellow daikon on it. (I don't like daikon)

A must visit if you're in the city!
author: Linda N.

description:
My work colleagues easily gave me the excuse to leave the juicy spinach tuna salad in the fridge. We went food trucking and i saw...

http://www.yelp.com/biz/chairman-bao-bun-truck-san-francisco

had the steam buns (Banh Bao!!!) braised pork (yum), pork belly (yummier),and crispy garlic tofu (you can only do so much to make soy beans come to life on your taste buds).
author: Dat N.

description:
3.5 stars

I've been obsessed with pork belly buns ever since I've had the ones at Momofuku Ssam in NY.   Chairman Bao's steamed pork belly buns are pretty good, but not quite as good as the ones from Momofuku.  The meat was a little dry, especially at the end, and the pickled daikon overpowered it a bit.

The braised pork, on the other hand, was delicious!  It was packed with flavor.  I had to fight my hubby for the last bite.  

$3.75 for the steamed buns.  The steamed pork buns at Spice Kit are better and cheaper.  I would go back for the braised pork though.  

- Cash only
author: Ring K.

description:
Chairman Bao was soooo good! 

Both my boyfriend and I got the Pork Belly and Pickled Daikon Steamed bun at Off the Grid in North Berkeley and it was definitely the best food truck food I have ever tasted. The bun is perfectly soft and light, the pork belly is super tender and flavorful with just a little bit of crispiness to it and it is topped was delicious pickled daikon. The daikon really helps balance the bun out from the heaviness of the pork belly and leaves a refreshing taste in your mouth. My only regret was not ordering more! Next time an going to get the larger sized baked bun with the pork belly and try one of the other flavors of steamed buns, probably the tofu. 

If you are going to Off the Grid, I recommend that you go a little early, closer to when it opens, to beat the lines. The Chairman is definitely the most popular truck there! But even if there is a line, I can guarantee it will be worth the wait!
author: Kayleigh B.

description:
85% Yes. 15% No for the price. The Chinese Bun Truck; finally Asians are hitting up the Fast Food Truck market. Watch out Taco Trucks, there's a new up-comer in town. A great spin off of the peking duck dish found in your local Chinatown, they took the soft steam buns and wrapped it in with pork bellies, pulled pork, or sesame chicken sprinkled with pickled vegetables. Just like "White Castle" these little creations aren't going to get you full and there is a 6 bun limit per customer. 

This will be good as an appetizer. Walking the beat of the Asian Street Fest this past Saturday, Chairman Bao was a treat. Three bites and on to the next vendor. The price tag of one of these buns are $3-7. If you are into trying new food, Chairman Bao will fulfill that need.

To find the nearest Chinese Truck, follow them on Twitter. I don't promote vendors, but this is a moving restaurant.
author: Uland W.

description: I had food here today and let me say it was so good! I had a mix of everything. Chips are great. Chicken and pork delicious! Can't go wrong with the food and service is excellent! Highly recommend this truck to all you yelpers and will do so to my family n friends!
author: Anton Z.

description:
Do yourself a favor, if you want to order multiple flavors..buy the steamed buns because the baked buns are frikken HUGE/ like "super size me" status. the red sesame chicken was spicy goodness. The addition of carrots and cucumber added a cool sweet flavor..ingenious combination and i absolutely loved it! but unfortunately I ate it first, got incredibly full and couldn't really enjoy the pork belly bun so i had to pass it off to someone else. 

 chairman bao FTW!
author: Cindy C.

description:
I have eaten at The Chairman since it was Chairman Bao. I like the new less communist name. 

Every time I come through I get the steamed pork belly. The first time my lips touched this scrumptious meat I actually did a little dance. Unfortunately, much like crack cocaine ever time I come back the pork belly is a little less tasty.  Was the first bite really the best? Will I ever get another perfect pork belly again?  I hope so.  I will keep trying like a pork belly junkie.

They also sell cool black T-shirts now too.
author: Jason L.

description:
THE BEST! I get so excited when I see them setting up outfront the Gift Center! It's like the best day ever. I have had everything on their menu and its all to die for, its the most high end burst of flavor I could ever imagine for $3.25. My favorite is the spicy chicken and crispy tofu on a steamed bun, $6.50 for lunch? Really? In SF? YES! 
I love you guys, keep on truckin'! 
p.s. anyone who doesn't give 5 stars has no taste buds and should try the nasty philly cheese steak truck next time instead. Blah!
author: Leilani L.

description:
I've long wanted to try the famed CBBs. Today (Jan 6, 2011), the stars aligned ! Traveling on S. Van Ness on my Triumph, I hit traffic and decided to take a side street (15th to Valencia). Good I thought to myself, I'll drop in on Munroe Motors and say 'hi' to the gang.
How auspicious that the CBBT was parked right in front. Fate, destiny, call it what ever you wish... mine was the pork belly & braised pork buns!
The year is starting off right!
author: Gregg M.

description:
Yum! I visited the Chairman Truck when it was at Brannan Street yesterday.  

I had a steamed tofu bun and the baked pork belly bun for $10.  It was a very decent sized lunch (maybe if you're a guy/have a huge appetite, add another steamed bun).  

The steamed bun is kind of like a taco shape and the 'bun' itself is soft and easy to eat.  The baked buns are like hamburgers.  I found the pork belly quite rich (but pork belly is!) but very tasty.

I'd come back again!
author: Pig E.

description:
Went to Off the Grid at the Chronicle Building. We were like the 10th in line and waited an hour. CBBT had the longest line. This gave me time to look at the menu and decide on what I wanted. 

Pork belly- steamed $3.75
pulled pork- steamed $3.75
red sesame chicken- baked $6
matcha pina colada- $2.50
bao chips- $2.50

First off....what is with the huge price difference with steamed and baked? When I buy bbq pork buns whether steamed or baked, I pay no more than $1. I'm just saying............

Pork belly: Reading another review someone said they got slabs of pork belly. I only got two slices. What's up with that? It was crunchy and fatty and good with the sauce in the bun. The bun was thin flat pancake like. So it looked like a tiny taco. 

Pulled pork- yuck! Please pass on this. 

Red sesame chicken- spicy!!! I don't  think they mentioned that this was spicy. Ok red = spicy. I'm thinking Chinese here so I was thinking of the red bean curd in brine. It's the same baked bbq pork bun was was sliced in half. Kinda like a hamburger. 

Matcha pina colada- home made and this is a must.

bao chips- fried wonton chips, tiny strips of nori, tons of salt and spice. It was ok. 

Oh yeah....the girl short changed me! 

All in all this was a little bit on the pricey side for such tiny portions.

No I didn't eat all this by myself. I had the pork belly and half of the pulled pork. Not filling at all. 

Would I go back? Yes. For the pork belly, matcha pina colada, and they had another drink I didn't see on the menu but saw people with. It was a yellowish/clear drink. i think there was mixed fruit cocktail in there.

As a Miami food truck junkie I did my research while planning my trip to SF. I knew one thing and one thing only - this was the one food truck I wanted to track down on my trip to SF while on the west siiiiide. Chairman Bao, your honor, your excellency - I salute thee and thank you for not letting me down! I really enjoyed their steamed pork belly bun and their baked (never had a baked one before) braised pork bun. Both were awesome - washed them down w/ a Kirin draft and I was in food truck fat girl heaven.
author: Faby P.

description: I love the Chairman!!  What's not to like about Pork Belly?  Their flavors are so delicious and the portions are pretty generous.  When I first tried the Chairman, I had the Pork Belly and the Spicy Chicken.  Both were excellent.  Another time I went, I tried their baked buns and it's HUGE!  At first I thought it would be like the baked pork buns you get at dim sum, but to my surprise they made it like a sandwich, so they used the baked bun and then the pork belly...brilliant!  The only thing is they put so much daikon and other things it was all falling out.  But sooooo good.  If you ever see this truck, I highly suggest that you try something from it.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Leah A.

description:
I met Chairman Bao at Off the Grid one cold Friday evening and he made me wait for 45 minutes to taste his baos.  During the long wait in line, the owner, whom we shall name Chairman Bao, came out of the truck handing out what I thought was a menu but turned out to be the flyer that said to vote for him in the Food Network truck race.   Anyway, he told me that most people order the pork belly bao so I did.  Boy was it delicious.  The filling was excellent but I thought the bun was pretty decent too.  I also go to try the sesame chicken but it wasn't as good as the pork belly.  After that long wait, you are only allowed a maximum of 6 per order so a bunch of us just ordered together and got the max.

While we were eating our baos, Chairman Bao came walking towards us again and we yelled at him.  "Hey!  You tell us to try your truck and you're eating ramen from another truck!"  Trader Bao.  He said when you have your own truck, you just get tired of it which I guess makes sense.  It's just funny that he's standing in line promoting his truck with a bowl of ramen.  

He told us that people complained about the buns and they were frozen before so he said they just started with buns made from someone who worked at Yank Sing.  Wow.  A top notch truck I suppose if you like Yank Sing.  

Thank you, Chairman Bao, for the yummy buns.  However, I do not think it's worth a 45 minute wait in the freezing cold.  I could've gone to Chinatown and back in the same amount of time and paid 45 cents.    I know, I know.  It wouldn't be as good.
author: Stacey C.

description:
A-MAZING! Whenever I go to Chinese restaurants with my family, one of my favorite dishes is the roast duck buns with hoisin sauce and shrimp chips on the side. Chairman Bao is serves buns just like that, but with a twist. My favorite is the Pork Belly w/ Daikon Radish bun, followed by Roast Duck w/ Mango. The pork belly melts in your mouth and the daikon radish gives a little zing to each bite! Nom nom noms.

They're at Off The Grid every week, but the line is ridiculously long. If you're in the city a lot, I suggest hunting them down on other days where they camp out in front of various bars and shops because the line is shorter and that's always a good thing, cause girrrrrrl I'm ain't tryna wait foreva for my buns, I wants it NOW! If you must, go to OTG early or split up with friends and choose who has to be the unlucky one to wait in that super-long line while the rest of your crew roams around to check out other trucks haha.
author: Helen Z.

description:
My FAVORITE food truck at Off the Grid in Fort Mason (except for Cupkates on the dessert side). I went earlier tonight and it was good enough to warrant a same-night review :)

$3.75 for the steamed bun. It includes: delicious, buttery-soft chunks of pork belly and crispy, pickled daikon sandwiched between a pillow-soft white bun. 

It was DELICIOUS. An explosion of flavors in my mouth. The fattiness of the pork belly contrasted so well with the sharp flavor of the daikon. Yes, the pork buns are expensive. But yes, they are so, SO worth it. 

The sounds kind of weird, but the flavor of the daikon reminded me of the flavor of the slaw at Bakesale Betty's. And the bun reminded me of the buns on the famous pork buns at Ippudo Ramen in NYC (so, so good as well!). I definitely want to return to try their other buns/menu items.
author: Anita C.

description: Holy awesomeness!  Food trucks are few and far between in my neck of the woods, but was pleasantly surprised at the selection found at the Treasure Island Flea Market.  I was glad I chose to try the Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso on a steamed bun.  It was incredible.  I wish I bought several of them.  I'll be fantasizing about this bun for awhile!  Now if only I didn't have to drive an hour to get one.
author: Lizardp P.

description:
Every time I tell my friends about food trucks, this is one I *always* mention and strongly suggest that they must try. 

I have eaten their Pork Belly, Braised Pork, and Red Sesame Chicken in their steamed and baked forms. 

My favorite is the Pork Belly, as it is the perfect combination of flavors that fit into a fluffy bun. I prefer the steamed bun, because I feel that the sweetness of the baked bun takes away from the delicious savory filling. 

The price is a tad high for the amount of food you get, but it's not expensive considering the quality of food and its comparison to food trucks in general. I think it's worth the money (but for the steamed instead of baked buns, heh heh). 

p.s. one might think these buns are like the ones you find at dim sum restaurants which are filled prior to steaming/baking. Instead, these are more like a sandwich and stuffed to order.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Big flavors in these buns but I can't help but feel they are too expensive for what you get. Sure, they use all kinds of fancy pants organic, free range meats and things but my waiifish self dropped over $10* on three steamed buns and was still starving after.

I'll definitely pick one up in the future as a snack but probably won't be planning another whole meal around them again.

*This brings up a pet peeve of mine - they add sales tax on these buns. That just seems downright wrong...when you look at a food truck and see something as $2.95 it should be $2.95, not $3.21 or whatever they were.
author: phil h.

description: Got the steamed Pork belly with daikon and the Baked Spicy Chicken. Both were delicious and super filling and great with a little extra kick! (Thanks Sriracha) Usually takes about 10 minutes of wait time if they're busy but the food is always warm which is nice. The steamed dishes are smaller and cost 3.75 or you can get the baked version which is more like a burger size and available for 6.75 - loved the pickled everything.
author: Kajal G.

description: Pork belly on a baked bun....amaze balls. I'm a pork belly snob...this particular pork belly paired with the baked bun equals hog heaven! The bun is equally as good as the pork belly! Wonder twin powers activate....shape of a baked bun....form of pork belly! Insert witty onomatopoeia sound here
author: Nick L.

description:
Thank goodness for this truck! I really wanted to try it at the recent Off the Grid in the Haight, but the line was RIDICULOUS and we were starving. I am actually glad for that, since I was able to use an AMAZING, delectable pork belly bao to cleanse my palate of the oafish cheese nightmare from 3-sum... 

Every component was delicious, from the tender bun, to the PERFECT meat, to the crisp and flavorful daikon slaw. Well thought out, and perfectly executed. Same with the sesame chicken one. So, so good! 

Can't wait to eat here again, and try their other flavors and styles!
author: Teal H.

description:
They're tasty, but they're not bao. 

Let's be clear, a bao is a steamed bun filled with something or plain. When I say "filled" I mean that the contents are inside, and have been steamed with the bun. 

Chairman Bao gets packages of pre-made buns in chinatown and uses them like tacos to put things on. Their fillings are actually quite tasty, but that's not a bao. It's more like a fancy chinese style taco. 

So if you want asian-fusion-ish stuff on a bun, check it out. If you were actually looking for anything authentic like, for instance, a bao, this isn't the place.
author: Jacob L.

description: Loved this place! Those crazy rice buns melt in your mouth and the service was great. Definitely a great place to grab lunch- quick, easy to take to the office and delicious.
author: Edward C.

description: Not that I'll live longer, but dying with a smile isn't so bad!
author: Ben T.

description:
Gaga Flagging:  Sight UN seen /thx, Angel S.

Cool [hard-2-miss logo!]  -Just think. . .  PORK BELLY & PICKLED TURNIP

DROOL,

C
author: Clifford L.

description:
Just happened to stumble upon this truck on a cold and rainy weeknight..

Pricey, but the pork belly with pickled daikon, served open faced on a slightly sweet steamed bun...

Decent wait time.  Cash only.
author: Marilyn H.

description: The Chairman food truck (and I) can sometimes be found at Bishop Ranch 3 on Tuesdays.  My favorite is the Steamed Pork Belly and surprisingly, the Steamed Miso Tofu buns.  Not sure how to describe it, but I love what they do with tofu!
author: Evangelene G.

description:
I was driving to a restaurant for lunch and saw the Chairman Bao truck parked in Emeryville.  I was so excited I did a quick illegal U-turn and immediately found a parking spot.  My eyes were bigger than my stomach so I ordered 1 baked bu and 2 steamed buns.  

I ordered the Chinese spices duck confit with fresh mango salad which I highly recommend and costs $5.75 for the baked version.  This puppy is huge.  It is not your ordinary bao.  The duck tastes hot and fresh and the mango salad bursts with flavor.  The baked buns are definitely the way to go.

I also had a  steamed tender pulled pork belly with pickled daikon which costs $2.95.  I didn't really enjoy this one mainly because of the pickled daikon.  

The line was pretty long at 12:10 so get there early.  They show up in Emeryville on Hollis and 63nd on Wednesdays.  They also accept Visa and MasterCard.
author: Danny P.

description: We had our company Holiday party at Bluxome Winery and had The Chairman food truck.  The food was amazing, the service outstanding and best of all our people raved about the experience.  I highly recommend them and am still dreaming about the pork belly!!!
author: Meg G.

description:
Pork Belly.  The combination of crispy outside, melty fat, and flavorful sauce, cut by the acidity of pickled daikon and a soft sweet roll is just absolutely retardedly perfect.

Tip: One is not enough. Buy at least 3. Or 6.  Or a dozen. They won't go to waste, ever.
author: Yingjue C.

description:
One of those trucks with too much hype! just like the creme brulee cart. 
the pork one was pretty good, but the duck was def. a downer.  Ive had a better duck bao.  tasted kinda like a taco.
author: kim w.

description:
One of the best food trucks always found at Off The Grid, Thursady nights at Stanyan and Waller. 

Their steamed buns make for a filling meal in orders of two, a rough equivalent to eating just one of their baked buns (a sandwich-like configuration). Their lychee-ginger slushy drinkie is also out-of-this-world!

They lose a star for no longer offering the duck confit & fresh mango bun -- the only real five out of five star offerings on the scene at OTG. [chants] BRING IT BACK! BRING IT BACK! It's been almost a year --- what gives?
author: Kelly O.

description: I tried their baos during the Sacramento Mobile Food festival and the line was over 2 hours long (by far the longest food truck line @ the festival). The baos are so unique-I had the pork belly and the sesame chicken. One of them had pickled radishes on it and I must say, they were very delectable.
author: Brenda L.

description: Got myself a delish pork belly on steamed bun at SactoMoFo. It was amazing and well worth the massive line. Thankfully I live in the City so can go back and try the coca-cola braised pork!
author: Lindsey R.

description:
The whole concept of trucks is so unique to the bay area. It seems there are hundreds of these running around and I'm not sure why, but I always associate them with cheap, good food. 

The good part is correct, the cheap part isn't. 

On one of my days off, I was craving for a couple of these. Granted I'd never had them before, but god the pictures and descriptions were tantalizing enough. Plus given the innumerable delicious options in SF I've rarely found the need to repeat any visit to any restaurant, barring a couple (mainly due to proximity to my place).

So, I got on twitter, stalked Chairman Truck's account, and found out they were near the Market/Castro area for the night. As I walked there I was contemplating my choices (and hoping there weren't any lines I had to deal with) I love that they only have a few. Makes life a lot easier. Given that I didn't exactly understand the portions, I tried two things, one steamed and one baked. And my choices were the Baked Spicy Chicken Puree with toasted sesame puree, pickled carrots-cucumber and cilantro and steamed crispy miso cured tofu with garlic-tofu mayo and baby boy chum.

If you want bigger portions, baked is the way to go. If you want more bite-sized portions, then steamed is your go to choice. My favorite of the two was hands down the baked spicy chicken. It wasn't bite sized, perfectly done, the spices were balanced, and the hot sauce I had it with made it one of the best baos I've ever had. I wouldn't say this is incredibly authentic, but who cares when it's so damn good?! I hear the pork belly bao is amazing. Next time I get a craving that will be the one I'll be trying. 

The tofu was good, but not nearly as satisfying and it paled in comparison to the chicken. And lastly, the bao they use is great. Perfectly buttered. Get 1 (or 10) and be happy :)
author: Aditi R.

description:
Chairman Bao runs a tight ship for a mobile food truck.  I had visions of a long line, slow service and then learning that they ran out what I wanted just as I placed my order.  The line moved quickly, a printed receipt was given at the order window and your number is called from the pick up window when the food is ready (the wait for the food and shaved ice wasn't long - 5 minutes?)  I was still admiring Chairman Bao's red & black bun truck, wondering if they sold t-shirts and had stickers or pins, when my number was called.  They had three people inside to take orders and payment and assemble orders.  The truck had a few bottles of srichaca outside.  

The menu is short - 6 types of bun fillings that you can have on a baked bun ($5.75) or steamed bun ($2.75): pork belly, sesame chicken, lion's head meatball, Chinese sausage & egg, garlic tofu, duck confit.  They also have four types of shaved ice.  Meal deals are $9 + tax (one baked bun + shaved ice drink OR two steamed buns + shaved ice drink).

* Ginger lychee shaved ice: Firm slivers of lychee jelly sit atop a mound of finely shaved ice and chewy tapioca pearls at the bottom. I enjoyed the various textures, the tartness, and the subtle ginger taste.  I thought with all that ice, it would taste too watered down but that didn't happen.  
* Lion's head meatballs with fresh kimchee steamed bun: The steamed bun is folded over the filling, almost like a taco.  The bun was fluffy, smooth and nice.  The meatballs were tender and good but the napa cabbage kimchee wasn't crunchy at all (ick) and they added a salty brown sauce (hoisin?) that wasn't necessary or complementary.  I wouldn't get it again unless they improve that soggy kimchee and remove that sauce.
* Pork belly with pickled daikon steamed bun: Yummy, the same excellent steamed bun, a thick slab of luscious, moist five spice pork belly, thin, crunchy rounds of sweet yellow daikon and a bit of onion mixed in.  The daikon was fine but not special.

The buns are small but that pork belly bun is delicious and I'm also a fan of the shaved ice drinks.

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description: Delicious.  I had the red sesame chicken with bok choy, and my friend had the duck with mango salsa.  We ordered ours on the baked bun.  That sandwich more than filled me up, and it definitely did not skimp on the filling either.  They have a max order of 6 buns per person, but I was so full that there was no way I could have even eaten two, let alone six.  I tried them at Off the Grid at Fort Mason, and this was definitely the food truck with the longest line.
author: Vi N.

description:
Who could buy a .20 bun from chinatown throw some pork belly and daikon and charge 6 dollars and have people rave about it?  I guess if I didn't grow up eating peking duck with bun, I too would rave about this place.  Is it all about marketing?....................Absolutely!!!

Look.............it's not a bad concept.  I actually admire them for it because it takes balls to come up with an idea like this.  An Asian inspired dish and infuse it with an american twist...............Why not?!?  I am not one to hate on great concepts.  But, to have a non asian company invent a dish and then make it better than what the asians can come up with is absolutely incredible.  And.............we would stand and wait in line for it.

I wouldn't be surprise if those pink boxes of buns were picked up from "Good Luck Dim Sum" in  Chinatown.   I guess growing up in Chinatown and paying .50 for a Char siu bau got me thinking.........
author: jason g.

description: Overcome by curiosity and hunger, I found myself longing to try a bao sandwich. I ordered the spicy chicken on a baked bun; it was a scrumptious cross between a cha siu bao and a banh mi sandwich. The chicken had some heat, which was balanced perfectly by the sweet and tangy vegetables. I hope this truck comes back to my hometown soon because I'm already craving another one.
author: Queen K.

description: Finally got to taste the steamed buns today!!!  Thought this truck would be all hype, but DAMN!  The pork belly with the diakons is SOOOOOO GOOD!  The pork belly was cooked perfectly! By far my favorite steamed by out of two I ordered.  I also tried the duck confit with spicy mayo and that was good as well.  I cant wait to try the other steamed buns..  Also the paint job on the truck is sweet!
author: David K.

description: Leave all your experiences of having bao at the curb. It's not like the traditional bao that you may have had growing up. It's not better but it's different. There are vague similarities to the ones I ate when I was a kid. The pickled radish with pork belly but they do it with a twist and I have to say I am definitely a fan. The pork shoulder with the mustard at first was not too tasting but as much as I didn't like the bitterness...there was something that made me what to take another bite. It's not because I was taught to not waste food but something about the mustard and the pork intrigued my taste buds to take a second chew. The pork belly was definitely yummy and the pickled daikon was a nice complement to the fattiness to the belly. The steamed bun has that hint of sweetness that gave you that nice ending as you swallow. I can see why there is always a line for this truck.
author: Eve C.

description:
Chairman Bao offers delicious creations served on steamed or baked buns. They have always sold out when they were selling at China Basin. Everything I have tried was good (pulled pork, pork belly, red sesame chicken) but the proportion are on the small size so they're a little overpriced. My favorite was the red sesame chicken. 

The steamed buns are the size of street tacos and the baked buns are the size of a small sandwich.
author: Sunni F.

description:
The steamed buns are $3.25ish and the baked buns are $6.75ish.

Were they good? Yea...pretty good
Was it worth it to pay that much for it? No

I had a lot of good buns in my life that I feel a little cheated
author: Emmie N.

description: I've always lusted after chairman bao's buns - they've looked so amazing when others got them! Today I tried the "new" flavor, red sesame chicken. It was just ok - it was supposed to be spicy but wasn't. The little chunks of chicken were good but not very flavorful, although I liked the pickled carrots on top. Next time I would try a different bun.
author: Lisa K.

description: Favorites are the Coca Cola braised pork and chicken - one of each steamed is perfect!
author: Robert M.

description:
First off, as others have written, the Chairman is definitely not cheap. I think their stuff, especially the baked buns, is priced pretty high.

That said, I liked the two steamed buns I had (crispy tofu and pork belly), though I was surprised that they looked like tacos. I may be a white girl, but I know that steamed buns are usually self contained, not taco-shaped! I did love the pickled vegetables in the baos. They were a nice touch.

The standout was the ginger lemonade with lychee jelly drink --  to die for!!
author: Emily M.

description:
We ordered the "baked bao".  

What we got was sandwiches on egg buns.

Fans of this truck clearly have no idea what bao is, nor does the vendor.
author: Josh B.

description: Coca-Cola Braised Pork steam buns. The End.
author: Anna S.

description: Chairman Bao I had seen at a couple stops and frankly I had no desire to taste it since I get pork buns usually for like a buck or two. What could be the difference? Well finally I gave in to my curiosity and it was pretty darn good. It's more of a sandwich than the pork bun I'm used to a the fastfood joints.  I got the baked  pork belly bun for like $6.75 and a water. I must say that if the bun was $5 i would probably give it 4 stars. For the price and taste i think it's a solid 3 stars.
author: Rod M.

description:
What can I say that hasn't been said?

Me and my buddies went over to the Haight meetup of food trucks, and wow! It was a winter wonderland of foodie goodness.

Our first stop was Chairman Bao. I had the duck confit bun, and it was delicious! I wish I could have tried more buns, but there was much other food truck goodness to be had and I didn't want to fill myself up.

Chairman Bao, if this is the kind of food that a devotion to Communism brings, then consider this my official good-bye to Capitalism! (lol jk)
author: Rachel H.

description:
Same profane joy at Off The Grid 9/30/10, only this time it was a spicy Duck Confit w/ Mango.

This time, it was the $9 deal that included a Shave Ice Juice w/Tapioca. My flavor was Pineapple and Salted Caramel. It tasted familiar, but I couldn't put my finger on it. My wife identified the flavor profile immediately - PINEAPPLE UPSIDE-DOWN CAKE! In a refreshing drink form.

That's it. I'm attaching my own rickshaw to the back of this truck.
author: Andy R.

description:
Not the best truck out there, but I give it props since it's one of the first.  

My favorites are the mango duck and pork belly.  Everything else is just whatever.  I'm not sure if I'd wait 30 minutes in line for one bun!

They make the baked buns now, along with the steamed ones, for $6.50.  It's basically a burger size with lots of meat and daikons/carrots.  My friend ordered it.  Looked a bit too greasy for me, so I'll just stick with the steamed ones.  Steamed ones can be pretty greasy too.
author: Nancy S.

description:
I liked the pulled pork steam bun.

The pork belly was good, but the pulled pork is better

C.B. should list their prices WITH tax. You throw people off by adding tax and then they have to scrounge for change, slowing down the line.

They have to earn their living, and the "bao" is expensive. $2.95+tx for steamed.
author: qirk z.

description:
I was so excited when this truck came by for lunch, as I was starving and I love pork buns. 

The pork belly buns may as well be renamed pork fat buns. I understand that pork belly tends to be a fatty piece of meat, but it shouldn't be pure fat...and both of my buns contained pieces of all fat. ALL FAT!

Gross.
author: Daisy D.

description:
Although my two cents on what Chairman Bao has to offer will probably be lost in an ocean of similar feelings, the tenderness of the pork belly is compelling me to join the chorus.

Sure, Chairman Bao usually has the longest lines at any food truck gathering.

And sure, the buns are a lot more expensive than the buns you can purchase at your neighborhood Chinese bakery.

Once you bite into the sweetly glazed bun and melt-in-your mouth pork belly bun, you will think yourself crazy for ever having doubts.

The daikon brings a different dynamic to the swirl of flavors in your mouth, but you can easily imagine eating the bun without it.  

Immediately upon finishing, you will either consider rejoining the line or daydream about the next opportunity for you to sink your teeth into the pork belly bun and be carried away by its potential.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Finally got the chance to try this at MVBL Feast. I got the pork belly bao on a baked bun with pickled daikon. Delish! Perfect blend of richness with tangy crispyness as contrast. 

I like the spin on pulled pork BBQ, but asian style. Really good. I would recommend if you are a fan of Asian fusion. Very tasty!
author: Kristen S.

description:
Hyped? Hecks yeah.

Worth the hype?  My mouth is still singing.  Well, it's more like it's sort of... vibrating. I think this is a reaction to the amount of salt that I just ingested, but odd bodily reactions are worth the food at this truck.

With two Chairman's Buns (the pork belly and the duck) and a bag of won-tonny, seaweed sprinkled, sodium soaked chips, I was completely satisfied. Those buns may look small, but they're packing.

The Bao truck succeeds by serving up a fantastic combination of flavor and texture.  The food is just unique enough to raise your eyebrows, but without losing a certain comfort-food quality that makes you close your eyes and smack your smiling lips. 

And salt.  Mmmm, salt.
author: Mariah M.

description: Holy Cow! The pork belly bun and the the braised pork bun were both so good that I couldn't pick which was my favorite. I will def. track this truck down again the next time I am in San Fran.
author: Katie A.

description:
I've had Chairman Bao's several times at Off The Grid events. Tonight we saw them at the Gourmet Food Truck event in Pleasanton at the fairgrounds. We were so excited to hear they were going to be there, we arrived at the event early. They always have a huge line when we see them at Off the Grid when they are Ft. Mason so we wanted to be early.

Being early paid off because we were able to get our favorite - the duck confit buns. It was a little different than we've had before. It didn't have the green onions and the duck was pressed instead of shredded. I like it better the original way but this was still good - the other is just better. 

Previous times we also tried the pork belly buns and that is also very good.

To the guy that took our order - "FIGHT ON!"
author: C R.

description: the pork belly bun is SO amazing. this is the only thing i get here. i get the steamed version with the white colored bread. the baked bun is too much bread and it has a different texture than the steamed white bun. i've tried the other buns they have but pork belly is the best one they have. love the pickled daikon. yum yum yum! and i love the name, which is very very clever. and pandas are just awesome. i love you chairman bao!
author: Sylvia K.

description:
I have joined a new political party...one whose figurehead is an adorable panda by the name of CHAIRMAN BAO.

yes, I will carry your schedule around with me like the proverbial "little red book" though you and I know the schedule's contents are far, far more delicious.

i will follow you around the Bay as if you were a hippie jam band that had the same crazed and loyal fan at every show.

your garlic tofu baked bun was itself a manifesto-- at once a protest against inferior food establishments and a celebration of all that is good in bun-sized form. 

oh how I shall spread your political message-- EAT BAOS AND BE HAPPY-- to the far corners of the Earth. and by "Earth" I mean the Bay Area and by "corners" I mean at least my co-workers and friends.

LONG LIVE CHAIRMAN BAO!
author: Yaamini R.

description:
Chairman Bao's buns are soooo yummy.  I love that they offer baked versions that are twice as large so that I can just get one and be filled.  If it's your first time, don't skimp.  Get one of each and figure out which ones are your favorite.  My boyfriend loved the Pork Belly bun and my all time favorite is the Fried Tofu bun.   

For those expecting a typical Chinese bun...let me warn you - don't.  I mean, come on.  #1: You're buying baos from a TRUCK.  #2: The truck is called Chairman BAO.  Good, authentic, Chinese restaurants never have such clever names.
author: Jessica C.

description: Pretty good, not quite as good as the alpha pork belly bun at momofuku but decadently belly enough to make you not miss it. The baked variety are basically burger sized so that's a good thing to know going in.
author: Misha T.

description: One pork belly and one braised pork, so good. Only problem is trying not to order three or even four. They were also out of the duck which was a shame, but just another reason to return very soon...
author: Nicolas H.

description: Delicious!  Tried the pork belly, the tofu and the pork shoulder. All yummy.
author: Nora S.

description:
Usually one has to hunt down the food carts. Ever so rarely, when the stars are aligned, the food carts come to you. Such was the case today when I was minding my own business walking home, only to discover Chairman Bao parked right up in my business (i.e. a block from home). The hype had been loud, I knew I had to seize the moment and give it a shot.

Other yelpers have mentioned excess oil, which yours truly usually calls out, but perhaps it was the lingering hunger from a night dancing that my steamed chicken bun had no chance. Don't check for oil. Do not pass go. Just eat.

$3 later and after a few bites of heaven on wheels, consider me a fan.
author: Jason B.

description:
The first time I tried this truck I stood in line for about 40 mins and let me tell you, after that first bit of pork belly stream bun heaven, that 40 min wait was worth every minute! 

Chairman Bao has been deliciously consistent ever since I first visited over a year ago and only keeps getting better with them perfecting their flavors. And if mouth watering melting pork fat isn't your thing then there are still plenty of options for you! Garlic tofu, Braised Pork, Duck and Chicken to tantalize your taste buds. Though...... you could never go wrong with some succulent pig.
author: Sarah S.

description: Good food...but for the portion, you have got to be kidding me on the price!!! I can get the same thing in chinatown, be it greasier and less appealing, for half the price!!! But still yummy for once in a while!
author: Michelle I.

description: While the steamed bun is not such a good value for $3.75, the baked bun at $6.75 was totally worth it, spilling over with perfectly cooked pork belly and crunchy daikon on top.  The pork belly managed to be slightly crispy on the outside and not too fatty on the inside, just right...
author: Henry Y.

description: Chairman Bao Pork Belly bun is amazing.  The layers of pork and fat are balanced, juicy, fatty, and delicious.  I love that the edges are slightly crunchy.  It adds more texture to the bun.  I don't care for the daikon... it actually kind of overpowers the meat.  I've been craving for NYC Ippudo or Momofuku pork belly buns for some time.  This did the trick.  It's not as good as nyc pork buns but this is the best i can find in SF and i'm more than thrilled!
author: Jessica N.

description:
i was looking to hire a food truck for a birthday party and found out they are able to do smaller events. there is a minimum though and you just have to work it out with them. 

truck came promptly. staff were friendly. food came out quickly. all the bao were delicious. we had the Pork Belly, Chicken and Tofu.  

highly recommend them for catering
author: Annie c.

description:
The lines are always ridiculous, but I really believe that Chairman Bao lives up to its hype. If you see Chairman Bao at a food truck festival, always head there first because the line WILL multiply.

At $3.25 per steamed bao, the price definitely adds up quick, but the preparation and quality is good. The pork belly is tender, fatty, crunchy. I'm not a big fan of biting into a piece of fat, but this pork belly has a nice balance of textures. The miso vegetables & tofu bao is no token vegetarian option; it's delicious in its own right. Nice greens dressed in miso, with a lightly fried tofu steak. 

I had the baked bao once, but I wasn't much of a fan. I thought it would be liked the baked char siu bao; however, it was basically the filling between what very much resembled a hamburger bun.
author: Ada T.

description: Finally got to try the Chairman truck this week at the SF Food Truckstop for lunch!  Long line but definitely worth the wait!  I got the tofu one and the tofu was tasty and blended very well with the bok choy.  I would recommend getting two steamed buns for lunch if you want to be full or 1 baked bun.  They have a great assortment of meat flavors to choose from and I hope they can come up with other veggie flavors too.  Would definitely eat here again.
author: Bebe W.

description: Tried the steamed buns again at The Chairman and they were fantastic this time. Seems like they were much fresher and the meat was much more tender. Only 3 stars because of the inconsistency... If I have them a few more times and they're as good as these were I'll update the review to 4 stars.
author: Mike B.

description: Finally, a truck that makes me think the food truck phenomenon is truly phenomenal and not just hype.  I've tried a few here in the SOMA area.  Le Truc, 51st State come to mind.  Chairman Bao is the first one with food that knocked my socks off.  Worth the wait.  I had the garlic tofu steamed bun, followed by the braised pork baked.  Spectacular, both of them.
author: Robin W.

description:
THIS AINT YOUR AVERAGE CHINESE BUN! Chairman Bao Bun Truck knows how to create great Asian fusion foods. The steam buns are used like hot dog buns and about the size of a small hotdog bun. The baked buns are used like hamburger buns and about the size of an average burger bun. They also have misc drink such as water bottles, coke, and coconut water.

I paid 3.25 for garlic tofu steamed bun and 6.75 for pork belly baked bun. Totally worth it considering the amount they give.

The pork belly bun is really delicious. The pickled daikon slices they used with it perfectly compliments the taste of the pork belly with a nice sour taste.  The pork belly was soft and surprisingly less fatty than your average pork belly. The sauce they used was really sparse and sort of hidden by the source taste from the pickled daikon.

The tofu steamed buns are pretty great, but I couldn't taste the garlic. The dressing (maybe ranch?) they used really overpowered the tofu taste. The tofu texture was cripsy and soft. It's a nice Asian take on tofu dogs.
author: Steven B.

description:
The line for Chairman Bao was long and it may have been hyped, man, I thought it was pretty tasty.

The chicken was pretty good, but oh my, the pork belly. Yes, pork belly. You can never go wrong with pork belly.

Maybe it is hyped, but I think having a "taco" made with a Chinese bun was pretty cool in my eyes and it tasted good enough for me.
author: Ryan C.

description:
The fact that one of the better SF-based trucks is making regular stops in the South Bay is worth 5 stars alone. We got the 49ers, then we got the Chairman Bao truck.....who knows what's next?

(goes back to craving their perfectly flavored, crispy pork belly).
author: K S.

description: Tried this place for the first time yesterday.  Ordered the Baked Porn Bun, and I was impressed.  Was worried that the hype was going to make it disappointing, but it was well worth it.  Will def come here again to try the other things on its menu.
author: Joshua P.

description: I ordered $60 dollars worth of food for me and 2 friends.  We had the duck confit in steamed bun, pork belly in steamed bun, and Red Sesame Chicken with Scallion and Bok Choy on Baked Bun.  Skip the pork belly please.  Maybe my standards for pork belly is just too high but it really was a joke when I tasted it.  Just dry, flat and the texture rubbery.  WRONG! WRONG! WRONG!  However, the duck confit is well worth the money and wait.  I will go back for it.  The Red Sesame Chicken and Boy Choy on baked bun is really innovative and fun to eat.  It is spicy in a good way.  I loved it!  Two reasons why I will not go back again:  Lady who gave me the food had major attitude and when I took the boxes of food back to the car, I found out they did not give me my complete order.  No biggie but in this foodie mecca, thankfully I have plenty of restaurants and food trucks to spend my money.
author: X L.

description: Street Food AT IT'S BEST!! Got the Spicy Chicken steamed and WOW was that a party in my mouth! So much flavor and just the write amount of spices. Not too much, not too little. It's a perfect size for a snack if you're just craving something small for the moment. Affordable price, nice people, great atmosphere in Willow's Glen's "Movable Fest". Will definitely come back where ever they may be and try the same thing, only baked for something different! Track 'em down if I have to ;-)
author: Bria S.

description:
Chairman Bao in the East Bay! They stop in Emeryville at Hollis and 53rd almost every Monday during lunch (11:30-1:30ish).

My favorite is the pork belly with pickled daikon baked bun. In the past I've also had the duck with mangoes and spicy sauce which was really yummy, too. I also recently tried the braised pork bun but it was a little on the dry side and needed some sort of sauce.  

Only problem is that the buns are pricey! $6.75 for a baked bun is too much for the portion. Still a nice treat to have one in awhile.

Follow them on twitter/facebook to find out where the truck is =)
author: Annaliese D.

description: came across this food truck when walking around the soma street food park, what originally caught my eye was the cute girl that was taking the orders. Then i decided to walk by and take a look at what they have on there menu, let me tell you the spicy chicken is AMAZING!!!!!!! The bun was also perfect that they throw on some pickled carrots and pickles on the sandwich. I love food trucks and i have to say this place def jumped up into one of my favorites. I will defiantly be eating at this place again and hopefully soon!
author: Dmitriy G.

description:
I bow to the bao.

After many months of coveting I finally tried their creative take on steamed buns. Let's just say I'm an addict now and this poses a problem for my wallet. The Chairman has me under his spell with the red sesame chicken with cukes, carrots, and some delish sauce I can't remember.

Between that bun and the spicy mexi chocolate cupcake from Cupkates it was an epic lunch.

Oh god I need another already.
author: Liz K.

description:
I love the Chairman Truck!

The tender pork belly with pickled daikon with baked bun is so delicious.

I suggest going to one of the Off the Grid events to try this truck out. Go early so you can avoid the long lines!
author: Jenny T.

description:
I commend them for the great marketing. Awesome name for a food truck and cool graphics... Made me think, "Gee, why didn't I think of that!" The food on the other hand, is nothing to cry about.

Discovered this truck at Off the Grid, and of course lined up because there was a huge line. Wherever there's a line, it HAS to be good right? NOPE! Honestly, just listen to other Asians on this review. If you ever in your life had real baos, this is not good bao! And trust me, Chairman Mao would be sooo disappointed in Chairman Bao.

I had the pork belly and it was like half fat dripping with fat. For about $4 a bun, I just felt a little ripped off. You can honestly go to Chinatown and get ONE delicious bao for 50cents. I guess that's not the point of a food truck. For something to hype up, it's gotta be exclusive or rare. Like Facebook once was...

By all means, I do wish this truck much success. I hear it's hard as hell to make a life off a food truck. So if you're curious, please support them and give it a try--I could just be a varying opinion. My only advice is just don't expect too much.
author: Anita W.

description:
I don't know what I was thinking, not yelping this place before I walked uphill (in heels!) to go try some of these buns.  I guess when I was thinking buns I was thinking those big buns you get when you go to Dim Sum (Cha Siu Bao? Please correct me if I spelled that wrong or if I'm just plain wrong).  So when I departed I only brought enough cash for one thinking that the portion would surely suffice.  Dead wrong.

Oh no, my friends.  These are not THOSE buns.  These are little fold-y buns.  Delicious, but not what I was expecting.  I rolled up to the truck when it was parked at Sabin Alley one day and was delighted to find only a few people in line.  That huge hill must be a deterrent to the lazy (usually me, but my addiction to trying new street carts was motivation enough).  I ordered a pork belly bun from the brightly colored truck (sooo cool, but the ordering and pick up windows are kind of high, not good for the short statured).  And it was GOOD.  If you don't like pork belly it might not be your thing.  Next time I'm getting two! My coworkers each got a different kind.  One got tofu, one got the chicken version and everyone was super satisfied with their meals and couldn't stop thanking me for telling them about this super secret truck (patting myself on the back while typing is hard!)

You can also get a large version of the bun that I definitely want to try, but that whole walk uphill...
author: Mary O.

description:
This food truck always has the longest queue and for good reasons. Pork Belly bun! You can't really go wrong with pork belly but the sourness of pickled daikon brings out the fat flavor even more. 

Both pulled pork and red sesame chicken are good but not as good as I'd skip them and get the pork belly instead. The red sesame chicken has good medium kick of spiciness to it so beware.

Crispy skin of the tofu is really thin but still good nonetheless. I'd prefer this over pulled pork and chicken.

Steamed (taco size) or Baked (burger size)? If you don't care either way, baked bun definitely give you more filling for the buck.

If it's your first time, you'd probably get 1 steamed bun of each fillings. Then come back with the same conclusion as mine just like my friends did.
author: Agustinus T.

description: The Chairman is my favorite food truck in the Bay Area, and I've tried a bunch of 'em. Their product is unique (to my knowledge of local food trucks), they basically do one thing - buns (or 2 if you count steamed vs baked) - in a few variations, and they do it really well. I'm not a vegetarian but some of my best friends are (seriously) so I appreciate that there is a tasty tofu option (although I'm not gonna lie - the pork & chicken are better, in my opinion). Also, their use of compostable packaging is highly appreciated by this environmentally concerned citizen. Thanks for regularly appearing in the South Bay, Chairman!
author: Nicole B.

description:
The food: 
1. Duck steamed bun: the duck was extremely dry and the sauce did not mesh well with the mango or duck.  
2. Pork steamed bun: the fatty pork was delicious.  The pickled daikon was slightly under flavored.
3. Strawberry shaved ice with coconut: it was refreshing and not overly sweet.  
The service: 
People working the truck were extremely friendly and service was quick considering the line.  

Cons: 
$9 for 2 taco sized buns and a drink is pretty pricey for "truck food".  The "LA fad" of serving ethnic cuisine out of trucks loses its appeal when the food is priced like a sitdown restaurant.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Let me get this out the way right now:  it's a "roach coach" no matter how you decorate it, where it's located, and/or whatever fancy name you wanna call it.

That being said-the people of Bishop Ranch business park in San Ramon decided to have a "Gourmet Truck" (rolling my eyes at that) lunch for the tenants back in October. About 5 trucks participated-this truck being one of them.  I've never heard of them until this event, and since I like manapua buns (that's what they call the steamed pork buns in Hawaii) I decided to try theirs.

Not what I expected.

I ordered the sesame chicken, since I wasn't too crazy about the other menu items. I expected the usual meat stuffed in the bun; instead, the bun was split in the middle and the meat placed in it like a small taco. I ordered 3; they were spicy as hell but pretty good. 

I don't work in the City to visit the truck on the regular, so I hope Bishop Ranch decides to do the event again and invite them back. It's rare to find something for lunch in San Ramon that won't leave you broke.
author: Pamela J.

description:
Of course they are good! There isnt really anything else out there like Chairman Bao...really enjoyed my buns steamed...if you know what I mean...and they are much better in pairs....next time I will try it baked....

Also major kudos for joining up with truckstopsf.com
author: Sarah M.

description: The spicy chix sandwich comes on a baked or steamed bun. I got the baked and it was incredible.  Warm, yet crusty, the bread melted in your mouth and totally made the experience a delight.  Long line but worth it (I went twice!!)
author: Tameka S.

description:
Ummm so I just got back from volunteering and living a year in China. And what they're making in the Chairman Bao Bun Truck isn't what I'd find over there but nonetheless it's hella good!

Bao tza in a taco form that's damn creative!
author: Josie C.

description: I went to this at off the grid. SO GOOD!! I got the pork belly steamed bun and the braised pork. The pork belly steam bun was AMAZING. So much flavor and just the right amount of crunch on the pork!!! The sauce was yummy :) The braised pork was okay but next time, I think i'd rather have two pork belly buns. yum yum yum A+ from me!
author: Jenni I.

description: They came to Bishop Ranch today and what a great idea.  It got my co-workers and I out of the office and I was excited to try them.  The line was really long and pretty slow but the people working inside were nice.  I ordered the meal deal with two steamed buns (chicken and duck) and a shaved ice.  The shaved ice wasn't my fav but both steamed buns were delicious.  The duck had mango on it and the chicken sesame had onions, bok choy and was somewhat spicy.  Next time I will try one of the pork options since my co-workers seemed to enjoy those.
author: Amanda K.

description:
Quick Tip: If you know Chairman Bao is going to be at a certain location get there early because the lines get ridiculously long.

I have a food truck fetish and I had been itching to try Chairman Bao since I got to the bay area. 
I finally got my chance when I went to the local food truck gathering in Palo Alto on Mondays. I showed up at around 4:30ish and of all the trucks present Bao had by far the longest line. As it got later the line got longer and longer so I was glad to get there early. 

I only got one bun there, the pork belly on steamed bun and it was fantastic. The bun was soft and sweet, the pork belly was fatty and had a nice salty flavor. The pickle daikon and vegetable provided a nice refreshing sour crunch to go with the soft chewy texture of the bun and meat. 
Throw in some siracha and you have an item that combines 4 distinct flavors into one delicious snack.

The main reason that I can't give Chairman Bao a 5/5 is because of the price. At 3.75 for a steamed bun and 6+ for a baked bun, you just don't get much food for how much you pay. The buns are quite small and to get a full meal you would have to buy 3+. 

However, the food is good enough to warrent buying a bun just because it tastes so good. I would recommend getting a bun and another item from another food truck to augment your meal.
author: Kevin S.

description:
When I was in college, I went to a Mos Def concert on campus. Doors opened around 6 and, after the opening acts, it was finally time for Mos. Now, like a typical star, he didn't come out right when it was his turn to perform. Instead, he decided to take his sweet ass time and make the crowd wait... and wait... and wait... Things got so bad that the MCs had to resort to holding an impromptu freestyle rapping competition a la 8 Mile between guys who were convinced they could flow, but were in fact really terrible. But that's another story. 

Anyway, as the crowd got increasingly restless and began to throw things at the MCs on stage and started chanting "refund!" Mos finally came out and performed. The crowd went crazy and by the end of the show, all was forgiven and everyone left satisfied.

Why do I tell you this story? Because that was basically my experience with Chairman Bao. Being one of the more well known food trucks in the Bay Area, Bao's reputation precedes itself. I first encountered Bao at SJ Eats aka "Let's Try and See How Many People We Can Cram Into One Condensed Area Before They Want To Kill Themselves." While all the other trucks had been open for a good 30 minutes, Bao was still not open, but a sizable line had formed. I decided to skip out on Bao that day, but we would meet again the next week at Off the Grid. 

Trucks began opening by 5pm, but Bao was again taking its time. A line again started to form in great anticipation and this time my gf and I got in it because when you see a line start to form, you naturally just get in it because you don't want to miss out, right? Anyway, after all the other trucks opened for business, an Off the Grid staff member knocked on the Bao door and told them to get moving and open up. They obliged.... kind of. They opened their windows, but still weren't actually taking orders yet. We could see the workers inside prepping food... and you knew they could see the line that was waiting on them as well. 

Finally, probably a good 20 minutes after they had been told to open up, they started taking orders. And, like my Mos Def experience, after you eat their buns, you sort of forget that they made you sit there and wait and wait and wait. After trying five or six different places that day, it was clear that Bao has something unique. A little pricey? Perhaps. But you really can't get their style of bun anywhere else. 

Anyway, let's recap. Chairman Bao: kind of a diva, but worth the price of admission.
author: Eddie L.

description: The Chairman is ridiculously good. They serve bao in either a steamed bun or baked bun. I love the steamed bun, and usually get myself an assortment of three for a meal, or just one for a snack. My favorites are probably the cola-braised pork and miso-cured tofu. They are so flavorful and yummy! I love the sauces they use. Only problem is if you don't eat it right away the steamed bun kinda falls apart so grabbing a fork is a good idea. I usually catch these guys at Off the Grid and lines can be long, but its worth it!! Give Chairman a try next time you see them, you won't regret it!
author: Erica M.

description:
I'm surprised it's taken me so long to review Chairman Bao.  I've been to this truck at least 3 times and each time it's been consistently good.  Because I don't eat meat, I get the steamed tofu buns and they're always delicious.  Crispy tofu with fresh mustard greens and a garlic sauce... yummy! 

I think the steamed buns are kind of pricey for what you get, as I could easily eat like 3 or 4 of them, but I recently tried a baked tofu bun and I found it to be cost effective because it totally filled me up.  The wonton chips are good, at first, but they're really salty.  I can't vouch for the pork belly, but everyone I know who's tried it basically says it's a mind blowing experience.
author: Laura C.

description:
Disclaimer:  I hate hipsters and the inconvenience of food trucks.  (Loved the trucks when I was spending time in SOMA and would happen across them, but trekking around and then finding out that they are out of what you want is very frustrating.  Nob Hill is great for many things, not so much food trucks.)

With that being said, I would scale a mountain for Chairman Bao.

Their steamed buns are my favorite--especially the pork ones and the duck.  (They didn't have the duck the last time I went though.  Sad.  Hope that's not a thing.)  I'd be happy with any they offer--even chicken and I am not a chicken kind of girl.

Baked buns are a satisfying meal for like $6!  Definitely the budget-friendly option, but I usually go for the seamed ones because I like the variety.

Now please just find a spot to park on Polk or California and I will become your best customer.
author: Bailey D.

description:
Saw them at Off the Grid: San Mateo.  Line actually wasn't too bad.

Shared the tofu, chicken and braised pork buns.  (Not a huge pork belly fan in general.)  Actually liked all of them, with the tofu one being my favorite.  Found the chicken one a bit difficult to eat.  (It was also spicy, if you like that.)

But in general, pretty pricey for what you get.  And may not be worth it if you have to endure an insane line.
author: Ken L.

description:
I've been waiting for this moment for a really long time! When I can finally try Chairman Bao. I've been trying to track it down for a while with no luck. I finally figured out that it comes every other week to Civic Center.
 
I had the chicken and the pork belly. Wow, the pork belly was sooo good!! It was crispy pork paired with yellow daikon radish. I'm not such a huge fan of daikon that is SO yellow.. seems quite unnatural. But it was crunchy and paired well with the fatty pork belly. 

The sesame chicken was okay... meat was tender, tasty, and all that, but nothing to write home about.

Steamed buns are 3.25 or 3.75, depending on the filling. Kinda pricey, but not too bad for a food truck, and 2 are enough to fill you up for a meal. I want to try a baked bun next!
author: Cathy S.

description:
steamed tofu bun = my idea of heaven. i want them to cater my wedding reception. 

i'm not even engaged, that's how far ahead i am thinking. and how much i love the chairman.
author: Shannon C.

description: Love their buns! The lines for this food truck are always long but it's definitely worth the wait!
author: Joe Y.

description:
Off the Grid visits Larkspur on Sundays and since I'm walking distance from the trucks I always check out what's on the menu. I had never tried The Chairman before so figured I'd explore and give it a shot.

The pork belly with daikon spicy chicken with pickled carrots was obscenely delicious. I got some more food at another truck but wish I had just gotten seconds.
author: William S.

description:
The steamed buns are all I have ever had, and they are sooo delish. The pork belly with pickled daikon radish and the red sesame chicken are standby's and I can see why. So solidly tasty and not the least bit greasy... which most people may think of the pork belly. 

Not so. oh soo yummy in my tummy. I've been known to return a few times just to get another when the lines are short enough at OTG Upper Haight. yes I am that glutton :-\

Only minor gripe is that they are a cash only establishment - no cards of any kind are accepted. Which can be a bummer sometimes when I've not had the chance to stop by the ATM before going over to see them.
author: Kira G.

description:
Pretty underwhelming - as someone who counts Bao as their favorite food, this promising truck definitely left a lot to be desired. 

That being said, I wasn't expecting fusion Chinese food - if that's what you like, definitely give it a shot.
author: Alex L.

description:
Well you certainly rule my heart.  I found you at OTG an was aware of the propaganda  regarding your deliciousness.  You were the only one that had a line although not too bad due to the weather.  Still, I remember thinking you better be good or I may lead the revolt.  No need (stand back liberation army)  you delivered and I'm officially part of the movement!  

The offering was the braised pork (whaaa no pork belly) steamed or baked so I opted for one each.   The steamed is the winner folks.  Pork was tender and the pickled daikon an mustard seeds on that soft warm bun...Amazing!  This is the food truck movement I'm talking about.  I actually wanted to go back in line an order a box (or two) it was that good.   Damn you Chairman and your commie tactics.  You actually going to turn me into a twit (er - the pork belly and duck must be conquered okay) and have me running all over town for you.  Yes, you are the Peoples Republic of Street Food and I too bao down!
author: Stephanie E.

description:
OMG SO GOOD. We waited in line for 45 minutes at OtG Fort Mason to try these guys, then waited longer to pick up our order. Sure tasted like 45 minutes!! Very worth the wait, as justified by the giant masses of people lining up for these guys.

They have a maximum order of 6 buns and their stuff ran out fast during OtG. Their Chairman chips are really good... fried wonton chips seasoned with something... Japanese like. The chip bags have little strips of nori tossed inside, which adds an extra kick to the salty deliciousness. They may be too salty for some people, but I LOVE SALT. They were SO GOOD.

The buns are greasy and hard to eat without napkins, but they are oh so good... Love the creativity that is put into these things. So good. SO GOOD!!
author: Anna V.

description: The buns are on the pricey side but they're pretty damn tasty. Had the pork belly and duck confit ones. I've never seen the guy in NYC but I've definitely had the ones David Chang is famous for and I think these give those a run for their money. Looking forward to trying the baked one to see if they warrant the higher price tag
author: Kim N.

description:
3.75 steamed= small tasting size
6.75 baked     = sandwich size

okay so let's talk
pork belly baked bun sandwich size.
omgoodness....okay so here it is play by play.
first off, they use the baked chinese classic sweet bun...cut in half....grilled on each side for sweetness and a light crisp.

then it is loaded with sweet pickled daikon with chives (the pickle is amazing..is it mustard seed? i dunno but the taste is so flavorful)
