and then stacked thick pieces of pork belly in a light char-su sauce (chinese bbq pork flavor) they really do not skimp with the meat!!!

this is a really different treat. very cool. i dig it.

also for vegetable-tarians there is a garlic tofu option that sounded amazing!!!
author: Tiger Lily ..

description: I love this truck!  I always get the steamed red sesame chicken bun.  The chicken is packed with flavor and I love the carrot pickle thing they put on top of it.  I know they are famous for the pork belly bun but I haven't gotten the chance to try that one yet.  Maybe next time I will.  I could definitely eat two but I try to limit myself to one so that I can try foods from other trucks too.  You got to try it at least once to see if it lives up to all the hype, I obviously think it does.
author: Love U.

description:
HMPH drove away and didn't see me walking toward the truck! jerks lol that was my first experience. 

Today they just happened to be where I was shopping with my dad.  We decided to give it a try. 

Ordered (from what they had left) all baked buns:
-Pork belly
-pulled pork
-duck with mango
-Pinapple Salted Caramel

I wanted to try the steamed buns and the lion's head.  My dad was pretty much saying all the good about them. Like how they're really good at fusing the two cultures together.  American (hamburger) and Asian (lion's head meat ball, and pork belly) foods together. It's like adapting and being able to create something that maybe the hipsters would like to eat. 

I still think food truck food should not be at such a high price. $9 for buns and a drink? I know this is "gourmet" or whatever but come on. There are way better Chinese buns out there. AND TO CHARGE ME TAX?! on your fancy POS system!!! geezz 

Anyway that's not all that made my rating for here go down. The food was edible, nothing to write home about. I like my pork belly either juicy or fried crispy. It was neither.. the daikon on it was nice. 

The Duck had a stem of some plant in it.. and a small bone.. -_- stem must have dropped into the truck while they were prepping or something. 

I think the one i liked most was probably the pulled pork for the dressing on the salad/coleslaw. I felt like the buns were nothing special (maybe because i grew up on fresh baked bbq pork buns)..so the steamed one would have been more interesting with these ingredients. 

Pineapple Salted Caramel. It was quite tart! I couldn't pick up the salted caramel part. But i did pick up on the ginger. 

Overall it's a nice try, colorful truck, interesting presentation of ingredients and drinks. But i won't go out of my way to try it or buy it.
author: Connie M.

description:
I tried the baked pork bun with mustard seed. I initially ordered it and had to run to work as I was late. I got to work a little so I had to refrigerate the bun and save it for later. Lunch time came around and I didn't really want to stick it in the microwave because that would make the bread soft and limp so I decided to do the toaster oven. 10 minutes later I pulled out this bun that looked like when I received it from the truck. I also had the chips which were fried wontons mixed with dried sea weed. They were so good.

The pork bun had the perfect combination of sweet and savoury. The price was worth it. I will definitely look for the truck in the future.
author: ryan n.

description:
The hype is well worth it to the San Francisco foodies. One tip that I must reinforce is to get the baked buns. Although not your traditional "bao" but more "sandwich or hamburger" (laughter), Chairman Bao has effectively used well placed ingredients evolving the traditional bbq pork and chicken buns into pork belly or duck confit for example. 

Pork Belly - Fatty and the way pig should be eaten when not in crispy bacon form. The pickled daikon gave a nice contrast with a nice crunch.

Duck Confit - Succulent pieces paired with papaya and mint that paired perfectly. 

Red Sesame Chicken - Spicy flavored chicken topped with pickled carrot/cucumber, that didn't quite hit home with me right away.

All in all, this is one of my favorite trucks in the city and I normally don't mind the wait during events like Off the Grid. However, if you have the opportunity to locate this truck at an off-peak lunch hour, it's heaven to have some quality time with this truck =)
author: Casey L.

description:
Easily one of my favorite food trucks!

Ok, lets admit it, the line here is always insanely long.  The first time I had The Chairman's buns I waited about an hour and it was good, but I wasn't too sure it was worth the insane line.

The next few times I've lucked out and had a very short and acceptable wait and let me tell you, the pork belly and daikon bun is amazing.  The warm belly, the cool daikon make for a great marriage in this super tasty bun.  I never pass up the chance to grab one if I'm hitting up an OTG or they are miraculously close to me one work day at lunch.  I'm not sure why the baked buns are so much more expensive than the steamed (can anyone answer that?).  Maybe there is some legitimate reason, but it seems insane for it to be twice the price.  Luckily I like the steamed, but I still feel this is enough to knock off a star.  But make no mistake, the buns are awesome!
author: Jen K.

description:
This is definitely one of my favorite trucks at any OTG event! What I look for in a perfect food truck is 1. good price and value, 2. really tasty food, and 3. freshly prepared with great ingredients (preferably local and organic). In that order. Chairman Bao satisfied all of my criteria AND includes friendly service. Not so much quick service all the time, though, which would only improve my review. 

I love the tofu bun--either baked or steamed (although I slightly prefer it on a steamed bun), but my heart mostly belongs to the baked duck bun with the mango salsa, which I haven't seen in a while but I'm hoping will return soon. The best part is that I can get a baked bun for about $6 and it totally fills me up. Now that's what I'm talkn' about, Willis!
author: Amy B.

description:
3.5 

I want to round up, but for 1 - it's sort of messy, 2 - it's kind of pricey 3 - it's from a food truck, so you never know where they will be.  not dinging a star for number 3 just saying...

Got the baked one with Duck and mango.  Pretty tastey!  Only bummer was that it falls apart, but that's a good problem since that means they gave a lot of meat.  Might have been a tad bit too much on the spicey side for me, but I really like the concept.  Could afford to come down a dollar or two.  (yeah, I'm semi stingy sometimes, but c'mon!  honestly in Chinatown it'd probably be cheaper)
author: Brian Y.

description:
Oh those steamed pork buns!

First of all, I know they smell great, and you've been standing in that long line, but TWO is all you really need.

Secondly, the chicken bun is good, but do yourself a favor, if you get a chicken and a pork belly, EAT THE CHICKEN FIRST.   The pork buns are so much better that you owe it to your mouth.

Oh, and I saw that some people complain about the line, which has been about 15-deep when I get to them, What do you expect?  They're not serving pre-made sandwiches, they're cooking delicious food.  Be patient, it's worth the wait!
author: Daniel S.

description:
I love these little steamed morsels of goodness.   The tofu one was just okay, but the chicken and pork were amaze-balls.  I went back twice.
And they take credit cards so brace yourself or you might max out your limit.
author: Bret S.

description: I was fortunate enough to have Chairman Bao come to my school campus so I didn't have to wait in an excruciating line for my bao. I believe I ordered the pork belly and it was crazy delicious. However, $4 is extremely expensive for a bun in my opinion. I'm Asian so I know that most buns usually cost about $1. If it were $3 instead of $4, it'd still be on the expensive side but at least I could justify the cost with the taste. But $4 is too much. I tried it once and it was delicious, but I wouldn't purchase again for the price :(
author: Lily Z.

description:
I don't just love the clever play on its name: Chairman Bao, the food justifies its ridiculous wrapping and looping line too.  Baked buns each for $6 may look small, but pretty sure caloric-wise one is enough for your lunch.  I was fortunate enough to be able to try 4 different kinds thanks to having 3 lunch companions.  

Pork belly with daikon is so fatty and so wrong but the pickled tangy daikon makes you forget you are swallowing fat one mouthful after another.

Braised pork has the perfect balance of flavors---most of us thought that was our favorite.

Chicken sounded super boring but was actually really good.  Also full of strong but well-balanced flavors. 

Tofu is probably the most boring of them all, but it was kinda nice to have something a little more subtle and mild after the other strong-flavored buns. 

The buns themselves are quite spectacular: doughy but not soggy and can withstand the sauce from the fillings.  

My only recommendation is to arrive early and bring your own knife if you intend to share.  Trying to tear those bad boys apart using bare hands is virtually impossible.
author: Candice B.

description:
I thought I had written a review for Chairman Bao a while ago, but I guess not. Since I've been here before, I don't typically wait in line for them if it's too long. After a hiatus from CB, I had their buns again this past weekend. I'm not sure if their menus rotate depending on the events/location, but their menu was narrowed down to a few steamed buns and no specialty drinks. I was a bit disappointed at the selection. 

In the past I always get the Spiced Duck Confit with Mango Salad. The bun had a nice balance between the cool sweet mango slices and some spice from the duck confit. Another favorite was the Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon. A nice big chunk of seared pork belly with tangy pickled daikon, such a great combo. These are my top two buns. Of course you have to wash it down with a Pineapple Salted Caramel Shaved Ice.
author: Adelina W.

description:
I don't know why I was resisting it for so long. Maybe I was turned off the snaking lines every single week.

Finally tried it and it's sooo good. The pork belly was good and I liked both the steam and the baked bun. And I liked the pickled veggies they put it in even if it smells to high heaven. Never had a bun like this before.

Come back: Yes. Praying no one sees this review and stay outta line! ; )
author: Van C.

description: The seared pork belly bun was incredible, I must try the steamed buns next time, they also looked really good.
author: Randy P.

description:
Dude I could eat like 10 of these...

And yes, I am such a nerd! I saw their FB posting 8 minutes after posting, then found myself leaving work early and first in line...waiting like a hungry monster to get my hands on these much hyped BAOS. 

And I must say...This sh*t is delicious. 

These little scrumptious asian tacos (as one of the bao guys described) were freakin' tasty. When I bit in to the pork belly w/ daikon steamed bao, I completely forgot about my  6:30pm workout class that I had to get to and I was going to let this melt in my mouth and straight in to my muffin top. LOL I also got the duck confit w/ mango salad steamed bao, but I recommend you skip that and buy 5 more of the pork belly. Mmmmm...

Chairman Bao please come my way again soon! :)
author: Lisa T.

description:
My 1st taste of this Yummy goodness was lunch at 5th/Minna. I waited in line for about 15min and it was sooo worth it. I got the Steamed Pork Belly and I've been hooked since!! Everything blends together and just melts in your mouth!! 
1 is good if you just want to try it out ... but you'll want another!!
author: Stephanie P.

description: Hit up the Chairman Truck at Truck Stop on First & Mission for lunch yesterday with co-workers.  Our group has the 7x7 100 Things to Eat for 2012 list up, and naturally, we went for the pork bell bao from the Chairman Truck.  We had to get there at 11:30am to beat the line, and really glad that we did.  We all tried the pork belly bao and one spicy chicken bao.  Both of these were absolutely DELICIOUS.  In my opinion, the pork belly was hands down the best out of the two.  Not only was the pork cooked perfectly, there was a little bit of crisp on it that made it that much better.  Also adding to the bao was the pickled radish.  I'm usually not a big fan of takuan, but having it compliment the pork belly was absolutely delicious!  The spicy chicken was also good, but was definitely second fiddle to the pork belly.  And to be honest, the vegetables in this definitely made the bao.  The spicy chicken was just spicy enough and the carrots in this were great.  Overall, I don't want to get in the habit of eating these all the time, but they were certainly a delectable treat for lunch!
author: Lisa I.

description: 5 star rating is for the food. I am in love with their pork belly and pickled daikon on their steamed buns.  Sooo delicious and I can eat plenty more of that pickled daikon any day.  I am, however, not in love with their prices.  To satisfy my hungry stomach I ordered 3 of them, at $3.75 a pop.  I can't complain because it's so good and if I really want something I just get it.  This is just coming from someone who is pretty tired of the lunch choices around my work area and I just don't eat pricey like that everyday, it would be absolutely absurd.
author: Emy B.

description:
The lines wrap around Fort Mason for this take on the chinese "bao".  Chairman Bao boasts a variety of gourmet buns from duck confit to pork belly.  They serve it on your choice of the steamed buns or baked buns.

I think the best (in my opinion) is the pork belly with pickled daikon radishes on a baked bun.  The crisp yet tender cut of pork belly has a slightly salty flavor, mixed with the crispness and sourness of the pickled daikon, and the soft and slightly sweetness of the baked bun marries all the flavors well.
author: JJAMZ C.

description:
Love their duck bao!!  Though it totally just reminds me of the peking duck which I've eaten my fair share in my lifetime.  Now for $6??  ummm...I don't think i am a stoopid chinamen.

Just saying that a single peking duck with a bun isn't worth $6.00.  I think you can get the entire peking duck with about 12 buns in a chinese restaurant for about $30??  So yeh...you do the math.  Though this truck is thee only place I know where I can buy a single peking duck bun and it's quite tasty!  So 3 stars for you and I will just maybe splurge $6 next time I am drunk and your truck is in front of that bar....unless Kung Fu Taco truck is parked next to you...
author: Patrick C.

description: PORK BELLY BUNS. THAT IS ALL YOU NEED TO KNOW. It's always tempting to get this every time I see it at OTG. I fail most of the time and get it anyway. That's how good it is! Luckily they accept card! :)
author: Emmanuel C.

description:
Strange how the name is the chairman truck instead of Chairman Bao but this food truck is amazing! I have heard a lot about this truck at off the grid and saw the ridiculous line with a velvet rope. But after trying the food, I can see why people wait. 

Food: 
Pork Belly- Amazing! The pork belly is tender but not too fat and it works very well with the daikon that comes with it.
Braised pork- Very good 

The steamed bun is the size of a taco and the baked is the size of a BBQ pork bun. 

Highly recommended but I would suggest to try this truck at truck stop early because the line is more reasonable!
author: Elliot T.

description:
Pork belly bun=get in my belly NOW!

So delicious I can't even formulate a better description.
author: M S.

description: I love the Chairman!  I always get the steamed bun with Coca Cola braised pork and the steamed bun with pork belly.  The meat is juicy and perfectly spiced, the sauce is zesty, and I love the pickled radish and cabbage.  The steamed buns are soft and sweet.  The Chairman gets you your food a lot faster than many food trucks at MVBL.  The only reason I give this place 4 stars instead of 5 is that I would love a couple more flavors.
author: Abby F.

description:
SIX STARS!  TWENTY STARS!

Oh. My. GOSH.  I am still reveling in the steamed pork belly bun with pickled daikon.  

I arrived at Off the Grid @Fort Mason at around 5:30.  As I scanned the trucks, I noticed a large crowd in a Disneylandesque rope line.  Sure enough, the red truck was behind it.  Without even waiting for my friend to arrive, I hopped in the line, craning my neck to see what they were offering.  After about 40 minutes in line (and a couple tacos from The Taco Guys - YUM!), I sat down to sample the deliciousness.  

I literally started laughing when I took my first bite of the pork belly.  Everything about it is perfection.  The combination of textures and the balance of savory and sweet are incredible.  I also ordered the braised pork with cabbage and mustard seeds.  Very good but paled in comparison to the belly.  I was hoping to try the duck with mango.  Here's hoping they're serving it on Monday when I stalk them in Emeryville.
author: Shauna F.

description: This was my last stop at Eat Real Fest. I was quite full at that point, but I had wanted to try The Chairman for awhile so I thought 'might as well since I'm here.' The line was pretty long but I didn't really mind waiting as it gave me time to digest and make more room in my gluttonous stomach. I ordered the Pork Belly Bao. Meat was tender and plentiful, and the pickled daikon gave it some good contrast. $4/bao that day, a bit pricey considering the size of these, but that was expected at a food truck festival.
author: Kevin N.

description: I had the trifecta of pork belly with pickled daikon, the spicy chicken, and the braised pork. I opted to have all three bao buns steamed. The buns were perfectly pillowy and fluffy. The pork belly had a nice caramelized glaze and crispness, while the meat was succulent. Actually, this was the best pork belly I have ever had. This is how pork belly should be! The pickled daikon added a nice tangy counterpoint to the fattiness of the pork. The braised/pulled pork was also quite good. It reminded me a lot of the pulled pork Carolina style barbecue I grew up with, oddly enough. It is topped with a slaw and mustard seeds. The chicken was my least favorite of the three, but still enjoyable. Overall, I was really impressed and will be back again next time I'm in town.
author: Eugene C.

description: I had seen so many reviews & a few shows mentioning the Chairman as one of the best food trucks in America, so when I saw it at the Treasure Island Flea Market I had to try it....& OMG! The steamed Pork-Belly Bun is heavenly! It's an explosion of flavors & the pork's so tender it melts in your mouth! & the pickled radishes.....oodles & oodles of flavor! It was like a When-Harry-Met-Sally moment! A Must-try!!
author: Amy C.

description: Happened across this food truck at Off The Grid at the embarcadero today.  Ordered the Tofu Baked Bao, and it was very substantial and delicious!  Topped with some sriracha sauce it was out of this world!  Bonus points for having a really cool staff too.
author: Matt S.

description: Chairman Bao is a staple at Moveable Feast in Willow Glen and always has a 20 minute line to show how popular it is.... and deservedly so!  The buns are amazing (get the buns your first time, not the sandwiches).  My wife, who would never eat something with the word "belly" in it, devoured the pork belly bun like she was surrounded by a pack of hungry wolves.  The food is simply amazing, blending a potpourri of different tastes and cultures into one bite.
author: Ted B.

description:
Finally had a chance to try them & I loved it. I loved it, not too spicy just right, as others have said it ain't your average bun.
Going to make sure I follow their twitter locations.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
I went to Off the Grid yesterday night... more like ran there! Yes, I will run for food. Crazy packed there! I think Chairman Bao Bun Truck had the longest line there!!! I waited an hour for those buns... I got so cold. I kept thinking, while waiting in line, that they better be worth it. My friend had tried it before and said that it was too hyped.

When I FINALLY reached the truck's window, I got two steamed buns: one with the pork belly and pickled daikon and other was the red sesame chicken with carrots. The chicken was pretty delicious. But, I wish I had tried that first before trying the pork belly one because the pork belly was WAY delicious. It was very, very flavorful, and the pickled daikon complemented it very well. 

My only gripe was the price. The buns aren't that big, so one pork belly and one chicken for $7 was pretty much pushing it. However, I think it was worth to try the pork belly one at least once, even if you have to wait an hour.
author: Vera W.

description:
Pork Belly Bun, right? RIGHT?! That's what everyone's going to talk about. That's how I heard about it , actually! From everyone talking about it! 

Tried it yesterday at UpperHaight and it was tasty! It is oily but the oil is so yummy and tasty! 
Honestly though I somehow assumed the bun was going to be a little bigger for $3.50 but that's how street food is. You gotta expect it.

The pickles on top compliment the pork belly very well! Not sticky like the pork belly your grandma might make at home
author: Veranna N.

description:
I finally tracked tracked the ol' panda down... or rather, it tracked me down right after I ate a pizza earlier this afternoon. Being the good yelper that I am, I immediately mustered up the appetite for a second lunch. Bao!

Unfortunately, I think its more of a novelty experience than good food. I *love* steamed buns, but the pork belly was so greasy that it covered the bun (and my hands) in oil - not so great. I dig the design, and the service was quite pleasant; everyone was super nice. Lastly, the pineapple shaved ice drink was way too sweet for my taste, but I do support all the fruit chunks!

Worth a try, but not sure I'd be so pumped to see it parked nearby again...
author: Stephanie P.

description:
This tiny red truck packs in a pretty solid punch. I have tried all their buns, my favorite ones are:



Pulled Pork with Savoy Cabbage and Pickled Mustard Seeds on Steamed Bun - $2.95
Crispy Garlic Tofu with Miso Greens on Steamed Bun - $2.95
Tender Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon on Steamed Bun - $2.95

Which only leaves 2 other buns... which aren't far behind on my list. 

Bouncing around busy bars, events and locations in sf, this truck has really grown in popularity... and for a great reason. Great service, and amazing food!

Perfect to grab 1-2 buns and enjoy them with a cold beer at a bar. I believe the truck is outside Bloodhound on Wednesdays... A great bar in SOMA... call and check first before you embark there, they may have changed day/hours. 

For a corporate event or a big party, book this truck to add some deliciousness to your event!
author: Anish B.

description:
Twenty to thirty minute ques for nouveau steamed buns that cost more than double what you can get in almost any Chinatowns? 

I'll have one of each, please.
author: Ian H.

description:
I stood in line for this truck at the kick off SJ Eats event - you know, the one where they tried to mash a billion people into one dinky parking lot - and waited 2 hours before being able to place my order. Then I waited another 30 minutes for my pork belly and daikon buns to be ready for noms.

That 2.5 hour wait was so. effing. worth it. The pork belly was so tender, the bun was so fluffy, and the daikon was so crunchy... I was sitting and tearing my way through the saucy bun so quickly that the sauce was running all over my hands and even dripped onto my jeans :c I didn't care though! 

I fell asleep that night dreaming sweet dreams of Chairman Bao pork belly buns.
author: Carolyn K.

description:
Delicious! My friend got us some of the buns so I'm not exactly sure what I ate except that it was pork with some pickle looking thing on top.

2 thumbs up, now I just need to figure out where to find the truck...
author: Rachel R.

description:
The gold standard for food trucks as far as I am concerned.  How these folks put out this caliber of food from a truck is beyond me.  The steamed buns are amazing.  Purists may say it's not authentic Chinese (uhhumm.. you know who you are;), but who cares.  Incredible flavors.  

Service is fast and friendly.  Even if there is a line it goes pretty fast, and anyway, it's worth the wait.  Prices seem a little high, but for the quality fair I think.  

We go when they are in San Jose.
author: Dave P.

description:
Thanks to Off the Grid, I was able to finally experience the elusive Chairman Bao Bun Truck. I came right when it opened to so long lines. Of course I order what else... Pork Belly.... Get in my Belly... It definitely didn't disappoint :D I paired it with the sesame chicken, which was also very very decent. 

The only down side is that the snack size steamed bun was definitely a small snack. So 2 buns were like $7 buckaroos... Man if i was to get my grub on, I would be up to $30-35 bones... OUCH... So very tasty bun, but very expensive, which doesn't lead to cheap in cheerful in the pocket, but at least cheap and cheerful in the belly...
author: Minh V.

description:
The power of the steamed bun once saved me from the middle school bully. Here was an eighth-grader so tough, she would steal lunches on the bus and spit gum in the back of your head in class. As fate would have it, she was my seat mate in choir and I only survived by crossing her palm daily with the red bean steamed buns my mom would send me to school with (damn asian funky ass lunches!). Turns out this raccoon eyed blondie of a bully took a yen to the sweet, foreign, taste of my "buns" and I was able to stay on her good side.

Point of that lengthy exposition, is that steamed buns rock. They can save nerdy middle-schooler's lives, and they can also satisfy your hunger after ferocious work out. Found the Bao truck parked outside Crunch today on Polk St. and had the Sesame Chicken with Scallion & Bok Choy. For less than $3.00 it was a revelation. Piping hot, soft, chewy bun, and savory insides with the flavors of the chicken and vegi's really complementing each other.

Turns out one wasn't enough, so I'll be following on Twitter to get my seconds!
author: Lummi B.

description:
OMG pork belly! Delicious! (Fried tofu and sesame chicken also very good!)

These guys had the longest line at Edgewood Eats last night, and for good reason! A delicious step-up from the been-there-done-that tacos at other trucks.
author: Jen Y.

description:
The TOFU!
What's the secret to making a tofu sandwich that's so satisfyingly "meaty?"

I've been eating tofu for decades. I've had it grilled, fried, sauteed, blended, baked, marinated, made into eggless "egg" salad or mock tuna salad, I've even made it from scratch myself. 

I've never had it like this. Even after deconstructing the sandwich and examining it, I can't explain it. There's something about the texture of the tofu itself. 
Even when it's frozen, then defrosted and cooked, while the texture changes, it's not like this.

If I could make tofu taste this yummy, I'd make it this way all the time!

Partly it's the crispy crunch in the char-grilled exterior, partly its the creamy, not mushy inner part, but that's not all of it.
Maybe it's the seasonings in the accompanying slaw. Maybe it's the slightly sweet baked bun (and the sweeter steamed, pillowy one).

All I know is, the sum is greater than the parts.

Since I'm gluten-free, I tasted the buns (both steamed and baked) for research purposes, after downing some digestive enzymes. Then I transferred the insides of the sandwich to gluten free bread. BIG mistake. 
Had to put them back where they belonged to get the full enjoyment.

It's the whole package together that makes any later agonies of digestive and respiratory reaction to the gluten totally worth it. The "gestalt" as some would say.

A glorious sensory experience.

I don't eat meat but the blissful faces chowing down on the pork and chicken around me tell the tale.

So 1 steamed ($3.75) and 1 baked ($6.75) bun --- $10.50 for more than I could eat in one sitting. The larger baked bun or two of the smaller would have been a perfect-size lunch.

OH - and maybe because it was San Ramon, maybe because it was 12:45, but there were only 2 folks ahead of me and my food was ready in 3 minutes.

Go to their website and find out their weekly schedule.

:-D
author: C M.

description:
Definitely a fan of the steamed pork belly buns.  $3.75 is somewhat pricey for such a small bun, but worth the splurge.

$6.75 for the baked version.  The pork belly one was pretty good as well.  We also tried the baked braised pork bun which is also worth the try.
author: Sharon S.

description: If I had to wait 2 hours to get a $7 pork belly bun I'd be fatty pissed.  But since I only had to wait 5 minutes at the North Beach farmers market I was a happy fat ass.  The baked pork belly bun was delicious.  I've eaten at most of the food trucks in the city and this was probably one of the best things I've eaten off a truck.  The food trucks serve is usually disappointing and expensive for what you get.  But I was definitely impressed with their interpretation of a baked pork belly bun,  I also had the braised pork in a steamed bun and it was also delicious.  $4 for the steam bun is borderline highway robbery and goes back into my opinion that food truck items are overpriced but it was good.  If you want a goo hearty portion definitely go for the baked bun version.
author: Fatty A.

description: Delishious!!!  I had the opportunity to try these guys out at the Trucktober Fest in Sacramento.  I had the pork belly on a steamed bun and the spicy chicken on a baked bun. Both items were spiced very well. The meat was succulent and tender.  I was very impressed.
author: Roz G.

description:
I tried this truck at the first SJ Eats, after ~2 hours wait. In fact, the line started before the truck were even open. They definitely took their time as all other trucks opened at 5pm and this not until like 6 something. Good thing I was with friends and they were keeping me company.

When it was finally my turn, they run out of chicken. I had 2 pork and 1 tofu on steamed buns. The pork almost melted in my mouth, as I bit into it. Tofu was beyond all my expectations (Ok, I never expected much from tofu): crispy panko coating and tender interior and what's more, it was flavourful!

A friend got the baked bun, which I am personally not a fan of since it was just a standard Chinese bakery type bun.
author: Cindy B.

description:
I'm not sure if I thought this was just okay because I eat similar things all the time, or if it was overhyped.

I didn't eat the famed pork belly bun, but I got the Chicken wrapped in the soft bao bun.  It tasted like a mock peking duck.  Pretty good I must say, but nothing special, and definitely not worth the price.  I'd have to say though, if you don't eat Chinese food often, it is probably worth a try.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
Argh. First saw the truck at Off the Grid, but the line was waaay too long. Glad to see them on the bill for Edgewood Eats. (Un)luckily 51st state sf was having issues (next time guys!) so I got three steamed buns - pork belly, red sesame chicken, and duck confit. Pork belly was my favorite. SO GOOD yum. Radish balanced the pork belly nicely. Meat was nice and fatty. Duck confit was pretty good, accompanying mango salad did not taste very mango-y though. Sesame chicken was my least favorite. If you can't take spicy, would not recommend this one. Chicken meat was flavorful, but not as moist as I would have liked. Would rather get 2 pork belly and maybe a duck confit for variety.

Yes they take credit cards. Service is fast(ish) and friendly. Buns come in wrappers that make eating much much easier and neater. Only downside is the price. $10.25 for three buns, that don't even make you full. As tasty as the buns are, it's not worth the price. Maaybe every once in a while. Well maybe the pork belly buns more often...
author: Joyce C.

description: I dream about this place. The pork belly is "melt in your mouth, i need 19 more right now" delicious. My second favorite is tofu, and I don't even like tofu. YOU MUST TRY THIS. Prepare to become addicted.
author: Noel H.

description: Had the Duck and Pork belly buns. Both were just ok for me. The duck was a little to spicy for my. It was just ok . The pork had a nice buttery and crunch to it. I enjoyed it very much. The price is the killer here though. They should serve 2 for the price they sell it for. Still a nice flavor and product they are send out.
author: Joseph G.

description:
I'd try the pork belly bun again if it was convenient and nearby.  Wasn't particularly flavorful to me.  You usually can't go too wrong w/ pork belly.

I wouldn't eat the pork shoulder again.

I tried the chariman bao at the fort mason off the grid.
author: Jerry W.

description:
$6.50 Pork Belly in BAKED buns = Happy asian guy!
- Steam buns is okay, but so much less meat...
- specials are a good gamble.
- braised pork knocked out of greatness by silly pea leaves... just slaw it already.
- even if you don't believe me, find them once, eat $6.50 Pork Belly in BAKED buns and tell me if you can hate...
author: Jim L.

description:
I've always caught the bun truck either at San Mateo, OtG Fort Mason or the Civic Center. 

I've tried the pork belly and the red sesame chicken buns (both steamed and baked) and  O M G - their GOOD! I prefer the baked bun better than the steamed.

The pork belly has a fresh, kinda salty but meaty taste to it and the chicken one is a bit spicy (which for me is perfect) 

they are GOOD! a bit pricey but I don't mind buying them, it's all about quality and flavor here!
author: Elisa R.

description:
2/5 whatever!

pricey, hit or miss. hype.
author: Alvin D.

description:
Comrades, this is my favorite food truck (not because it's Chinese, cause I'm not biased like that). Unlike all the other normal looking white food trucks driving around with their logo, this one definitely stands out with the red paint, unique & catchy logo and Chinese-y symbols all around. You won't miss this truck!

I had a sampler of three buns - tofu, chicken and pulled pork. I ate it in that order and my favorite also is in that order (yeah, pretty surprising that tofu came in first on my list). The tofu was different, it was fried with caesar salad, which tasted surprisingly good. The chicken reminded me more of the typical semi spicy Korean spice with scallions and bok choy. The pulled pork (at this time I was pretty full) tasted alright with the radish, I thought the meat could've been a bit more tender though.

I also had the strawberry/coconut pulp drink and lemon/ginger lychee pulp drink. Both were just mediocre... the lemon drink was a bit too sour for my liking (but on a hot day, I guess it's good) and the strawberry drink was just meh.
author: Ede S.

description:
Had it last night outside john collins and then drove out to redwood city to have it for lunch with the bf. yeah. im crazy. but ill go to far lengths for pork products wrapped in my favorite kind of bun- duck bun. yummy glaze. meat that tastes fatty. fat that tastes meaty. boom.

side note: had the strawberry coconut drink... a little too much going on for me. too floral, too much chewables inside, good taste though.

got 2 steamed buns (porkbelly, of course!) last night for $6
got the 2 steamed buns and the drink for $9

i think its a great deal for delicious meats and starch.
author: Sydel S.

description:
*~Update~* 6/24  4 Stars 

My friends and I came out to the SJ Eats/Moveable Feast event on 6/18.  Everyone wanted to try Chairman Bao and I was ready to give them another chance.  I tried the pork belly again in hopes it would live up to all the hype this time around... and it did!!!  The pork belly was flavorful like last time and was juicy and moist as it should be.  We hit up almost every truck at the event since there was 10 of us.  I would have to say that Chairman Bao was the only truck that we came back a 2nd time for.  

Curt - If you are reading this, thank you for responding to my previous review.   Whatever you communicated to your staff definitely worked.  I can't wait to have Chairman Bao again.  Keep up the good work!


*~First Review~* 3 Stars
I had very high hopes for Chairman Bao with all the reviews and appearing on Eat Street.  I ordered the steamed pork belly bun, the tofu bun and the braised pork bun.  The tofu was AMAZING!!  Omg, the crispy goodness with the sauce and veggies were a perfect compliment.  If you're wary of tofu this bun will make you a believer!!  Now, to the pork belly bun, I loooooooove me some pork belly!!  I think I may have hyped myself up too much for this bun.  The meat had very good flavor but it was extremely chewy and dry.  I'm not sure if the belly is fried after the braise it but it was hard on the outside.  The braised pork was tasty and the meat was a little chewy as well but at least it wasn't hard as the pork belly.
I will give Chairman Bao another chance and I hope I can update the review at that time...
author: Thuy N.

description:
LOVE this place... the buns are amazing and the service is great. 

HIGHLY recommend the pork belly and the duck confit.

Doesn't get better than this. I'm obsessed!
author: Fiona T.

description:
I ran into the Chairman Bao truck at the Rockit Room on Clement last night at 1:45am.  I heard about this truck just a few days ago and was really surprised I ran into it on my way to Quickly's down the street.

There was no line, friendly service and a delicious sounding menu.  I ended up getting the Red Sesame Chicken w/ Scallion and Bok Choy steamed bun.

Took about 3 or 4 minutes to prep and then I dug right in.  The bok choy was really, really, really (no, really) yummy.  It had this pickled vegetable taste to it, which I loved.  The bok choy had the right crunch and flavor.  The red sesame chicken was a tad dry but had a very tiny spicy kick to it.  Not sure if that was the scallions or actual hot sauce.

The only reason I didn't rate this truck 5 stars is because of two things. 

1) The steamed bun had a very hard edge to it.  It almost tasted like the bun was either from frozen or steamed then re-steamed.  I couldn't quite tell.

2) The baked bun price was a lot higher than I expected.  $5.75 for a baked bun and $2.95 for a steamed bun.  I opted for steamed because of the big price differential.

Overall, I would definitely come back here and try the different buns.  If you're looking for a traditional bao place, this isn't it.  If you're looking for a tasty new take on bao...give this place a try, pronto!  Now if I could only find them again as conveniently as I did last night...

Menu:

Buns - Baked ($5.75), Steamed ($2.95):

Filling:
-Tender Pork Belly with Pickled Daikons
-Red Sesame Chicken with Scallion and Bok Choy
-Lions Head Meatball with Fresh Kim Chee
-Chinese Sausage and Egg Sandwich with Hoisin
-Crispy Garlic Tofu with Miso Greens
-Chinese Spiced Duck Confit with Fresh Mango Salad

Bun Meals (Combo):

-2 Steamed Buns and a Fresh Fruit Shaved Ice Drink - $9
-Baked Bun and a Fresh Fruit Shaved Ice Drink - $9

Fresh Fruit Shaved Ice Drinks - $3.50:

-Pineapple Salted Caramel
-Strawberry Coconut
-Ginger Lychee
-Mango Matcha Green Tea

Other Beverages - $1.50 and up:

-Iced Green Tea
-Coconut Water
author: Bobby L.

description:
BAO o BAO that was good!

this is the 2nd time ive tried this truck.  made a u-turn after almost sideswiping the truck mobbing down folsom, excited coz i never see this truck near my location.  

i always get the steamed version coz the baked kind is like a humongous baowich-cant do it.  ive tried the red sesame chicken, crispy garlic tofu, the pulled pork & the chinese spiced duck w/ mango...THIS is my favorite.  i dont eat duck or order duck on the regular, so im surprised the oily fowl was pretty good in this bun, and the mango salad was spicy so that was a plus.

any one else know of a bao stop?  otherwise, i bao down to this truck.  im goin back for the drinks.  maybe then theyll get their 5th star.
author: Lady K.

description: Just thinking about the Tender Pork Belly with pickled daikee makes me salivate. The pork belly is always cooked to perfection with crispy edges and tender inside. I see that some Yelpers have mentioned dry pork, this has never been the case for me. The baked bun is absolutely the way to go. It is messy, so get a few extra napkins!
author: Daniel K.

description: King of the Moveable Feast in San Jose, The Chairman seems to have a longstanding following in San Francisco. This is hands down the best meal on wheels I have ever consumed and I fully comprehend the boldness of the implication I am making.  I have sampled the entire menu and all of the items are of a legitimate gourmet Chinese Fusion Cuisine caliber, only served rapid fire in an almost morning bakery style manner by an enthusiastic crew.  The standout is the Coca-cola braised Pork served on the baked version of the signature Bao roll, which has a cabbage/chipotle mayo garnish that Rivals the flavor profile of the best Carolina pulled pork and slaw sandwiches.  Come here with any kind of an appetite and you will have a hard time not completing this particular item in its entirety.
author: D M.

description: The baos are very pricy but they were delicious! I got the braised beef, duck confit & pork belly. Gourmet baos at it's best!
author: Ennie L.

description:
i love (but also feel like i should be offended?) that this cart decided to name itself after the controversial crazed, sifilis-eroded communist dictator and then draw him as a smiling anthropomorphized panda. i'm certainly not offended enough to stop going here though. Chairman Bao is straight up delicious and worth another visit. $9 meals include either: 
1) 2 steamed buns (served like large peking duck tacos) + shaved ice/fresh fruit/jelly combo drink 
or
2) 1 baked bun (cut in half and served sandwhich style) + shaved ice/fresh fruit/jelly combo drink

A little on the pricy side, but the they serve high quality food, so not particularly unreasonable. Just don't go expecting regular lunch truck prices.

tried:
Pork belly + baked bun seems to be one of their specialties. half fat, half meat, is rich tasty and indulgent.
duck confit with mango on steamed bun - really liked the spicy mayo/duck/mango combo taste but agreed with other reviews that the duck was a little dry. maybe they'll work that kink out as they get their rythem down.

the ginger lychee drink my friend got was a little sweet for my taste. I liked my mango green tee drink a lot. i heard people really liked the pineapple salted caramel drink. they have little jelly/boba pieces in their drinks, so if you arent a fan of those then these drinks are not for you.
author: James W.

description: I was not expecting a sandwich when I ordered the spicy chicken boa, but I am definitely not complaining. Both the spicy chicken and pork belly steamed baos were amazing. Try it, you won't be sorry!
author: Matthew L.

description: I love Chairman Bao! It's awesome. I've had both the braised pork, the other pork one, and the duck one with the spicy aioli. They were all awesome. My favorite thing at off the grid. They are worth your money and their pretty fast, if there isn't a long line. Can't wait to get some again. :)
author: Breniel L.

description: Chairman Bao is by far the best food truck out there. The Pork Belly bun (steamed or baked) is one of the best things I've ever had, and I'm a serious foodie. The mix between the salty and savory of the pork belly with the sweet and crunchy of the pickled daikon? Forget about it! I seriously ate this 2 nights in a row (Moveable Feast WG and Quakes game) and could have easily gone back for more. The employees are really friendly too, always good service. The spicy chicken is super legit as well! Can't say I'm a big fan of the duck though...
author: Justin M.

description:
DISAPPOINT  !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

If people put 4-5 stars for this truck, which mean they never taste real good bao before.
Please don't put panda from your logo, because you food is not relate Chinese food totally. 

OVER PRICING
It cost almost double price than regular restaurant, plus TAX?!

TOO MUCH SAUCE ON BAO

SIZE of the Bao too small
author: SteveMorris M.

description:
Delicious greasy lunch deliciousness.

Do not come here looking for pious options on a Monday after gorging yourself all weekend. Come here on a Friday, early, if you are slightly hungover from Thursday happy hour that went longer than you anticipated. 

Red sesame chicken steamed bun with marinated carrots - tender and sweet and spicy and sour and awesome.

Baked bun with braised pork and savoy cabbage - not really a terribly Asian item with brioche bun and mayo-y slaw, but I'll take it. Adding sriracha makes it more authentic, right? A little too greasy, but that didn't stop me from devouring it.
author: Erin K.

description:
Never heard of Chairman Bao until today! Ebay Mobile sponsored this truck today whom passed out free lunch from 11:30am-1:30pm on the corner of 5th & Mission Street. *so if you're reading this right now and you're in the neighborhood, hurry down & try them out....for free!!

I had the Red Sesame Chicken, Braised Pork w/ Savory Cabage & Fried Garlic Tofu. 

Red Sesame Chicken:  Wooooooohooooooo, if you love spicy then this is for you! It's definitely the most bold tasting out of the 3 items I tried.

Braised Pork w/ Savory Cabage: This bun is more on the mellow side kind of like Kalua Pork w/ coleslaw, that's pretty much how I'd describe it to taste like.

Fried Garlic Tofu: This vegetarian item is delicious. I liked this bun a little bit more than the Braised Pork because the tofu is fried w/ a garlic crust that's MMMmmm MMMMMmm MMMMMMM!!!

The fried wonton skin chips are pretty delectable as well. Goes good w/ all the buns. 

For the drink, I had the Strawberry w/ Coconut bits which is a Strawberry Lemonade w/ coconut pieces in it. Not bad but it was a little bit to the tart side.

All in all, a very unique concept that I enjoyed very much. 4 out of 5 stars!
author: Victor C.

description: During a recent business trip to SF, I was fortunate to find out my co-worker was a Yelp elite, so I trusted that when she told me The Chairman was guaranteed to be good- it would be. We hit the trick at Fifth and Minna in SF right at noon and while the line was long, we ordered and got out food in about 20 minutes... Not bad. I tried the steamed bun with both the spicy chicken and the coca cola pork. Both were delicious, but that spicy pork and the sweetly pickled, thinly sliced carrots. Oh, man. THAT was good stuff! On an especially hungry day, 3 steamed buns kept me full, 2 would probably suffice, but hey- I'm not knocking an extra bun or two. The service was friendly and quick, and even for a relatively unadventurous eater this was an amazing find.
author: Natalie L.

description: Pro tip, Get the Chicken Baked or Steamed but ask them to substitute the sesame puree sauce that comes on it for the Garlic Aioli.  You'll never go back!
author: Sam G.

description: Had my first Pork belly today...it's definitely one of the better food trucks out there. Now I know why they have such long lines.
author: Nico M.

description:
I've been to Chairman Bao two times now--once at Off the Grid--Fort Mason, and again at Moveable Feast (formerly SJ Eats).

I'd have to say this is probably one of the more tasty of these new food trucks.  I've tried the Pork Belly, Braised Pork, and the new Sesame Chicken--all delicious, but the Pork Belly, hands down the best of the three.

My only gripe is that the lines at these events for Chairman Bao can get kind of long, but once you get your order in, it doesn't take too long for them to call your name. Though compared to other trucks, it doesn't take the most out of your pocket, but $3.75 for steamed buns and around $6 for the baked buns (which I've yet to try) is a bit pricey for the size of the buns.  But again, if you don't hit up these trucks too often, it's nice to spend a bit more for some tasty food.  

If you haven't it's definitely a must try. Follow them on twitter @chairmantruck to figure out where they've setup shop for the day.
author: Josh J.

description: The best.  My #1 food truck choice.  Nothing beats the braised pork baked bao - just incredible.  They just need more trucks, so there's always one near you.
author: Peter G.

description:
Heard the hype so I had to give it a try. Since I couldn't decide, I just got one baked and one steamed. 

For the baked ($6.75), I chose to have tender pork belly with pickled diakon. If you get the pork belly, just know what you're getting into. It's greasy and fattening which makes it so delicious and they give you giant, generous pieces. I'm still trying to decide if I liked the diakon in this bun, so I might have to give this another try before I come to the full conclusion of this bun. I did enjoy the bun itself. 

For the steamed ($3.75), I got it with pulled pork with savory cabbage and preserved mustard seeds. I liked the meat of the pulled pork - it flavorful and not dry. I liked the cabbage, but the mustard seeds were bitter so if I took a wrong bite I'd get a shooting splurge of bitterness. 

Next time I'd probably give their other buns a try before settling on a favorite. 

If you know where they are going to be and plan on going, I'd go early because the lines will start forming.
author: Lang T.

description:
I heard so much hype about this truck that  I had to try it for myself.  My first opportunity was at the SJ eats event, which was a complete and total disaster. The lines were extremely long and trucks were running out of food.  Then they had a similar event in Sacramento which was at a larger venue but with the same long crowd.  I actually waited almost 2 hours to finally sample their item (I can not decide if it was worth it though).

I tried 3 items (because that was all they had to offer), which BTW were all steamed for $3.75 each:   

1). crispy tofu:  Just okay, probably wont get again  
2). pork belly: I had a bite of my bf, and I was disappointed I didnt order one for myself.  VERY YUMMY and I am not even too keen on pork.
3).   braised pork:  Very good as well.  

I will definitely go back and try something else with pork.
author: Day A.

description:
3 1/2 stars folks

first appearance here at Genentech tag team with Seoul on Wheels. the food that Chairman provided I have to say I would go back for the pork belly steamed bun.. price is not not to bad for steamed buns are $3.75 baked $6.75 tried two of the buns they offered

the duck confit with mango slices sorry folks I don't know if it is the one I got in general but it was super salty the mango slices could not cure the extent of saltiness provided on this steamed bun. straight beer face, the kind of face you get when your drinking a pale ale haha

the pork belly with pickled cucumbers and fresh cut onions was delish got this one steamed also, the portion is small but the taste was all there, being filipino didnt mind adding some mang tomas(sauce based for lechon (roasted pig)) on the pork belly to give it a homey feel

the price again lil high but it is a truck so what you get is what you pay for again definitely will hit this truck up again for there pork belly steamed bun

food *** 1/2  4 stars for the porkbelly steamed 2 for the duck confit super salty
price $$ tad pricey but so are most specialty type taco trucks
service ***** quick, friendly
ambiance **** they set out some tables for standing dining but for the most part depending on weather good quick eat.
author: Clarence A.

description:
Braised meats with pickled vegetables, wrapped up in a white bread taco. Not remotely authentic bao, but I suppose this is fair enough from a San Francisco food truck.

The mouthfeel was good, plenty of bright crunch with savory gooey-ness. Despite the taco presentation, they were difficult to eat on-the-run. I kept loosing my veggies. The flavor profiles were traditional, five spice-ish and salty. The pseudo-bao were seriously overpriced, and the people too cool for school. The guest list cutting the line at Off the Grid was pathetic.
author: Ben G.

description:
I love you all, I do. And I'm totally on the same page that for a bun this is a lot of cash to pay. But if I want a $.99 to $1.25 bun, I'll go to chinatown or Ranch99. 

Yes this is totally hypocritical, but for $7 I can get two buns that are absolutely filling for lunch on a Friday and still have $3 I woudln't have if I ate at other locals near Civic Center. Also, they are delicious and until I can make them at home I'll be okay paying this much every once in a while. Yes that is the rule of thumb, if I can't make it myself, I can't complain about a moderate to high price... just saying.
author: Niki M.

description: Tried three of their boa varieties and each of them were exceptional. My favorite was the pork belly, followed by the coca-cola braised pork, and last but not least the spicy chicken. Each bite is perfectly seasoned and flavored, and it just doesn't get better!
author: Misha Z.

description: This is a pretty good place for bao's. The coca-cola braised pork was yummy, and I was both disappointed and relieved that I didn't taste much coca-cola flavor. The pork belly bun was superb, I had a great time biting into those layers of fat and what seemed to be some pickled cabbage topping. All in all, a good experience, a little more than what I'm used to paying for bao's at Chinatown, but I'd definitely come back.
author: Alton Z.

description:
Fortunately for me I got to try the duck confit on the steam bun and pineapple drink.  

The duck confit is so flavorful and the mango salsa goes so well with the duck that my mouth is salivating thinking about it.  Just delicious little bites of delectable goodness.  

Don't expect any typical about these baos (especially the price, $3 for tiny steam bun)!  It is not what you would expect to find in a Chinese dim sum restaurant...and I love dim sum.  The flavor combinations work so well that I have to ask why didn't anyone else think of this earlier.

My suggestion is for Chairman Bao to have a physical location...but there is probably some nostalgia of a having it on a truck.  An affordable pricing would be helpful -- maybe that's why they take credit cards.

Pass on the pineapple drink, nothing really to rave about -- save your $$$ for another bao.
author: just d.

description:
I tried Bao's buns today for the first time.  I ordered the pork belly and the duck confit steamed buns for $3.75 each.  They were delicious!

The spiced duck confit comes with a sauce which has a bit of a kick.  I like spicy food, and this sauce definitely has a bite.  So if you really do not like spice, this may not be the bun for you.  Otherwise, the mango salad on top of the bun is refreshing and counters the spice nicely.

The pork belly was heavenly.  Yes, it is fattening, but it is also true that the pickled daikon helps add a nice crunch and flavor to the pork belly.  If you think you're going to feel guilty ordering the pork belly because you worked out this morning, don't order it.  But it is delicious...

The portions of the steamed are small enough you could hold it with one hand and eat in a few bites.  I ordered two and found myself satisfied.  Not full to a point where I had stomach aches, but enough where I could probably eat one more and be done for lunch.  I still have to try the baked buns, but I bet they will be just as delightful.
author: Mogi D.

description:
I was very skeptical when I joined the winding line for Chairman Bao at Off the Grid.  I mean, come on, a bao is a bao is a bao, right?  I've had my fair share of char siew baos.  But, despite my initial hesitation, I was just too curious.  I joined the line.

Bit into the steamed pork belly bun, and thought... oh... man.

OK, fine.  It really IS worth the wait!  Perfectly cooked pork belly, and the pickled daikon added a perfect brightness and crunch to it.  Delicious!

You win, Chairman Bao. You win.
author: suzanne l.

description:
I remember a Yelp reviewer saying the line was long but it'd be worth the wait. Well, imagine my disappointment when I thought Chairman Bao wasn't at last night's Off the Grid at Fort Mason. While scanning the other trucks to see which would make for a suitable choice, I heard a woman say, "Yeah, that's the bun line."

It's clear what happens next, right? The line moved quite quickly. A friend and I split two steamed buns (had to save room for other fares, too!): the pork belly with daikon ($3.75) and red sesame chicken with carrots ($3.25). 

The pork belly bun was phenomenal and by far the best thing I had all night.

Go. Go quickly. Wait patiently. Feel great afterward.

Tip: Do not get coconut water as it is actually coconut juice with coconut pulp.
author: Half P.

description: Probably one of the hardest things to give up when I became a vegetarian was barbecue Peking duck with steamed buns, but Chairman Bao gives me an opportunity to revisit that. They didn't get lazy with the veggie bun, either; it was pretty creative considering what went into it. The overall sweet yet savory taste mimics that nostalgic (at least for me) barbecue duck flavor profile. Greatly appreciated.
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Yes! Finally got to try some of the baos from the Chairman Truck.  This truck came down to Cupertino's Off The Grid at Whole Foods last Tuesday. My husband and I got there around 5:15PM and some of the other trucks were open and had one or two customers. Chairman truck was still closed but had roughly 5 to 7 people waiting in line for it to open.  My husband was a little skeptical saying how well does a bao feed someone.  The guy in front of us turned around and said, "You got to try the food here, especially the pork bellies."  He gave us his tip to buy the steamed baos and buy at least 3 to fill you up. He was spot on.  The steamed baos were so good.  I had one Pork Belly Bao with Turmeric Pickled Daikon and Green Shiso, one Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds, and one Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro. Wow, all three blew me away.  The pork belly bao was my favorite, since it was tender pork belly and the seasoning was very tasty. My second favorite was the spicy chicken. This bao had a little kick to it but it was not over-powering.  The Coca-Cola Braised Pork bao was also very tasty and I enjoyed all three.  My husband got three Crispy Miso Cured Tofu with Garlic-Tofu Mayo & Baby Choy Sum and he loved the bun and the flavors of the miso cured tofu.  If you see the Chairman Truck in your local Off the Grid, I strongly suggest you try it.  You can't go wrong with the baos here.
author: Christina C.

description:
One word. Addicted.

I was introduced to the food truck phenomenon by a coworker and immediately though the idea of gourmet  food trucks was brilliant.  Why didn't I think of it?!

Small menu, but that is perfect for this type of adventure.  Can find them at Off the Grid events, which is nice to have that "schedule" or on their own around the Bay Area, including my workplace in Emeryville. Check their twitter to know where they are that day. 

Simple. Clean. Tasty. More. More. More.

Red sesame chicken bun and pork belly bun are addictive.  Just a warning.
author: Mike C.

description:
Unique truck.  Usually bao or manapua (in Hawaii) comes steamed with filling inside the bun. Chairman Bao offers a unique spin on this by wrapping the bun round the filling (like a taco).

The chicken was good, tender and delicious. The picked veggies on top were yummy. You need to order 2-3 to get full since each one is pretty small. Worth a try.
author: Chili B.

description:
I would say this place is overrated and not worth that long line of a wait.

I got the steamed bun with the braised pork.  The pork wasn't too tender and there wasn't much to it.

I don't think i'll wait in the long line for this again.
author: Mimi P.

description: Line is long, but I guess because there's no other truck like it.  Food wise, it's good, but not great.  Not flavorful enough and very messy.
author: Zhiyu L.

description:
OMG...AMAZING....Tender Port Belly--still crunchy! The spicy chicken had a yummy kick. (I had them both on steamed buns) 

Vague memory--but I think they were called Chairman Bao at some point..but definitely GO! I actually had them for free, courtesy of the opening of the Umqua Bank on Sansome St in the City; never tried it but the ppl I went with made it an easy sell..plus something about this line, though longer, moving faster than the other food truck. 

If only, they came around the FiDi more often!
author: J. S.

description: This is probably the best food truck so far. Everything is fantastic, especially the pork belly sammich on a baked honey bun. The chicken sammich on the baked bun is outstanding as well. I always look for this truck at all the food truck events. Try it.
author: Rick H.

description: I always wondered what all the hype was about...UNTIL NOW.  This food truck is TRULY LEGIT!  I got the baked bun with coca cola braised pork....Holy Crap it was awesome.  $6 is the price you pay for perfection!
author: Daniel W.

description: Chairman Bao was one of two food trucks at an after party my company hosted. Devon helped coordinate beforehand. She was very laid back, and I was initially a little nervous about execution, but I needn't have worried -- the team was friendly and prompt the night of the event, and the food was delicious. the Garlic Tofu bun was all I indulged in myself, but from the word of mouth at the party, everything was perfection. Chairman was a highlight for many, and more than one local at the party mentioned the truck was one of their absolute favorites. Thanks, guys, for a great night!
author: Rachel A.

description:
When I was a young'un I used to be a slave to ice cream trucks. When I'd hear their signature tune make its way into the house, I'd come running out, flailing my arms, telling them to waitwaitwait!! This was serious business. I even dragged out my bright blue Playskool safe just so I could crack that puppy open right on the spot and buy ice cream without being left in the dust. My friend and I also used to chase down the ice cream truck w/ our bicycles too. Oh the memories...

Fast forward to today and you'll find me obsessing over the Chairman Bao Bun Truck, the adult version of my childhood ice cream truck. If that thing were on the run, I would gladly chase it down, arms a-flailin' and purse in tow.

Luckily, I didn't have to do any chasing this past weekend. Thanks to Twitter, I was able to swoop in on a few of their tasty buns. The Tender Pork Belly w/ Pickled Daikon bun, plus the Chinese Spiced Duck Confit w/ Fresh Mango Salad bun, were both to die for! I love daikon and don't see it served very often, so it was a real treat seeing it incorporated into something that already sounded good on its own.

Make a point to cross paths with this truck or you'll be sorry!
author: Tiffany M.

description: The Coca-Cola braised pork - both baked and bao - were bomb. You can't ask anymore from a food truck. The food was prepared surprisingly quick, but rest assured, this does not mean it's low quality food. It is high quality and very delicious. Would definitely be back for more.
author: Vincent C.

description:
Why did no one tell me about pickled daikon sooner??!!!
I finally came across the Chairman Bao truck when there was a survivable line in front of it- my mind is strong, but my stomach is weak and will go with what it can get first at Off The Grid.
The pork belly and pickled daikon bun was soooooo delicious. My new favorite snack.
author: Johanna S.

description: This truck is really different. I didn't know what to choose from especially with the choice of buns. I choose two of them because the stream buns was very inexpensive. I tried the Coca-Cola Braised Pork with Savoy Cabbage & Preserved Yellow Mustard Seeds and Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro. Each had its own different flavor. The coca-cola braised was sweet with the mustard which give it a tart taste. The Spicy Chicken had like a bold flavor with tartness of the pickled Carrots-Cucumber. The stream bun help piece all the flavor together.
author: Ashley G.

description:
it would be a 5 star if they offer, whole wheat buns and more non fatty choices.  Plus let me takeout-without those containers that last only 2 minute.  (yes, it's compostable but I don't need those containers)  (remember those McDonald styrofoam 5 min life span containers aren't use anymore?,  10 year history...)

Fatty pork is not for me, I see enough people taking high blood pressure pills.  Sorry, eating can kill you know...   sorry to be a sour puss  (my tax dollars are paying for billions of free health care and it burns me inside)
author: Sunny O.

description:
I have little to no experience with this type of cuisine, so find another review if you are looking for an "expert."  That said, these are some tasty buns. I had the crispy garlic tofu with miso greens, and it was excellent on all fronts. The ingredients were fresh, well-prepared, and complement each quite well.

I can't say I'd actively seek out Chairman Bao, but I'd be pleasantly surprised to run across him somewhere.
author: Janna M.

description:
I am a MAJOR fan of food trucks - doesn't matter what they serve, I am so there!  The Chairman Bao Bun Truck does an interesting take on Chinese buns.  It's more like a bun sammie than a bun, but that's okay.

Bottom line:
- interesting ingredients, with big slab of "meat" (duck or pork belly or tofu) or diced chicken -- the big slab is a bit off-putting for me and the bun cannot hold up next to the slab
- interesting slaw toppers
- totally prefer steamed buns over the baked buns
- a bit pricey for what it is
author: Fontane L.

description: A group of us waited a good hour in line at an event these guys were at. After an hour of waiting we were about to be served when they abruptly closed up shop. Apparently poor planning on their part as they didn't have nearly enough supplies on hand. You would think they would at least have the courtesy to warn people in line that they might be running out of food.
author: Kevin G.

description:
Party in your mouth! 

Chairman Bao's is delicious! 

My sister and I had the opportunity to try them while they were at SJEats. Since this truck is mainly an SF thing, we thought, why not? We ended up waiting 2 hours for the damn things...but I will say it was worth it! 

We both got one baked pork bun and one steamed pork bun. Both have essentially the same fillings: moist, tender pork, pickled veggies and a creamy (possibly mayo based?) sauce. It all sounds kind of whatevers...but everything together = party in my mouth.

The steamed bun looks like a little taco. The "bun" is like a steamed piece of flat bread. Pretty good. I definitely enjoyed the baked bun more. It comes out looking like a giant hamburger. The bun/bread whatever it is is soo buttery and fluffy. And goes so well with the meat and veggies, absorbing all the juicy and saucy goodness. 

Hopefully, I'll get to try these again, just with a shorter wait! :D
author: Minna Y.

description: This is the very first food truck I tried and I have been back again and again for their awesome buns! I love all their items!! I always get their steamed buns because I don't like baked buns. However, one of my friends got a baked bun from them one time and they are surprisingly great! The baked buns cost more than the steamed, so I always like to go with the steamed. Everything on the menu is great! The pork belly, the tofu, the duck, the spicy chicken; but my all time favorite is the braised pork! The braised pork is juicy and the mustard seeds give it such a nice flavor! Do not pass this truck up!!
author: Lauren D.

description: This is one of the best food trucks I've encountered. The spicy chicken is quite amazing - possibly the best chick sandwich I've had all year. The pork belly is also very good.
author: Eugene A.

description:
After weeks of anticipation, the day has finally come! The food options near my office are really... eh, and get old after just a short while. So, my coworker and I are always scanning the foodtruck map. We've been hoping the chairman would stop by for weeks. So needless to say we were entirely too excited and ran up to the truck giggling like schoolgirls.

We had steamed buns, I tried the pulled pork, duck, and sesame chicken. At 2.95 each it made a filling but totally reasonably priced lunch. I gotta say, the fatty inside of me would have had 4 or 5 of those things because they are delicious! The steamed buns are light and fluffy. All the meat was cooked to melt-in-your-mouth perfection, the seasonings are unique and brilliantly paired with their meats; the greens on the sesame chicken were fabulous, as was the cabbage and mustard seed on the pork. Out of the three I had, the pulled pork and the duck were my favorites. The mango and onion on the duck, with a hint of ginger, is something I'd eat over and over again. 

My coworker also says the pork belly was fabulous.

One thing - if only they had a sweet bun or a sesame ball or something. That would just make the whole experience utterly complete.
author: Kay M.

description:
Super tasty!!!

No need to say more since everyone has written repeatedly about the buns themselves.  But if you get a chance, $3.75 or not, try one (or three) for yourselves.  Then I think you'll understand why people are willing to follow this truck everywhere.
author: Jennifer F.

description: I love chairman bao. My fav is the pork belly, the duck confit has too much sauce on it. Oh yea get the bun steamed, that's how it's suppose to be. So much flavor in such a small mouthful. I'll wait in line anytime for this. Yumsies!
author: Vanessa K.

description:
This truck is over-hyped and over priced. 

Chairman Bao Bun's are not that flavorful and are usually full of the fatty meat.

I've experienced this truck twice, hoping my second time would be a better experience, but again. I got a bun full of fat.
author: Jo R.

description: Being pregnant right now, I have a more specific taste for food and the pork belly buns really hit the spot for me!  I prefer the baked one ($6.75) over the steamed one ($3.75) just because it is bigger, meaning more meat inside.  The pickled daikon added the perfect crunch and sour taste to compliment the slight sweetness of the pork marinade.  They did not add fatty pieces of pork.  My coworker also enjoyed the spicy chicken buns.  Just lost one star because I felt the steamed bun needed more substance inside (lacked meat and daikon).  Overall rating - MUST TRY CHAIRMAN BAO!  It's worth the wait in the long hot line at the San Carlos airport!
author: Mary Ann M.

description:
I had my gf wait in line here while I was getting other food at Edgewood Eats.  She had to wait over 30 minutes which isn't really a problem since it's a decision she/we made.

For one thing I think the price icons for this place needs to be raised.  It's almost 3 dollars for a bun but the bun is smaller than a taco.  I can literally eat one in two bites so it will definately take more than $10 to get me full.

They have interesting twists on the buns but I could not believe how much sauce they put on each one.  It is ridiculously drowned in sauce.  It makes a mess and it makes it near impossible to actually taste what is in each bun...

I had the chicken bun with carrots, shredded pork,  and pickles and the veggie tofu bun.
author: Daniel K.

description: Best food truck at OTG. Get the baked not steamed and stick with the pork of all sorts. Chicken and tofu good too. I love it when they come to the Proxy.
author: Rachel H.

description: Holy shit that was a good pork belly sandwich!
author: Dave H.

description: What a cute little truck...it's so elusive that I couldn't turn away when I found it parked in front of City Hall SF.  Their menu is pretty simple...5 different items offered mostly baked or steamed.  I settled with the cheap but most popular option: steamed pork belly (only $3.75) and bought the zesty won ton chips.  The BEST PART: they take credits cards....SCORE!....thinking that food trucks only take cash.  Their won ton chips were good but oily....maybe because they drizzle the oil and forget to let the chips sit on a paper towel so the oil can be soaked up (reminds me of the Hurricane Popcorn from hawaii).  But I'd have to admit the chips were still crispy even after not opening them for 4 days.  I can't wait to find them again so I can't their other menu items.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I made the trek to try Chairman Bao's Bun truck at the Emeryville stop coming from San Jose; needless to say it was a tasty trip that was worth my time.

As a pork bun fanatic, I've been itching to try this truck.  I finally had the chance to grab a bite on my day off at work.

I arrived early, about 11:45am, but apparently that wasnt early enough to snatch the highly sought after pork belly bun with daikon.  The line was minimal and picked up by 12:15.

I ended up getting two of each of the following steamed buns; Duck confit with mango slices, braised Berkshire pork with savoy cabbage and preserved mustard seed, and spicy sesame chicken with pickled carrots.  

All of them had a great balance between savory, and sour-y.
My fav meat might have been the pork....it's oh so tender.
The duck confit also had wonderful flavor.  The chicken had a spicey kick but not to strong.  The buns are soft, I'm not sure if they are house made or from a vendor but they taste authentic.
I also ordered the pina colada matcha which was freakin sour! It doesn't pair to well with the buns imo.  It's way to soury, the buns have enough acidity imo.

Overall, I am very pleased and will try again so I can order a porky belly bun.  Good stuff. also one of my fav artist, James Jean did the truck art. sweeet!
author: Alan B.

description:
I think my review may be skewed by the high expectations set by the hype.  Service was slow.  Yes, three people in line and they were still slow.  Even with all that high tech order management software.  The build chart looks very McBao.  Either know your shit or simplify your already simple menu.

The food: I ordered the lion's head and pork belly.  The pork belly meat itself was good....everything else not.  I was hungry so this should have made things taste better.  The sauce was horrible.  For all the fancy build charts they have, the actual construction of the food doesnt really work very well especially with the excess for crappy sauce.  The lions head was not impressive at all.

Hopefully they will improve.
author: H C.

description: Delicious spicy chicken steamed bun.
author: Inigo M.

description: Both the pork belly and braised pork buns are delicious. The sweet buns and toppings complement the meats well. I was pleasantly surprised at the size of the bun for the price. Service was very friendly. Even with a short line, it still took a while to get our buns, as each one seemed carefully constructed. Wouldn't mind going back!
author: Tammi H.

description:
Chairman Bao, you never cease to amaze me.  We were first introduced at the 2nd Haight St. Off the Grid where we had the option of the red chili chicken, crispy pork belly with daikon, or the tofu.  We got one of each of the meat offerings and were impressed.

Today, one of my co-workers alerted me that your truck was at pier 28 not too far from our office so we rush over there.  I was so impressed with the steamed pork belly bun that I get one of them and decide to try the duck with mango and a ginger lychee drink.  The duck was amazing.  The combination of spicy, with sweet and succulent was to die for.  I am sure I will be back to eventually try all of your many flavors.
author: Chris L.

description:
I went to the Chairman for the first time last week when it was in SOMA. Being a Hong Kong native, I'm pretty picky about baos, and I was impressed! When I heard about Chairman Bao, I was a bit skeptical... It sounded like a novelty thing that couldn't possibly be enough to be a meal, but I was wrong!

I thought that their menu always had everything on their facebook menu, so I really wanted to try the duck on steamed buns, but they didn't have it. I ended up sharing 3 steamed buns plus 1 baked one with my boy:

Baked:
Pulled Pork - This was so filling! I think we could have ordered just 1 baked + 2 steamed buns. The pork was tasty and tender. The huge mustard seeds were interesting...

Steamed:
Red Sesame Chicken - I loved it! The chicken was very flavorful and the chopped pieces of bok choy was a nice touch.
Crispy Garlic Tofu - This was pretty good. Probably the most tasty tofu I've had in a while, but the texture was a bit too mushy for me.
Also Pulled Pork

I really enjoyed the buns and will come back for more! Looking forward to trying the duck confit in a steamed bun to see how they interpret the traditional combination.
author: Tracy W.

description:
Next to Roli Roti, Chairman Bao is my favorite food truck in San Francisco. Just the thought of their pillowy steamed buns filled with fatty, savory pork belly and crunchy slices of pickled daikon makes me salivate. 

Their duck confit and mango salad bun should also not be missed. After waiting in line (this truck usually has the longest line), you should get your fill on both. 

**For my full review on foodtrucks around SF, visit my blog link under my profile. Enjoy!**
author: Karin V.

description:
The only dish that matters.

Tender Pork Belly Bun

Week after week, this menu item has been consistent in taste and quality.
author: John N.

description: I can't put my finger on why these baos are so good. Their secret ingredient must be crack or something with a small splash of LSD. On the serious note, these baos are insanely addicting,  they need to start a BA meeting (Bao Anonymous) YES THEY ARE THAT GOOD! I always order the pork belly baked bao. The steamed ones are good too but the baked ones are bigger and the crispy texture works better with the  soft pork belly. The acidity of the daikon cuts the richness of the fatty pork belly. I can't get enough. I'm afraid I'll turn into a bao at the rate I'm eating these.
author: Luna C.

description: I wish I was able to give The Chairman ten stars. I fell in love with the food last year when I experienced it at Off The Grid in San Francisco.  Since then I have enjoyed and followed them all over the bay area.  The decision was easy to make to have them cater a private event for us. I must share that not only was the food unbelievable, the truck was on time and ready. The staff was so friendly and accomodating that it made the rest of the stress of the night bearable.  Thank you guys so much. Look for us to definitely use The Chairman again.
author: Robin B.

description:
