So far I have tried the duck, the chicken, and the pork belly steamed buns.  These guys are 3 for 3.  I've still got to work my way through the rest of the menu.  Grab your bunch, step to the left, drizzle on some sriracha sauce, close your eyes and bite into that little steamy piece of heaven!

Throw in the fast and friendly service, as well as the convenience of being just outside John Colins on a Thursday after work, and you've got a winning combination.

Deelish!

So which bun should I try next???
author: Yasir S.

description: This is a standard stop on my weekly food truck stop in the Haight. The pork belly is my absolute favorite, but you can't go wrong with any of their buns. This truck is a must try and your will be coming back every week for your next bun fix.
author: Steve K.

description: Got a chance to have another food truck experience while in Sacramento at the Asian Heritage Festival in Old Sac. Good food but for a "bun" that is 3.75 I would say it is pricey in my opinion... but for 7.50 and two mini buns, I was able to share w the fiance and at least get to try the food and have the experience.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Just a little FYI for the yelpers, the wait at this truck @Golden Gate is only 5 minutes right now.

The baked pork bun (kind of sandwichy really) was delicious. Pork mustard cabbage awesomeness. The flavors were really well chosen to complement the meat and the bun, which was an excellent bun. Really this is one of the best food items you can find for $7.
author: Andy G.

description: This was the first time I tried the pulled pork at moveable feasts in Willow Glen from the Chairman.  What was I waiting for it was fantastic.
author: Susan P.

description:
It never occurred to me that I would like pork belly, but it was amazing. The braised pork is also good. The chicken was decent.

Make sure to get the steamed buns; they are the same type of buns used in peking duck and are delicious.

It was so good, I am almost ready to embrace Communism.
author: Bruce G.

description: This food truck appeared during one of my visits to Off the Grid (Thursday near the Berkeley campus on Haste).  The pork belly burger was delicious: the pork belly was tender, moist, and the fat oozed out of it.  The wonton chips went well as a side to the burger, although I wish they had more flavor (a sauce, perhaps).  However, everything can get pricey at around $11 considering their small portions.  To get full off of their food, you would probably have to order two of their main dishes for around $14, which is quite pricey considering it is not a full-fledged restaurant with waiter service.
author: Stanley H.

description: Ok am I trippin? I really don't get it. We stood in line for a good half an hour at Off the grid, I got the pork belly one and eh! it wasn't half an hour line awesome at all. Just don't get it. I rather have my duck bao with hoisin sauce and green onion at a Chinese restaurant :0p
author: Karen T.

description:
Great food and friendly! 
I was riding my bike home from work and I saw the truck parked out front of Cocomos but they hadn't opened yet. I asked and the guy running the truck (Giro i think) said to give him ten minutes so I talked to him for a bit about business and that I've heard great things about them. 

Pork Belly with Daikon: Meat was tender, flavorful and the daikon added 
some texture and color. 

Sesame Chicken: Chicken was delicious and the green onions and bok choy on top was a really good combo. 

Pulled Pork and slaw: Yummy 

All around good food, awesome service and attitude and a good concept.
author: Erik B.

description:
Dear Chairman Bao,
i love you, i love you, i love you!! I have been wanting to try you forever and there you were today at Civic Center-- just a 10 minute walk from my work. Your pork belly and duck steamed buns made both my mouth (teeth extractions have made stayed away from "hard foods") and tummy happy. Your mango matcha green tea slush was to die for. I'm going to save all my money up so you can cater my future wedding!
author: selina n.

description:
I don't care that there's over 175 reviews, I'm just agreeing with everyone!  Instant yummy-ness, instant happiness!

don't forget they have a sign saying 6 bun limit per customer!
author: Rebecca R.

description: I fell off the vegetarian wagon when Lilia brought pork belly buns to work...but it was worth it.  Pork belly is so flavorful.....
author: Wakako U.

description:
I was riding my bike through Potrero today and lo and behold I spotted the red Chairman Bao Truck parked on Arkansas with NO LINES.  I know there has been a lot of buzz about the Baos and the lines usually meander with hungry food truck foodies.  So of course I had to stop and try the pork belly bao with pickled daikons.  It was a bit pricey at $3.75 for a small steamed bao...but I must say it was mighty good and quite addictive.  The pork belly was slow-cooked with a hint of hoisin sauce and the pickled daikon slices added a little crunch.  I can see why people love them!

This reminds me of the succulent Peking Duck at Hong Kong Lounge, which they serve with warm little bun pockets, scallions and hoisin sauce.  You can stuff yourself silly with a whole plate of them buns!
author: Lis A.

description: Delicious! I am kind of shy to trying new things, but after my friend took me to off the grid, I fell in love with this truck. I follow them on twitter just to know where there at. The steamed pork belly bun is so good, just melts in your mouth. I try to bring all my friends to it, and they have all loved it.
author: Maria H.

description: A relatively limited menu, but from what I've tasted they do it quite well.  I had the tofu "baked bun" (but really a burger).  Very tasty, well seasoned and textured tofu, with condiments on a baked bun.  Good textures, good flavor.  I had the seaweed wonton chips on the side.  Very tasty, but watch out, there's a lot of salt in there if you eat a whole bag.  Very different than any other food trucks in the area, and they do it well.
author: Eli R.

description:
I had a missed opportunity last month when arriving to Off the Grid late and all the trucks closing up shop. 2 weeks ago I finally had a chance to get some Chairman Bao in Emeryville.

I got myself the pulled pork steamed bun, my girlfriend got the same but with the baked bun.

The steamed was a better deal, the pork was great, but for an extra $3 for the baked bun ($6.75), I'll go with the steamed for $3.75.

I couldn't help but think of cooked duck with steam bun and hoisin sauce, something you can get from a restaurant. I think I must have hyped up Chairman Bao alittle too much because I ended up walking away telling myself that the price and experience could had been spent at another truck.

I will have to give this another try, but not quite sure if I will make a special trip for it...
author: Alen K.

description: Still pretty good, but I've noticed a drop off in the product.  The last few visits the pork was a bit dry, and the buns were overall too wet.
author: Nellie N.

description:
The pork belly here is really really good. Once in a while I get a craving for  pork belly, and now I know where to go. The baked ones are better than the steamed ones imho. The baked ones are easier to get the whole thing into your hand and get all the flavors into your mouth at the same time. The steamed ones, the few ones I had the buns fell apart and I had to end up using a fork. Very. yummy. pork belly.

The shaved ice drinks are also quite good, better than Verde. It's not nearly as sweet as Verde and definitely hits the spot.

Try the pork belly!
author: Cyn W.

description: Pork Belly baked is insane! Loved the garlic tofu steamed :)
author: Justin H.

description:
Tasty treats that will hit your wallet.  I love food trucks for the fact that the food is good, quick and relatively cheap.  Chairman Bao takes care of two of those criteria.  

I had the Pork Belly baked bun.  Definitely very tasty but was overpriced for the portion provided.  

I'd have to have a definite urge to go back at these prices.
author: gareth l.

description:
the food is good. and usually the service is great. but today there was a girl i havent seen in previous visits. she took my money. i waited for food. looks like
they were very behind cuz orders were coming out slow. then i saw same lady making food with the other guys. then she boxed and called my order. i hate when cashier handles money and then touch the food. i threw my order away. if they cannot understand simple cleanliness then no clue how clean other area are kept.  i wont be coming back.
author: Shontai C.

description:
This was everyones recommended truck at Off the Grid and the line was so long and we ordered both kinds of their buns....not at all that great.

*Steamed buns:  it's a smaller bun and it has a good sauce.  
*Baked buns:  It's a much larger bun but it has a dry texture.  

Overall, not sure what the fuss was all about.  They have a huge following which is great, but it's not worth the long line that they have.  The line just seemed to be long because it takes a long time to make them!
author: Dianne G.

description:
Tried them out at the Eat Real festival in Oakland.  They had a super-long line for most of the day, but it quieted down later in the afternoon.

I had the pork belly steamed bun.  I wasn't crazy about the pickled veggies (daikon?) but I loved the pork belly and sauce.  It was definitely one of the better items we had at the food fest.  Wish they would go to the south or east bay.
author: Arlene M.

description: Can not wait to get some steamed buns at the Larkspur Ferry Terminal on Thursdays.  This food truck rocks!
author: Jm B.

description: I went to civic center this Friday to try their  bun.  Ordered pork belly & their new spicy chicken on steam bun since my friend highly recommended their spicy chicken(new on menu).  Not bad.  The pork belly was very tender but I was expecting something more similar to traditional twice cook pork belly instead of the glossy sauce on top.  For the spicy chicken, it tastes like Tex-Mex chicken without oregano in the seasoning.   Bring ur own napkins because none of the food trucks there provide napkins.  I walked to the library to wash my greasy hands afterwards.  If the mango duck is back on the menu, I will go back to try again.
author: Ada C.

description: Each protein has a distinct, well seasoned flavor (chicken can be pretty spicy!) And the choice of breads is fun and changes the character of each sandwich. If you're just sampling, go for the steamed bread. Baked bread is larger serving and heartier.
author: Alexander J.

description: Ohh Yes, These are Good!! The Coca-Cola Pork with finely shredded savoy cabbage with mustard seeds on a soft fluffy bun is a magical combination that would make a 1st Class Hong Kong Chef Proud! Hype or not, I was finally happy to try this food truck after miss opportunity one after another until now.  I can say this luscious 'Bao' beats a fine dim-sum house anywhere in the Bay Area.......two thumbs up!
author: Wolfy W.

description:
I heart Chairman Bao! I first tried them at Off the Grid.  Oh wait, that's the only time I've tried them.  I'd heard lots of good things and it had the longest line, so we got some tacos from Kung Fu Tacos and ate while we stood in line for Chairman Bao.  It took maybe 10-15 minutes since we had gotten there fairly early.  I ordered the Red Sesame Chicken w/ Scallion & Bok Choy steamed bao and the Duck Confit w/ Mango Salad steamed bao.  I went for the steamed bao because it was cheaper than the baked bao at $2.75.  I could get baos so much cheaper in Chinatown or Clement Street or on Irving Street.  But I had to try these baos.  

My favorite was definitely the Red Sesame Chicken one.  Oh so good!  Not something I'd eat all the time because I'd go broke.  You don't get filled up just ordering two baos, so you have to order more food and at those prices, it really adds up.

Ending.  Food good.  Price not so good.
author: Kris L.

description:
I biked over to their stop in SOMA at 1.39. Much to my chagrin, they had closed at 1.30 and were already packing up for their next location. When I approached the window to confirm my fears, Ray (one of the owners) came out and offered to make me a tofu bun because they hadn't put it away yet.

It came out seconds later, yummy, drippy, and delicious. And when I offered to pay, he refused to take my money because he couldn't offer me a full choice of menu options. 

Loyalty for ever.
author: P Z.

description:
The first time I had Chariman Bao was at the Superhero Street Fair last summer. With a cape on my back and several strong cocktails in my system, these yummy little bao-inspired tacos hit the spot in the best possible way. Did the memory hold up to my mid-week lunchtime experience a few months later?

Yes and no. I had three of those little tacos -- and I say "tacos" because that's basically what they are, yummy fillings served on top a round piece of steamed bread, and "little" because for $3.50 and $3.75 a pop, they are easy to finish in three bites. Flavorful, but with sobriety, it just seems a little on the expensive side. 

The pork belly and daikon is a great flavor combination, but the pork belly was not as tender as I was expecting. The duck confit packed a lot of spicy heat, and the tender greasy meat paired well with the mango. The sesame chicken felt meaty and substantial and the sesame flavor mixed well with the sauteed greens on top.

The next time I'm stumbling out of Bloodhound, I'll be happy to enjoy a bar-time snack with the Chairman.
author: Joel A.

description:
Chairman Bao Bun Truck has some awesome Bao. They arent the bao your thinking of when you think of Chinese Baos. Its not like your typical BBQ Pork Bun. I ran into this truck at the Civic Center when they showed the Giants game clincher there. (AND THEY WON THE WORLD SERIES!) 

Anyways, I had the Spicy Pork and the Garlic Chicken bun (I think thats the name) on a steamed bun. Total came out to be $6.50. Pretty dang expensive. But it was GOOD and my mom loved it. Wasnt really filling but it was REALLY GOOD.

Minus 1 star for the high prices! =(
author: Daniel S.

description:
I was dying to try the Infamous Chairman Bao Bun Truck. 

First off, being a design major I LOVE the art on the truck. Definite cool points there and that's not just because I love pandas. 

Pork Belly Steamed Bun. With Pickled Daikons and Chives. YUMMY! I love fatty pork belly and the steamed bun was really good as well. The flavors mixed really well together, the tanginess of the daikon was subdued by the fat of the pork and the sweetness of the bun. I'm looking forward to eating their food again!
author: Constance C.

description: Baked Coca Cola braised pork bun...  what just happened to me?  WOW.
author: Sara W.

description: I LOVE THIS TRUCK! Best food truck ever. I get excited and have to stop whenever I see them. The pork belly is the stuff dreams are made off! I walk by the Soma Streatfood park and have to stop if I see this truck there. Seriously the best ever.
author: Jill T.

description: I bee-lined it to the truck when I saw it at the North Beach Farmer's Market to put in my order for the coca cola braised pork on a baked bun.  I don't even like pork!  I had tried it on the reference of a co-worker and thought it was amazing.  The only drawback is the price ($6.75)--too expensive to order two, although I could easily eat that much.
author: Jamie D.

description: Very yummy! I got the steamed bun as opposed to the baked one because it's 2 dollars less, but it's half the size also. There are different options but finally decided on the spicy chicken, which has pickled carrots, and cilantro all inside of steamed (open) bun, what a delight! My second time here and I haven't been disappointed yet.
author: Brandi W.

description:
I was pleasantly surprised to find one of SF's food trucks that I'd yet to track down parked a block away from my apartment this morning. I'll admit it wasn't the highest mobile cart on my (long) list because there are lots of stationary Chinese restaurants and Chairman Bao didn't sound too unique.

I was wrong. As the name implies, Chairman Bao Bun Truck specializes in steamed and baked buns that are not your standard Chinese food fare. The steamed buns looked similar to the ones you might find at a Dim Sum place that I'd never been a big fan of, so I went with the Spicy Red Sesame Chicken baked bun with bok choy. It was delish! It was somewhat spicy (a good thing in my book) and the chicken was well spiced. I'm not a huge fan of bok choy but the chicken was dominant in the bun and the bok choy complemented it nicely.

The baked bun is enough for a small lunch, I would add on a steamed bun (which is smaller and cheaper) to make a complete meal. I hope they have the duck confit bun next time!
author: Adam B.

description: I've eaten from this truck twice and it was awesome both times! What puts it over the top for me are the marinated veggies which are included in each bun, they're really flavorful, crunchy and go wonderfully with the flavor of the meat. I'm a creature of habit so both times I had the pork belly and the spicy chicken. The spicy chicken is good but I would not say amazing (although the marinated carrot is yummy), the pork belly is perfection! I've had both the steamed bun and the baked bun and liked each one. The baked is quite a bit larger than the steamed which I did not fully realize, I think next time two steamed buns or one baked bun will be a good portion size.
author: Sofia S.

description: Pork belly and pickled daikon, pulled pork and mustard greens + mustard seeds. Bun was correct, soft and structurally sound, dry and hand friendly. Attractively "plated" and the right ratios of everything. Put the other fancy pork buns I've had (momofuku, spice kit) to shame. I'm still not used to truck food not being cheap food.
author: Michael F.

description: You know what I'm not really gonna say much about this place cuz the food does the talking. Its soo good.. Pork belly Bao get it.. Try it and love it!
author: Carl T.

description: My favorite food truck in the bay area so far!  I love Chairman Bao, I go almost once every week because i love it so much. Steamed Pork Belly and Steamed Chicken are my favorites!  It may be a long line- but it's totally worth the wait!
author: Food E.

description:
Baked is $5.95. Steamed is 2.95. We went for steamed for all of us.

Got a whole bunch for a group of us, but I had:
Duck
Pork Belly
Pulled pork

Liked the last two. For me, the description for first one was getting a bun, adding some duck, and sauce from the fridge. Seemed very basic.

Drink: Lychee ginger. I twas interesting...Was able to drink and it tasted more and more like lychee, since that was at the top and it slowly went toward the straw at the bottom. Light ginger flavor. At first tasted like one of those Chinese dried plums in a plastic wrapper, then paper wrapper.
author: Anita C.

description:
ok, im notching it a bit up.

i CAN see myself buying a $6 bun. it is pretty dope. would i make this my goto lunch? no. would i seek it out and drive all over town for it? no. but i would buy a $6 bun when they are conviently parked at an OTF stop. 

my fatassness proved me wrong.
author: Euge L.

description:
I've been dying to try the infamous "Chairman Bao Bun Truck" and unfortunately the hype probably created too high of standards for me.

I've only tried the pork belly steamed and baked bun (boo they were all out of the duck when I went) and for the the size, the food was overpriced (let's not forget, it's a food truck and their overhead must be low).  

Don't get me wrong, the pork was well-seasoned and not too salty, and I loved the crunch and flavor the pickled daikon gave it, but it's still just meat fat on buns.  The bao bun truck is generous on bun to meat/fat ratio, but at the end of the day that much fat shouldn't cost that much. 

What I found delicious though was the $3.50 mango matcha green tea drink. Not too sweet and full of different colors and textures.  I highly recommend everyone to try these concoctions. I almost feel like these refreshments should be the truck's stronger selling point! 

That said, I'm glad I tried this truck and would probably eat the food again, minus having to wait the 20 minute for my pork fat on a bun combo.
author: Laura H.

description:
Baked is $5.95. Steamed is 2.95.

we got the steamed buns (white ones like the ones you get with peking duck), but now that i know, i wished i ordered the baked instead. the bun is bigger and looks super tender and i can only assume it means more filling too. next time, next time.

the duck and chicken were good but nothing revolutionary. the surprise winner was actually the tofu and garlic. Vegetarian, who would've thought? Yuuuuuum.
author: Lily L.

description:
I am a huge fan of food trucks, so when I heard they were down the street, I had to try it.  What I generally look forward to is yummy street food with cheap prices.  There were only 2 buns on the menu, so I tried the pork belly with daikon on a steamed bun for $3.75.  Imagine my disappointment when I opened the box to find a tiny little bun that was gone in about 4 bites.  I could have eaten 5 of them!  

The baked bun for $6.75 looked yummy and was the size of a good sized hamburger.  I would pay 7 bucks for a decent hamburger, so next time, I may give Chairman Bao a chance to redeem itself.  While the smaller pork belly steamed bun was very yummy and tender, it's definitely not worth the money.
author: ThirtyTwo P.

description:
Finally got a hold of some buns, wait...that just sounded funny but i like saying it! lol Anyways yea, finally got a hold of some buns at the Boobs4Food 1year anniversary party held at BloodHound as the Chairman was parked right outside. score, boo-yah! these were as good as i had heard from tweets and friends. Plus those working the truck were friendly and informative!

Got each of the following:
Steamed Tofu bun = Boom!
Steamed Chicken = Bip!
Steamed Pork Belly =  BAO!
author: Nick V.

description: Awesome flavors. I had the duck confit and pork belly steamed buns. The steamed buns are the same as you'd expect at a chinese restaurant or from the freezer case of a chinese market, but the fillings are amazing. The strawberry coconut drink was also really, really good.
author: Kevin L.

description: Chairman Bao!  We love Friday nights at Off the Grid and always make sure to stop at the Chairman truck (you'll find it by following the long line).  We favor the smaller steamed buns and would recommend the coca cola buns, spicy chicken, and then the miso tofu to cleanse your palette.  Enjoy!
author: Kim K.

description: This one is a knock-out. The food is great, with fresh ingredients and it's so flavorful. I didn't expect much out of a food truck at first but it totally knocked it out of the park in terms of flavor, food, and service. Not only that, now I got my family and friends hooked on those delicious spicy chicken steamed and they too claimed that they're now "addicted".
author: Ellie H.

description:
I'm loving how all these SF food trucks are slowly finding their way over to Emeryville. Ya'll know the East Bay needs some food truck love!!

The Garlic Tofu with Miso Greens was awesome. I love the flavor combination and the little steamed buns are cute. I also tried the Red Sesame Chicken with Scallions and Bok Choy. Very tasty!

Three buns filled me up, but I could have easily eaten four. $2.95 a pop, its not really cheap eats, but worth a try. 

I hope to see more food trucks in E-Ville. Especially since our lunch options around here are slim. Keep 'em coming!!
author: Joshua C.

description: I go ,I wait and I order a 'baked' spicy chicken and a 'baked' pork belly and I'm good to go .....be prepared to wait in line tho'
author: Carlos G.

description: Sad to hear that about the name controversy.  "Chairman Bao" is quite catchy.  Nonetheless... the buns are still tasty.  Crispy pork belly bun is SO delicious.  I only wish they were less pricey, I could eat at least 4 of them in one sitting!
author: Juliana S.

description: This is definitely one of my favorite food truck. I follow them around and try to go when they are nearby. I followed them to the Alamada antique fair this past weekend and a few weeks back, they were giving out free baos for one of the new start-ups at 3rd and market.  What a fun idea to use the Chairman to promote new biz or birthday party. First time I went, I couldn't decide what i wanted so I ordered one of everything on the menu. The steamed buns a about $3.25 or so and the baked buns are about $6+. I can't remember. When the food is so good, I don't think about price. My two favorites are the steamed pork belly and the spicy chicken. I prefer the steamed to the bake, but they are all great. The steamed are smaller so order 2. The baked are like the size of a regular hamburger. You'll just need one, but for you hungry guys, you might want 4 steamed and 2 baked.
author: Jay S.

description:
I had two of the steamed buns this evening....

Sliced pork belly with pickled Daikon...

The pickled daikon was over powering the pork and would have been better off if it was cut julienne style rather than sliced up.


Red Sesame chicken with scallions and bok choy....

Again the vegetables over powered. The scallions and bok choy gave it an odd taste, like the scallions and bok choy were over cooked.

 The flavors just don't jive quite right.

I also had the pineapple and salted caramel shaved ice drink. Would have been better if you could taste the caramel and salt.

I also don't understand why of all the food trucks at Off the Grid Fort Mason that Chairman Bao had a HUGE line...in fact the ONLY line. This was not really worth waiting almost 30 minutes for, especially considering that these guys opened up almost 20 minutes after Off the Grid officially started.
author: Leo V.

description: Last night I stopped by Edgewood Eats in Palo Alto. I ordered the chicken bun and it was so darn good!! Spicy chicken and pickled carrots on a warm soft bun $3 It was very very flavorful. I cant wait to try the rest!
author: Gina H.

description:
Chairman Bao was in San Ramon today! How cool is that ?? Finally it's about time that SR is getting hyped, after Pinkberry madness.

I added 1 additional star hoping that they will visit SR more frequently! Yes I agree with everyone here in east bay. San francisco, please share your awesome food with us.. Anyway their quality seem to improve, the duck confit and pork belly tasted better than before.. not to mention, the strawberry coconut slush is sooo refreshing!
author: Jazzleen H.

description:
Oh food trucks, you all are the reason why I am always broke. 

I love the design and concept behind this truck.... kinda bummed that I didn't come up with the idea first. Nonetheless, on to the review!

FOOD: 4 stars.  I have tried the tender Pork Belly, Crispy Tofu, Coca Cola Pork, and the Spicy Chicken (basically all except for the Duck Confit). For some reason the Duck Confit Bao is always sold out when I go to the truck, I blame being responsible and attending class. All of the options (for the most part) are delicious and the combinations are just genius! 
   -Crispy Miso Cured Tofu: MY FAVORITE! I am always on-and-off vegetarian, and this option is my go-to regardless of what kind of food-restrictions I have. 
   -Tender Pork Belly: MY other FAVORITE! The tender pork belly is what I wished bacon tasted like and the daikon's slight acidity cuts the some of the fatty qualities that pork belly has. 
   -Coca-Cola Braised Pork: It is like Asian carnitas. 
   -Spicy Chicken: Even though this is my least favorite, it does not mean they taste bad...I just prefer others. The spice level is mild, so it is suitable for most taste palettes. 
   For all the options, you can choose between baked or steamed buns; both have a soft & fluffy texture with a hint of sweetness. I recommend steamed, they are like....chubby tacos? 

PRICE: 4 stars. I feel so wrong thinking that The Chairman Truck is a tad overpriced since nothing on the menu is over $7. Steamed buns are $3.25- $3.75 and if I go food truck-ing on an empty stomach, I can't just order one... at least two... maybe three? These baos are no where near as inexpensive as a Chinese Bakery, but to some extent The Chairman's baos are worth it. 

Final Words: If you spot The Chairman Truck, do stop by and pick up a bao or two. I recommend the Crispy Tofu and/ or the Tender Pork Belly.
author: Thank Y.

description:
I have tried several of the offered buns and all of them have been great.
I have been going to the truck round up at Fort Mason and it has been terrific.
author: Leigh S.

description:
The walk (and the wait) was worth it!  Finally the star aligned where I was free to make a decent walk for lunch and the Chairman was kind enough to post itself within striking distance.

With a head full of anticipation and expectations, I walked nearly a mile and climbed a few steep blocks on California to reach Chairman Bao.  I decided to gorge and go for the baked bun combo meal + an extra steamed bun for variety.  This meant a baked bun with pork belly as well as a steamed bun with chicken.

The pork belly sandwich was great.  Keeping it simple, it went without any fancy sauce and stuck to the basics of pickled daikon along with fatty, yet flavorful slices of pork belly.  Nomalicious to say the least.

The red sesame chicken w/ scallion and bok choy can be likened to korean spicy chicken.  It had a similar flavor and crunch from the greens and was smothered in spicy sauce.  

The buns in itself were good and of high quality, assuming they were bought from a legit Chinese bakery.  To top it off, I had a lychee ginger shaved ice drink that was uber refreshing.  

4 very solid stars and the only reason it doesn't get 5 is because, for some reason, I just wasn't blown away.  This could be due to the high expectations or 2 months of anticipation, but it was simply very delicious, rather than amazing.  Need to revisit to give the duck a try and maybe it'll bump it up.
author: Jeff N.

description: Delicious! I love their combination of ingredients in their bao. Totally unexpected and yet delicious. Totally worth a try at least once!
author: Catherine T.

description: I recommend getting the steamed bun over the baked. The buns are nice and soft and the fillings have great flavor. There is usually a line but they move pretty fast. My two favorites are the Crispy Miso Tofu and the Pork Belly with Pickled Daikon.
author: Alice J.

description:
One of our go-to spots at Off the Grid. There's always a line but we've never had to wait more than 5-10 minutes, and your food comes fast after ordering.

My personal faves are the pork belly and tofu. Both are very flavorful and the steamed buns are just the right size.
author: Cyndi L.

description: Love this place! Get the steamed buns...don't even mess with the other items.
author: Rick P.

description:
pork belly bao - that's all you need to know. their tofu is really good, too, but the pork belly rules. last year, they offered duck confit, but i wasn't able to try it. (they always ran out before i reached the window.) you get a choice between baked or steamed bao. both are good, but i prefer the baked.

please bring back the bao chips. those are super addicting!

great t-shirts - i always get complimented on mine.
author: Sasha R.

description: The baos are excellent! I've tried all the different flavors but pork belly is my favorite. I don't usually eat at food trucks but Chairman Bao has me stalking him all over the city.
author: Nori L.

description:
Umami! Oooh, mami! 

Sweet and flavorful and unexpected marriage of flavors and textures, in the charmingly post-apocalyptic industrial wasteland environment that only a randomly parked lunch truck can provide. 

The pork belly bun was phe-phrakin-nomenal. Tender, juicy, succulent. 

The sesame chicken bun was good but more ordinary. It met my expectations and pleased me but didn't provide any surprises. 

The fresh pineapple salted caramel slushie bubble tea was a delightful exclamation point to end the meal. 

The food was all rich, but the portions were small, so I felt fine eating everything. $9 for the whole shebang. 

Cute truck, too!
author: Melinda K.

description:
This is hands down one of my favorite Food Trucks. Its fast, and tasty. Had the Pork Belly, Chicken, and Duck. The steam buns are like a soft taco and the baked buns are like a small burger. I definitely prefer the baked buns, but not sure if its worth the extra $3. 

My favorite is getting baked buns with Pork Belly and Chicken. The green onions, spice and celery with the chicken are so awesome.
author: Chris C.

description:
Amazing concept.  It's a deconstructed traditional steamed chinese bun.  Love it.

I had pork belly (my favorite) and the chicken (eh).  My vegetarian friend had the fried tofu and was kind enough to let me try a bite.  That was pretty fantastic too, but I'm surprised they don't have a vegetable-based vegetarian option.

I seek out this cart from now on.
author: Alyssa W.

description: I travel to find this truck rain or shine! I drive an hour (sometimes more!) cross two bridges, wait in traffic, lines and fight for parking when I get there. ALLL worth it!
author: Austin S.

description: Coke braised pork baos!   That is all...kidding!   Love everything on the menu and those baos in particular easily made it to the top of my list after taking my first bite of one during off the grid at fort mason a while back.  Recommend to everyone!
author: Dominic Y.

description: Really enjoyed the steamed buns here! I tried the braised pork, spicy chicken and pork belly. All three were excellent, very succulent with interesting fusion-y flavors that I wasn't expecting. I really wanted to try the duck but they were out, definitely going back to try it.
author: Ely L.

description:
Imagine my surprise when Chairman Bao was parked out in front of Munroe Motors this past Saturday. I had gone to MM to pick up some parts for my Triumph and the clerk was damn near inhaling his steamed bun.

"Damn, that looks good," I said.

He just looked at me with glazed eyes and nodded an emphatic yes.

I picked up my parts and since we hadn't eaten we decided to go for it.

Duck Confit Bao filled my peckish needs so well that I stood in line a second time to try other offerings. My girlfriend and I were craving burgers so we didn't fill up and as it turns out we should have. Because the burgers were lame (see the Bistro Burger review).

I'm really digging the food truck craze that is sweeping the Bay Area (and the country). 

Chairman Bao truck is a winner.
author: Michael D.

description:
I've eaten at this truck a couple of times and really have no plans not to keep going back on a regular basis. This would be a 3.25 rating if possible Why the lower rating then? Only because some items miss the mark a bit due to just a bit too much grease and the drinks are a little too sweet for my taste. The baked buns are simply not worth the price and actually hurt the meal in my opinion. However some of the dishes, especially w/ the steamed buns are palette perfect!

The combos complement each other really well. pork belly with pickled is good, but very greasy. The duck confit w/ mango is amazing! Stick with steamed buns, it's half the price and minus the serious grease intake.
author: Nick V.

description: I really liked the food here. There is just one catch. After eating here, I got hives all over my stomach and back and it lasted for 2 weeks. I am allergic to MSG, so we asked the next time we saw the truck if they used MSG. They said no, it is just in the sauce (so, um, that's a "yes"). There you go.
author: sarah m.

description:
I've been stopping by the Off The Grid Friday lunches at Civic Center the last 3 weeks and have tried food from at least 1 food truck each time and I have to say this is my favorite so far.  As far as menu choices go, they have the least to offer yesterday.  They have the pork belly or chicken served either on steamed or baked bun.  I ended up ordering both the pork and chicken on baked bun, feeling somewhat foolish for paying $6 each for a bun.  But when I got back to the office and saw how much food each order contained, I was somewhat mollified.  One bite of the pork belly bun turned me around completely.  Everything complemented one another:  the perfectly shredded cabbage, the succulent pork, the magical sauce, the sturdy bun.  I was stuffed after one bun so I had the chicken bun for dinner.  Surprisingly, the bun did not become soggy as I have feared.  The chicken was still delicious even after it's been sitting around for 6 hrs.  

I hope they are selected for "The Great Food Truck Race" that they are lobbying the network for.  I know they will be tough to beat!
author: Yvette F.

description:
The foood was really tasty and flavorful, each flavor was distinct and added well to the bun. I had a steam bun with pork belly and marinated daikon. Pretty delicious.- cost ~3 bucks after tax.

I also had the larger Baked Bun with Lionshead meatballs. That was tasty as well, but i definitely had better Lionshead Meatballs. 

They don't make their own bread though, they buy it from somewhere else.

Overall- kinda pricy for what you get, but the flavors were exquisite.
author: Wayne H.

description:
Went here today for lunch because they had a special at Bishop Ranch in San Ramon....I was soo excited to try them I made my dad come with us so that I could have more variety :) 

We got all steamed baos; pork belly, chicken and 2 ducks. My co-workers got chicken and pulled pork. And OMG sooo good....the chicken and pulled pork are some what spicy, but soo tasty they said! Chicken had like kim-chee pickled veggies, the duck had a mango sauce and the pulled pork had pickled daikon. ALL were delcious, the only problem was that my dad was still hungry after we shared 4 of them. Haha, but he's a big eater. I wish there was a place like this around San Ramon, cuz' i would go there often! Ooh yea, each bao is around $3 each, so pretty reasonable. Plus we got a discount cuz we work in bishop ranch. Chairman Bao, come to San Ramon more often...but only during work week lunch hours please..haha
author: Michelle Y.

description:
it is good!

the pork bao is delicious!  I'm glad I didn't have to line up to get it (but the folks who I had asked to line up for me waited a considerable time).  A bit pricey ($3.75/bao, $3.25 for others) but.. WOW.  so good.  I suppose the high price ought to help me with portion control, but I couldn't help it and went down an hour later (not much of a line) and ordered another braised pork bao with the mustard seeds and cabbage and the spicy chicken with pickled carrots.  MAN these BAOS are bout it bout it!

=8)
author: Grace M.

description: What is small, melts in your mouth, and full of flavor? M&Ms..........and The Chairman's pork belly steamed bun.  This truck gives you the fattiest meat you will ever have in your life, depending on whether or not you live long enough before your arteries clog up.  For something you can finish in two bites, I think 3.25$ is kinda expensive.  However, the pork belly is good and definitely worth coming back for.
author: Andrew V.

description:
this is about what i expect of food trucks now-a-days, fusion-y "weird" food filled with a lot of hype. at least with the chairman, the prices, at $3.75 for a steamed bun with pork/chicken/tofu and $6.75 for a bigger baked bun, aren't too bad. 

but in terms of taste, it was just mediocre and rather bland--the descriptions were more flavorful and robust than the actual food. and yes, they are small.
author: Melissa N.

description:
My friend Sing, Kevin and I enjoyed Chairman Bao for the first time at the Civic Center Off the Grid one misty Friday afternoon. Given the food is coming off a truck, this food is pretty yum. Service is good too. One lady walked up and down the line to make sure everyone knew what was on the menu, how to order and made sure everyone's questions were answered before getting to the front and creating a stand still.

I had their Miso Tofu bun with their Mango Green Tea and I was definitely pleasantly pleased. The miso tofu wasn't fried too deep and the slightly pickled baby bak choi was the perfect filling for the perfectly steamed yummy gua bao. YUM. I *heart* gua bao.

The only reason they aren't getting a perfect 5 is b/c I want more vegetarian options...otherwise, I'm happy and could live with this one Tofu option for a while longer. Can't wait for the next encounter with the Chairman. =0)
author: Nicky W.

description: I'd heard this truck was very good, so I made it a point to try it out when I went to off the grid this past Friday. The line was long the whole night, but when I finally went over and waited in it, near the end of the night, it moved really quickly. A couple friends and I each got the baked buns, one got tofu, the other and I both got chicken. It was tasty, sort of the tastes of a banh mi, but in a different format. It's a little bun sandwich. Nice and filling too.  The other selections were something cooked in cocacola (I don't drink soda) and a pork belly one, which my friend told me not to get cuz it's basically just softer bacon fat. Ew. I would probably go back, and try the steamed ones, which are smaller (I was hungry so I didn't get that) because it seems to be their more famous thing, in retrospect.
author: Merredith L.

description:
Fun fact: There never was a person called Chairman Bao. 

I've been to this food truck many times, both when it came to work and at Off the Grid at Fort Mason.

This isn't your grandmother's bao, it's served more like a crazy little steamed burger. The fillings always seem to be changing, but all have been so delicious as to make me question democracy. 

For a while, they offered a combo of two buns and a delicious blended ice drink for $9. I'm not sure if they do this anymore, especially during winter.

My only complaint is that the portions are small AND overpriced. This doesn't seem to be hurting their business much, but it is just high enough for me not to get in line when their truck rolls around.
author: Nik D.

description:
So I checked these guys out, and man are those buns delicous. Ive only had the steamed buns, but I tried the pork belly, pulled pork, duck and tofu. The Pork belly is king, with the duck as runner up. 4 buns is overkill, and 3 would have been enough, but I couldnt let any of them go to waste! 

The tofu was a little bland, but crispy. I only got it cuz I read good reviews about it, but I wouldnt order it again with such great choices as the pork belly. I plan on hitting this truck up again this week, I cant get the pork belly off my mind!
author: Steve S.

description: If you go to Clement St., buy some Chinese BBQ and a bao from from the dim sum ladies, and you can make a much tastier version of their offerings for 1/4 the price.  In the meantime, it's interesting to see the yuppie/hipsterfication of Chinese food for a change.  Not really a good thing, but interesting none the less.
author: Jim S.

description:
strolled on by in emeryville about 10 mins before the truck was to close down and they kindly took my order even though you know most places are rushing you off by this time.

honestly i ended up here because ms. wally's cafe had a sign on their door last week that left customers out due to a family emergency/car accident.  i remembered that chairman bao does it's mondays in eville so i quickly yelped and twittered and saw that they were in fact stationed in eville about 7 blocks away.  i then set my sights on these mysterious baos that my friend has been telling me about.

i wanted to sample the pork belly and duck confit but they ran out of the pork belly so i had the duck confit on a steamed bun, also because they ran out of the baked buns [understandable since i showed up way past opening].  i also ordered a pineapple slush.  the total for 2 duck confit buns and the pineapple slush were about $9 + $1 tip.  not too shabby for a quick lunch.

the baos are slider size so for a big eater, you may need 4-5 in order for your stomach to agree that it's happy.  i really liked the sauce that they drizzled all over the bao and i know this because it got all over my dress while i was scarfing these buns down in my car [i couldn't wait to get back to my office].  the pineapple slush was definitely refreshing and tasty although i'm not sure if it'll be something i'll order regularly.

the woman i took the order from was also very helpful and kind.  once i try some of the other baos, i'll be back for an updated review.

ps - you can't miss the chairman bao truck - it's like a big red short bus :]
author: J K.

description: Boo. I love the Chairman but went today at Hiller Museum and the baked bun was significantly smaller and way less filling. I hope this was an off day, and not that they are shrinking the size for the same price. It was not nearly as flavorful as usual. All my co-workers said the same. Bah.
author: D R.

description:
i've just died and gone to pork belly heaven. okay, so maybe that doesn't sound so great, but this truck stop is a must.

no, really....you *have* to try this. RUN! ...don't walk when you see this food truck roll by. delicious little portions that aren't really so little. 

i had the pork belly as well as the tofu bun. both steamed. both very flavorful and ridiculously delicious. this has officially made my friday and started my weekend off right.
author: Tina N.

description:
I first saw the Chairman Bao truck at the Eat Real festival in Oakland. The line was so long that I didn't get a chance to check it out but I made a mental note that I wanted to check them out.

I then saw they were going to be near my work so i figured I would check them out.

Once the truck got to the location they didn't open up right away so we waited and waited and waited. I think it took about 45-50 minutes for them to finally open up and start taking orders. Which knocked some points off there.

I decided to have the Pork Belly Bun, Red Sesame Chicken and the Pineapple Salted Caramel drink.

I must say the buns were quite tasty but the Pineapple drink just tasted like Pineapple. I didn't taste any salt or caramel.

So overall it was an ok experience. I would try them again but I wasn't that impressed.
author: Noah B.

description: Loved the steamed buns here. I had the red sesame chicken and the tofu one too. Both were very flavorful. I was trying these bao's for the first time and I loved it. I am waiting when this truck will make a stop at the fidi truck stop again.
author: R P.

description: Short and to the point: I tried the pork belly with pickled daikon in a steamed bun. I was concerned that when I bit into the bun, the pork would all come out in one piece. I was mistaken. It was so tender that I had no issue achieving a clean bite. Add to that the freshness of the pickled daikon, made for a really good experience at Chairman Bao. It's not a surprise that this truck always has long lines wherever its parked.
author: Mark Y.

description: Founds this place at Fort Mason on their Off the Grid route, and we've been on a quest to find this place to eat there since. Finally we saw them on Castro street at the Gas station spot they occupy during the week. The Pork Belly was our favorite. I could eat these buns for the rest of my life and never get sick of them. These guys are the best!
author: Michael N.

description:
How can one imagine pork buns to be better than the authentic, traditional style? 

You'll just have to eat it to find out. 

Try the pork belly and the tofu. Eat the tofu first though 'cause you'll want the pork to be the last taste in your mouth.

Ohhhh sooo good...
author: L C.

description:
Had all 3 buns at the Oakland Eat Real Festival.  

All 3 were surprisingly good but the  Pork belly with daikon bun stood out as very good.

Now that chef Eric Rud has left, we'll have to see how Chairman Bao evolves..
author: Ellen H.

description: 3.5 stars.  I waited a long time so I ordered 3, even though I only needed one to share.  I got the baked pork belly bun and the steamed vegetarian, which was fried tofu with greens, and the steamed spicy chicken.  They were all pretty tasty, with the pork belly being the clear favorite, but I don't see myself waiting in a long line, or paying $3 to $6+, for it again.
author: Seong P.

description: Maybe because I was one of the stragglers banging on the food truck, at the close of the evening, when all the goods had already been pillaged, but my first experience at Chairman Truck left much to be desired.  I tried the pork belly and the pulled pork creations, but my buns were assembled sloppy with a random assortment of ingredients because there was a shortage on supplies.  The pork belly was tasty, but the salads that were thrown on top were conflicting to the palette.  Maybe next time, the right layers of flavor will be assembled for a more accurate reflection, but until that time, I can only recall a tasty meat morsel on a soggy bun with sloppy veggies.
author: Diane N.

description:
More like a 4.5 but WHOA. THIS TRUCK IS DAAAANK (as in delicious)!

So being quite acquainted with down-home Chinese food since I was little, I have some expectations for Chinese food. But these little baos of deliciousness are such a modern take on the Chinese classic steam baos! 

Usually a long wait, but I think it's worth it. My favorite is the pork belly with daikon! The pork belly is SO tasty and fatty and yummy and rich...perfect with the crunchy texture of the daikon! The duck confit with the slightly spicey mango sauce was good too but I can be a little wuss about spiciness (and it really wasn't all that spicey) so I think the pork belly one WINS! 

Next time I'll try the baked baos but apparently they're the size of the hamburger and whenever I eat these baos, I usually eat other stuff too. 

It's something you hafta try, whether you wanna or not!
author: Eryn K.

description:
Stopped by here during the Bayview Sunday Streets. I was craving some more local flavor, barbeque or something, but my companion was distracted by the freshly painted red van. He offered to pay, so I was down to try something new.
I guess these little sandwiches are like the Chinese White Castle? The fillings were very tasty, but I would have needed a few of them to avoid being left hungry. At $5.75/each, that's not going to happen.
Back to tacos for me!
author: Claire C.

description: Chairman Bao returned to SacTown for another visit, this time at the Pacific Rim Festival. Prices were higher compared to the Sactomofo ($3 for all steamed bao). A lil disappointed to pay $3.75 each this time but they were still yummy. Best part was that i didn't have to  stand in line for an hour!
author: Tina T.

description:
First time I ate here, I can truly say the idea was original and the food was great even the tofu. This could also be due to the fact it was the Sactomofo event where we waited for three hours in the sun. In my previous review, I had a gripe about how the prices were more at the event after I noticed the price menu that was posted on yelp. I took back my words and apologized after a chairman bao rep wrote back and explained that the prices were old and that they were unable to take down posted pictures on yelp. 

Returning yesterday for the Sactomofo 4 event, I decided to show my support by starting my food truck tour with you first instead of the much talked about Nom Nom truck. After waiting a much appreciated one hour only in line, my mind was made up and determined to get one of those pink boxes displayed on the pickup window. When I asked the girl from the order window how many comes in the pink box, I was told it depends on how much I order. Because of her reply, I ordered one of everything baked and steamed and then asked if that was enough to get me the pink box. Ecstatic from her sales pitch, she proudly confirmed that I would be one of the few to be "looking cool" walking around with their exclusive box. However, my food were packed in three plain dull beige looking boxes. When asked why it's not packed in the pink designed box, I was told that they don't "give those away" and that it was "bolted down". Frustrated, I told him I would not have ordered that much if I wasn't able to get the box and that I was told by the cashier girl that I would. Without an apology, his only response to me was "you wanted the box"? 

Talking about customer service. I don't know you do it up there in s.f. but our local food trucks appreciate the businesses they receive here in Sac. Food trucks cannot legally operate in Sacramento but us foodies show full support to the food truck industry largely due to their food and their appreciation to us patrons. For someone who is well respected in the industry such as yourself, it is shameful that you are using sleezy sales pitch to get more orders in. I expect lies from salespeople, but never thought a food truck would operate in the same way. The food may have been good the first time around, but the tasteless way how you handled it this time around left a bad taste. I should've demanded a refund and not even accept the food but out of respect for the event I said my peace and angrily accepted it walked away. My face may be covered on yelp but I wasn't being anonymous when I was yelling about ur lies in front of everyone. No food is worth a bad unapologetic service, especially from a small business owner.
author: Minh C.

description: If they had this food in the south it would be mobbed. This so reminds me of southern barbecue. The sweet and savory tastes reminds me of barbecue and cole slaw. It is sinfully delicious. Loved the steamed and baked bun. The pork belly will literally kill you but you'd feel like you were in heaven. Needless to say you could try the sesame chicken or the coca cola braised pork to save some calories. This is not for the diet conscious.
author: Vicki S.

description: Oh how I love thee.  I salivate just thinking of our delicious pork belly bun and steamers.  I will see you soon my dear.
author: Suz L.

description: thought it was just all hyped up, but seriously, worth every bite =)  had the five spice chicken steam bun and tofu steamed bun...YUUMMMMYYYYYYY for my tummy.  i can just imagine the pulled pork!  next try, the actual sandwiches.  these surely won't disappoint!!! oh and the wonton chips, a must buy!
author: Christine E.

description: I'm right in the middle for CBBT.  I was pretty excited to see them at OTG:  Upper Haight last Thursday after having missed them right outside my office at lunch time.  And so I didn't mind having to wait in line for the 15 or so minutes for the 2 buns I ordered.  But just like how some of their reviews are great and some are not, that's exactly what I experienced.  First off, I got a pork belly bun cuz my coworker said it was DEE-LICIOUS...and you know, it was pretty good.  It had lots of flavor and the toppings complimented each other.  The second bun I got was their St. Paddy's Day special made with pork shoulder.  I gotta say, I wasn't impressed.  In fact, I had buyer's remorse.  Haha.  Unlike the pork belly, the pork shoulder was dry and bland and was a poor comparison to the other I just had.    So yeah, take what you will from this review.  There's obviously other items on their menu, but in a situation like Off The Grid where there's a lot of people and several other choices and trucks to eat from, I doubt I'd line up again just for the one bao and I'd be wary of trying anything else unless I read a really good review about it.
author: Joe M.

description: Another winner at Off the Grid. These are really terrific buns. Full of flavor and creativity. I tried a veggie, a chicken, and a pork steamed bun and they were awesome. Rich sauce, marinated veggies, delicious protien.
author: Ivan L.

description: This is as good as it gets. Quite simply, if you have not had one of his steamed buns, you need to go out and find this truck. I had the pork belly with pickled daikon on a steamed bun. It is the best bang for your buck that you are likely to find.
author: Alex E.

description:
I walk out of The CIty Beer Store and theres the truck. From the other side of the street I had no idea what I was looking at. All I could tell was that it was a food truck and I was hungry. I ran across the street and much to my surprise it was a bun truck.

I was incredibly pleased. I had the duck bun (awesome), the pork belly bun (to die for), and half a chicken bun (good).

If you see this truck you should capitalize.
author: David Z.

description: Great tasting pork belly sandwiches! I preferred the steamed version over baked. A little pricey for the size..
author: Mary R.

description:
The first time I had the steamed Chairman Bao pork belly, I died because it's greatness. The combination of the Japanese pickled radish (Takuan) went perfectly with the hoisin and rich pork meat. Everything was just awesome. 

The second time I went, I got the baked bun as well as the steamed one. The baked one was too sweet, and by the time I got to the steamed one, I was pork bellied out forever. The dish is great in small amounts. DO NOT get more than you can eat. The steamed one is the size of a burger. 

It was nice knowing you Chairman, perhaps we shall meat again.
author: Shizuka L.

description: Must try food truck!!! Visited BECAUSE of the great reviews and glad to say I did. The corner of Castro and Market is a great location because of the nearby tables. The braised pork on the baked bum was scrumptious and my boyfriend had the pork belly... Equally delicious. I highly recommend it.
author: Terry S.

description:
Worth. the. wait.
I knew I would love the Chairman once I laid eyes on his panda face (Wow, sounds like the start to a bad romance novel).
Anyway, I finallyyy came across the Chairman at Off the Grid in Upper Haight. Luckily we beat the crowd and I tried both the steamed buns with pork belly and braised pork.
I'll be the first to admit that there is a lot of hype surrounding food trucks as a whole, but the first bite into the pork belly bun left a stupid, greasy smile on my face. It was melt-in-your-mouth tender and tasty. It matched perfectly with the fresh, fluffy bun and the crisp coleslaw/daikon. I didn't expect much as much for the braised pork, but it was equally as juicy and well-marinated. Pork is easily overcooked, but apparently the Chairman can avoid that. I was also very impressed that while both buns were similar in content, they were both very flavorful and different in their own way. You know that everything isn't just slathered on with the same sauce and thrown on the bun, but there is actual thought to the menu. Awesome.
The biggest downfall is that they are pricey for what they are. $3.75 for the steamed bun (essentially the kind that looks like a taco that goes with peking duck) and $6.00 for the baked bun (resembles a giant cha siu bao, I presume). 
But believe the hype and try it.
author: Jen T.

description:
Peking duck with scallions and hoisin sauce sandwiched in a palm size white bun is what love tastes like.  T'was my favorite dish back when I was in China at the tender age of 12 years old.  

Chairman Bao comes pretty close, lemme tell ya.  There they were, their grand truck in front of John Collins......and there I was: parked illegally in front of some garage with my mom waiting in the car.  

I ordered 4 little steamed buns since the white ones are my favorite.  I think there was some kind of spicy pork thing going on in one of them.  We also had fried tofu which had a tater tottish breading.  My one and only beau: the chef, says that the sauce really makes the fried tofu bun.  

I found one of the buns to be a little dried out and that's a no-candoski baby doll.

Tip of the day, Chairman, put the tapioca on top and pass me a spoon.
author: Margaret S.

description:
Actually 3.5 stars, but the awesome logo and truck design give this place that extra 0.5 star for these Yelp ratings.

I stopped by here recently, and had the Pulled Pork on a steamed bun, the Duck Confit on a baked bun, with the Strawberry Coconut shaved ice drink.  

The Pulled Pork had too much sauce (although the pork itself was fine).  Every bite needed some pork, otherwise the mouthful of sauce would've killed me.

The Duck Confit, on the other hand, was amazing.  Plenty of duck, not under-seasoned or overcooked, with the mango salad for a bit of a contrast (but there were only 3 slices of mango in my bun).  It was well portioned too, comparable to the size of a small-medium sandwich.  

The Strawberry Coconut drink was good, not too sweet, but there was just too much.  I got tired of it about 2/3 the way through, although by volume, it's worth the $3.50.  

Definitely worth checking out at least once--they do the whole "fusion" thing pretty well.  The food is on the pricier side, but come on, it's called "Chairman Bao."  You can't say that without a smirk.
author: Derrek C.

description: The baked Coca-Cola braised pork and the pork belly were really good.
author: Leah F.

description: I went to a food truck meet with some girlfriends in Palo Alto randomly and came across the Chairman first because it caught my eye.  I've got to say it was amazing!  I got the pork belly and tried some of my friend's chicken.  I wanted to go back and try the rest of their menu but it was getting late so I didn't get to.  I tried both pork belly and chicken on steamed buns and both were full of flavor and texture.  I'm not a fan of vinegar but the sweet, savory taste balanced some of their pickled goodness they put with each bun bite.  I'm following their next moves to catch them in their greatness again across the bay!
author: K. C.

description:
I've been stalking The Chairman on Twitter for quite some time now waiting him to park somewhere near my office in the Financial District. Today was my lucky day. I trekked up California street to try these amazing buns I'd heard so much about.

The choices: Steamed Bun Meal: 1 pulled pork, 1 red sesame chicken with a ginger lychee shaved ice drink for good measure.

The pulled pork was good, but not amazing-oh-my-god-I-need-to-go-back.

Then I tried the chicken. That sealed the deal! Perfect amount of spice and flavor. Combined with the cooling ginger and I was pretty much in heaven. In fact, it was so good, I'm considering the trek to Off The Grid tonight to have it again.

Twice in one day. That should say enough.
author: Jenn V.

description: Definitely get the BAKED pork belly bun - also on the 7x7 Big Eat list and so dang delicious!  You can skip most of the steamed buns, except maybe the veggie.  I'd rather have a steamed bun from Chinatown or spots along Clement for a fraction of the Chairman price.
author: Chad S.

description: Pork belly bun with pickled daikon = the most delicious thing I've had in a long time!  The pork is melt-in-your-mouth, and the pickled daikon adds the right amount of acid to cut through the fat.  I also tried the tofu with miso greens bun, which was pretty good but not anything close to the pork bun.  The lines are super long, though, especially at Off the Grid!  Come early or after the crowds have died down.
author: T T.

description:
I haven't had Chairman Bao in awhile but my nephew loves them and had a craving for their bao.  After todays experience, we can safely say he hates them now.  Why?

They've raised their prices and rid themselves of the combo meals.
Nearly $4 for steam bao now?!  $7 for a baked bao?!  Outrageous.
They no longer make my favourite and the good tea drinks are gone.
The small containers for hot sauce doesn't even have the correct size lid, you'd think that they should have noticed that when they bought it but nope.

They have a special soup for the holidays and it is terrible.  It's a spicy butternut miso soup.  If you have an honest hate and rage towards someone, give them the soup.  It's a sure way to let them know how much you hate them with this disgusting goop they call a soup.  The smell of it still haunts me.

If you happen to see the chairman bao food truck, you've been warned.
Try it at your own risk.
author: J H.

description: So, the steamed ones are the way to go! I really didn't like the baked pork belly bun, but the steamed buns are really a flavorful, sweet treat.
author: Olivia P.

description: Tried Bao's at Off the Grid at Fort Mason last night. I ordered the Garlic Tofu baked bun and my friend ordered the Sesame Chicken, Scallion, and Bok Choy baked bun. I opened my box and was very disappointed to see mayo on my tofu. I'm allergic to mayo (and it wasn't listed on the menu), so I was bummed, but my friend was sweet and traded his chicken for my tofu. He really enjoyed it! The chicken was very good also, although it was a tad spicy. I liked the crunchiness of the bok choy.
author: Megan C.

description: I came to San Fran. Looked up food trucks. And hunted these guys down because their truck looks amazing! But boy, their food is just as amazing! I ordered one of each buns and sat in Washington park and had a good long lunch. I liked their tofu bak choi one the most despite loving to eat meat. Def would love to come back to San Fran just for them.
author: Mannie W.

description: Yum. Tried the pork belly. So good. Perfect bun texture and moisture wise. Great savory taste.
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description:
Tried 2 of the steamed buns -- chicken and tofu. Both were delicious, though I wish I had tried the pork one, as well. 

Spicy chicken steamed bun: delicious, not too spicy; the bun complements the chicken quite well, and the sesame sauce was a nice touch.

Miso tofu steamed bun: definitely try this one, even if you don't like tofu -- doesn't taste much like tofu at all! Would be better if it had a little more heat, but they had sriracha for those who wanted some added spice!

Overall very good, and at a good price for trying a couple of the different kinds. Would definitely go back to try the others!
author: Formerly Picky Eater J.

description: The food was delicious. I had chicken and pork buns and loved them both. The service was also quick and prices were very reasonable.  My co-workers and I were all discussing how much we enjoyed the food. Awesome job guys!!
author: Shreya C.

description:
Always happy when Off the Grid is back in Alameda!  Today I sampled a couple of sliders from The Chairman.

I have to say that at $3.75 each these are comparatively teeny sliders.  Usually I'm good for a four bite min on a slider, but the two I ordered were gone in about two and a half.

First up, the Miso marinated 'crispy' tofu with bok choy.  The flavors of the tofu and bok choy were nice but not quite bold enough to stand out from the steamed bun.  Also the tofu wasn't very crispy, in fact it was only remotely crispy on one side.  So I had mostly bun with some bok choy and a tiny slice of tofu that was basically the same texture as the bun.  I think this could be really delicious if it were done properly.

Second, a spicy shredded chicken with a delicious crispy carrot relish.  The spiciness of this one held up well and was a great compliment to the sweet sticky bun.  Unfortunately the chicken was a bit gristly and also very tiny and gone in under three bites.

I think this truck has the potential to do some really good things but I probably won't be going back to them until I've sampled the other trucks.
author: A H.

description:
After following on Twitter and Recommendations from my Fellow SF peeps in the Financial District, I decided to try it out. Pork Belly Steamed is killer...loved it and wish I ordered more than one. Along with my first meal, I ordered the Chicken Baked Bun and liked it, but not as much as the steamed bun. 
Lunch was gone in about 30 seconds (gave half of my baked bun to my coworker). Delicious food for a truck and will try something new next time around. 
Portions are small for Steamed and massive for Baked...price should have warned me. Anyhow, great place, good food so far.
author: Sean P.

description: Chairman Bao is one of the main trucks I look forward to whenever I attend Off the Grid. The only downfall is how long the line always is, but believe me, it is worth the wait! I would recommend going with a few friends. One person can fall in this line, while everyone else gets food from different vendors, then they can all fall back in the bun line and eat while waiting. I can't get enough of the pork belly buns. They're so good! Soft, fluffy bun with a perfectly marinated hunk of fatty pork and tangy daikon radish = perfection :)
author: Krizia M.

description: In love with their veggi  steamed tofu gua bao buns...My mouth is watering while writing this review
author: A S.

description:
i think my expectations were much too high before experiencing this bao. 

waited in an amazingly long line. got the steamed braised pork belly. paid over 3 dollars. stared at the little bun. and ate it in a few bites. 

the meat was slightly dry and flavors didn't mix together too well. the sauce overpowered everything and there was too much shredded lettuce. maybe the baked buns are more worth it? but at $7 i feel like i can get a lot more food for that amount.

overall not wowed. boo i wanted to like the asiany truck
author: Priscilla D.

description: Pick anything and you wont' go wrong here.  I prefer the steamed buns which is a bit smaller but a bit cheaper so you can try the 4-5 different flavors they got going.  If you see Chaiman pull over and grab a quick bite.
author: Grant L.

description:
what is this a cupcake? 3.75 for a steamed bun?  a little expensive but the proof is in the pudd... bun? 

its actually EFFFFEEEEN delicious.  the pulled pork is tender as shit and the vegetable stuff on top compliments the meat well.  the steamed bun is also perfectly steamed to its chewy/soft ratio utilization.

my complaint is mostly about its price point. i dont know if its worth 3.75.  you need ATLEAST 2 of them . and im kind of a grazer.  i would have to assume most people can stuff their faces with 3. easy.   

i also dont eat pork belly.  especially when you can jiggle it like homer's belly.
author: Doug ..

description:
pork belly with daikon is a ok...nothing too fancy about it.

i tried the sesame chicken and its ok too, nothing really special or anything really catches my eyes or taste at this truck. 

BUT, my friends LOVES their food. to each their own
author: Cali L.

description: The pork belly bun with pickled daikon is absolutely insane! I could have eaten 5 of those things. Only problem is, it would have cost me $19.75 to do so. These things are not big, and downing 4-5 would not seem gluttonous to me, but therein lies the problem, the price. I would easily rate this five stars if I could only afford to fill up on them.
author: Matt S.

description: Not just your average cult of personality, this Chairman is quite literally a revolution in steamed bun addictiveness. If you had to get just one, go with the pork belly. If you had a second one, try the Chinese sausage. If your timing is right, you'll be able to enjoy yours while sipping on a beverage inside of Bloodhound.
author: Nish N.

description:
Pork belly steamed bun FTW.
TOFU steamed bun FTW.

Wow, after many times of visiting Chairman Bao, I finally decided to try a vegetarian option and the tofu is surprisingly good! The skin outside is lightly crisped to give it that texture you like. Each bun is about $4 so make sure you get at least 2.

Totally a fan. I love how the truck is always on 2nd/Folsom or theLunchBox parking lot. WIN.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Chairman Bao Bun Truck - Chairman Mao would be rolling over in his grave now if he knew that capitalism has won out and the likeness of his 'name' is being used for such a purpose as a food truck. 

With a budget of $10.00 in mind for my Food Truck adventure, I only had $4 remaining to spend after buying a BBQ Spicy Pork Rice Plate (w/ White Rice) from Seoul on Wheels for the bargain price of $6.00. Now what can I do with $4?!?! I could donate it to charity. I could buy 4 cans of soda. I could have gotten a side of kim-chee to go with my rice plate at Seoul on Wheels. But then I saw the big panda bear and decided to take a look at the menu, and I saw the bargain price of $3.75 for a pork belly taco! 

Within 2 minutes, I was served with a piping hot and tender pork belly, wedged between a bun with pickled daikon on top. The daikon gives a crunch that contrasts with the tenderness of the pork belly. Did I mention how tender the pork belly meat was? 

On the other hand, the bun was so small. It was probably half the size of a BBQ Pork bun you'd get at a Chinese dim sum place. Yes, yes I know, this is NOT a dim sum spot and we are NOT in Chinatown, but with a truck that clearly reminds you of China (red colors, a panda, a name resembling Mao Zedong) we cannot help but think we'd get some "Chinese" out of this joint i.e. cheap prices and big portions. 

Was it good? You betcha. Was it expensive? Although on a Yelping price range you would give it a single dollar sign ($), if I was to have a full lunch out of Chairman Bao's menu selection, I would probably be dropping at least $15. Mind you this is a food truck! 

But based on the quality ingredients and the taste/flavor, it is definitely worth a try. It was a great "snack" while I was waiting for my BBQ Rice Plate from the other truck. (I am going to stop plugging for that aforementioned food truck, if you want to learn more, type them into the yelp search box above). 

In any event, based on the quick and friendly service (+1 star), delicious food (+1 star), use of a panda as your logo (+1 star), and most importantly the funky ass name of "Chairman Bao" (+2 stars!!!), I would have given you a 5-star rating. But alas the small portion for my bun for the slightly premium price makes me have to deduct one star (-1 star). Therefore if my math is correct, that gives Chairman Bao a 4-star rating and I am pretty sure I will be back for more of that delicious pork belly.
author: Kevin L.

description:
bao = hugs & buns

the lines are crazy at OTG, so i was super excited when i found out that they go close to my work for lunch.

today, was my lucky day b/c chairman bao showed up in brisbane near walmart. com.  i had the pork belly in a steamed bao.  the pork was nice and juicy with a layer of crispy goodness in a soft chinese bun.  i wanted to try the baked bao, but they ran out.  

bao = hug in chinese and bao = bun in chinese, so when i see this truck i think of hugs & buns!
author: michele k.

description: Had a steamed bun (pork) and a baked bun (chicken) at 11am today. It's almost 6pm now and I'm still so full I don't think I'll eat again until breakfast. Amazing flavors, great prices. All I can think of is Yo Gabba Gabba: "There's a party in my tummy, so yummy, so yummy!"
author: Michael C.

description: Thankfully this truck braved the haters and came to DT Oakland. Best pork belly bao EVER.
author: Jorge H.

description:
if you love BBQ or Pork Belly, get ready for an orgasm.

if you don't enjoy Chairman Bao, you don't belong here.

if you think it's expensive, you're too damn cheap.

if you don't like my review, you can kiss my ass.

*best bao experience on the planet*
author: Bruce A.

description: I had the crispy garlic tofu steamed bun today and was less than impressed.  There was nothing wrong with the bun, taste wise, but it wasn't anything special either.  Luckily, I had no wait, so perhaps that's why there's two stars in my review rather than one.  The big problem with the bun was the price.  $3.25 for what was a two bite snack is nuts.  At $1.50, I'd probably give the bun a 3 or 4 star, so this rating is really more about the value than the quality of the food.  Also, perhaps the meat buns are better/worth the price.  So for an expensive snack that was just average in taste, I can't do better than two stars.
author: Jay L.

description: It was aite. I mean, I didn't expect real chinese buns or anything like that, but I thought it would be more interesting and a lot more flavorful. Maybe the tastes just didn't suit me. The pork and duck which I both tried tasted the same and the stuff that came with it like lettuce with mustard seeds or the red pickled onions were alright. I doused my buns with sriracha. It's definitely fusion and far from being anything Chinese. I knew it was fusion but I thought it would be an enhancement to the Chinese dish with more flavor but keeping close to the real thing.  All those korean bbq trucks are bomb because its based with good korean bbq just with an extra unique taste. These were totally off the wall combinations that almost tasted American just with Chinese meats. They weren't that tender either which I'd at least expect.
author: Stephanie H.

description: This is definitely one of my favorite food trucks in SF. I like the steamed buns better than the baked buns, however, they are a bit smaller so if you are hungry definitely get two. The Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso is yummy.
author: Natalia K.

description: The steamed pork belly bun was 5 * the first time i had it. Hot, crispy pork belly, nice acid from the onions and daikon. Today my buns were lukewarm and greasy and no crisp to the belly. Boo.
author: H Y.

description:
tofu bun and pork belly bun.....oh how u always satisfy me! just damn good!

The best thing bout Chairman Bao is that they really listen to their customers. I joined Twitter just to follow the food trucks and some celebs. I never tweet, but one day I was bored and I saw Chairman Bao tweet that they tried to go to Daly City, but something happened and they couldn't make it. So just for fun I told them you should come to Sales Force/Capcom in San Mateo because a few other food trucks go there too. They actually tweeted me back to say they were interested. (I thought it was all talk) After some tweets and trying to find some info for them of how to go to Capcom, just 2 weeks later they showed up by my work!!! HOW AWESOME!!!

U GUYS ROCK! COME BACK AGAIN!!!
author: Karen H.

description: I love it.  Pork belly small steamed baos with pickled daikon and onions is my absolute favorite.  I'm hungry just thinking about it.  Please come further down the peninsula!!!
author: Cassie H.

description: Thank you thank you thank you Chairman Bao for delighting my taste buds with my first ever steamed bun. Came by for OTG: Upper Haight and knew I had to get my hands on one of the crispy garlic tofu buns. This sucker was huge! It could have put some tacos to shame with the magnitude of the tofu filling. The bun itself was small and dainty but the crispy garlic-infused tofu cutlet was the size of a cell phone! It came loaded on top with fresh (collard?)greens that had been tossed in a miso dressing. The best part was the greens included the leaves AND the stems. It was messy to eat and I probably looked totally awesome wiping miso off my face after stuffing it with tofu, but it was so worth it. My only criticism is that there is only 1 veg bun, however when its that good I might be able to overlook the lack of options.
author: Cori W.

description: Hands down my favorite truck. Every time I go to OTG I look for them first. Try everything. Crispy tofu bun is my favorite.
