author: Maria Ton M.

description: OMG--loved the pork belly baked bun! Don't think too hard about it being pork belly--it is delicious!
author: Lucie W.

description: I never knew such splendor could come from food served out of a truck. I tried the duck and the pork belly buns - both were outstandingly delicious, but the pork belly one stole my heart. It was perfectly cooked and the bun was my ideal level of squish. The duck was really good too, but beware - very spicy.
author: Megan S.

description: Growing up and being native to San Francisco, we are fortunate enough to experience so many types of foods and my grandfather has been buying me steamed pork buns since I was in elementary school...anyway, I watch food network and I had heard of the food trucks in Civic Center and being that I worked near there I decided to walk over for lunch one day...GLAD I DID! I noticed the line for the Chairman Truck was longest so that is the way I decided where to go (follow the masses) and I was pleasantly surprised!  I ordered the braised pork and the shredded chicken in the steamed buns and they were fantastic!  I must say I liked the pork much better and I have been a fan ever since...I follow them on twitter and I have voted for them a few times as best food truck on foodnetwork.com! I really need to try one of the other trucks but if Chairman is there I just cant:(
author: Danielle W.

description:
tofu done right.   which, if you like tofu, is pretty tough to do.

the other buns are good, too.  the chicken is nice and spicy.  and the coke-a-cola pork is good. 

but right now i want more tofu bun.  yum yum yum.
author: Peter K.

description: Very good fatty pork bun but prepare to pay a premium
author: Brandon C.

description: The food is great. I always get the baked goods. It's so good, I buy extra for later in the day and the next day.
author: Jen H.

description: I heard the hype, so I had to try it.... and was pretty good.  Tried the pork belly and the spicy chicken, and they were both pretty tasty.  The steamed buns are very small, so if you have a good appetite, get the baked bun, it's larger.
author: Matt M.

description: I had three steamed ones, the garlic tofu was nice and crunchy  and it was some of the best tofu anything  I have had, the chicken was nice and juicy with scallions great flavors on every bite and the pork belly was nice and tender and perfect with the daikon, best deal on off the grid for flavor and taste. I can't wait to see them on off the grid again to try some grilled buns.
author: Chris D.

description:
Ate at this bun mobile two days in a row--first at the Willow Glen Moveable Feast (Curtner and Canoas Garden, Fridays 5-9 pm) and then the very next day I went to the Saratoga Ave. Moveable Feast (Saturdays 11-2, near Stevens Crk). I tried the pork belly in both the steamed bun and baked bun, and the coca cola braised pork in a steamed bun.
 The Pork belly is definitely delectable, and the neon yellow slices of pickled daikon provide a splash of color and cut some of the richness of the belly. The cola pork was just okay.
 I love Chinese steamed buns, but they're really best eaten right out of the bamboo steamer basket. They're like fluffy pillows when they're still warm. I'm not sure, but the texture and temperature of the Chairman's bao suggests to me the buns aren't being steamed on the truck, which is too bad or maybe that's good, cause otherwise I'd eat too many of them. The steamed bun costs $3.75 and is snack size. The baked bun is like a small sandwich and is $6.50. 
And this is the cutest truck and easy to spot--bright red with a panda.
author: Ann A.

description: We had the Chairman Bao truck at work for dinner this week, and it was pretty tasty. I ordered 2-each of the meat baos, so 6 in total. Work paid for them, but I would probably be appalled if I had to shell out the $20+ for those. The fried pork belly is the best one, and from what other people were saying, I should have gotten the tofu one as well. There's always next time.
author: Doug D.

description: I really wanted to like this truck especially after reading all the amzing reviews but must say.. it was just "OK."  I got the Baked Pork Belly with Pickledy Daikon and although the portion size was good.. the bun itself wasn't anything to write home about, to be honest it was a little salty.  I will try it again and try the steam bun but def will not be trying the baked bun again.
author: Susie S.

description:
i was surprised at the price--$5.75 for baked
then i saw $2.95 steamed, and tried 2 which made for a decent appetizer.  still quite expensive when you can get a tasty cha siu bao for much cheaper
*tender pork belly with pickled daikon -- excellent, esp. for a mobile truck thus the high rating.  moist bun, 2 large succulent pork belly strips complemented with daikon chunks
verdict: tasty.  closest thing to momofuku
chinese sausage with egg sandwich was too salty, hoisin a little overpowering
chinese spiced duck with fresh mango worked well
red sesame chicken with scallion was heavy red chili based
i think they should be one of the more successful trucks up here, though baked bun price may be pushing it...
ate here again, this time pork belly bun with yellow daikon slices -- still good
this time also tried Crispy Garlic Tofu with miso greens: not worth the price but ingredients fresh
they had a new item, Pulled Pork with Savoy Cabbage and Pickled Mustard Seeds (chopped up cabbage) -- tasted good.
this is my favorite bay area truck
prices have goneup -- steamed pork bun now 3.75 but still with the nice crisper edges and kakuni like stewed flavor.
author: Rob C.

description: The steamed buns remind me of Peking duck style buns from Chinese banquet dinners - buns with meat with some veggie dressings and sauce.  Maybe I've been spoiled by having Peking duck for as long as I can remember (Imagine: little Chinese boy with a big smile eating buns with both hands and getting sauce all over his face and clothes), but Chairman Bao's buns just aren't that special.  And at $3+ a pop, they're comparable (if not higher) in price to the Peking duck at Chinese banquet dinners.  The baked buns with fillings can be had for much cheaper at Chinese bakeries scattered throughout S.F.  Just gotta know where to find them.
author: Kevin W.

description: I'd give it 5 stars if they didn't pack the bao so fricken full.  Guys probably love the mass messy blob, but it is one messy mofo that gets soggy if you don't eat it immediately.  Next time I'll order plain buns to double the pleasure.
author: Melanie C.

description: The line was long but it moved pretty quickly.  The meat was good and also the toppings.  I would go back for more if I lived in San Francisco.
author: Wolf N.

description: Super flavorful and filling.  If you like spicy the Spicy Chicken with Toasted Sesame Purée, Pickled Carrots-Cucumber & Cilantro was delicious.
author: Gina T.

description: Using secret recipes from the Little Red Cookbook Chairman Bao is making the Great Culinary Leap Forward.
author: Greg A.

description: Chairman Bao is possibly my favorite food truck. They're pork buns make me want to do backflips. For just a few bucks, they serve you a slice of the most tender, perfectly cooked pork belly in a bun, topped off with pickled daikon. It literally does not get any better than that. Once you add to that an amazingly friendly staff and a great truck design, you have a home run. Try this truck if it is the only food truck you ever sample. It will leave you craving more.
author: Garrett P.

description: Cute concept. I've been wanting to try this for awhile. There's really nothing at all remotely Chinese about the food. Everything was too salty. There was way too much sauce and it looked like a mayonnaise base. Chinese don't do mayonnaise (with the exception of Honey Walnut Prawns.) I had the duck with mango and the crispy tofu. The mango topping was good. I wished the duck had more five spice. There may have been a little but it was barely detectable. I am glad to have tried it but it was a novelty I wouldn't bother to do again.
author: E. M.

description: By far my favorite food truck - EVER. I literally follow them wherever they go. I absolutely LOVE the coke a cola braised pork sandwiches, and could eat them every day. The service has always been great, and I highly recommend this truck.
author: G. Meshone L.

description: I have only had the coca cola braised pork buns and they were delish.  So, my hubby and I would treat ourselves to these at Belmont's off the grid once in a while.  That's the only thing I've ever ordered.  This review is mainly bad for the poor customer service.  We live in Redwood City and go to Belmont special for this Off the Grid.  On Monday, I picked up my very active 2 year old from daycare and headed to Off The Grid for this food truck.  Upon arrival, they were not open yet and there was one person in front of me.  She ordered and received her food before I even ordered. Keep in mind that I'm 6.5 months pregnant and it was boiling hot and I was with a cranky 2 year old.  It took almost 10 minutes before they took my order due to computer issues, which is fine.  I placed my order for the same thing we always get.  They gave it to me and I rushed back to my car to get home as my 2 year old was pretty restless at this point.  When I got home ready to eat. I saw that they gave me the wrong order.  So, my husband went back there to get a refund.  By the time he would have got home, it would be an hour later and being pregnant, I cannot wait that long to eat when I'm hungry or I'll get sick.  When my husband arrived there for the refund they were extremely rude to him and blamed me for ordering the wrong thing and for picking up someone else's order.  How could I pick up someone else's order when there was only one person in front of me and she already got her food?  And why would I place my order wrong when I've never ever ordered anything else from them.  Safe to say, we probably won't go there again due to customer service.  It's too bad.
author: Traci D.

description: Cute car and fun food here.   Luckily we had their food at OTG San Mateo when it was rainy so the lines were really short.  The pork belly was really yummy but I have to try the others too when I have a chance.
author: Durif M.

description:
after weeks of waiting, the chairman finally came to the FiDi on a day i could catch him. i made sure to get there early enough so that i wouldn't put myself at risk of missing out any food.  when it came time to order i got a number of the steamed bun and a shaved ice drink:

- pork belly w/ pickled daikon - best of the lot w/ the pork belly cooked very tenderly and w/ loads of flavor.  the daikon added some much needed texture and tasted good too.  highly recommended for anyone coming here.
- pulled pork w/ mustard seeds - OK with the pork being nice but not flavorful enough.
- spiced duck confit w/ mango salad - another highlight!  the spicy sauce worked well with the beautiful duck and the mango salad added a bit of acid to cut the richness.  good stuff!
- pineapple w/ salted caramel - great taste but i failed to find the salted caramel.  all i got was pineapple boba.  still tasty.

i definitely want to try out some of their baked buns next time around.  now that i know they come every other week to the location near work i will be able to try all the permutations possible!
author: Swarup B.

description: I would give the, 10 stars! Omg! Super good! Super flavorful, just melts in your mouth! I wish they had a sit down restaurant open 24 hr cuz I'd live there
author: m L.

description: Their pork belly steamed bun with daikon is really good, not filling at all. But for $3 in downtown SF, you don't expect it to be. I have to say I've had better crispy garlic tofu and will probably never get that again. I do plan on trying their braised pork in a baked bun which I have heard is delicious. And I can only hope that they will offer their duck confit in downtown SF in the food truck alley. Who knows, maybe that'll bump them up a star!
author: Analisa S.

description: Best food truck in the Bay - hands down. Don't come here without trying the pork belly bao. Only thing that sucks are the loooong lines, but there's a reason for those long lines - the amazing food at the end of it!
author: Melissa P.

description: Just had a pork belly w/ pickled daikon and it was superb.   I can see why there is usually a long line at prime time.  I went at 1:30 and there was very little wait.   I would definitely get that again, although I'm also looking forward to trying some others.
author: Rod C.

description:
ive been to my fair share of dim sum places in my life so when i heard that we were going to try this place, i was skeptical it was going to be another fusion place that falls short of promises and is selling bad chinese food.

i was wrong.  we ordered the chicken bun, which can be served on a hamburger bun or old school chinese bao and i was surprisingly satisfied with how they tasted and were presented.  pork belly bao was nice and tasty.  the crispy tofu needs more work though.  should be compressed a little dryer and fried more so that it is not so mushy and doesnt fall apart in the bun.

there were a few trucks lined up on the street, but this one had the longest line and fan appreciation.  

chairman truck continues the food truck tradition alive where it is about the food and making people happy.

i raise my little red book to chairman bao.
author: I Be E.

description: Got the chicken bun (small size). Was SUPER spicy, probably should be a warning somewhere. Was creative however and I heard good things about the pork belly bun.....and saw many coworkers chowing down on the different buns.....so looks like a hit overall. I will have to try the pork belly bun next time they are in South SF by my work!
author: Lee M.

description: I checked these guys out at off the grid. For like $3 and some change you get a steamed or baked ..taco? It's weird. Instead of the bun being stuffed and solidified, its sort of pre-steamed and wrapped. It's really good though. I sort of want to return just to try the baked variety. I had the pork belly and it's a taste of pure heaven. Now if only this truck would make it closer to work.  They seem to be located way way down Townsend as I usually see them when I am coming into the city on the train :( Oh well maybe more Off the Grid outings for me.
author: Greg G.

description:
recommendations:
-steamed Tender Pork Belly with Turmeric Pickled Daikon & Green Shiso
author: Way L.

description: This has to be one of my favorite food trucks in the city, the steamed buns are pure deliciousness!
author: Jon R.

description: I've found myself following these guys on twitter and riding my bike to their location if it's within 3 miles of me.  On top of that I've tried all their buns.  Bomb! Simply bomb!
author: Roger H.

description: Not that The Chairman needs another five star review, but what the heck.  I'm an avid no carb-er (as in bread is the devil in culinary form) and I have to admit, the steamed pork buns almost made my soul explode into a thousand glittering pieces of confetti and kittens. Or something like that. Seriously though, it's really that good and I wish I lived closer to the Bay.
author: Cokie B.

description: It pains me to give Chairman Bao one star.  After trying the bao at Momofuku and Baohaus in New York, the SF versions are falling flat.  First of all, the steamed buns are store bought.  Secondly, the fillings are not flavorful.  The pork belly was just unappetizing thin, chewy, gray slices of smoked bacon.  The egg and sausage, lions head meatballs, duck confit were just bad.  Especially the confit - the duck was bone dry and lacked any gamey flavor.  The only reason I am giving the Chairman a star is because the chicken bun with spinach and kim chee was tasty.
author: Monica L.

description: I feel bad for giving CMB three stars, but it was just okay for me. I think people hype this up to be too much. First off, I thought it'd be an actually bao, like the regular pork buns you get at dim sum places. They instead use the buns you wrap duck with at fancy Chinese banquets. The pork belly was good ... I'm just not sure if it'd be my first food truck choice.
author: Rosie W.

description: This food truck lives up to it;s rep for sure. Pork Belly baked bun is so good, I had to go back for secconds!
author: MysticZ T.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE!! The pork belly steamed buns are sooo good! Every time I go to any off the grid or food truck gathering, I always want to try a bunch of different things to get a mix of food. However, I CANT do that anymore, because every time I know the Chairman truck is there... I don't want anything else! If I do get something else... I wish I just got another pork belly bun!  :)
author: Meagan B.

description: I finally got back to the Chairman truck at 5th and Minna and I am so sorry I took a break from it. The buns were freakin' delicious! I love the pork belly . Tender, tasty and the garnishes. There's a slaw  that has mustard seeds and cabbage on the pork bun that is perfect in every way. Even their tofu is flavorful (hard to do). And the accompanying greens were fresh and perfectly cooked. Nothing mushy or overdone there. Sorry to have taken such a break from them but I will be back!
author: Sherry G.

description:
Mind. Blown.

I caught The Chairman (sporting its new name) today at SactoMoFo 5. Now, I haven't eaten a lot of pork belly, but I definitely know one thing. It's a damn good thing this is not a Sacramento-based truck. If it was, I would be getting a triple bypass within the next year or two.

In addition to the pork belly steamed bun, (can't fathom tackling the slightly larger baked version...) I put away a tofu steamed bun. I guess it was my attempt to counteract the godlike, sweet, delicious fat with something I guesstimated to be healthier. While I'm not sure my health logic was at all sound, (the tofu is grilled to the level of awesome) the tofu is probably a dark horse, and I feel it needs some props. It's not your run-of-the-mill tofu, because this has had some serious make out action with a grill after getting itself all sauced up. If I was a vegetarian, I would eat these for breakfast. And possibly those other meals as well. The bok choy is delicious, and the combination of sauces create notes of umami that take my brain into sushi-esque territory. (I could envision myself grabbing some of these suckers paired with a bottle of sake cloaked in a paper bag, running through the streets of The Bay like some kind of crazy gourmet gutter punk.)

So yeah, pork belly bun is deserving of all of its praise. It may *seem* a little dry at first, but the fact it's cloaked in heavenly fat is going to clear that right up. Get it on a steamed bun, as that will help also. Get several (they are cheap!) if you're going to gripe about size.

But... I have a feeling that every single bun this place produces is extraordinarily good. Your preference is probably simply a trivial opinion. This is gourmet level stuff from a freaking truck. No dress code, no reservations, none of that. But this stuff is every bit as legit. Seriously.
author: Russell R.

description: super tasty.  These guys came out to the TheatreWorks New Works festival in Palo Alto, and thank goodness! I tried 1 braised pork and 1 crispy garlic tofu. I appreciated the fact that they had vegitarian options. As a former vegie, and still grand fan of tofu, I like seeing who can do it right, and they certainly do!
author: Caddy M.

description: You guys better check on your employee. When i ask for a plastic bag, dont give me no attitude and lip about the saving the planet. Is your truck biofueled?? Wasup with the bandage over the eye? Did someone else stab you in the eye for giving them lip too? It's not like i ordered 1 bao and asked for a plastic bag, ok? I ordered 3. How about I take my business and friends' business somewhere else? You're lucky ur baos are good.
author: Jean T.

description: The pork belly sandwich... does not deserve 5 stars. It deserves 6. I thought I could just buy 1 of these and share... NO! Get yo own! You rocked Oakland last night!
author: Flip T.

description: Huge fan.  Tofu all the way but love all of it.
author: Doreen D.

description: Love the steamed buns from the Chairman.  The Pork belly buns with daikon are definitely worth any wait.  The pork belly melts in your mouth and is followed by the nice crunch of the daikon.  The buns are really good and not rubbery.  Also tried the spicy chicken bun which had a great flavor and a nice little kick.  Definitely, will visit them again.
author: Brandon M.

description: I LOVE Chairman Bao!!  Everything I've had there is delicious.  My husband loves the pork belly buns, and I like the tofu.  I'm so happy they come to Off the Grid on Friday nights!
author: Vero K.

description: They changed the owner, and it didn't taste the same anymore.  The one I had before was so much better.
author: Elena L.

description: Holy moly. The steam pork bao is AMAZING (both flavors). The combination of flavors is totally unique and wholly delicious. It's comforting, tasty, fresh, spicy, I want to say it has 'umami' because it's so good in such a different way that you have to use a fancy new word.
author: Klevin D.

description: I tried the braised pork steamed bun and pork belly on a steamed bun today. I thought it was going to be an actual bun with meat on the inside but more like a pita-type-thingy. Both were so freakin good! I cannot wait to eat these again mmmm.
author: John S.

description: Pork belly bun? Sounds gross and something I had to try.  Wow is the meat packed with flavor and perfectly crisp in all the right places.  The veggie topping and taco-esque bun were delicious too.   The chicken was almost as good.
author: Jordan F.

description: My friends and I have gone to many food truck events and The Chairman is always our favorite. It's the 1st truck that we always stop at. Their baked pork belly bun is to die for. Sometimes my kids would crave it and I'd drive out and order 5 or 6 for our dinner. As for the price its $6.75 each. Good food is hard to come by, so you can't put a value on that. Plus the portions are very reasonable. Keep up the good work guys...
author: Linh T.

description:
pork belly! need i say more? that's my favorite!!!! it's so good... fatty good!!! this is the pork belly with the steam bun! nom nom nom

this is so good... wish they were in fidi for lunch everyday... =T  

oh well... check them out at off the grid at fort mason... get there early or there will be HUGE line!! 

PORK BELLY!!!
author: Kelly H.

description: One of the best food trucks, and the baos are delicious!!!!  I usually get two steamed boas, one pork and one tofu.  The pork is rich, flavorful, with a touch of tartness from the pickled dikon. The tofu is light and fresh yet gives a light meatiness without meat.  This is food truck food at its best!!!!
author: Miranda m.

description: Sampled the pork belly, pulled pork, and sesame chicken buns.  All were very tasty.  The chicken with marinated carrots was the favorite and most flavorful, but I'd go for any of them again.  Friendly and fast service tonight at Off the Grid San Mateo.
author: John K.

description:
Really, really, good. The lightest, fluffiest dumplings I have ever experienced - and the fillings are all absolutely yummy. A great starter experience is the combo of steamed buns #1 and #3 (pork belly, chicken) - perfect taste, perfect quantity, seven bucks.

This (tied with Chez Sovan) is my favorite eatery in the Bay Area. No joke. How often can you say that?
author: Michael J.

description: I've developed an addiction to the red sesame chicken and their pork belly. OH, the pork belly.  Crispy, melt-in-your mouth goodness!  I have only had the smaller, steamed buns but am anxiously awaiting their return to Truck Stop SF so I can try a meal-sized baked bun!
author: Wendy U.

description: I heard about this place from some co-workers and so during lunch one day I walked over to check it out. I was definitely unimpressed. The steamed buns are tiny and over priced. The duck wasn't that tasty either. They did have these good chips with seaweed strips. That's about all I can say about this place. The menu is very small. Nothing that amazing.
author: Polina S.

description: Had their coca cola braised pork baked bao sandwich, and it was so good I went and got another one.  The bun was super soft and tasty as was the pork and sauce.  Super yummy.  If I see the truck again I will definitely try their other stuff.
author: eric p.

description:
I've only ever had the crispy garlic tofu with miso greens bun, but if the rest of Chairman Bao's buns are that good, I think I could live on these buns for the rest of my life and die happy. I've had the tofu bun both in the baked and steamed form, and I can't decide which one I like better - the recommendation from the folks at the truck is to get at least 3 steamed for a meal and 1 baked bun is considered equivalent to 2 or 3 steamed buns. I had one baked and one steamed and was very satisfied with the quantity. Does it get pricey? A little depending on how much food you want, but it's completely worth it. 

This is some of the best food I've had, and it would take a lot for me to skip out on this truck.
author: Sweta M.

description: Pork Belly steamed bun had me craving to stand in line again but I fought the temptation. Seeing Chairman Bao Bun truck at the Government Center got me hungry without realizing I was. Price is reasonable but be sure to get at least 2, 1 does not satisfy, even if you're only a little hungry.
author: P G.

description: As good as the hype.  We had the pork belly, tofu, regular pork and sesame chicken.  All steamed.  The pork belly was the best.  Cooked absolutely perfectly.  The tofu was a close second, made awesome by the miso dressed mustard greens.  The pork was good, but the first belly and tofu are so much better.  The chicken was just ok, I would not order it again.  The vegetable toppings are all first rate.
author: Amber B.

description: What an amazing experience! We found this food truck in Palo Alto with a fleet of other trucks. The line to this truck was a mile long and worth the wait. When i finally got to the window, the woman (Yoori?) was very pleasant and did not rush me. My order came up in 2 minutes. The steamed & baked pork buns were delicious!!!
author: Kay D.

description: All I had at Chairman is the spicy chicken bun.  Love the pickled veggies that goes on top of the chicken. Spicy, a little sour and some sweetness and overall, makes the sandwich delicious.  The buns come in steam or baked.  I prefer the steam but the bake is not bad.  Base on this one dish, it is awesome!  That's it for now until I try other dishes from Chairman.
author: Armi S.

description:
Wow!  This funky truck churns out some fabulous chinese street food, and I happened to stroll by.  The wait was quite long, as this was only their fourth day of operation and they are still working out the undoubtedly dubious details of managing four busy servers in a small truck.  However, my pork belly sandwich (I guess it's called Gua Bao) and sesame chicken dim-sum "taco", were delicious!  The pork featured very complex and subtle flavors and generous garnish of pickled daikon.  The Sesame Chicken was equally flavorful and had a fried green onion garnish.  The buns, both baked and steamed, were exquisitely fresh and tasty.  Expect a long line and a long wait (at least until they streamline their operations)

I only wish they could park downtown by my office!  =:(
author: Aaron C.

description: My mom and I shared a baked braised pork bun and a steamed pork belly bun.  Honestly, for the price of a baked bun, I'd be better off getting six regular baked BBQ pork buns from Clement Restaurant (http://www.yelp.com/biz/clement-restaurant-san-francisco).  But, the pork belly bun with the pickled daikon was pretty tasty, and if I were in the mood for shelling out $4 for a taco-sized steamed bun again, that would be the one.
author: Jenn C.

description:
ever since coming to SF, been trying to get a taste of you guys, but the lines were crazy.  what I have come to learn about the bay area, is that there are lines everywhere, but not because the food is necessarily the best but because food options are spread out!! 

suffice to say, NYC has so many better bao places, but I must be fair and rate SF against SF standards.  

pork belly was good, nice big pieces.....not much trimmings on these baos.....either simple daikon or kale.  

the steam bun however is not good, they were not fluffy like little pillows as they should be.

with that said, it's a passable bao for a street truck, I won't be hunting them down anymore though.
author: Monster E.

description: Sorry for not updating sooner. These dudes are solid, it's always delicious, and the only problem is that everybody knows how awesome they are so the lines are always crazy. Second truck?
author: Wangston P.

description: damn that pork belly with daikon steamed bun was amazingly good!
author: Helen L.

description: Chairman Bao is good.  A little on the hipster side for me, but hey...thats SF for ya.  The buns were soft and meat was tender.  Flavor packed a punch!  Only downside was that the buns had soaked up a lot of liquids from the fillings and went soggy.  4 stars
author: Dominic V.

description: This place does not live up to the hype.  I have no idea why the lines are so long.  I had to try it since my friend raved about it.  The flavors were good, but nothing mind blowing.  At $3.75 each for a tiny bite (I'd say you'd need at least 4 to fill you up for a tiny person), it is definitely not worth it.  Especially the baked bun, which is almost double the steamed one.  Wtf.  I got the pork belly and other pork one (with mustard seed), both were tasty but I'd pay at most a dollar each.  I liked the other food trucks better at Edgewood Eats.   I know it's no comparison, but all I thought about was there's a delicious huge juicy bbq chicken banh mi for less than $3 I'd muuuch rather have, though it's in SJ.  It's sad to see them go from $2.95 to $3.25 to $3.75 or whatever just based on demand.
author: Xue H.

description: Pretty good. The pork belly baked bun was tasty. The bottom piece of bread was soaked with grease but hey, it's pork bellaaaay!
author: Daniel N.

description: Went to Off the Grid last night at Fort Mason so I can try all these famous food trucks that I rarely get a chance to try.  Everyone raved about the pork belly bao and I just had to try it...good thing we got the last 6.  Pork belly and daikon on a steamed bao..who would have known it would taste so good and not leave a fatty after taste. Woohoo!
author: Allison T.

description: Saw them in Newark last night.  Pork belly with pickled daikon was delicious as everyone says.  Tried the tofu one as well and great flavor.  Will definitely try to catch up with them whenever they are near.  I know they are at City Beach Fremont tonight, but don't know if they will be regulars there.
author: Marcus K.

description: Delicious!  I usually get two of the smaller steamed buns, which make a perfect lunch.  My favorites buns are the duck confit with mango, and the braised pork with preserved mustard seeds.
author: icka b.

description: I don't live in SF, but every time I am there I try to go to Chairman Bao. The pork belly steamed is my favorite, but they are all good. Especially good with beer.
author: Aaron R.

description: Tried this for the second time this year but this time I got the steam and bake bun. The steam bun with spicy chicken was really good and more filling. The steam pork belly bun was amazing and the pork belly melts away in your mouth. I would get this all the time but I don't think it's too good for my health lol.
author: Tammy L.

description: Amazing braised pork on steamed or baked bun! You can't go wrong with either :) I'd go with the steamed just so I can keep trying more amazing food, but if you're particularly ravenous and impatient, go with the huge baked bun burger.
author: SF F.

description: Again was dragged out here by co-workers. The line was short when we got there because we got there 5 minutes after 11am. I didn't know what to get so I went with the safe choices sesame chicken and lion heads meatball with kim chee. I got the steamed bun and it's nothing exciting or special for me. I spent $5 for 2 buns which is more like a snack. I'm glad I brought my lunch. The buns are small and the filling is not very much either. For the price you pay and what you actually get - I'd rather get something else. But it's good just to try it once and have the experience of waiting in a long line in the cold and getting an expensive snack.
author: Candace F.

description: My wife brought me a deconstructed BBQ pork bun. Very tasty! Can't wait to try this again, wherever they go.
author: Benjamin T.

description: Who knew you could get such amazing deliciousness from a food truck.  I get alerts when they are in my neighborhood and try to get there before the crowds.  They park in out of the way spots so dont count on just running into them.   My favorite (currently) is the spicy chicken that is a little like a soft taco filled with chicken and spicy Asian sesame flavors and (I think ) sweet daikon.
author: John A.

description: Timed a trip up the Peninsula to grab a bite from this truck at the Hiller Aviation Museum. Worth the effort, because, wow, the pork belly was crazy good. I was a bit worried that the daikon radish would be too strong, but it was perfect. Wish I'd bought a couple more.
author: Mark P.

description: Pork belly bun is the FANTASTIC! But in my opinion the braised pork was BEST as it has less fat content Long wait but well worth it.
author: Richard L.

description: Love love love Chairman Bao! The pork belly and braised pork are bomb dot com! Wish these were a little cheaper, but hey you have a business to run.
author: Beth W.

description: Boo for Bao!!!  Way over-hyped. Lines were long, yes, but at least in hopes of some delicious big bad baos!!  Baos were so small--similar to the baos that are served with peking duck..maybe slighty larger. A bao that size cost 4-5$! RIP!  The stuffing of the bao was very average. Nothing different from what you would taste at a chinese restaurant or bakery.  Way underwhelmed.  2 stars for average food and expensive prices.
author: Monique C.

description: love! this ranks way high on my food truck scale. the buns are superb and the filling is plentiful! the pork belly is always tender and the veggie ingredients are always super fresh! when i see the chairman in the food truck lineup, i know i have to make an appearance!
author: Marjie T.

description: Had the pork belly. Not a big fan of the over stuffed "taco" shape. Really good flavor unctuous pork belly, and flavorful pickled veges overpowered the very ordinary bun that was steamed slightly too long. Would go again to try the baked options, all sold out when I got there.
author: Peter H.

description: A little pricey but tastey. I wasnt sure what to expect or how to order and I ended up ordering a bit much as I didn't know how large portions were. The pork belly with daikon is the equaivalent of a sandwich and is served much like a sandwich - not like a cha siu bao which was what I was expecting.
author: Peter N.

description: I dunno -- aside from the trendy-cool factor, which is already starting to wear thin, they're good but not worth a special trip, which involves checking Twitter or Facebook to see where they happened to be parked that day, and then (if going by car) trying to find anywhere to park nearby.  Aside from that, three main things to bear in mind, I think:  1) they're sorta expensive; 2) if they happen to be nearby and not the subject of a special trip, definitely worth trying; and 3) they are nothing like authentic bao -- more like a foodie's conceit.  But that's ok, I like Taco Bell tacos.
author: moosedog i.

description: Chairman Bao-wow wow. There was barely a line for the truck when it parked near the Walmart.com building where I happened to be at for a clinic. I've always been curious since the lines for it at Off the Grid were like that of a Vegas club. People would be standing out there long before their windows would open. You know it was getting serious once they put up their "velvet ropes" of caution tape around it. The steamed pork belly bun was awfully tasty. Yes, pork belly is the epitome of fatty goodness that you can get out of a pig, and it's pretty greasy. Food coma is highly expected, especially if you order more than one for yourself. I'm a bit hesitant to have another stab at the Bao unless I happen to see them again around South City.
author: Rhia R.

description: I had to go run some errands during lunch and as I was on the F-Trolley headed towards Van Ness I looked out and noticed the Off The Grid at UN Plaza. So after taking care of business I stopped back by and was faced with the arduous task of deciding which of the trucks I was going to try as everything looked appealing. I looked at the menu and saw two options that jumped out at me...the Steamed Pork Belly and the Braised Pork. Not wanting to have to decide between them I got both. They looked amazing when I open the little carton but when I tried them I was completely blown away! That had to be some the most amazing mixture of pork, spices, veggies and bread that I have put into my mouth. The pork was succulent (Yes, I actually used that word!) the combination of savory and sweet was just made to perfection. YES! I will return in a couple of days to make sure that it wasn't a one off. Stay tuned!
author: Cristóbal José Indigo P.

description:
Tried the braised pork and red sesame chicken steamed buns at a corporate event.  The pork was tender and juicy and the sweet sauce complimented it well.  The chicken was a bit dry and I didn't care for the marinade, which was spicy and overpowering.

The buns were moist and tasted home-made and were particularly delectable once they soaked up the sauces.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
We tried a bunch of things at the Chairman Bao truck at Edgewood Eats in Palo Alto last week.  I didn't see the duck bun on the menu. Otherwise we tried almost all of the other bao offerings.

-pork belly on steamed bun- good, melts in your mouth, great with the radish garnish
-pulled pork with cabbage on steamed bun was really good. The meat was flavorful even without the veg.  My son doesn't like veg so I ordered one without but the meat itself was still quite tasty.
-red sesame chicken on baked bun- a bit spicy for my taste but the meat was flavorful
-crispy garlic tofu on steamed bun- I actually Really enjoyed this one. the tofu had a really nice garlic flavor and I liked the firm, chewy texture of the tofu inside the bun. The greens added a nice crispy contrast.

Overall, I was happy with everything we had.
Go again? Definitely would go again. I prefer the steamed buns so would probably just order all steamed next time.
author: J L.

description: Super overpriced without any vegetarian variety. Its yummy, but super pricey per bun and they're pretty small. Drinks are expensive too. Worth a try, but not habit forming.
author: Araceli E.

description: Amazing taco-inspired Chinese food. I thought I'd need three, but two was enough!
author: Bootylicious J.

description: Finally tried this place last night.  I had one friend recommend the braised pork and another friend recommend the pork belly.  So inevitably I ordered both  ; )  The pork belly was out of this world.  Well worth the wait in line which I was told was smaller than usual.  The braised pork alone gets this 5 stars from me.  The pork belly was also really good, but I have a dislike for chinese 5 spice due to the star anise.  I have always hated that flavor.  That's all I could taste when I was eating the braised pork, but that is just a personal preference.
author: Todd G.

description: Since my first trek to the Chairman Bao truck, I came back to bring some friends from Sacto to try it. Since in all fairness, I think the concept of a 'gourmet bao truck' is pretty unique. My buddies LOVED their duck bao (the only I think is worthy of tasting). I still think I can get much better baos at a dim sum house but I can respect what their trying to do especially since they're driving all the way out to Sacramento to help promote cart food out here! So I upgraded their stars because of this.
author: Wendy L.

description:
what i ordered... steamed bun w/ braised pork belly

i'll give the dish by taste a five star but overall it  ain't, but if it was served on fine china and silverwares  in chandelier lighted establishment with an attentive waiter then it definitely deserved nothing less than a five star.

the dish was so good, it looks and tasted like a fusion of a "small" steamed bbq pork bun, mushu pork and vietnamese pork stew w/ korean pickles. 

ambiance... bad (freakin' truck in a dark alley)
service... ok
cost... $$ (so pricey)
author: Gors P.

description: Loved the tofu baked bun and I'm not even a vegetarian.  However, I found the coca-cola braised pork was just so so.  Not sure it is worth the long lines.
author: Courtney J.

description:
ridiculously tasty. 

what I got: garlic tofu with miso greens- steamed please. oh, and a ginger lychee shaved ice :D 

service: awesome, friendly, radical. oh, and they take credit cards!!

price: totally on point. $2.75 for a perfect little midday meal. love. 

crossing my fingers they will make hollis street a regular stop. I must try a baked bun soon, I must!
author: Callie K.

description: CBBT should get 3 and half star because the over all flavor of food and service is good. But I down grade CBBT because I found out from a friend that they don't make their own baos. Dude don't know why but I'm majorly disappoint. Oh well. Still go check CBBT out :).
author: Fried Rice B.

description:
Love the Chairman Bao Bun Truck! 

When I visit the bun truck, there are two things I must get...the steamed pork belly bun and the steamed braised pork bun.

Seriously, these guys are the best!  My favorite food truck by far!
author: Karen D.

description: Good things come to those who wait.  I had been to Off the Grid - Fort Mason about a month ago and the wait for Chairman Bao was 1 hr :20min.  Needless to say, we didn't wait.  However, when I heard that they were coming to Off the Grid - Civic Center, I was determined to to try it this time around.  I had heard positive reviews about the duck bao, but unfortunately they didn't offer it on their 1st appearance at civic center, so I opted for the steamed pork belly.  Scrumptious! And the wait was only 10 minutes tops.
author: Stacey L.

description:
Let me just cut to the chase and say: yes, it is worth it. 

I would gladly stand in line for some of their crave worthy tofu steamed buns. And I have on may occasions.
author: Grace S.

description: all  I have to say is, you HAVE to get the pork belly bun with pickled radish. Ugh, SO GOOD!!!
author: Jessica L.

description: The Pork Belly Buns are awesome, but they are a little pricey. Make sure to get more than one, you will want too. I see them at Off the Grid - Upper Haight on Thursdays.
author: Nicholas H.

description: Chairman Bao was at the Truck Stop on Mission and 1st today.  When I first got there the line was so long that I almost walked away.  But it smelled so good that I just had to stay.  So if you ever visit and see a long line, believe me, it's worth it!  The line moves very fast and the workers are so friendly...each one of them with such a welcoming smile.  My friend and I had the pork belly bao and the red sesame chicken bao.  We were both so amazed.  We've never tasted anything like it.  It simply melted in our mouths.  Definitely made our day! This was the first time I've ever visited them and it most definitely will not be my last. I'm a faithful customers for sure!
author: Marie I.

description: I was lucky enough to catch them while they were by my work in San Mateo.  I was a first timer, so I tried the pork belly w/ pickled daikon (steamed).  SOOO YUMMY!  Good thing I ordered 2 =)  Can't wait till they're in San Mateo again!  Maybe I'll get 4 next time!
author: Karen G.

description: This truck stopped by to feed people finishing up the Walk for Life march earlier this year. We got steamed buns and they were so good it made us hungry for more. Absolutely downright delicious!
author: Garrett V.

description: pork belly was soooo goooooooood. Got it with pickles. Urgh..... yuck what's this smell. Oh... it's from my pork bun. Nevermind
author: Cliff T.

description:
I'm a bao lover.  I've been loving them since I had my first one in Asia 10 years ago.  I've been dying to go to this truck ever since I'd heard of it.  I love street food, and I especially LOVE food from trucks (I am from NJ!)  

I was kinda disappointed.  These bao were ok, but way overpriced for what you get.  How can something the size of a street taco, with much less meat be $3?  I didn't notice if it was organic or something, but maybe that's why.  Maybe they were having an off day?  I had the pork belly, and all it had was a chintzy thin piece of pork belly overwhelmed by the puffy bun.  I felt deeply unsatisfied.  It should have been a thick, unguent, succulent piece of pork belly.  If you want to try what I am thinking of, go to one of the Momofukus in NYC and try theirs.  That's what I'm talking about.

I guess I'll give it one more try, but I think I'll also stalk the various Chinatowns in the region to see what they have to offer.  Thanks, Chairman Bao, for making me crave bao, and not delivering!
author: jessica d.

description: Delicious buns, but ridiculously overpriced. $3.75 for a bite sized bun? $6 for a burger sized bun? Craziness. I really did enjoy their pork belly and roast duck buns though, but the prices were just busting my wallet.
author: Kevin L.

description: Coca cola braised pork baked bun yummmm!!!! D-Lish!!
author: Sdmomma R.

description: Had Chairman's steamed clamshell buns stuffed with pork belly, chicken, tofu--all wonderful, crunchy with pickled veggies. Am interested in getting Chaiman to cater a party of 70 people . Has anyone had experience with them as caterers for private event???
author: Yeh T.

description: I had the pork belly and sesame chicken. Wow- these were really good. I would highly recommend that everyone tries this place out. They have a unique thing going and now Im a fan. I also had the strawberry lemonade and it was a bit too sweet but nothing that a little watering down cant solve. Great meal for $9.50 total. =)
author: Genaro R.

description: Ahhhhhhh, pork belly. I am better off that they are not in the same place every day. They do damn fine buns!
author: Joe Bob J.

description: I haven't been to too many gourmet trucks in the Bay Area, nor have I actually had traditional Chinese steamed buns, but this stuff is awesome. I had a Red Sesame Chicken bun and a Garlic Tofu bun. Both were incredible - everything tasted very fresh. Also shared a bag of Bao chips. Tasty salty goodness. Will definitely visit again on Mondays when they're in Emeryville.
author: Tom J.

description:
so yummy and delicious! i tried these at the haight street off the grid and i can't believe i hadn't discovered them before.
filling is flavorful, buns are soft and amazing.
author: Abigail B.

description:
Talk about delicious! 
I ordered 4 different types of bun, pork, tofu, 2 ducks. Yummy in my tummy! If the line is long, then that means its good. Worth the wait, and I will be coming back. This time I will double my order, so I don't have to wait in line again on the same  night.
author: Annie E.

description: Awesome, they brought the truck over for work, Had to go get seconds. Very very good.
author: vince d.

description: This is probably the best food truck I have tasted so far.  I went to the 5th & Minna Off the Grid and tried it for the first time.  I got the pork belly and the sesame chicken steamed buns.  The pork belly was tender and flavorful and the pickled radish that came with it made for a perfect combination.  The chicken sesame was tangy with crunchy carrots and greens.  They were both delicious.  The only thing docking a star is the prices.  It was $7 for two tiny buns. I am going to have to have an afternoon snack. To be full, I think I need 4 of those steamed buns.  Maybe next time, I will try the baked buns and hopefully I will be filled up much better.
author: Dbear T.

description: One of my favorite things in  SF! Fast, super yummy, you never know where you might end up running into them and it making your whole day!
author: Tasha A.

description:
line is superduperlong and the portion is slightly small for the price you pay.

however, these things were delicious.

check em out every thursday evening at the beg. of ggp.

pork belly and duck buns 4 a well earned 4 star victory
author: Victor B.

description: Excellent flavor in the meats, buns were soft and warm.  The pickled carrots were a nice added flavor and texture to the combo.  They could use a little less oil though.
author: Eva W.

description: Delicious! Fresh, hot, steamed buns with tasty meat and vegetable fillings. This is not your grandmother's sticky bun. I would give 5 stars but for the fact that two of these little guys aren't enough to fill me up at lunch, and at that point it actually starts to be an expensive treat. I had their new red sesame chicken bun today and it was FABULOUS, but I could've eaten 5 of them.
author: Luke A.

description:
Yes, these are not your traditional bao. I know that a "baked" bao is a contradiction. However, I prefer their pork belly or sesame chikcen baked bao over any examples of the traditional style  - and I've eaten many a bao/manapua in my time. I'd always thought something more could be done with them and along came Chairman Bao (I know, they are not the first.) to deliciously reinterpret the bao. 

The pork belly was succulent; the sesame chicken was a savory bundle of joy; and the condiments were  yummy complements to the main ingredient of each sandwich.

The $6 price for a good-sized hot sandwich-style lunch was not too high. 

I'm ashamed to say that I get cranky when they skip a week in my neighborhood.
author: cali m.

description: The pork belly with daikon bun is truly delicious, with all the flavors and textures in balance.
author: Brad E.

description: SOOOOO fired up to have gourmet food trucks near where I work at Bishop Ranch.  I've seen them at Off the Grid but finally had the joy of experiencing Chairman ao on my lunch break.  Great atmosphere, shaved iced drinks were tasty and the chicken bun had the perfect amount of spice.  I hope Chairman Bao makes regular appearance here.
author: Andrea R.

description: Awesome food truck! If you want gourmet non-traditional bao, you must try Chairman Bao! I went there thinking they were going to serve bbq pork bun like those you can get from dim sun... But I was totally wrong! They serve the best porkbelly bun and the duck bun is a MUST try! Don't get the butter squash pine nut soup though... It was too much Ginger and tasted a little weird. But overall, awesome experience!
author: Helen W.

description: Tried to pork bun and duck confit bun.  They were tasty, but small for the price.  I don't really get this whole food truck thing going on right now, so I'm not going to rant and rave about it.  If you catch it, then try it, but I wouldn't go too much out of your way to chase it down.
author: Maxine S.

description: Tried this today at off the grid because it had a long line. It's okay. I got the duck with mango. The flavors went really well together but the duck was a bit too salty for my liking. I liked the spicy-ness and the mango together as well. Also tried the mango match green tea drink. Very interesting combination, wasn't my cup of tea though.
author: Annie W.

description:
This is the one food truck that always has the longest line. I'm pretty lazy when it comes to waiting in line for food or entertainment but finally got a chance to the tofu steamed bun with garlic at Off the Grid recently. 

I went to Chairman Bao at around 5pm and there was still a 45 minute wait to order. I sucked it up and stood there. My advice is to go with a few friends so everyone can take turns stepping out of line to check out the other trucks. 

Bao, your buns are pretty tasty but the hour long wait is a huge turn-off.
author: kirti p.

description: Culinary revolution! So, does the food live up to the neo-maoist-style-splendor? Yes! Get porkbelly, Duck confit, and chicken, for triple happiness. Steamed bun of course. Viva Charimain Bao!
author: Boris C.

description:
I  always wanted to try the Chairman truck and one day after coming home I went on one of my many social networks (twitter, duh) and they had tweeted that they were right in front of Crunch on Polk which is RIGHT by my house. I was thinking about going to exercise that day but decided that I'd rather eat, so I walked to the truck. Compared to when they're at Off The Grid they had absolutely no line, which is a plus and the head chef was even outside talking to people who had questions. I ordered the tender pork belly bun with daikon (regular not baked) and walked back home. It was FANTASTIC, it was so good that when my BF got home I took him BACK and he got the baked duck bun and the chicken. I got another bun (this time a baked duck bun) and a lychee/green tea slush and that was tasty as well. The drink is something I would recommend for those of you who don't like to drink things that are too sweet,  and are healthy. I now eat this at Off The Grid when I get the chance (when I have time to stand in line or I get their early ).

As far as service, my first experience was great and when I have to go to Off The Grid or popular locations, I know that we have to wait since everyone loves this place and that's just the reality of a successful food truck- CUSTOMERS.
author: Audrey A.

description:
Oh my god ... The food was SOOO GOOD! Great service too.

A littttle it on the pricey side for a pork bun, but so worth it.
author: P J.

description: somewhat standard pork belly on taiwanese steamed buns. i've had them for the first time in new york at one of those steamed bun places. and i expected the chairman truck to compare. the texture of the bun and the pork belly wasn't exactly right. they were a bit undercooked and not very well seasoned. little disappointed.
author: Te R.

description: The truck looks cool, which I assumed was just a great decision to spend money on a graphic designer and decent truck. The baked bun didn't look like much and WOW - I was wrong. The sandwich is straight-up DELICIOUS! I was absolutely impressed. Can't wait to find their truck again - just "liked" them on FB to make it easier!
author: Kirsten B.

description: tried the pork belly and the red sesame chicken. i liked them both! although i nearly choked on how spicy the chicken was. somehow, i didn't expect it to be spicy...my mouth definitely got a little kick from that. now i can see how ppl would wait in that ridiculously looooong line. luckily, we were early and didn't have to wait that long =) but yea, definitely worth a try!
author: Linda L.

description:
these are some darn good BAOs.

a bit pricey, and a bit of a wait at Off the Grid.. at least for all the suckers behind me, try get there 10 mins early to cut down on waiting time. tried a baked pulled pork, and it was ..AWESOME. and a steamed pork belly, and that was pretty good too. go for the baked if you have a decent sized appetite, cause it's much bigger than the little steamed sand dollar

trust me, it'll be worth it.
author: Michael L.

description:
went here for off the grid. waited in line for 45 minutes, by then the duck baos were sold out!!

Duck with mango - spicy. Pretty good
Ginger pearl drink - average
Tofu garlic bao  - gross

Can't say anything for the famous duck. But if they are sold out the wait is definitely not worth it.
author: E T.

description: I got a steamed bun meal here: duck confit with mango and sesame chicken, plus a pineapple salted caramel shave ice with tapioca. The duck was delicious, as was the chicken... but it's hardly a meal. More like a snack. The shave ice didn't blow me away (and I was starting to doubt any caramel content). If you're hungry, get FOUR buns. Trust me on that one.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Delicious.  Caught up with these guys at the Upper Haight "Off the Grid" on Thursday.  I chose a pork belly bun and the duck confit bun, both steamed.  The pork belly was delicious, no doubt.  I think I may have let it sit too long and not gobbled it immediately as designed.  It was a bit tougher and stringier than I expected when I scarfed it.  The duck confit was amazing.  They pair the meats with pickled this and that and I didn't take too close a look.  I go with what tastes good.  A tiny little bun/taco slice of heaven.  Next time I'll pay more attention.
author: Jeremy B.

description: I has the red sesame chicken steamed bun and it was delicious! I like how the bun is like a taco so there is not too much dough. They stuffed it super full too and so even only after one I was quite satisfied. Off the Grid is a great chance to check out so many trucks. I will def. be going again!
author: Sophia D.

description: I dream about the Crispy Garlic Tofu with Miso Greens. I bought too many yesterday, so that I could have them for breakfast today. Where Chairman Bao goes, I will follow.
author: Wan T.

description: The first time I ate at the truck I had the baked duck bun and a steamed pork.  Loved it.  Second time, not as good.  Truck opened late, most items were not available that day, ended up with a steamed bao, just not up to par.  But certainly will go back again and certainly recommend.
author: Gayle G.

description:
ummm OMG... So I cant believe that I live and work around the corner from two stops this wonder-truck of yummy goodness makes. 

Folsom, in between 7th & 8th, and Emeryville, Hollis & 54th. 

The tofu bun with garlic miso greens is TO DIE FOR-- I don't care if you're veggie or not. 

My BF had the pork bun assortment (he was in love) (I'm Jewish for the record and don't delve into the stuff myself)-- that said they were 'AMAZING' according to said reliable source. 

Hurray for upmarket 'taco' trucks-- usually with out the taco offering these days.
author: Leah C.

description: LONG line and NOT as GREAT as I had anticipated. they ran out of the  duck so had to try pork with bok choy. Interesting mixture but surprisingly yummy!
author: Sophie L.

description: Definitely the least friendly food truck in Emeryville. Was really hungry so I showed up a bit early. The place was sealed up like a drum. Even when they got out of the truck, and I was standing right there, they wouldn't speak to me even or answer any questions. Then when they finally opened (almost fifteen minutes later than they were scheduled) they were all "Hi, so glad to see you". Nothing like fake sincerity to make you want to frequent local businesses. Fortunately the food is good or I would stop going altogether, but I will certainly be cutting back.
author: Mick B.

description: Duuuuuuuuuuuck bun!  The others are good, but I found myself going back to the truck when I wasn't hungry and was otherwise having fun with my friends inside.  I wanted them to cater my impending wedding.  I don't call the shots on that though.
author: Ian S.

description: WOWOWOWOW!  How do they produce such mouthwatering, delicious food from a food truck?  The serve magic through those windows my friends.  Ed and I have been wanting to try these folks for a long time.  Unfortunately, we always arrive late at the events that showcase them and we either have a closer truck to try or they are out of the pork belly.  Well, they had plenty last night.  And we enjoyed it immensely.  We chose the steamed bao  (bun) as our recepticle.  They also have baked baos.  We tried the the miso marinated crispy baked tofu (maybe fried) on the baked buns.  This was served with crunchy bok choy in a lite miso dressing.  WONDERFUL!  Back to the Steamed Bao.  The pork belly was so worth the wait.  My mouth is watering as I think about it.  The sweet, chewy pork belly was topped with pickled veggies.  What a great contrast.  I want to try their pork braised in coca cola next for sure.   It took awhile to get to the window.  The cashier disappeared for awhile.  But, once I placed my order, it took about 5 -10 minutes.  They were well worthwhile.  This is a treat for the masses.  Don't miss out if you have the chance to delight in these delicacies!
author: Erin S.

description: This place is straight up legit.  I got the $9 lunch special - two buns & an iced drink.  Obviously, I got the pork belly, but if I am being perfectly honest, I think the duck confit bun was better.  There, I said it.  I got the pineapple salted caramel drink, and yes, it is delicious.  Great Friday treat for lunch out of the office.
author: Julie B.

description:
SO good!

I had the duck, chicken, and the braised pork.  All ridiculously tasty.  Can't wait to try the shaved ice.
author: Chancy F.

description: At first I was really excited to try Chairman Bao, the presentation was nice but the taste did not meet my expectations. I really wish I could like this place better but I felt it was a little overpriced AND the buns are store bought. I tried the pork belly and duck confit. I personally liked the pork belly better because the duck had this weird mayo sauce, I think it would have been MUCH better with Hoisin sauce. The only really terrific thing they had was GINGER LYCHEE SHAVED ICE!! DELICIOUS and highly recommended!!!
author: Alison L.

description: OMG, Pork Belly and vegi balance the greese with the steam bun(not too much carb)!
author: York S.

description: The pork belly sandwiches were fabulous!  It's quite a feat to make the perfect pork bao.  More often than not, the filling is dry or the bun is wrong.  Chairman bao's pork belly sandwich is one excellent bao. The meat filling is moist and flavorful. The bao portion is fluffy and sweet.  With the addition of the hoisin sauce and daikon made it the perfect combination. While my husband thought the pork was too fatty, I thought it was succulent. I'll be back for more.
author: Isabella L.

description:
I had heard about chairman bao through yelp & friends yet never had the oppertunity to try it. While on the way to grab some food elsewhere saw the Bun truck parked at Civic Center Plaza. Figured this was a sign from above and tried it. The reviews are completely accurate. Had the Braized pork belly with daikon on a steamed bun, Yum!. Didn't realize how small they  were so I ordered the Peoples' pork on Baked, Yum!. I can see how people down multiple buns. 

Definately worth finding again.
author: Robert T.

description:
YUM!

Caught them at the "off the grid" civic center and had the pork belly/daikon baked bun. Such an awesome combo of flavours!

sampled a bite of the S.O.'s chicken-- too spicy for my taste but still delish. We shared the tofu--not as good as the other two, but still worth while!
author: Persephone J.

description: I was skeptical about this truck... all the hype and hoo-ra about it... until I tried the buns!  It seems like it would be ultra oily and fatty like most people have been saying about pork belly, however, I did not find this to be true.  IN fact, I find this less fatty/oily than a regular hamburger or a bbq pork bun from dim sum place. The meat they use in the buns is actually quite lean and good quality pork/chicken.  I had the pleasure of trying the pork belly, cocacola braised pork and spicy chicken.  I have to say the spicy chicken was actually my favorite one!  I loved all the sauces and pickles they added to the bun, made all the flavors mash together well.  The tofu (though onlyhad a small taste was good as well but not crunchy enough for me.  Three small steamed buns is enough for lunch.. the baked a little large to me and also more expensive.. not really worth the almost $6 per bun in my opinion.
author: Margie C.

description: friendly girl on the truck who takes the orders.  interesting menu items and concept in general.  i got coca-cola braised pork bao and the crispy tofu bao.  both steamed.  they were quite tasty, though a bit on the greasy and salty side.  but it was good to try.
author: Ash T.

description:
Thanks to Chairman Bao Bun Truck for supporting Sunday Streets volunteers - and thus giving me access to their little bundles of pillowy, juicy, sweet and salty heaven. 

The staff people were really friendly, and the food was ready really fast - within a minute or two of ordering. I had two steamed buns - "crispy garlic tofu"  and "tender pork belly with pickled daikon." I didn't have to pay for them and wasn't even thinking about what they should cost - but they were really, really good. Instead of the buns (bao) you'd get at dim sum, that have the filling cooked into the middle, these buns are folded over the fillings, like a puffy white taco or a sandwich. I assume this is what makes it possible to have them be both freshly cooked and fast. So, maybe not the traditional presentation, but the ingredients seemed similar (higher quality meat than most of what I've had in restaurant or store-bought buns), and the texture of the bun seemed identical to the traditional ones. 

The buns themselves were perfect - tender and pillowy, a little bit sweet, and the right size to hold the filling. I was pretty hungry, so I was eating fast and taking big bites - I think it took me 6-8 bites to finish each one, plus the scooping up of fallen ingredients, and the satisfied licking of fingers. 

The crispy garlic tofu was as advertised - crispy (but not swimming in oil), with plenty of sauteed greens (bok choy maybe?) and a very tasty, garlicky sauce that was the consistency of creamy salad dressing. I could taste the greens and the tofu and the bun, so the sauce wasn't overpowering; the overall combination was a nice blend of flavors and textures. Not particularly spicy, and the garlic flavor is not strong until you're done eating.

The tender pork belly with pickled daikon was also good, though a bit more prone to falling out of the bun as one eats (perhaps I was chowing down too fast, though). The pork belly was tasty and went really well with the pickled daikon; together they were more sweet than salty/savory, and yes, tender and juicy.
author: Kate H.

description: wasn't sure if this food truck would live up to its hype so i had to try it for myself. this was only my second time at OTG and Chairman Bao was nowhere to be found my first trip there. my friend and i mosied our way down to fort mason, found primo parking and immediately directed our attention to chairman. I ordered the pork belly pickled daikon baked bun. POPPIN! for 7 bucks i was expected a lot smaller sandwich but it was huge!! i know people are huge fans of taking pictures of their food before eating it, but i wasted no time and dug right in. the daikons were definitely necessary and the sandwich lasted me just long enough before i was at the front of another line
author: Daniel S.

description:
checked out the truck at the mobile food fair in sf. got 4 buns for, i think, 10 bucks. moderately filling.

all very, very delicious. the duck was my favorite!
author: Sarah G.

description:
i've noticed this truck for the past week or so but didn't realize it was open for business until i happened to be walking down 7th street today and saw the large crowd of people. ordered the two steamed buns & drink combo ($9). there is only one veggie option, fried tofu with miso greens, but it was quite tasty. however, my beverage, a ginger lychee shave ice boba, was way too sweet and not gingery enough. it also took over 20 minutes between waiting in line to order and then for the food to come out which seems like a long time for a food truck.

i would definitely come back to have the tofu bao again but would try another drink and stop by before the lunch rush begins. it would also be great if they added another veggie option to their menu.
author: stykkisholmur t.

description: I love this truck! I've only tried the steam pork bun. I love the crunchy stuff that they top. Whenever I want the bake pork bun, they're always sold out! Def will come back to try it!
author: Men A.

description: great buns...just wish the schedule format on fb is not as confusing
author: Martin C.

description: It was aiiiiiiiiiiiiiight.  Wished service was a little better especially for a startup truck. I was waiting in the wind tunnel outside John Collins while some dude was talkin shop to the owner...yea, I may have been the only person in line at the time but still! I was going to give them two stars but the duck was not bad...and they were pretty nice with the portions. Oh and please dont give me crap about asking for a box. It looked pretty messy and I was not going to walk home with an open plate of food.
author: Angela J.

description: before trying their steamed bun with duck and mango i couldn't understand the hype. long lines for something similar to peking duck? now i LOVE me some peking duck, so i figured a truck couldn't beat the real deal. but boy was i wrong. the succulent smoky duck amidst a soft airy bun with a hint of refreshing mango is why you will now see me waiting in line for more and increasing the hype. plus...there's a giant panda on the truck. i'm all about chasing the panda!
author: Regina C.

description: Yum! What else I could say.  I ate at the Chairman a few times and they always consistent food and fast service.  My favorite is definitely the steamed tender pork belly.
author: Kham L.

description:
Time & Location:  12:30pm, parking lot of Walmart.com

Food:  Two Steamed bao meal with shaved ice drink--1) pork shoulder with pickled daicon  2) lions head meatball with kimchee.  Both delicious!  Pork shoulder was well stewed and nice and fatty.  Lions head was moist but had a little too much onion.  The kimchee was creative, but was not very authentic.  The portions were small though so if you have a BIG appetite, you may need more bao.

Beverages:  The 2 steamed bao meal came with a shaved ice drink!  I tried the delicious mango matcha shaved ice drink with little jellies at the bottom.  Yum!  Selection of other drinks were standard fare; sodas, coconut juice, waters, etc.

Service:  Energetic and friendly and open to feedback.  The only down side was the lady who stood in front of me going into a LONG drawn out conversation with the cashier about when the truck should be there because her schedule was blah blah blah.  Get over yourself and let the people behind you order!

Overall:  Tasty value for $9.00 but the portions are on the small side.
author: Sarah S.

description: their food is BOMB DIGGITY!!!! I bet anyone 100 bucks that they put crack on it or something close to that because their food is Uber addicting and to die for!!! price is a little high for each but you really get what you pay for!! you gotta try their food especialy with their spicy sauce.... you know what I want some pork bun right now so I'm going there!! WOOHOO!
author: Paul C.

description: Oh my.  What a nugget of goodness.  First time visiting the Marin Country Mart Food Truck Crush.  Will be seeing you more often.  I had the crispy tofu and kale.  Yum Yum!!!!
author: PHill Resident G.

description: pork belly...delish; the meat is so tenderrrrrrr...miso tofu...yummm....service..very friendly...the steam bun..fluffy....
author: Pikachu P.

description: I am totally in love. We tried two different sandwiches which were both great. The pork belly sandwich and the coca cola braised pork. The coca cola sandwich was my favorite, but they were both great. I think next time I will try the spicy sandwich. You can to give Chairman Bao a try.
author: Tiffany G.

description: I have been eating at The Chairman truck for some time now.  The crew is always friendly and the will answer any questions for you about the food. At the truck meets, they seem to have one of the longest lines. My favorite is the spicy chicken on the baked bun, but the pork belly is a pretty close second.  I have tried most of their offerings, but I never had a chance to try their duck. I think their pickled condiments (carrots, daikon,...) really compliment the chicken and the pork on their buns.  The Chairman is awesome.
author: Greg A.

description: Their baos taste nothing like real Chinese baos, but they ARE delicious. Love their pork bao with dikon.
author: Joy X.

description: After hearing so many good things about this food cart and seeing all the scrumptious pictures of their peking duck-like buns on steriods, i decided enough was enough...i was going to check this place out for myself! After ordering the pork belly and sesame chicken steamed buns from the girl in the truck, i stood aside with all the other hungry patrons and patiently waited for my buns. When they finally called my order number, I almost jumped for joy. Opening the paper tray, I knew I was in for a treat! The aroma of the fatty pork belly along with the spices of the chicken was so mind numbingly good that I wanted drop my bags and sit on the sidewalk with everyone else and wolf them down. Of course my bf wanted to wait till we got home first so I reluctantly agreed(he drove). 30 mins later and 10x hungrier I finally got to take my first bite, and I swear I heard my taste buds sing, or dance, or both. Not only was it absolutely delicious, but the bun held its form and texture. Translation: They were NOT soggy! So fluffy and soft, like a cloud. Not a rain cloud, but a happy one on a sunny day. I downed my buns in what seemed like mere seconds, drank some water, and know that I will look back on today and think "that was a goooood day".
author: Melissa Y.

description: I love, love, love the garlic tofu with miso greens bun! Currently my favorite sandwich.  The texture of the tofu is perfect and the dressing on the greens combined with the sweetness of the bun is sooooo good!
author: Md G.

description: although i'd seen the bao truck several times at the civic center OTG, i'd never tried them until today.  even though the day was chilly, there were still long lines at all the trucks.  i ordered the pork belly and red sesame chicken (or something like that) both on steamed buns - they were out of baked, but i guess from the reviews, steamed is the way to go.  i was surprised that they were so tiny...the description said "taco size".  these were more "bite size".  i liked both very much, especially the pork belly one which was juicy and full of flavor but at $3.75 a pop, these little buns are quite expensive for not very much food.
author: Vic S.

description: Feels like a Chinese taco. Found it at Civic Plaza and was able to be able to get my order in before last call. Tasty but greasy. Great in moderation! 5 stars for uniqueness, even in SFO.
author: Dayfu Z.

description: pretty sure i've tried all their bao meats whether in a steamed or baked bun. while the baos themselves are tasty, the price for what you get plus the wait bring down my rating. seriously, you could have a whole peking duck (with the steamed buns) for 20-30 bucks and here they charge like 3.50-4 for just one bao. i was embarrassed when i was waiting for my order when the truck was parked on clement st and some chinese ppl walked by and were like, "dang, four bucks for a bao?" not a deal. and not worth revisiting. come on, there are no chinese ppl running the truck. that should tell you something. =P
author: dianne l.

description: I've been hearing about this truck for quite a while and had the chance to try it for the first time at a food festival in oakland. I have to say, they live up to the hype! I got the pork belly bun with pickled daikon and the fried tofu bun. It was..... SO GOOOOOODDDDDD! I preferred the pork belly over the fried tofu though. The meat was soft and it was a great mix between sweet and tangy. However, $4 for one bun was a bit much for me. It's not something I could afford to fill my tummy for a meal. But they make great snacks.
author: Kim V.

description: my freind told me about this chair bao being at the jtown festival and wanted to go. at first i didnt even know it was a food truck...lol i thought she was talking about a person. got there got 2 of those pork bellys baked.so good i was skeptical about that daikon but it was actually pretty good. i can tell it was good since my freind bought 6, yea 6 of them not all for  herself tho lol but like her bros,sisters and niece.
author: David M.

description: I tried these guys out the other night at Ft. Mason. I had the spiced Duck Confit with Mango Salad Baked Bun and it was tasty, but messy. It was a nice snack to hold me over till dinner. I also tried a chicken bun my friend had. Seems like a decent place with a different take on buns. Cool guys running the truck too.
author: S A.

description: LOVED IT!!!  Finally got to try it at Off the Grid on Thursday night and it was delicious.  Red Sesame was the best!!  The pork belly was a bit greasy but still yummy.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Tammy S.

description: I had Chairman Bao at the Eat Real Festival in Oakland a while back. I think the prices have gone up and it feels like the food has shrunk. Steamed buns used to be $2.95, now they are between $3.50 and $3.75. Baked buns are about half the price. I spent $11.25 to get 3 steamed buns with pork belly. They were tiny. The buns (mantou) were not plump looking. I wondered whether they were freshly made. Sure, they were good. But if you have to spend $11.25 to get 3 buns to get full, not including any drink or side, I think there are cheaper and tastier things to eat out there.
author: Crystal L.

description: yummy! i had the pork belly! it was delicious! i really liked the radishes on top. i think the radishes actually made the bun! my friend has never had pork belly before and was even hesitant to try it. i was able to convince her to try it and she loved it! she even went back to get a second bun!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
after several failed attempts (hello crazy lines at sj eats) to try chairman bao, i finally got the chance at edgewood eats.  and it totally didn't live up to the hype!  so disappointing. first off, the buns are expensive - $3.25 for a really small bun.  i wouldn't mind paying the price if the food was amazing or even just good....but i found it very mediocre.  the red sesame chicken bun was way over seasoned and the garlic tofu bun was bland! 

so glad i didn't wait for hours to try it!!
author: jenni l.

description:
great tasting baos no doubt. im a fan of their touted daikon+pork belly bun. so good in fact that i choose to be stubborn and dont wanna try anything else (but ill try to try something else next time). the pork belly basically looks like a greasy thick piece of bacon in there. @_@

two points
1. definitely pricey as people have said. two tiny baos are $7+ already
2. one bag of those bao chips will definitely give you high blood pressure. the chairman needs to lay off the salt on those things
