its good but i must limit the times i eat here as it will burn a hole in my wallet and still leave me hungry. you can get more bang for your tasty bun buck at chinese restaurants
author: Kyle Z.

description: Was disappointed that I didn't get to try their duck bao, but I did try 4 of their steamed baos and I have to say, THEY ARE MIGHTY DELISH! 5 STARS for the Bao, 3 Stars for the price. At about $3.25-$3.75 and $6-7 for the baked, I rather get my money's worth and just try 1 of each. The Pork Belly steamed bao was my favorite. Fatty, salty, with the nice warm bao definitely gives you a jolt with the first bite. I am a fan!
author: Thomas J.

description: I was excited to try this truck because I heard so many great reviews. It was a windy and rainy day at the Spice of Life Festival but it didn't matter, I was determined to try their buns. We paid about 10 dollars for 2 buns, one baked and one steamed. I thought the wait in the rain was going to be worth it but man was I disappointed. The food was not what I expected it to be. There was no heat, literally ice cold, to any of the food. The topping to the teeny tiny steamed "bun" (more like a taco) was overwhelming and made the pork belly disappear under the pickled mustard. The portion size for the baked bun was nice but it was hardly a bun and more like a hamburger. Disappointing. It too was ice cold and whatever heat was left from the pork had disappeared along with my excitement. The daikon overwhelmed the pork and it seemed just A OK. Would I try it another day? Sure, why not. Would I recommend it? Probably not.
author: squishy b.

description: I was sucked in by the cute moniker... And then I was out $16 bucks for 4 of these puppies... OK, the pork belly with the pickled radish is nice, and I also tried the tofu... but seriously? All that time in line and that's it? Luckily my friend and I got Vietnamese sandwiches first so we ate those while we were in line...
author: yvonne l.

description: Good, but are you worth the wait? Probably not - but if you have a short line I'll eat you. Don't waste your time on the other buns, my favorite is the pork belly - sure I'm a pork belly fanatic so I'm a little swayed there, but any bite of any crispy pork belly in a bun had me at "hello". Either their pricing is inconsistent or their pricing has gone up, sigh...to add on evil to more evil.
author: Jeannette L.

description: i tried the truck at the eat real festival in oakland.  chairman bao had the longest line of them all.  the three of us tried the crispy garlic tofu with miso greens, the red sesame chicken with bok choy and green onion, and the pork belly with pickled daikon.  the chicken was really flavorful and saucy, i liked.  i wish the "bun" part of the bun was a bit better, though.  they definitely were store-bought, mass produced buns.  i wouldn't wait in such a long line to eat this again, but glad i got to try it.  a+ for originality.
author: micaela r.

description: I just had these buns for lunch today and they were mad good. I got the tender pork belly with daikon, red sesame chicken with scallion and bok choy, and the chinese spiced duck confit with fresh mango scallion. Three buns filled me up and it came in one tiny box! I have to say that this does serve a tasty meal when you have nothing else better around you in Brisbane. I also can't tell which bun is the best. I suggest you try them all out and see which one you like. I think the Pork Belly with daikon was pretty spicy!
author: Dave Y.

description:
i LOVE food trucks. and i love buns. i've always wondered why buns haven't taken off, and with the rise of food trucks, i wanted (fantasied about) my own buns truck. of course, someone beat me to it. food out of this truck is quite expensive. buns is something that can be eaten as a snack, part of a whole meal, or as a meal. aside from the small steamed soupy buns or buns with fancy ingredients, buns are in general supposed to be inexpensive. these buns are ~3 bucks for steamed and almost 6 bucks for baked. these are also not the whole buns steamed/baked with fillings; they're cut open with stuff put in. this seems to be the predominant style of buns in non-chinese chinese food culture right now, which really annoys me 'cuz while that's a real style of buns, most buns eaten by chinese people are filled. anyway, the style and price were disappointing, and i had to stand in like for maybe an hour to get them (at fort mason). when i got them tho, they really were quite tasty. they may not be the most authentically chinese buns, but they're at least chinese food-inspired, seems to be made of high quality ingredients, and tastes really good

they also have iced drinks, which are really good as well. if you can get over the price, the wait, and the style, this truck is excellent. i LOVE food trucks, and this is a good one
author: Dave Y.

description: pretty dope. but wash your greens dudes ( crispy garlic tofu ) i got some grit.
author: marky m.

description: love the food. not the portions. it's very good, but it's too small! got 2 steamed buns, a chicken and the very famous from 7x7 mag, pork belly. both were very good, but really, it left me wanting more. did not fill me up at all. it's as if i could have eaten 4 of those. and yes, it was definitely a little pricey. but at the end of the day, it was definitely worth the try. i'll definitely be back for some more whenever the food truck comes around. :)
author: mai c.

description: Dude..this truck is awesome..I'm not a fan of these food trucks because they all seem to just take some ethnic food and wrap it in a tortilla. That's where chairman bao differs. They actually have awesome tasting food that took some thinking to create. crispy garlic tofu steamed bun was my favorite..next was the red sesame chicken w/ scallions. I think you should get it as a steamed bun. reminds me of peking duck...but way better..yumm...
author: amanda c.

description: Peeped this at Off the Grid on Haight. The duck bun blew my mind. Nothing but stars for these guys. Well done
author: Kyle P.

description: Got the duck and pork belly steamed buns... gotta say... looks like the baked ones taste better, but at double the cost of the steamed buns? couldn't do it. Liked the flavors of the pork belly, but the G loved the duck more.
author: Ed C.

description: managed to catch this truck at the end of the asian-american heritage festival. kiri and devon are the best ever!!!
author: Shelby C.

description: Came across this place as my friends and I stumbled out of John Collins last night. Even though I'd suggested trying some buns on the way into the bar, and at least three times on the way out, one of my friends (possibly more stumbly than the rest) had a sudden and urgent epiphany that she was starving and we absolutely HAD to get some food there, just as we were starting to walk away. There were four of us total, in various states of inebriation, so actually reading the menu wasn't working out for us and I finally made the call to just order two of everything. For that reason I'm not exactly sure WHAT we ate, but I know that it was all amazing. And probably would have been just as amazing had we been sober. Somewhere in the commotion of all of us realizing we needed one more trip to the bar's bathroom before hailing a cab, the stumbliest friend dropped one of the four boxes of baos she'd been trying to balance. As we promised at the time, I just want to give a shout out to Chairman Bao employee Guillermo (hope I spelled your name right...) for noticing what happened and replacing our fallen food for free. Loved the food either way, but probably wouldn't have written the review if not for that.
author: M Z.
